1 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 3, 1997


Sports - General;
Nigerian Sports: Set for Battle


BYLINE: Taye Ige, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

Lagos - Aspirants for election into the boards of the 24 associations under the ministry of youth and sports position themselves for the task, which must be completed by February 10.

Across the board last week, there were intense jostling in the 25 sporting associations as contestants into their executive councils primed their arsenals in readiness for the elections, the guidelines of which were released January 13. Some of the aspirants, however, believe that the guidelines are no different from those used to conduct elections into the board of the Nigerian Football Association in September last year. For instance, they point out that as was the case with the NFA, of the 15 members on the board of each association, seven will come from the seven sports zones of the country. This, in the opinion of Ayo Ositelu, former Lagos State chairman of the lawn tennis association and current board member at the national level, may lead to a selection process in which money will determine who emerges. 

Ositelu, who last week declared his intention to serve again on the board of the Nigeria Lawn Tennis Association, believes that as a result of this provision in the election guidelines, "by and large, government candidates will emerge as the helmsmen."

But by far the more contentious provision in the guidelines is that which disregards the courts and makes the Federal Ministry of Youth and Sports the final arbiter in disputes emanating from the elections. Rotimi Obajimi, ex- athletics international, believes that rather than make itself the final arbiter, the ministry should have borrowed a leaf from the International Amateur Athletics Federation. According to him, the IAAF has a body of legal- minded jurists who adjudicate in matters of this nature. Ositelu, on his part, believes that while it is not healthy for the ministry to assume such a role especially as it concerns an election which guidelines it drafted, the clause is necessary if the bureaucracy must free itself from court cases which often impede sports development.

Having carefully studied the guidelines, Ositelu does not see much difference between the new system of electing association board members and what obtained in the past when government merely appointed people into association boards. He is right, for the ministry maintains absolute control on the election process and is the only body that can ratify the final results. With such powers, "the government has a right to annul an election if it is unhappy with the outcome," Ositelu remarks.

Such complaints notwithstanding, sports administrators have been busy mapping out strategies to help them win election or secure nomination into the boards. Obajimi, who has his eyes on the exalted post of chairman of the Athletics Federation of Nigeria, says that his gameplan is to work through the zones to get elected into the board. "It is after that, that we can begin to talk of getting into the chairmanship race," he tells Theweek.

If he succeeds in getting into the board, the one-time national coach will find formidable opponents in Abdulkareem Amu, the incumbent chairman, and Smart Akraka, who reigned briefly before Amu staged a comeback in 1995. While both Amu and Akraka attempt to sort themselves out based on old rivalries, smooth-talking Obajimi who reportedly endeared himself to the athletics community by his impressive records as an athlete, a coach and an administrator, may just sneak in and carry the day.

The time may also have finally come for David Johnson, former vice-chairman of the Nigeria Amateur Boxing Association, to finally ascend the throne as chairman. After being disqualified by the Sola Rhodes-led National Sports Commission during the 1995 elections, Johnson, former chairman of the Plateau State Sports Council, went to court. He was later persuaded to withdraw his suit by Jim Nwobodo, the sports minister, who promised to conduct fresh elections. Another court order, however, scuttled the minister's plans and Ademola Farri, elected in the 1995 polls, reigned on. But Farri's tenure was crisis-ridden, leading to its dissolution. As a result, when the country's contingent left for the Olympic Games mid last year, boxing was the only association without a board. Nigeria's woeful outing in the sport in 1996 is one evidence that a change is highly desired in the leadership of NABA.

While Obajimi and Johnson may have to first face the zonal challenge, Ositelu, a veteran sports commentator, is hopeful of government nomination. Even then, "I won't lobby for it," he says. "I know what I have done for sports and they know too. I can't afford presents or hampers for anybody. In fact, I don't believe in such things. I prefer it (his nomination) comes by merit."

If Ositelu eventually returns to the lawn tennis board, the former sports editor of Punch newspapers will have to work extra-hard to displace Chuka Momah, the incumbent chairman.

As in athletics and lawn tennis, intense tussles between the incumbent and some younger administrators who desire to get to the top seem imminent in other associations. This is in line with the thinking in sports circles that only contestants who have paid their dues as athletes and coaches, and therefore can fully appreciate the import of their actions or inactions in office, are best suited to lead the associations.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


2 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 3, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Nigerian Football: In Search of a "Messiah"


BYLINE: Taye Ige, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Lagos - The Nigerian Football Association and the sports ministry are gearing up for the unemployment of a technical adviser for the national teams.

Our Players in big clubs in Europe and they equally need a better coach in the national team. I assure you that we've concluded everything and the technical adviser will be named before the end of the month."

That was a thundering Jim Nwobodo, the sports minister, January 14 asking the Nigerian Football Association to either employ a foreign coach to take over the rest of Nigeria's qualifying matches to France '98 or risk the ministry naming one for the association. 

Exactly one week into the minister's ultimatum, Abdulmumini Aminu, NFA chairman, is now appealing for an extension. Hear the retired former military governor of Borno State: "We will suggest to the minister... that it would not be possible to have one in two weeks. We will appeal for an extension. We must wait and take the best. What we are talking about is for national interest because whatever we do is for the country."

Aminu's seeming procrastination appears to be a product of his experiences in the few weeks that he has called the shots from Ogunlana Drive. Here was a chairman who came into office at a time when Nigeria's football was at its glorious peak. He had, also, hardly settled down in office when confronted with the Jo Bonfere crisis. The Dutchman had refused to return home with the Dream Team, which he had piloted, to an unprecedented Olympic soccer glory.

In the face of other unresolved crises, sports reporters had asked Aminu if his administration would consider signing on a replacement for Bonfere. The new chairman replied, asking the newshounds to be patient and give the local coaches, He further pledged to adequately support the trio in their efforts to ensure success for their respective categories. He even matched his word with action November 9, last year, when he authorised that Amodu be paid a $6, 000 match bonus, double what his boys received when they beat Burkina Faso 2- 0 in Nigeria's first France '98 qualifier.

For Aminu, however, nothing can be more disappointing than the performance of the local coaches. Hamilton could not find the wherewithal to push the Flying Eagles to the finals of the world age-grade championships, later this year. Amodu's performance in Nairobi, Kenya January 12 was hardly better. Coming at a time all hopes for revival of Nigeria's football were invested on the country appearing in next year's world cup finals, the January 12 draw against the Harambee Stars was taken as an equivalent of defeat.

Nwobodo's January 14 directive, viewed against this background of poor outings, becomes instructive. The sports minister, sources claim, was under pressure from higher quarters to "do something" to arrest the drift.

Aminu's "plea" to Nwobodo for an extension of time, sources say, has to do with a resolve to ensure that adequate steps are taken to avoid a repeat of the Westerhof and, later, Bonfere experiences. In addition to taking its time to look at their paper credentials, the football house is also said to be seriously vetting the careers of the applicants.

On return from the United States where he finally gave recuperating Kanu Nwankwo the federal government's $50,000 gift, Aminu gave Nigerians a list of six applicants for the technical adviser's job. Surprisingly, the list excludes Ivica Osim, a Yugoslav, Claude Le Roy, a Frenchman and Westerhof, all of whom had enjoyed ample mention in the media as possible favourites for the job. Rather, in the chairman's list were Phillipe Tronssier who for years tutored both club and national team in neighbouring Cote d'Ivoire; Kenny Dalglish, now of Newcastle United, an English premier league side; and Harold Wilkinson, said to be technical director at the English FA. There is also Kalman Meszoley who once called the shots for the Hungarian national team; a German named Dirk Mark and Hansruedi Heiniger, a Swiss.

Theweek learnt that to avoid the pitfalls of the past, the NFA is likely to contract a private law firm to fashion out an iron-cast terms of employment for the new coach, using the cases of Manfred Hoener, one-time Nigerian coach, Westerhof and Bonfere as "examples of what to avoid."


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


3 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 3, 1997


Business and Finance;
The Budget: Smile, Nigerians Smile


BYLINE: Akaninyene Esiere, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2427 words


 

Lagos - Amidst a flurry of official promises, Nigerians are still searching for manna in the 1997 budget. Anthony Ani, the finance minister, says the pudding is in its implementation.

It was January 7 and the ministers were already seated for the Federal Executive Council meeting on this year's budget. One minister was conspicuously missing - Anthony Ani, the finance minister and perhaps the most sought after at the crucial meeting. When he finally strolled into the Council Chambers, Aso Rock venue of the meeting, the ministers instinctively rose to give him a rousing applause for, in the opinion of the cabinet members, the impeccable manner he managed the economy the previous year. The day before, Ani had enthusiastically informed State House correspondents that the then-to-released 1997 budget would literally put food on the table of every Nigerian. 

As if on cue, the three spokesmen who addressed the press at the end of the FEC. Council of States and Provisional "manna-from-heaven" promise. Based on this, the anxiety that preceded the budget broadcast amongst Nigerians was understandable. But, by 8.05 a.m. Saturday, January 18 when Sani Abacha, the head of state, had finished his nationwide broadcast on the budget, many Nigerians thought the promise remains a dream, that Abacha's "real" broadcast was yet to come. Their unbelief stemmed from the fact that they could seemingly not sign post any issue in the broadcast that had a pretense of lifting their battered souls. Worse, two issues that dominated media reports last December - the merger of the dual exchange rates and privatization of government parastatals - and on which most Nigerians hung their hopes, were studiedly played down by the head of state. To demonstrate their absolute belief that at leas a firming up of the naira would bring about substantial reduction in prices of goods and services, Nigerians literally stopped further purchases until the budget broadcast. In fact, dealers in imported goods, fearful of an imminent loss began reducing prices of their goods to attract customers. The building anxiety therefore underscored the nation's disappointment that this singular matter was again returned to the cooler.

Premised on this apparent forlorn hope, Ani again came smoking Monday, January 20 when, during his budget breakdown speech, he sought to reassure Nigerians that the economy was accelerating on the track of recovery, growth and development.

While trying to convince the nation about the prospects of the 1997 fiscal plans, Ani made two points crystal clear. One was that consistency could not be jettisoned for expedience and that government was not done yet with the philosophy of "guided deregulation" which it had adopted since January 1995 as its lane to a market economy.

Ani's explanation on the knotty issues of exchange rate and privatization flew from this base. He said the fiscal policy it adopted had let to a stab le value of the naira for most of last year, which substantially aided planning and hence dual exchange rate. Just like last year, Ani said the ultimate aim of government was to merge the dual exchange rates. While giving last year's breakdown of the budget, he had said that government's aim was to see to the merger of the official exchange rate of N22 to one United States dollar with the autonomous rate that opened at N85 to $1. But what Ani did not offer was the profit motive behind government's reluctance to carry through its promise. For pumping $1.9 billion into the autonomous market last year, government made roughly N62 billion. Were the AFEM rate of N80 to $1 to prevail throughout 1997, government intends to fund the market to the tune of $2.7 billion. But by proposing to earn just N47 billion, there is an expectation that the naira will firm up. Another reason that worked against effecting a merger by fiat was the fear that government business would have suffered immeasurably from high cost. For instance, were the exchange rate fixed at the touted N56 to $1, the N44 billion ($2 billion) government sets aside to service its external debt would have automatically translated to N112 billion (still $2 billion). Based on this calculation, it is apparent that the two exchange rates will not find a meeting point even by December. But government intends to make the naira appreciate marginally this year.

On privatization, the minister was a little more forthcoming, though in the build-up to the budget, the impression was created that government parastatals meant for privatization were automatically going to be thrown into the market. It was this expectation that caused the dismay on the budget even within the international community. The much-awaited policy on privatization was underscored by several pronouncements from top government officials indicating its commitment to the programme. The difference being that, in the character of the Abacha administration, the programme must be done at a time that suits only the administration. Expatiating on the imperatives of privatization as a key to expanding investible resources, Ani said government would "expose the potentials for privatising and commercialising a number of state-owned enterprises in order to free the resources tied up in such ventures for social development." He said this would be done via a committee that would advise the government on the best way to achieve its objectives.

But what Ani did not guarantee Nigerians were that the committee would not constitute itself a red tape as virtually all such bodies under this government have; and, more importantly, that the policy would not be bogged down by political considerations Late last year, some interest groups, allegedly from the northern part of the country, felt their grip on power could be in jeopardy were such behemoths as the National Electric Power Authority, Nigerian Telecommunications Plc and Nigerian Ports Plc taken to the stock market. So they had mount pressure on Abacha to apply the breaks. As it were, the earliest these agencies would be up for sale is 1998.

But by far, the greatest quake from the budget visited the financial sector. Virtually everyone within the sector was affected for good or for ill. Take the Central Bank. It was first asked to go and shed some fat by purging itself of all commercial banking activities before being saddled with new responsibilities. Another area the CBN lost out is that the role of one of its babies - the Nigerian Deposit Insurance Corporation - has been taken away by the now robust Federal Ministry of Finance Incorporated. But the apex bank has been adequately compensated in other ways too. It now has direct control of such institutions as the Development Banks, the People'' Bank, Community Banks and Mortgage Institutions. This is a major step towards intense supervision of the entire financial sector and also a huge indictment of the National Board on community Banks and the Federal Mortgage Bank of Nigeria.

However, the CBN could not clink glasses as its fight for wholesale autonomy was only half-way achieved. Unfortunately, many misread its reversion to the ministry of finance as a greater loss of autonomy. Fact is, the CBN Decree 24 of 1991 that amended its 1958 Act effectively brought it under the office of the president, a wholly political office, which subjected the CBN governor to the whims of the president. At the budget breakdown, Mohammadu Haladu, the industries minister, said: "In order to ensure probity and accountability, the CBN should be under the ministry of finance. The whole purpose is to give strength to the CBN." He may be right. But critics argue that the sandstorm over the controversial mid-year N8 billion surplus where the two organs of government came up with contradictory figures may have led to the ministry. The federal government felt embarrassed by the CBN refutal of the claim on the budget surplus figures.

If the CBN has been well tooled to perform its statutory roles, the same may not be said of the banks. In fact they are in for the worst of times. Ultimately, government's action on banks this year is a masterstroke to save the financial sector from itself. The new policy may however see many of the institutions falling by the wayside; though this will restore sanity to the prevailing chaos in the system. To be sure, banks certified as seriously distressed have been given up to March 31 to beef up their capital base or risk being liquidated, while all bank have been given 24 months to raise their minimum paid-up capital to N500 million. By all standards, these are tall orders. There are at least 40 banks that fall under the first category and the problem is not so much as being healed of "benign" ailment of recapitalisation but that of the "malignant" obstacle of the new minimum paid- up capital. What this means is that even if some distressed banks could rally up a few million naira by March ending, it would be near impossible to get as much as half a billion naira a few months after. But for the less-distressed and solvent banks, getting up to N500 million will not be a tea party either. In the budget, government has covertly taken certain steps that may help the surviving banks. The return of commercial banking for government agencies, the repayment of debts owed them by the government and the phased refund of the stabilization securities to banks will raise the banks' level of liquidity this year. There are however fears that even with the full dose of the options, some banks will still be hard-put meeting target.

While the banks have been given what looked like a lifetime assignment, government seems set to sink its teeth into the real sectors of the economy. Ani said since 1996, government has been embarking on a reversal of the structural defects in the economy which stifled increased output, job creation and low prices, and that this would be continued this year for the desired result to be achieved. Here, agriculture, the long-forgotten saviour, is staging a come back. To achieve growth and development, government says it can no longer toy with the landing cultivation sector. Incentives such as credit, subsidy and facilities are being dangled before the sector in fiscal 1997.

Agricultural rejuvenation is pursued alongside the rural development and empowerment3. The Family Economic Advancement Programme, with a take-off grant of N4.3 billion, is the agency government believes will achieve this. Equally, the marginal success recorded in last year's exploitation of the mining and solid minerals sectors has given government the fillip to invest more in that sector. Apart from greater incentive here, government says it is further opening up the sectors to private investors, believing that more money could be made from them than from crude oil. Ani boasted that Nigeria as the best coal with the leanest sulfur content in the world and that for the first time in 21 years the country exported the product last year. To give it a boast, a N200 million grant has been given the Nigerian Coal Corporation.

The iron and steel sub-sector is also to be pampered this year, just as infrastructural facilities are seen as the hub of growth and development are receiving an unusual attention. Government is staking a huge N34.5 billion, (24.6 percent of the N189 billion federal budget on infrastructural development) in this area of the economy. These are mainly in the areas of water, electricity, health, education, roads, erosion control among others.

But the manufacturing sector can genuinely claim that it may not directly benefit much from fiscal 1997. This, more than any other sector, expected a greater appreciation of the naira which would have translated to lower cost of importation and clearing of goods. This huge loss has feebly been compensated by in-built incentives as the continuous reform of the Ports and Customs a slicing of duty on some goods, streamlining of multiple taxation and the expected improvement in infrastructural facilities which, hopefully will translate to reduced cost of doing business and increase in capacity utilization, employment opportunities and lower rate of inflation.

Informed analyst, despite its conservative outlook, views this year's budget as growth inducing and realist. Even by government projection, the economy is expected to grow at 5.5 percent by December, an improvement over the 3.25 percent rate it grew last year. Inflation is expected to peak at 15 percent, an improvement over the 28-percentage point that it reached last December. Government also intends to sustain the macro-economic stability it largely achieved last year. But apart from the attention to agriculture, Nigerians are still wondering how the budget will influence micro-economic variables such as greater job openings and improved purchasing power of Nigerians which were at the core of economic crisis for much of last year.

Even if the lofty targets are not met, government can hide under the umbrella that budgets are largely intentions.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


4 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 3, 1997


Nigeria;
The Final Blow for Labour


BYLINE: Austin Owete, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Lagos - The death Knell sounds for organised labour following the promulgation of a new decree with far-reaching consequences.

All is not well with the organised labour movement in Nigeria. Within its rank and file, there are grumblings and disenchantment. The reason is the promulgation of a new decree, which not only clips the wings of the labour movement but also makes it impossible for it to wriggle out of the knotty web of the legal draughtsman. 

The decree, titled "Trade Union (Amendment) Decree 26 of 1996," empowers the minister of labour to de-register any trade union not acting in national interest. It also bars professional unionists from contesting elective posts in the Nigeria Labour Congress. The decree further prescribes a five-year jail term or a fine of N100,000 for any person who contravenes its provisions. And any attempt to seek redress in any law court has been crippled by an ouster clause, which bars any law court from entertaining cases in relation to the decree.

With the promulgation of Decree 26 of 1996, the independence of trade unions to collective bargaining and freedom of association, as provided for by International Labour Organisation conventions 87 and 98, may have been eroded. It has also checkmated the dream of such labour veterans as Paschal Bafyau, secretary-general of the Nigerian Labour Union of Railwaymen, and Adam Oshomole, secretary-general of textile workers union, to contest the presidency of the NLC.

The labour movement in Nigeria has been reeling under the jackboot of government interference since the National Union of Petroleum and Natural Gas Workers and the Petroleum and Natural Gas Senior Staff Association of Nigeria staged a nationwide strike in 1994 to protest the annulment of the June 12 1993 presidential election. As a result, the government resolved to decapitate the workers' unions. In one such attempt last year, a plan to fully democratise the central union ran into a stone wall as a result of government's alleged determination to ensure that only such people that are sympathetic to it are elected into the various offices of the NLC. After a series of merger talks and elections at the primary level, Decree 4 of 1996 was rolled out, allegedly at the instance of Uba Ahmed, the labour minister. The high point of the decree is the provision that election would be "limited to card-carrying members." This, it was gathered, automatically disenfranchises secretaries, since they are appointees and not members of the unions. The textile workers union had then amended its rules to enable Adam Oshomole, its secretary and former deputy president of the NLC, become a card- carrying member and consequently become qualified to run for the election. The legal manoeuvre has stalled the election, which had been scheduled for April 1996. The elected executive council of the NLC was dissolved along with those NUPENG and PENGASSAN by Decree 28 of 1994.

At the Yaba office of the NLC, an official who pleaded anonymity told Theweek that the new decree is a "most awkward and undesirable law at a time like this." He added that "one would have thought that the government would realise the need to court the goodwill of the labour movement rather than kill it completely." Theweek gathered that Ahmed Gusau, the sole administrator of NLC, was away to Abuja.

And at Textile Workers Union building along ACME Road, Ogba, Lagos, a source told Theweek that the government might have realised its objective of muzzling the labour movement which is seen as another bastion of opposition. This action, the source said, will only compound the federal government's problems with the international community, which already has a low opinion of the present administration on account its poor human rights record. Another official, A.B. Dania, a senior deputy general secretary, declined comment but offered the telephone numbers of Adams Oshomole, said to be away to Kaduna. Dania insisted that Oshomole is the only competent person that can comment on the new development.

The new decree has opened a new chapter in the history of organised labour in the country. But the question of when Ahmed will first invoke the spirit of the new law is left in the womb of time.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


5 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 3, 1997


Nigeria;
All Bark, No Bite


BYLINE: Festus Owete, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 4574 words


 

Lagos - Growing indifference to the Nigerian situation by the Western powers and apparent reluctance by the new secretary-general of the United Nations to take on the Sani Abacha government dampen the morale of activist amidst fresh hints that the head of state may transmute into a civilian president.

It showed in everything about him. As Kola, first son of Moshood Abiola, presumed winner of the June 12, 1993 presidential election, arrived the courtroom at 8.45 a.m. last Tuesday, he was in full spirits. If anything, the way he conducted himself gave the impression of a man almost sure that the judgment on government's appeal against a federal high court ruling that his father be produced in court to untie the legal chain over his choice of counsel in his treasonable felony trial would be favourable. Dressed in a resplendent black suit with a red dotted shirt and matching shoes, Kola had on alighting from his white Mercedes Benz S-Class car discussed light heartedly with A.O. Jagun, the lawyer standing in for Rotimi Williams, a senior advocate and his choice as leading counsel for his father. He then took his seat and awaited the good news. 

As it were, Kola's ego was soon deflated. In the unanimous judgment which lasted barely 30 minutes, Umaru Kalgo, leading two other justices of the Abuja Appeal Court, ruled that it was not proper for Chrisanthine Senlong of the Federal High Court, Abuja, to order Ibrahim Coomassie, inspector-general of police, and the Abuja police commissioner, to produce Abiola in court to make a choice on who, between Rotimi Williams and G.O.K. Ajayi, another senior advocate, should represent him in the treasonable felony charge brought against him for allegedly declaring himself president on account of the voided election of 1993.

In the 31-page judgment, Kalgo stated that the order to produce Abiola in court to choose his counsel was not properly given. He pointed out that there was no prima facie evidence tendered at the lower court by Williams to warrant an order for Abiola to be produced in court to identify his counsel. To discountenance the order made for the production of Abiola in court over the matter, Kalgo cited section 53 of the Federal High Court Act. Quoting from the Act, he said that "a judge may issue a warrant under his hand for bringing up any person confirmed as a prisoner under any sentence or order of commitment for trial, provided that court warrant shall not be granted as of course, unless the judge shall have probable grounds for believing that the evidence of the prisoner is likely to prove material."

Similarly, Kalgo ruled that the court warrant issued by the Federal High Court, Abuja, on May 6, 1996 for the police to produce Abiola in court expired two days after it was issued. This, he said, was because, two days later when the order on the warrant was to be executed, Senlong failed to reactivate the warrant since it was not acted upon, but acted contrary to the law by issuing a court order compelling Coomassie to produce Abiola in court on May 10. Kalgo ruled that since the warrant was not executed on the day it was ordered, coupled with the fact that Tobechukwu Onwugbufor, solicitor- general of the federation and leading prosecutor in the Abiola case, had denied any knowledge of the warrant, and given the absence of Ajayi whose presence was required in court for Abiola to make a rightful choice of counsel, it was improper for Senlong to have issued an order of compliance on the police. The appeal court judge consequently thumbed down Senlong for describing the failure of the police to produce Abiola in court on May 8 as " executive rascality" and "executive disobedience." He observed that "there is no other prayer in the motion asking for the issue of a warrant for the production of the respondent in court."

On the tussle between Williams and Ajayi over who qualifies to serve as counsel to Abiola, Kalgo, drawing support from order 17 of the rules of the Federal High Court, stated that such a matter should be discountenanced as there was no request made asking the High Court to strike out Ajayi as counsel to Abiola. As he put it, "it is very clear from the motion before the trial court that the issue of representation in that court was not an issue to be determined by the court. What the respondent's counsel prayed for was for his name and that of another senior counsel to be entered as legal practitioners for the respondent."

Given the turn of events last week, one of the options left for the Abiola family is to proceed to the Supreme Court, an action which could tantamount to a wild goose chase capable of further keeping Abiola, who was arrested on June 23, 1994, in detention without trial.

Kola's deep feeling of disappointment as he left the Federal Court of Appeal, Abuja, compares equally with that of pro-democracy and human rights campaigners in the country. But whereas the young man's sorrow is occasioned by his father's plight, that of the activists goes far beyond to include the attitude of the United Nations, particularly the United States, and European nations towards the Nigerian situation.

In the case of the US, the first indication that the "policeman of the world" might have softened its stance on Nigeria came on November 19, 1994. That Saturday evening, the cream of Nigeria's pro-democracy and human rights crusaders had gathered in the official residence of Walter Carrington, the American ambassador to Nigeria, to explore ways to get the Western powers, especially the US to increase the pressure on the Abacha regime. There to ostensibly compare notes with Beko Ransome-Kuti, the now-incarcerated chairman of the Campaign for Democracy, Frederick Fasheun, currently in detention, Olisa Agbakoba, Femi Falana, Olabiyi Durojaiye and Abraham Adesanya, among other top activists, was a visiting six-member American congressional delegation. Led by Harry Johnston, a Democrat from Florida and chairman of the House of Representatives sub-committee on Africa, the delegation included Alice Hastings of Georgia, Floyd Flake of New York, William Jefferson (Louisana), Donald Payne (New Jersey) and Cynthia Mickinnwy (Georgia), all members of the American Lower House.

It was the height of the clamour for Abiola to be released from detention and sworn in as president and expectations were high that the US would help to resolve the political logjam in the country. For the activists gathered in Carrington's house in Lagos, however, it was an evening of disappointment, as the visiting Americans surprisingly took sides with the government, preferring to give support to the constitutional conference set up five months earlier to draw up a constitution for the country. Flustered by the unexpected development, Agbakoba and then the other pro-democracy and human rights crusaders sauntered out of the envoy's house to reflect on the meaning of it all.

As if to reaffirm their support for the conference, Johnston, who had on June 14, 1994 co-authored a two-page letter to Warren Christopher, at the time American secretary of state, asking the Bill Clinton administration to take diplomatic action to restore democracy in Nigeria, said at a world press conference that same evening of November 19 that following a meeting they had with various members of the conference, they felt that "a document could come forth from it," that is, the conference. He assured that they had a commitment from General Abacha that the document would not be interfered with.

Two years after, the official position of the US government to the Nigerian problem remains a far cry from what it was from the annulment of the 1993 presidential election, to the trial of the alleged coup plotters and the hasty execution of the nine Ogoni nationalists. Following the election annulment, the Clinton administration, barely few months in office, was in the vanguard of calls for sanctions against Nigeria to force its military government to walk the path of democracy. Matching words with action, the US government quickly slammed limited sanctions on Nigeria. The anti-Nigeria stance by the country reached a crescendo following the conviction by a secret military tribunal of the alleged coup plotters including Olusegun Obasanjo and Shehu Yar'Adua in July 1995, and the hanging of Ken Saro-Wiwa with eight other Ogoni rights champions four months later. On both occasions, the US had joined other countries and international bodies such as the Commonwealth of Nations, European Union and United Nations to express outrage against the Abacha regime. Indeed, in reaction to the execution of the Ogoni Nine, Carrington, like many other envoys flew back home " for consultations." He returned early last year and since then the Clinton administration has grown progressively indifferent to the situation in Nigeria.

Since Nigeria is one of the largest suppliers of oil to the US, the National Democratic Coalition, as well as other activists, have consistently campaigned for a boycott of Nigeria's oil as the best way to hurt the economy and bring the military regime to its knees. The pressure has not only been in vain, but the US has continued to warm up to the Abacha administration to the discomfiture of pro-democracy and human rights groups. The frustration in the ranks of the activists was poignantly illustrated last week when a NADECO top shot in exile in the US in a telephone conversation with a colleague in Nigeria lamented bitterly about America's attitude towards the Nigerian situation. According to him, the Clinton administration has developed cold feet in the current crusade to get Abacha's government to march to democracy, release Abiola, Obasanjo, Yar'Adua and others wrongly convicted or detained, as well as respect fundamental human rights. Unwittingly, echoing the sentiments of the NADECO exile, Ayo Adebanjo, a NADECO chieftain in Lagos, regretted last week that US has not taken any clear step to help Nigerians out of their predicament. Adebanjo, who regained his freedom after months of detention, last year, told Theweek that there has not been anything like a definite plan by the US to free those detained unjustly by the regime. He noted that the country's response to the Nigerian crisis has only been at the level of condemnation of human rights abuse and lack of democracy in black Africa's most populous nation.

Similarly, Innocent Chukwuma who coordinates the international lobby project at the Civil Liberties Organisation, told Theweek that there is no US policy on Nigeria apart from occasional statements by congressmen and government officials. Noting that oil sanction is the most potent instrument to whip Abacha's regime back to line. Chukwuma lamented that the US does not always want to take the lead in matters concerning Nigeria. Said the CLO top shot: "It (US) rather concedes the lead to Britain, perhaps out of the feeling that being our colonial masters, Britain will know the terrain better. " Chukwuma identified as an impediment, the fact that once it comes to issues pertaining to Nigeria, the US usually talks about the need to act in concert with other countries, as against the kind of unilateral actions which it takes in other countries all over the world.

With the benefit of hindsight, Nigerian activists are not placing any premium on the words of Madeline Albright, who when answering questions in the Senate while defending her nomination as the secretary of state for the next four years, said that Clinton "is concerned about what happens in Nigeria and is actively considering a number of options, including a variety of sanctions." Theweek found that in diplomatic as well as pro-democracy and human rights circles, Albright's assurance that the American government would intervene in Nigeria's political crisis is viewed as vague and bound to end up at the level of rhetorics.

In the circumstance, activists both at home and abroad are mourning mutely the almost certain shattering of their hope that there would be some decisive action against the Abacha regime during Clinton's second term in office as president. Last week one prominent activist spoke of how he and his colleagues had banked heavily on Clinton's second term in the expectation that, contrary to the situation during his first four years in office, he would feel free to act since he would not be seeking election again and so would not need to fear reprisals by voters who might feel that he was paying too much attention to foreign issues. The activist alluded to the current thinking in America which favours pre-occupation with domestic issues. He said that indications were that Clinton, who began his fresh mandate after being sworn in last Monday, may feel that so long as there is peace in Nigeria, even though a false one, there may be no need to worry about the political situation in the country.

Reflecting the new thinking in the pro-democracy community, Adebanjo said last week that America would not take any step beyond what it has already done. He regretted that while the US is contented with pressurising the Abacha regime to genuinely democratise and respect human rights, the regime is not a listening one. Corroborating Adebanjo, Ayo Akinbobola, a teacher of international relations at the University of Lagos, said that Clinton is not likely to take more action against Abacha's government, having already imposed limited sanctions on Nigeria. "Nigeria" he said, "is one of those countries suffering for not democratising. It is not receiving official assistance because it falls within the defined scope in which those not democratising are found."

Akinbobola, a former information commissioner in Ondo State, said that Clinton's failure to decisively act against Nigeria is understandable considering the presidential system of government. He explained that even if Clinton as a person may be willing to do more, the US president is seriously checked by the congress and that, in any case, the resources to execute any decision taken must be approved by the congress. Said the international relations lecturer: "The congress, dominated, not by the ruling Democratic Party but by the more conservative Republican which controls the purse, will not allow the president to spend money without question.

In what may be considered a double tragedy, the UN appears not prepared to take a definite position on Nigeria. Attempts to convince Kofi Annan, the new UN secretary-general, to bring the country's plight to the front burner were said to have ended in frustration. One of the attempts, Theweek learnt, was by some activists who reached out to Annan, seeking to convince the new UN scribe to prompt the world body to give the Nigerian crisis prime attention. The activists specifically requested the UN to intervene in the continued detention of Abiola and imprisonment of alleged coup plotters such as Obasanjo, former head of state, and his erstwhile deputy Yar'Adua, both considered as friends of the West. Annan was said to have confessed that he is not prepared to risk his tenure on Nigeria. As if to underscore this, Annan said in an interview published last week that the UN would assist Nigeria in the implementation of the on-going transition programme if such request is made by the government to it. According to Annan, he would assist in whatever way as "that is how we (UN) normally operate."

The new secretary-general disclosed that he supported what Boutros Boutros- Ghali, his predecessor, did by choosing the path of dialogue, indicating that he would continue with it. Apparently under pressure, Boutros-Ghali had last year reluctantly despatched a four-man UN fact finding team headed by Koffi Amega, a former Togolese foreign minister, to Nigeria in connection with the execution of the nine Ogoni nationalists and the controversial transition programme.

Although the team had earlier described the human rights situation in the country as terrible and the political situation as terrifying, its 24-page report surprisingly gave the regime a clean bill of health. The report stated that the transition programme seemed genuine and warned against further sanctions on Nigeria. Analysts expect the US policy towards Nigeria to largely reflect the UN thinking, given the level of support the new secretary- general enjoys from the Clinton's administration.

With the international community relapsing into cold indifference except for occasional tantrums by some influential countries, organisations and individuals, the stage may be set for the Abacha administration to maneuver things whatever way it wants. So far, the regime has rebuffed persistent appeals to release prisoners of conscience while its commitment to the transition programme remains suspect. Since the unfolding of the transition programme in October 1995, little has been done to inspire confidence in the project slated for completion in October 1, 1998. As the implementation set sail early last year, there came avoidable hitches, hinting on a possible extension of the life of the regime. Aside from the March zero-party council polls, which took place as scheduled, activities meant for other quarters had to be carried forward. For instance, the creation of states and local government areas originally billed for the second quarter never came until the third quarter of the year. Similarly, the party-based council polls fixed for the last quarter of the year had to be shifted to the first quarter of this year. As at now, the compilation of an authentic voters register scheduled for last year is yet to be concluded.

Rather than inject some credibility into the transition programme, the registration of the five political parties last September 30 has boosted speculations that Abacha may transform to a civilian leader. Mohammed Bello, former chief justice of the federation, kicked off the debate over the eligibility of the head of state to participate in the 1998 presidential race when in August, he cleared off the legal and constitutional fog thought to debar Abacha from contesting if he so wishes. As if taking a cue, a myriad of groups and individuals, including top government officials, joined in campaigning for, or speaking in favour of, an Abacha candidacy. Among such groups is the Kaduna-based National Tranquility Movement led by one Mohammed Gashash. The movement claims that Abacha has brought hope to Nigerians and therefore should be supported if Nigerians want him to continue in office. Down South in Lagos, another group known as the National Youth Consultative Forum has also emerged. Headed by Abimbola Davies of the defunct Association for Better Nigeria which played an inglorious role in aborting democracy in 1993, the NYCF says that an Abacha presidency is necessary because "Nigerian politicians are disoriented, weak, visionless and lack the zeal to arrest the drifting political situation."

One of the top government officials who have declared support for Abacha's presidency is Abdulkareem Adisa, works and housing minister. Adisa recently declared that the head of state remains the best material for president, stressing that he is "the only person serving today with more experience." On his part, Ishaya Bamaiyi, chief of army staff, has noted that it is not a crime for somebody in uniform to run for an election if allowed by the constitution. Said he: "If the constitution allows one in uniform to contest and I contest and win, is that a crime?" According to the army chief, the Nigerian constitution is very clear on the issue and the major qualification to contest is that one must be a Nigerian. Among the latest contributors to the debate is Maryam Abacha, the First Lady, who does not see anything wrong in "anybody who has the capability and the capacity and the will and the wish to assume the responsibility of keeping his country together." Speaking specifically on the chances of her husband seeking election, the First Lady said: "I do not see anything wrong in that if he wishes. If he says he wants to retire and if it is the will of God, let it be."

Rather paradoxically, since the registration of the five political parties, many of their leaders have been trying to outwit each other in their bid to woo Abacha. Observers are already saying that it should not be a surprise if at the end of the day Abacha turns out to be the only candidate for the presidential election. Given their alleged close links with the government, fears have been expressed that the parties may successfully lure Abacha to exploit the single candidate clause in the 1995 draft constitution. Section 36 sub-section A of the draft constitution states that a candidate for an election to the office of the president shall be deemed to have been duly elected to such office where being the only candidate for the election: (a) he has a majority of yes or no votes cast at the election, and (b) he has not less than one-third of the votes cast at the election in each of at least two thirds of all the states of the federation and the Federal Capital Territory, FCT, Abuja."

If in the end Abacha chooses to join the race, can he be stopped by the National Electoral Commission of Nigeria ? The possibility, going by the explanation of Sumner Dagogo-Jack, the NECON chairman, is remote. As Dagogo- Jack told a group of American journalists two weeks ago, his commission does not have the power as spelt out in Decree 3 of 1996, to dictate to anybody whether to stand for election or not. He explained that political parties are solely responsible for picking their candidates, who would then be subjected to screening by NECON.

For now, all that remains is for Abacha, who last November reassured the nation that the military would go in 1998, to indicate his interest to contest. The general seems to have everything going for him. The field has already been shorn of political heavyweights who, frustrated by the non- registration of their political associations, have jumped out of the transition boat. The Failed Banks Tribunal is also taking its toll on some money bag politicians and, with the Failed Contracts and Parastatals Decree on the way, more politicians who would possibly pose a threat to the head of state may well come under the hammer. While giving the 1997 budget breakdown in Abuja last Monday, Anthony Ani, the finance minister, revealed that the decree giving legal teeth to the tribunal took effect from January this year. Another development, which has fuelled speculations that Abacha may transform into a civilian president, was the unfolding of a long-

term economic programme called Vision 2010. Modeled after the economic programme of undemocratic, but industrialised, Asian countries, the committee to lay the foundation for the project was inaugurated late last year and is currently at work.

Thanks to the air of distrust surrounding the transition programme, even well-intentioned populist initiatives by government aimed to ease the hardship facing the vast majority of Nigerians are being seen by critics as a design to "bribe" the masses to back an Abacha presidency. Chief among these initiatives is the Petroleum Trust Fund established in 1995 and charged with helping to make the roads motorable, drugs available in the hospitals, food on the table of Nigerians while equally tackling the problems of the education sector.

But the real masterstroke of the regime may yet be the just introduced Family Economic Advancement Programme aimed at increasing the tempo of economic activities in the rural areas thereby curtailing rural-urban migration, especially among younger, able-bodied men and women. "The programme," Abacha said in his budget broadcast on January 18, "is aimed at facilitating the setting up of productive cottage enterprise that will use local labour and locally available raw materials and locally fabricated equipment in the rural areas."

With such programmes bearing modest fruits and the opposition with its back against the wall following Thursday's revelation by the police that it had iron-cast proof that NADECO is behind the bomb blasts in the country, the government seems set for a rich harvest of public affection. The game may yet be steaming.

With Malachy Uzendu, Abuja, Taye Ige and Austin Avwode


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


6 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 4, 1997


United States and Africa;
Consolidated Great Lakes Report No. 11 (01/25- 31))


BYLINE: U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2671 words


 

Washington DC - GREAT LAKES GENERAL: * African foreign ministers arrived in South Africa on Monday for crisis talks on the conflict in central Africa, where Zaire's army has begun a battle to regain rebel-held territory. (Reuters, 1/27/97)

* The President has authorized the use of up to $38 million from the U.S. Emergency Refugee and Migration Assistance Fund to meet the urgent needs of refugees, returnees and other conflict victims in the Great Lakes Region of Africa. (State 17323, 1/29/97)

REPATRIATION TO RWANDA: * About 2000 refugees are being repatriated per day at the Ruzizi I and II border crossings. Operations are hampered by a lack of trucking capacity. As a result, there are more refugees wanting to repatriate than there is available transport capacity. Furthermore, the Alliance's lengthy and thorough inspections of the refugees' personal property slows the process. (Kigali 405, DART/USAID Field Sitrep *37 1/28/97) 

* Nearly 8,000 Rwandan children who were separated from their families during the chaotic return of refugees to their homeland have been reunited with their loved ones by the Red Cross. The International Committee of the Red Cross said Thursday it used its computer tracing program to track down the families of three quarters of the 10,500 children who strayed during the trek from Zaire and Tanzania. (Associated Press, 1/31/97)

SITUATION IN RWANDA: * USAID/DART Field Officer asked NGOs and UN organizations if any new security measures had been implemented. The relief agencies had not received official information concerning incidents earlier in the week. Furthermore, no steps had been taken to formulate a security plan which encompassed both the UN organizations and the NGOs. NGOs have talked about security issues and are devising their own plans and relying on each other for support. (Kigali 405, DART/USAID Field Sitrep *37, 1/28/97)

* There has been another attack on a Spanish aid organization in Rwanda. A group of armed men entered the base of Medicins San Frontiers in the south of the country but nobody was hurt. The Spanish aid workers have evacuated the premises to avoid further incidents. (Courtesy FBIS, 1/28/97)

* Hutu extremists killed some 20 Tutsi civilians and wounded at least nine in a village in northwestern Rwanda at the weekend, aid and hospital officials said Thursday. (Reuters, 1/30/97)

Shelter * The Ministry of Rehabilitation and Social Integration presented the government's new policy on resettlement to the international NGO community. The new policy calls for group settlements consisting of 100 - 200 families. Committees headed by the local bourgmestre will be established at the communal level to plan site selection and implementation of the new policy. NGOs may be allowed to complete the rehabilitation of houses where work has already begun; all future shelter work must conform to the new policy...According to the plan, each family will receive a house with land for farming within two kilometers of the house...Whether an NGO would be allowed to complete housing rehabs that had been started would depend on the stage of implementation. In all cases, the local bourgmestre would determine whether an NGO should finish the rehabilitation of a house or abandon it. (Kigali 441, DART/USAID Field Sitrep *39, 1/30/97)

Food * While food distributions are being handed over from NGO's to local authorities, WFP will continue to deliver the food to the communes for handling and distribution to the communal authorities. (WFP Emergency Report *4, 1/24/97)

SITUATION IN ZAIRE: * Airlift operations from Kisangani to Tingi-Tingi and Amisi resumed after a brief suspension...but normal schedules are being disrupted due to insufficient availability of planes. (WFP Emergency Report *4, 1/24/97)

* According to humanitarian workers in Kisangani, the delivery of food aid to refugees near Lubutu and Shabunda has been seriously hampered by the military's "requisitioning" of private planes and trucks rented to aid agencies. (IRIN Emergency Update *90, 1/31/97)

* Rwandan refugees seeking repatriation continue to surface in several locations, mainly in Shaminunu, Bunyakiri and Shabunda (south of Bukavu.) No truck transportation is available from Shaminunu due to poor road conditions, and refugees must walk out to the barrier at the eastern entrance to the forest (Kahuzi Biega National Park) or to Madaka...No NGOs or international organizations have access to Shabunda, so refugees must walk from Shabunda to the border crossing. (Kigali 405, DART/USAID Field Sitrep *37, 1/28/97)

* At present, the health situation of refugees appears to be deteriorating. Malaria, dehydration, malnutrition and pneumonia remain the major health problems... NGOs are performing triage on the refugees arriving at the waystations to identify and provide some assistance to the most vulnerable before they reach the border crossing...The push by the Alliance and the GOR to get the refugees to their home communes as quickly as possible means that little assistance can be provided to the traveling refugees. (Kigali 405, DART/USAID Field Sitrep *37, 1/28/97)

* Zairian health officials have reported an unusual outbreak of Monkeypox in the Katako-Kombe region of western Kasai province. 71 Cases have been identified -- 6 being fatal. (Kinshasa 594, 1/28/97)

* UNICEF said refugees were moving in small groups towards Punia, 100 km northwest of Shabunda. Some 17,000 refugees had already arrived by Saturday. Aid workers said that conditions in Punia were worse than Tingi-Tingi. (IRIN Emergency Update *89, 1/29/97)

* Local authorities in eastern Zaire asked all international relief agencies on Friday to suspend aid activities in the Lubutu area near camps sheltering some 160,000 Rwandan Hutu refugees, the U.N. refugee agency UNHCR said. (Reuters, 1/31/97)

* UNHCR Spokeswoman Pam O'Toole said the order to suspend relief operations in the Lubutu area came Friday from Zairian provincial authorities. She said aid agency representatives were told their offices and installations in the Lubutu area are not legal, and relief flights will no longer be allowed to land in the region. (Voice of America, 1/31/97)

* ICRC is the only organization working in Bukavu and Uvira focusing on IDPs and vulnerables as well as refugees. All other international organizations in Zaire are principally concerned with refugees...Although UN organizations and NGOs have been invited into Uvira by the Alliance, the ICRC is the only agency with a presence. Uvira was more devastated during the recent fighting and subsequent retreat by the FAZ than Bukavu or other cities in the eastern Zaire border region...The ICRC delegate described the overall health situation in Uvira as "not good", but not destitute either. ICRC has reestablished five health centers in the outer region and three in the lower region surrounding Uvira. ICRC is also training and equipping personnel in the health posts and hospitals. (Kigali 409, DART/USAID Field Sitrep *38, 1/28/97)

* In Shabunda, where 40,000 refugees live in dire conditions, the local Zairian population is also suffering as the crops are systematically plundered: Zairians are now said to be escaping to the forests, hoping to find alternative means to feed themselves. (UNICEF Update *37 on the Great Lakes Region, 1/28/97)

SITUATION IN BURUNDI: * The relief community operating in Burundi is concerned that the fuel it needs to conduct humanitarian operations has been held up by the Regional Sanctions Committee...We are concerned that a shortage of fuel is beginning to adversely effect the delivery of vital relief supplies to at-risk groups inside Burundi. (State 18598, 1/31/97)

* According to UN sources in Burundi, some 75,952 Burundians have returned from Zaire since 24 October 1996. Of these, 56,678 have returned spontaneously to the provinces of Cibitoke, Bubanza, Bujumbura-rurale and Bujumbura-mairie. The rest, 19,274 came through the Gatumba transit site, with 17,044 continuing on to their home communes and some 880 remaining in Gatumba. (IRIN Emergency Update *90, 1/31/97)

* A report, released yesterday, by the UN human rights mission in Burundi claimed that the Burundian army is responsible for the massacre of hundreds of women and children in the last two months. It claimed that at least 1,100 people have been killed by either the Burundian military or Hutu rebels in the seven weeks from December 1 to January 22. (IRIN Emergency Update *90, 1/31/97)

* Burundi's military leader Major Pierre Buyoya promised to investigate reports by the United Nations that his mainly Tutsi army has killed at least 1,000 people since the start of December. (Reuters, 1/31/97)

TANZANIA: * In late 1996, following the ADFL capture of towns in eastern Zaire, the Tanzanian town of Kigoma received an influx of large numbers of Zairean refugees fleeing across Lake Tanganyika. After being screened in holding centres in Kigoma approximately 40,000 Zaireans were trucked to Nyaragusu camp, north of Kigoma. This camp is now full leaving some 10,000 Zaire refugees in four holding centres in Kigoma while 800 to 1,500 continue to arrive on a daily basis. According to humanitarian workers their situation is critical. The rate of cholera in Kigoma is also said to have almost doubled. (IRIN Emergency Update *90, 1/31/97)

ACRONYMS:

Refugees, and Migration

Congo-Zaire

NOTE: The Consolidated Great Lakes report is a compilation of information from the following sources: USG cables; U.N., IO, and NGO situation reports; press clips; and USG departments, bureaus, and offices. The date and source of each entry are noted, but the information should be checked against source materials. Information is reported as of the date of the source; however, conflicting information may appear within the consolidated report due to rapidly changing events in the region.U.S. Government cables are denoted by a capital city name followed by a number. Ex: KIGALI 4831
