7 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 4, 1997


Swaziland;
COSATU Reiterates Support for Swazi Strikers


BYLINE: Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Johannesburg - Having analysed the joint statement made by both the Foreign Ministries of South Africa and Swaziland, COSATU wants to make it clear to both Ministers that it is an independent Federation - it does not take orders from governments.

COSATU applauds Minister Nzo for acknowledging the autonomy and independence of COSATU. Solidarity knows no borders when trade union rights and human rights are violated. Besides, COSATU's founding principles commit it to international solidarity. Swaziland has ratified some of the ILO conventions and COSATU expects it to live by those same conventions. 

The notion that says the Swaziland Constitutional Review Committee will bring about democracy in that country is rapidly becoming a hopeless dream. The Swaziland Committee should be reconstituted according to the demands of the Swaziland Federation of Trade Unions (SFTU), namely:

1. It should be a transparent body committed to an open process;

2. It should involve ALL stakeholders. The review committee at the moment is a toothless dog that lost its credibility from its inception.

Swaziland Blockade

COSATU has not yet taken a decision to blockade Swaziland. We have asked our members to go slow in handling goods from and to Swaziland. However a blockade might be one of the options to be considered if the SFTU leaders are not released soon and if genuine negotiations do not take place.

The COSATU National Executive Committee will meeting next week on the 11 & 12 February. Amongst other issues, is the intensification of COSATU's solidarity with the SFTU will be discussed.

Picket

In the meantime COSATU will hold a picket at the offices of the Swaziland High Commissioner in Pretoria on Thursday 16 February 1997 at 12noon - 2pm. The address is : 1090 Arcadia Street, corner Hilda and Festival Streets, Hatfield. We demands that the Swazi government :

* release the detained trade union leaders immediately;

* enter into genuine transparent negotiations with SFTU and other stake holders.

COSATU calls on everybody concerned about the Swaziland situation to join the leadership in this picket. We cannot allow basic human rights to be abused and workers rights to be undermined.

Issued by Nowetu Mpati, COSATU Head of Communications, Tel: + 27 + 11 + 339- 4911 Fax: + 27 + 11 + 339-2281 E-mail: nowetu@cosatu.org.za.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


8 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 4, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 93 on the Great Lakes (02/04)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2827 words


 

Nairobi - Zairean military sources told Reuters that Allied Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL) rebels had captured the town of Kalemie, 400 km south of Goma, on Monday. Kalemie is a major port on Lake Tanganyika and is the railhead into Kabalo that intersects with the Lubumbashi /Kindu line.

Humanitarian sources told IRIN that the loss of Kalemie to ADFL rebels could block humanitarian aid being sent via the Lubumbashi /Kindu rail link, further complicating an already difficult logistical operation. According to Reuters, ADFL rebels appear to be moving south towards Moba, 150 km from Kalemie, the last major Zairean port on Lake Tanganyika not already in rebel hands. Both towns are in the mineral rich province of Shaba, Kabila's birth place. Military sources told Reuters that the rebels had captured large amounts of military equipment in Kalemie. They also confirmed that Watsa, in Upper Zaire 500 km north of Goma, had fallen and Lubutu, 240 km from Kisangani near the Tingi-Tingi refugee site, was being surrounded by rebels. 

Despite the increase in fighting leading to the fall of Kalemie, IFRC reported no increase in refugee arrivals to Kigoma, across Lake Tanganyika in Tanzania. Arrivals, mainly of Zairean refugees have been continuing at between 800 and 1,500 per day for most of January, and the total refugee population in and around around Kigoma town, according to IFRC is 40,000. All the Zairean refugees are being moved to a new site at Lagufu, which has a capacity of 50,000.

In a continued effort to restore order to the FAZ, scores of soldiers have been arrested and charged with looting and desertion. A group of 150, including a few civilians, were disarmed on 28 January by SARM in Bumba, Equateur province, and flown to Kinshasa to face trial by a special tribunal, said Reuters.

Despite the internal clean-up, the Zairean counter-offensive, led by chief- of-staff General Mahele Lioko Bokungu, is still hampered by a lack of adequate financial and logistical support. Analysts question Mobutu's commitment to regaining the east. A victory over the ADFL rebels following reorganization of the military, they say, would make General Mahele too powerful a force; one capable of supplanting Mobutu's traditional control over the army.

Opposition forces in Zaire are also hindering the war effort with appeals to Morocco, Togo and Egypt -- all of which have strong ties with France -- not to assist Zaire with troops to fight the rebels, said AFP.

* Insecurity in the Watsa area has forced Sudanese refugees, who have been in Dungu 160 km north of Watsa since 1991, to flee back to Sudan. Some 2,000 have already arrived in three camps southwest of Meridi, western Equatoria. WFP, who has a permanent team based in Meridi, told IRIN that it has provided a 26-day ration for the returnees and NGOs have provided non-food assistance. An Operation Lifeline Sudan news release today said the returnees began trickling back in early January, but to date there is no clear indication of how many of the former refugees will return. The original 1991 refugee population, which fled insecurity in southern Sudan was estimated between 30- 40,000. Humanitarian sources told IRIN that the refugees reported fleeing from raping and looting FAZ soldiers. It is unclear whether this is a new development resulting from the current fighting around Watsa or if the refugees were fleeing the previous FAZ looting spree following the fall of Bunia. Moving from one conflict zone to another, the returnees have arrived in Sudan amid a renewed Sudanese People's Liberation Army (SPLA) offensive in that area.

* Following EU commissioner Emma Bonino's criticism of the international community's response to the plight of some 400,000 Rwandan refugees in eastern Zaire, Rwanda's UN envoy, Gideon Kayinamura, on Monday said that the remaining refugees were composed of 40,000 ex-FAR and their families. "We know that the bona fide refugees have walked back home, the (ex-FAR) soldiers walked into the forest with their arms to join the Zairean army. These are the ones the humanitarian agencies say need assistance," ambassador Kayinamura told a news conference in New York. "We are saying that it is not appropriate for the humanitarian bodies to extend refugee status to a criminal army that is inside Zaire, and that is holding a few Rwandan refugees as their own hostages, including their own families," he said.

Belgian Foreign Ministry spokesman Andre Querton told AFP that Belgium would appeal to UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan on Tuesday to "reactivate an international presence to provide humanitarian aid " to the refugees. The previous Multinational Force lead by Canada barely got off the ground when it was terminated following the propitious mass return of refugees to Rwanda. Querton told AFP that Belgium supported Kengo wa Dondo's government, whose proposed July elections offered a "democratic perspective", unlike its counterparts in Rwanda and Burundi.

Sadako Ogata, the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, on Monday added her voice to the call for an international police or military force to separate extremists from bona-fide refugees in situations such as those in eastern Zaire. She said the force could be used to prevent Hutu extremists from gaining a foothold in the camps and preventing people from returning home. Humanitarian workers told IRIN that the organizational structure of the camps and statements from refugees indicated that elements of the ex-FAR and Interahamwe were already in control of the camps. Analysts are not confident that an international force would be willing or able to identify and neutralize the extreme Hutu elements in the camp any more than they were able to due so in Goma and Bukavu where conditions were more favourable. Humanitarian sources also question the political feasibility of disarming refugees who are clearing fighting alongside FAZ forces.

Humanitarian sources told IRIN that the crucial issues facing humanitarian operations in eastern Zaire have not been addressed. No international call has yet gone out to the Zairean government, insisting on the relocation of the Amisi refugees to a safe haven away from the front-line, preferably to a location more logistically accessible to humanitarian operations. The source said that the continued detainment of innocent refugees in Amisi was " criminal" and that continued assistance increased the risk that both humanitarian aid and logistical equipment, trucks and plans, could be diverted to the war effort.

Ogata begins a tour of the Great Lakes region, including Kenya, on Thursday. AFP quoted Ogata saying she was "very worried and disappointed" that information emerging daily on the plight of the refugees does "not seem to be have been absorbed very much by the international community."

* Former Tanzanian president Julius Nyerere, in his role as mediator, held talks in Arusha Tanzania on Monday with Burundian military leader Pierre Buyoya, the secretary-general of the Organization of Africa Unity (OAU) Salim Ahmed Salim, the special US envoy, Howard Wolpe, the UN representative in Bujumbura, Marc Faguy, and a representative of South African President Nelson Mandela to seek ways out of the deadlock, said AFP. He warned, "So far we haven't made any progress. I am beginning to feel that I am providing an umbrella for the killings." Nyerere said he favoured maintaining economic sanctions against Burundi, which were imposed following the July 1996 coup. Humanitarian sources told IRIN that exemptions to the sanctions for humanitarian operations were becoming increasingly more "bureaucratic". For supplies delivered by road from Kenya, agencies are now required to negotiate individual exemptions with the Kenyan National Sanctions committee as well as that of Tanzania. The sanctions were intended to force the Tutsi regime to " restore constitutional order" and open negotiations with the Hutu rebels. Their effectiveness, given a reportedly flourishing and lucrative black market trade, is a matter of debate.

The government-organized four-day forum on restoring peace to Burundi ended 31 January with many of the 60, mainly Tutsi, delegates divided on how to stop the civil war. Jan van Eck, an expert on conflict resolution said that " There was a substantive shift in favour of negotiations," where "several months ago you couldn't even speak about negotiations." Hutu parties boycotted the debate and Hutu rebels were banned from participating in the national forum unless they declared a cease-fire.

Referring to the recent national forum, former president Nyerere was not so optimistic saying he and "many in Burundi, did not consider the conditions were right for holding a national debate in Burundi," largely because of the high degree of insecurity in the country, said AFP. "Conditions are worse than they were last July," he said. "The killings are going on."

Burundi will proceed with the trial of 80 people accused of participating in massacres following the 1993 abortive coup by elements of the Tutsi military against the first Hutu president, Melchior Ndadaye. The assassination sparked mass killings around Burundi. At present, only 13 of the suspects are being held for trial while others remain free.

Some 2,250 Burundian male students headed for military training camps following last month's decree that military service would be compulsory for first year university students, most of whom are of Tutsi ethnicity. Female conscripts are expected to leave for military camps next week. This marks a change for the Burundian army which until recently has been composed only of professional soldiers, said AFP. University dean Gilbert Midende announced the introduction of compulsory "civil and technical" service for some 3,000 first and second year students.

* The Kenyan 'Daily Nation' reported that the Ugandan military had rescued more than 200 civilians allegedly taken captive by the Ugandan Allied Democratic Forces (ADF) in a series of battles in the Rwenzori mountains over the last few weeks. Security officials claimed that more than 1,000 people have been taken hostage since mid-November 1996. Zairean support for the ADF rebels has been a source of contention and justification for a Ugandan military incursion into Zairean territory.

The state-owned Sunday Vision paper, quoting the Ugandan minister of state for defence, Amama Mbabazi, said that Uganda would not attack the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) rebels' base in Sudan. "This government respects international borders and therefore we are not planning any such action," however, "if they choose to invade us, we'll be able to show them it was not the best option."

* The HRFOR has recently released a report criticizing aspects of the genocide trials in Rwanda, stating that in trials held between 8 and 20 January there was a lack of fair-trial guarantees as required by Rwandan law and Article 14 of the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights, to which Rwanda is a party. The report follows HRFOR monitoring of court proceedings for 13 persons being tried in Byumba, Butare, Gisenyi and Kigali Ville prefectures, proceedings which resulted in seven persons being tried, convicted and sentenced to death and six persons having their trials adjourned.

The HRFOR report cites cases in which defendants were not allowed lawyers to defend them, were unable to respond to allegations against them and were not able to cross-examine evidence. In once case, a defendant charged with genocide was asked if he had a lawyer. When a lawyer offered to defend the accused this was disallowed by the presiding judge as the lawyer did not have authorization from the Ministry of Justice to represent that particular defendant. When the defendant requested an adjournment so he could find a lawyer this was not granted. In the final event, the defendant was sentenced to death without having been given the opportunity to defend himself and without witnesses having been called, either for the prosecution or the defence.

The HRFOR report urges the Rwandan authorities to ensure that 'essential rights', including the right of civil claimants to legal counsel, are safeguarded during the trials. The HRFOR also expressed the hope that the Government of Rwanda will soon act on a proposal submitted by the Rwandan and Foreign Lawyer's' Initiative, supported by HRFOR, to train Rwandan and foreign legal counsel to represent defendants in each prefecture.

* HRFOR also reported that during December four people were extrajudicially executed by the Rwandese Patriotic Army in two separate incidents. On 10 December, three murder suspects were killed by RPA soldiers during a public meeting in Mbuye sector, Satinsyi commune, in Gisenyi prefecture. The three were accused of killing a local businessman on 4 December. On 21 December, a recent returnee from Zaire who was suspected of murder was executed in a public meeting by RPA soldiers near Ndago, Mubuga commune, in Gikongoro prefecture. He had been accused of killing a genocide survivor and three other persons on 11 December. HRFOR reports that when it raised these incidents with the Ministry of Defence they stated that the events were regrettable and that orders had been given not to carry out such executions. HRFOR has requested the authorities to investigate the incidents and carry out appropriate disciplinary measures against those found guilty of violations.

* WFP issued a statement dated 29 January, that northern Uganda and other parts of the country could soon face food shortages if the current conflict is not resolved. A WFP needs assessment mission to the northern district confirmed that some 200,000 persons had been displaced by renewed fighting between government and rebel factions. Although many of the displaced risk returning to insecure areas in order to salvage food from their farms, the small reserves remaining will likely be consumed by the end of February, rendering the displaced totally dependent on food aid. Unless there is an early resolution to the conflict before the next planting season, the July harvest will be lost and "full-scale famine will ensue", WFP claims. This will further complicate the region's food supply situation, already diminished due to drought conditions in Kenya and parts of Tanzania.

Nairobi, 4 February 1997, 15:00 gmt (ENDS)

Africa News


February 4, 1997


Zaire;
Zairian Army Sets Up New Brigades


BYLINE: Munkeni Lapess, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 849 words


 

KINSHASA, Zaire (PANA) - Zaire is carrying out a vast conscription exercise aimed at mobilizing manpower for the creation of new brigades to beef up its armed forces now battling rebels in the eastern part of the country.

In a statement made available to PANA in Kinshasa on Tuesday, the country's Deputy Prime Minister, Gen. Likulia Bolongo Lingbangi, said the operation involves setting up "rapid intervention units" to beat off the rebel attack. 

Lingbangi said the conscription, which will go hand in hand with the provision of modern equipment to the Zairian Armed forces (FAZ), is being carried out among youths between the ages of 15 and 18 years who had at least four years of post-primary education.

The statement said the general mobilisation seeks to strengthen the armed forces "so that they become a deterrent force and an effective defensive shield".

News about the brigades had been circulating for the past two weeks in Kinshasa, since it was announced that rebels led by Laurent Kabila had overrun Zairian troops and seized several towns in eastern Zaire.

The latest reports indicated that the port of Kalemie on the shores of Lake Tanganyika, has fallen to the rebels.


LOAD-DATE: February 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

10 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 4, 1997


Business and Finance;
Coca-Cola Announces $220 Million Investment in SA


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - Coca-Cola has pledged an investment of 220 million U.S. dollars in South Africa over the next five years.

This is one of the largest foreign investments in post-apartheid South Africa, and comes amid a period of significant new interest in the country by United States companies, including a possible return of the giant automaker, General Motors.

Announcing the new investment, Coca-Cola's chief executive, Doug Ivester, said it was aimed at doubling the group's business in South Africa. 

Currently the bottler's turnover in South Africa stands at some than one billion dollars a year in retail sales.

South Africa is presently Coke's 10th largest partner among a total of 210 countries in which it does business worldwide, a ranking which places it between the United Kingdom at ninth and China at the 11th position.

Coca-Cola officials, who announced the new marketing drive Monday in Johannesburg, said the investment would be split with the seven locally-owned companies which bottle the group's products in South Africa.

With spare capacity available in the local bottling industry, much of the spending would be aimed at expanding and improving the availability of products to emerging markets.

"We believe in the future of South Africa," Ivester said.

"We believe the country offers tremendous growth opportunities to those who show long-term discipline, and we believe the time to invest in South Africa is right now," he added.

The group already employs 13,000 people in South Africa, and the new investment is expected to create many more jobs.

Coca-Cola Southern African President Charles Frenette said the final size of the investment would depend on the needs of the market.

"This is not about bottling plants. It's about expanding the marketing infrastructure. This is about energizing the market to increase demand and consumption," Frenette said.

The Coca-Cola Group has also significant interest in sub-Sahara Africa. It recently invested some 100 million in Uganda, Tanzania and Mozambique.

Ivester is scheduled to visit Zimbabwe later this week to review the group's investment in that country.


LOAD-DATE: February 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


11 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 4, 1997


Congo;
Army Recruits Mutiny At The Loudima Camp


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo (PANA) - Youths who once belonged to the numerous Congolese militia groups have since Saturday been involved in a mutiny at the Loudima military camp, 350 km from here, where they were undergoing training for their integration into the national army.

Military sources in Brazzaville said on Tuesday that the youths insist they should be enlisted into the national army with the rank of sergeant.

The youths were recruited in efforts to end the political turmoil that led to the death of 2,000 people in the Congolese capital in 1993, triggered by allegations of rigging in parliamentary polls held that year. 

To press their demands, the mutineers took control of Loudima railway station, where they erected barricades to prevent traffic between Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire, the country's economic capital. As a result, no train has moved between the two cities since Saturday.

Railway sources said the mutineers threatened to set fire to any train that approached the Loudima station. A military and governmental delegation was expected to fly to Loudima on Tuesday to tackle the problem.

In February 1996, some 300 newly recruited militiamen staged a similar mutiny in Brazzaville, to press demands for integration into the army and the payment of back salaries.

They seized the M'Pila armoured regiment, East of Brazzaville and forced the high command to give in to their demands. Five people were killed in the fighting which ensued.

The rebellious militia go by such names as the 'Cobras' of the Congolese labor Party (PCT-Former single party led by Gen. Denis Sassou Nguesso), the 'Ninja' of the Congolese Movement for Democracy and Integral Development (MCDDI-Party of Bernard Kolelas, Opposition leader) and the 'Zulu' of the Panafrican Union for Social Democracy (Upads-Party of president Pascal Lissouba).

These militia groups were officially dissolved in 1995 under a "peace pact" which was signed by the political leaders, leading to the integration of some 2,000 militiamen from various political parties into the regular army.


LOAD-DATE: February 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


12 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 4, 1997


Liberia;
UN Recommends Political Framework For Liberia


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

NEW YORK, United Nations (PANA) - The United Nations has proposed measures aimed at establishing a credible political framework for elections in Liberia next May.

In his latest report on the war-ravaged West African country, the UN Secretary-General, Kofi Annan, said the proposals were based on the conclusions of a technical survey conducted by a UN team that visited the country last December.

"The recommendations were also developed on the basis of the need for the elections to be as inclusive, operationally simple and cost-effective as possible," Annan said in the report, released in New York on Monday. 

He said the recommendations would be tabled for confirmation as an " provisional electoral package" for the elections, scheduled for may, at a special meeting of the ECOWAS committee of nine and the Liberian parties later this month.

The package is also expected to be incorporated into the Abuja agreement, the peace accord signed by warring parties as a formula for ending the six- year-old civil war in Liberia.

"The package would not seek to replace or reform the existing Liberian electoral system, nor to change the country's constitution, but would serve as a provisional mechanism (for) ...the installation of a government of national unity and pave the way for a return to a constitutional order," the UN chief said.

Meanwhile, Annan has expressed concern at the disagreement among Liberians on some of the recommendations, including the number of chambers in the legislative assembly and whether there should be a run-off in the presidential elections.

Disagreement has also been voiced on the composition of the electoral commission, voting by refugees and the roles to be played by the West African Economic Community (ECOWAS) and the UN.

"The inflexible tone of some of the reactions, especially on the part of certain of the faction leaders, could be cause for concern," he said.

"It is hoped that these questions will be resolved through a fully constructive approach by all parties."

In October last year, the UN received a formal request from the Liberian Council of State for assistance in developing a suitable electoral framework for the elections.

The UN, which maintains 78 military observers in Liberia, and the Ecowas Peace monitoring group (Ecomog), whose 7,500 troops are helping to keep the peace in the country, are jointly monitoring the implementation of the Abuja agreement.

The latest action by Ecomog has been the disarming of combatants from the numerous warring Liberian factions.


LOAD-DATE: February 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


13 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 4, 1997


South Africa;
South Africa's New Constitution Takes Effect Today


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - South Africa's new constitution, hailed as one of the most progressive in the world, came into effect at midnight Monday.

It replaces the interim constitution under which the country has been governed since the inception of the first democratically elected parliament in May 1994. 

Its final certification in December 1996 by the Constitutional Court ended negotiations which began after President Nelson Mandela's release February 1990 from 27 years in prison.

All South African parliamentary parties were involved in the drawing up of the new constitution, with the exception of the Zulu-dominated Inkatha Freedom Party, which walked out halfway when its demands for international mediation went unmet.

The new constitution reaffirms South Africa as a constitutional republican state. Significant features include a Bill of Rights which enshrines the rights of all people in South Africa and affirms the democratic values of human dignity, equality and freedom.

The Bill of Rights will be enforceable not only by individual citizens and organizations against the state but also between individuals and civic organizations.

The new constitution provides for six state institutions supporting constitutional democracy: the Public Protector; the Human Rights Commission; the Commission for the Promotion and Protection of the Rights of Cultural, Religious and Linguistic Communities; the Commission for Gender Equality; the Auditor-General; and the Electoral Commission.

The new constitution also stipulates that it has to be reviewed annually by parliament.

The first major event under the new constitution will be the inauguration Thursday of the National Council of Provinces. This body replaces the Senate and is geared to giving the nine provinces a more direct say at national parliamentary level.

In Cape Town on Friday, Mandela will open the first parliamentary session under the new constitution at a joint sitting of the National Assembly and the council.


LOAD-DATE: February 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


14 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 4, 1997


Tanzania;
Tanzania Reshuffles Cabinet


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

MBEYA, Tanzania (PANA) - Tanzanian President Benjamin Mkapa has reshuffled his cabinet naming Daniel Yona as the new minister for finance, to replace Simon Mbilinyi, who resigned recently.

Reporting this Tuesday, the Tanzanian news agency, Shitata, said Dr. Aaron Chiduo became the new minister for health. Chiduo, who once served in the same portfolio under former President Julius Nyerere, takes over from Zakia Hamdan Meghji, who moves to the ministry of natural resources and tourism.

Trade and Industries Minister Abdallah Kigoda and that of energy and minerals, William Shija, exchange offices. So too, do ministers Muhamed Seif Khatib (office of the vice-president) and Bakari Mbonde (office of the prime minister).

Deputy Minister of Energy and Minerals Nassoro Malocho becomes the minister in the presidency, in charge of planning and restructuring of state-owned firms.

A number of deputy ministers were also appointed.

Ismail Juma Ivwata is the deputy minister for water and Monica Mbega, the deputy minister for finance, replacing Kilontsi Mporogomyi, who lost the job.

Manju Salum Msambya becomes deputy minister of energy and minerals, Mudhihir Mohamed Mudhihir goes to the ministry of lands and urban development and Pius Mbawala, agriculture, in charge of cooperatives.

Gladness Mziray shifts from education and culture to health, with Bujiku Philipo Sakira becoming the new deputy minister for education and culture.


LOAD-DATE: February 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


15 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 5, 1997


Sudan;
UN Says Zaire Conflict Forces Sudanese Refugees Home


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 934 words


 

Nairobi - Operation Lifeline Sudan (OLS) agencies have this week delivered emergency food and relief supplies to a group of more than 2,000 Sudanese refugees who returned from Zaire in January due to rising conflict.

The returnees have settled in three camps -- Gbuo, Nabanga and Bamani -- southwest of Maridi, Western Equatoria. They were robbed of all their possessions en route to Sudan and some women were reported to have been raped.

They were among some 30,000-40,000 Sudanese who fled to Zaire in 1990-91 to escape escalating fighting in southern Sudan between forces of the Sudan Government and the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA). The Sudanese lived among the Zairois in various parts of north-eastern Zaire, near Isiro. They said they were returning to Sudan due to increasing instability. 

"We decided that we would come back home, even if home was not liberated fully," returnees Umoya Ginana and Arale Semuma told an OLS assessment team. " We are glad to be back home."

The assessment team found that the returnees looked reasonably well- nourished, but were weak and hungry from their journey. They had returned with very little food, mainly cassava and sweet potatoes, most of which had run out.

The coordinated OLS emergency response included a full food ration to last for 26 days, medicines and vaccines, and 675 survival kits containing items such as blankets, jerrycans, cooking pots, mosquito nets, plastic sheeting, fishing equipment, soap and salt.

The food was purchased by the World Food Programme (WFP) from World Vision International (WVI) which had obtained stocks of grain from local farmers through a barter programme. It was transported by WVI truck from Nzara on the Sudan-Zaire border, along with the survival kits provided by WVI.

Medical supplies and vaccines for a measles immunization campaign were provided by Aktion Afrika Hilfe (AAH), Medecins sans Frontieres (MSF)-Belgium, and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). MSF-Belgium, with support from UNICEF, will dig shallow wells to provide immediate supplies until boreholes can be drilled in each camp. OXFAM is providing on-ground coordination for the emergency response, as well as assistance with the transport of food and supplies.

In neighbouring Mundri County, another 22 tonnes of WFP food and 325 WVI survival kits will be delivered for some 8,000 people who were displaced during 1996 by fighting between the SPLA and the Sudanese Army. The people are reported to be in serious condition.

MSF-Belgium will conduct a nutritional survey to determine malnutrition levels, and a further 50 tonnes of WFP food will be delivered in the coming days.

Teams of UN and NGO staff will remain in the area to monitor the situation of the displaced and returnee populations. Sudanese are continuing to return from northeastern Zaire, where an estimated 20,000 Sudanese are believed to be living in the Dungu area.

The newly appointed OLS Coordinator, Mr Carl Tinstman, praised the NGOs and UN staff for their rapid response.

He said: "The returnees and displaced people were clearly in a desperate and vulnerable state. The OLS agencies responded in a well-coordinated and mutually supportive manner within 48 hours of the need being identified. This kind of emergency response is what OLS was created for."

The emergency response is coordinated by the Sudan Relief and Rehabilitation Association (SRRA) in cooperation with UNICEF, WFP and five NGOs operating under OLS -- AAH, Mundri Relief and Development Association (MRDA), MSF-Belgium, OXFAM-UK/I and WVI.

OLS is a consortium of more than 40 UN and non-government agencies providing emergency relief and rehabilitation for war-affected civilians in Sudan. As lead agency for OLS, UNICEF coordinates humanitarian activities, while WFP manages aircraft operations on behalf of the consortium.

OPERATION LIFELINE SUDAN - NEWS RELEASE: Nairobi, 4 February 1997

For more information, contact: Sally Burnheim or Christy Dow Brenda Barton or Communications Section Michele Quintaglie Regional Information Office UNICEF/OLS World Food Programme Tel: 622-403 or 622-410 Tel: 622-594 or 622- 336

UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re- print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


16 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 5, 1997


Zaire;
U.S. Media Group Protests Zairean Journalists' Arrests


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

New York - Text of two lettera from William A. Orme, Jr., executive director, Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ), to Prime Minister Leon Kengo wa Dondo of Zaire, January 30, 1997

Your Excellency:

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) strongly protests the arrest, on the orders of General Bolozei Ngbudu, of Jean Mbenga Muagianvita, an independent freelance journalist for the private newspapers "La Tempete des Tropiques", "Umoja" and "L'Example". Muagianvita was arrested by soldiers of the Military Action and Intelligence Service (SARM) on January 23, 1997, in connection with a series of articles published in November 1996 about President Mobutu's United States-based political lobbyists. Muagianvita is currently held incommunicado at SARM headquarters at Kitambo in Kinshasa. 

On the day of his arrest, SARM soldiers returned with Muagianvita to his home to search for documents. Seven SARM soldiers raped Muangianvita's 14- year-old daughter in the presence of her father.

As a nonpartisan group of journalists committed to the defense of its colleagues' rights worldwide, CPJ contends that this action against Muangianvita is a blatant violation of his right to hold and express opinions and ideas. CPJ also repudiates the brutal and violent rape of his adolescent daughter by SARM soldiers.

We respectfully remind your Excellency that Zaire ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, Article 19 of which guarantees the right to "seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kind." These rights are also guaranteed by Article 9 of the African Charter on Human and People's Rights to which, we again respectfully remind Your Excellency, Zaire is a signatory.

CPJ requests that Your Excellency do everything in your power to ensure the immediate and unconditional release of Muangianvita and the arrests and convictions of the soldiers who raped his daughter.

Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.

Your Excellency:

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) strongly protests the arrests, during the first week of January 1997, of Mrs. Biongo, the wife of exiled Zairean journalist Benjamin Sham Shamg Lapong, and her three young children. To date, the Zairian Security Service has refused to disclose their whereabouts. The arrest is believed to be in connection with articles written by Mr. Lapong that were published in the independent newspaper "La Tempete de Tropics".

As a nonpartisan group of journalists committed to the defense of its colleagues' rights worldwide, CPJ is deeply disturbed by the unlawful arrests of Mrs. Biongo and her three children. We regard these arrests as intended to intimidate and silence Mr. Lapong and we condemn the use of innocent persons and the unlawful means to this end.

We respectfully remind your Excellency that Zaire ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, Article 19 of which guarantees the right to "seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kind." These rights are also guaranteed by Article 9 of the African Charter on Human and People's Rights to which, we again respectfully remind Your Excellency, Zaire is a signatory.

CPJ requests that Your Excellency do everything in your power to see that Mrs. Biongo and her three children are immediately and unconditionally released.

Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


17 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 5, 1997


Sudan;
UN Says Zaire Conflict Forces Sudanese Refugees Home


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 934 words


 

Nairobi - Operation Lifeline Sudan (OLS) agencies have this week delivered emergency food and relief supplies to a group of more than 2,000 Sudanese refugees who returned from Zaire in January due to rising conflict.

The returnees have settled in three camps -- Gbuo, Nabanga and Bamani -- southwest of Maridi, Western Equatoria. They were robbed of all their possessions en route to Sudan and some women were reported to have been raped.

They were among some 30,000-40,000 Sudanese who fled to Zaire in 1990-91 to escape escalating fighting in southern Sudan between forces of the Sudan Government and the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA). The Sudanese lived among the Zairois in various parts of north-eastern Zaire, near Isiro. They said they were returning to Sudan due to increasing instability. 

"We decided that we would come back home, even if home was not liberated fully," returnees Umoya Ginana and Arale Semuma told an OLS assessment team. " We are glad to be back home."

The assessment team found that the returnees looked reasonably well- nourished, but were weak and hungry from their journey. They had returned with very little food, mainly cassava and sweet potatoes, most of which had run out.

The coordinated OLS emergency response included a full food ration to last for 26 days, medicines and vaccines, and 675 survival kits containing items such as blankets, jerrycans, cooking pots, mosquito nets, plastic sheeting, fishing equipment, soap and salt.

The food was purchased by the World Food Programme (WFP) from World Vision International (WVI) which had obtained stocks of grain from local farmers through a barter programme. It was transported by WVI truck from Nzara on the Sudan-Zaire border, along with the survival kits provided by WVI.

Medical supplies and vaccines for a measles immunization campaign were provided by Aktion Afrika Hilfe (AAH), Medecins sans Frontieres (MSF)-Belgium, and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). MSF-Belgium, with support from UNICEF, will dig shallow wells to provide immediate supplies until boreholes can be drilled in each camp. OXFAM is providing on-ground coordination for the emergency response, as well as assistance with the transport of food and supplies.

In neighbouring Mundri County, another 22 tonnes of WFP food and 325 WVI survival kits will be delivered for some 8,000 people who were displaced during 1996 by fighting between the SPLA and the Sudanese Army. The people are reported to be in serious condition.

MSF-Belgium will conduct a nutritional survey to determine malnutrition levels, and a further 50 tonnes of WFP food will be delivered in the coming days.

Teams of UN and NGO staff will remain in the area to monitor the situation of the displaced and returnee populations. Sudanese are continuing to return from northeastern Zaire, where an estimated 20,000 Sudanese are believed to be living in the Dungu area.

The newly appointed OLS Coordinator, Mr Carl Tinstman, praised the NGOs and UN staff for their rapid response.

He said: "The returnees and displaced people were clearly in a desperate and vulnerable state. The OLS agencies responded in a well-coordinated and mutually supportive manner within 48 hours of the need being identified. This kind of emergency response is what OLS was created for."

The emergency response is coordinated by the Sudan Relief and Rehabilitation Association (SRRA) in cooperation with UNICEF, WFP and five NGOs operating under OLS -- AAH, Mundri Relief and Development Association (MRDA), MSF-Belgium, OXFAM-UK/I and WVI.

OLS is a consortium of more than 40 UN and non-government agencies providing emergency relief and rehabilitation for war-affected civilians in Sudan. As lead agency for OLS, UNICEF coordinates humanitarian activities, while WFP manages aircraft operations on behalf of the consortium.

OPERATION LIFELINE SUDAN - NEWS RELEASE: Nairobi, 4 February 1997

For more information, contact: Sally Burnheim or Christy Dow Brenda Barton or Communications Section Michele Quintaglie Regional Information Office UNICEF/OLS World Food Programme Tel: 622-403 or 622-410 Tel: 622-594 or 622- 336

Africa News


February 5, 1997


Zaire;
U.S. Media Group Protests Zairean Journalists' Arrests


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

New York - Text of two letters from William A. Orme, Jr., executive director, Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ), to Prime Minister Leon Kengo wa Dondo of Zaire, January 30, 1997

Your Excellency:

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) strongly protests the arrest, on the orders of General Bolozei Ngbudu, of Jean Mbenga Muagianvita, an independent freelance journalist for the private newspapers "La Tempete des Tropiques", "Umoja" and "L'Example". Muagianvita was arrested by soldiers of the Military Action and Intelligence Service (SARM) on January 23, 1997, in connection with a series of articles published in November 1996 about President Mobutu's United States-based political lobbyists. Muagianvita is currently held incommunicado at SARM headquarters at Kitambo in Kinshasa. 

On the day of his arrest, SARM soldiers returned with Muagianvita to his home to search for documents. Seven SARM soldiers raped Muangianvita's 14- year-old daughter in the presence of her father.

As a nonpartisan group of journalists committed to the defense of its colleagues' rights worldwide, CPJ contends that this action against Muangianvita is a blatant violation of his right to hold and express opinions and ideas. CPJ also repudiates the brutal and violent rape of his adolescent daughter by SARM soldiers.

We respectfully remind your Excellency that Zaire ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, Article 19 of which guarantees the right to "seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kind." These rights are also guaranteed by Article 9 of the African Charter on Human and People's Rights to which, we again respectfully remind Your Excellency, Zaire is a signatory.

CPJ requests that Your Excellency do everything in your power to ensure the immediate and unconditional release of Muangianvita and the arrests and convictions of the soldiers who raped his daughter.

Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.

Your Excellency:

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) strongly protests the arrests, during the first week of January 1997, of Mrs. Biongo, the wife of exiled Zairean journalist Benjamin Sham Shamg Lapong, and her three young children. To date, the Zairian Security Service has refused to disclose their whereabouts. The arrest is believed to be in connection with articles written by Mr. Lapong that were published in the independent newspaper "La Tempete de Tropics".

As a nonpartisan group of journalists committed to the defense of its colleagues' rights worldwide, CPJ is deeply disturbed by the unlawful arrests of Mrs. Biongo and her three children. We regard these arrests as intended to intimidate and silence Mr. Lapong and we condemn the use of innocent persons and the unlawful means to this end.

We respectfully remind your Excellency that Zaire ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, Article 19 of which guarantees the right to "seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kind." These rights are also guaranteed by Article 9 of the African Charter on Human and People's Rights to which, we again respectfully remind Your Excellency, Zaire is a signatory.

CPJ requests that Your Excellency do everything in your power to see that Mrs. Biongo and her three children are immediately and unconditionally released.

Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 5, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopian Entrepreneurs Urged To Engage In Coffee Production


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - - The Agricultural Bureau of the Southern Peoples Regional State has called on entrepreneurs to invest their capital on coffee production as coffee yield is high in over nine zones and weredas of the region.

The number of private and collective coffee producers was minimal as compared to the size of land available and the yield, the bureau said adding this was beyond the capabilities of the investors of the region. 

According to the bureau there are not more than 247 industries established in the region to process coffee. it said the involvement of many more investors in coffee production would help the country boost its coffee supply to the world market.

The bureau remind heads of coffee processing associations to repair obsolete coffee pulper and husker machines, saying any entrepreneur must primarily submit the feasibility study of his plan to construct the factory.

Farmers could abandon their traditional way of coffee processing if they are allowed to get loan services and entrepreneurs set up coffee processing industries in the region the bureau said.

Up to 80,000 tonnes of the item including wild coffee is collected annually from 175,000 hectares f land in the region cultivated by farmers and the government.

LANGUAGE: English

20 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 5, 1997


Ethiopia;
Report: 150,000 Birr Paid To Fraud


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - - A total of close to 150,000 birr has been paid in salary to an individual who for the last 25 years worked with various governmental organizations under "false" documents.

According to a bulletin issued monthly by the Federal Civil Service commission, the fraud managed to occupy posts in two organizations without having the required educational background and work experience. 

"The man had been on the payroll of Mito Agricultural Development Enterprise and maintained his job when it (the enterprise) merged with the Ethiopian Children's Amba ( village) in 1987," it said.

The commission, acting on a tip, made investigation into his document which indicated that he had attended secondary education at the present Tana Hayik Secondary School, the Amharic monthly said.

"And the commission discovered that the document was a forged one," it added.

His certificate did not bear the officials seal of the school and the director's signature while half of the grades were written with pen and the remaining with pencil, it said.

The school, where the man claimed to have gone for his secondary education, has reported that it could not establish when and which class he had attended.

"It was impossible to prove the validity of his documents which certify that he worked as a teacher, hostel director, auditor and deputy manager," it pointed out.

There is nothing known as to how the man, 41, was given the employment which, according to the bulletin, has now been invalidated by the Inspection Department of the commission.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

February 5, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopia: Mineral Prospect Accord Signed


BYLINE: Asfaw Gemmeda, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - The Ministry of Mines and Energy of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia and Diadem Resources Ltd. of Canada yesterday signed a prospecting agreement for diamonds, saphires and other minerals in Western Ethiopia.

The agreement was signed by Ato Izaddin Ali, Minister of Mines and Energy, and Mr. Arthur Cresswell AspinwalL Howe, President of the company. The two parties were negotiating for the last few months on the terms and conditions of the agreement, according to a press release issued by the Ministry.

It was noted that the agreement gives Diadem Resources Ltd. exclusive right to prospect for diamond, saphires and other minerals at the Babo Gambel area will be completed in three phases - prospecting, exploration and exploitation - Ato Wakgari, head of the mines and operations department of the Ministry of Mines and Energy informed this reporter.

22 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 5, 1997


Ethiopia;
Authority says Draft Social and Economic Policy in Pipeline


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - - The Social Security Authority says it has prepared a draft proclamation commensurate with the new social and economic policy.

In a report presented yesterday to the House of Peoples' Representative Authority General Manager Fikru Desalegn said the law still in force was issued on the basis of the socio-economic conditions three decades back and reflected gender bias which has resulted in favouritism. Despite minor amendments on the pension bill promulgated in 1961 it still lacks basic reform in content he said and added that the draft proclamation in the pipeline will be referred soon to the management board. 

The authority has paid pension to 427,321 regular pensioners and legal heirs up until last November of whom 209,200 were among the legal heirs including spouses, children, grandchildren and parents, according to the report.

The least monthly pension paid was raised to 50 birr with average rises already given to those who earn upto 105 birr, the general manager said.

The pay-rise has been effected here in the capital beginning last Nov. while in regions the implementation began in December, he added.

Implementation of the pay-rise demands an annual budget allocation amounting to 21,689,146 birr, the authority said.

The authority has been responsible for the administration of the civil fund, one of the three funds established in line with the pension bill and the income generated so far from the funds has reached 1.36 bil. birr, the general manager said.

He said, the authority has paid in pensions 401.56 mil. birr up until Nov. 1989 E.C. and the balance which stood at 957 mil. birr was invested on ventures launched in various sectors.

A study aimed at providing social security services to employees in the private sector has been launched, he said, adding so far only civil servants were benefiting from the service rendered.

The study which was reviewed by the experts will be referred to pertinent bodies and later to the government for decision.

Officials of the authority gave explanations to questions Mps raised during discussions on the report.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 5, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopia Plans To Install 500,000 Telephone Lines


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - The Ethiopian Telecommunications Authority said it has plans to install over half a million telephone lines in border towns and rural localities in the coming three years.

Speaking at a graduation ceremony of junior technicians who had been on training for the past six months here at the authority's training centre, General Manager Mesfin Haile said telephone services will reach border towns and rural areas in line with the plan of action of the authority. 

The trainees, as executives of the development programme to which the authority attaches great significance, should work for the provision of telecommunication services to the farmers.

Complaints voiced over lack of access to the services could be over come through reforms on the out-dated working systems put in place nearly three decades back, the general manager said.

According to the general manager a new working procedure has been worked out following an 18-month study.

24 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 5, 1997


Nigeria;
One Administrator Fired, Another Takes Life Insurance


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Col. Victor Ozodinobi has been removed as military administrator of Nigeria's northern state of Borno, the Presidency announced Wednesday in a statement.

The statement issued by David Attah, chief press secretary to military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha, said Ozodinobi had been replaced by Lt. Col. A. Aniebo. No reason was given for the removal, or the fate of the former administrator.

Ozodinobi was among a set of military administrators sworn in August 1996. He becomes the first state chief executive to be sacked by the three-year-old Abacha regime.

Nigeria, with some 100 million people is a federation of 36 states, six of which were created in October 1996.

In another development, Col. Mohammed Marwa, the administrator of Lagos State has been insured under a 10-million-naira (about 120,000 U.S. dollar) life policy announced Tuesday.

The chairman of the state's insurance company, Olalekan Smith, who presented the administrator with the policy document in his office Tuesday said it became necessary because of the threat on Marwa's life.

The administrator survived a bomb attack, which injured at least two people in his convoy last December. Another bomb exploded near his office at Ikeja two days later.

No one has claimed responsibility for the two blasts and another bomb that injured a score of soldiers in January, also in Lagos.

In his reaction, Marwa said the unprecedented insurance policy was not personal to himself, but the occupant of the office.

Since assuming office in August, Marwa has initiated a number of programmes that have endeared him to the people of Lagos, Nigeria's economic hub.

Notable among these are measures to protect lives and property in the city of six million people, from heavily armed bandits.


LOAD-DATE: February 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 5, 1997


Libya - Sudan;
Sudanese Vice-President in Tripoli


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Sudanese Vice-President Gen. Zoubeir Mohamed Salah on Tuesday evening conferred with the Libyan leader, Col. Moammar Kadhafi in Tripoli, as part of Khartoum's diplomatic offensive in the wake of a worsening military situation in the southern part of the country.

Sudanese government troops and civilian volunteers are currently battling to fight off an offensive by an alliance of exiled Sudanese nationals, who have seized several locations in the Blue Nile province. 

The Libyan News Agency reported Wednesday that Gen. Salah conveyed a message from Sudanese president Omar Hassan Al-Bashir.

JANA said the message dealt with the situation in Sudan, Khartoum's worsening relations with its neighbors and bilateral issues.

Sudan has in recent times repeatedly accused Eritrea, Ethiopia and Uganda of supporting rebels fighting government forces in the country's southern and eastern parts.

Khartoum also accuses Egypt of being involved in an "American-Zionist" conspiracy aimed a overthrowing Gen. al-Bashir's regime by encouraging the secession of southern Sudan.

Egypt and the other neighboring states have denied the allegations, saying the situation in Sudan was basically an internal affair.

Gen. Salah's visit to Libya is part of his country's diplomatic move to secure the support of Arab states in its strained relations with the four neighboring states.

Africa News


February 5, 1997


Kenya;
Kenyan Police Announce Reward For Stolen Dollars


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - Kenyan Police have offered a reward of one million shillings (18,181 U.S. dollars) for information leading to the arrest of thieves who have stolen one million U.S. dollars from a Nairobi airfreight company. 

Police said Tuesday that the dollar bills were stolen by Charles Omondi in January and were circulating nationwide. Omondi presented himself at the strongroom of Kenya Airfreight Handling Limited and took off with the loot to Tanzania. He is reportedly still there.

The director of criminal investigations, Noah Too, warned Kenyans Tuesday against buying dollar bills from local money changers.

He said that the serial numbers of the stolen dollars had been circulated to the International Police Organization and all banks.

27 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 5, 1997


Science and Health;
Sleeping Sickness Re-emerging In Africa


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

ADDIS Ababa, Ethiopia (PANA) - At least a quarter a million Africans are affected by sleeping sickness or trypanosomiasis which is re-emerging as a major health problem on the continent.

The vector-borne disease, transmitted by tsetse fly, is endemic in a wide belt in Africa covering 34 countries across the continent, an international workshop was told here on Tuesday.

The workshop on "integrated rural development through sustainable management of tsetse and trypanosomiasis/mosquito and malaria," has brought together at least 100 participants from Africa, Europe and North America. 

It has been jointly organized by the Nairobi-based International Center of Insect Physiology and Ecology and the Ethiopian Science and Technology Commission, with the support of the European Union.

It is intended to provide public forum for the exchange of current options for "sustainable vector and disease management by both researchers and practitioners."

In a joint paper entitled "Wars and vector-Borne Diseases in Africa," an Ethiopian and an Italian scientist said trypanosomiasis is known to be prevalent in a wide belt covering 37 countries across the continent.

"Sleeping sickness is re-emerging as a major public health concern. At least 250,000 persons in Africa carry the parasite, and in 1994 there were epidemics in Cote d'Ivoire and Togo," they said.

The paper was prepared by Yonas Tegegn and Alessandro Loretti, programme officer and senior technical adviser for Africa, respectively, of the World Health Organization-assisted Pan-African Emergency Training Center in Addis Ababa.

They said most of the 53 African countries, with an estimated total population of 760 million in 1996, are highly susceptible to water-borne diseases.

As a result, the continent has the highest level of the incidence of malaria, with Sub-Sahara Africa accounting for more than 90 percent of all malaria cases in the world.

The scientists said malaria kills about two million people in Africa each year, about half of them children under five years of age.

The two also told the workshop that every year, some 200,000 cases of yellow fever occurred in 33 African countries in Sub-Saharan Africa. They added that Nigeria was the most INL002 from SSS.065 (970205-16:55) QN PANAINL .PANADKR MSG064G/02E PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PAN(2) affected, with an estimated one million cases in the past decade.

In the 1990, yellow fever epidemics have occurred in Kenya, Ghana, Gabon, Liberia and most recently in Benin.

Meanwhile, visceral leishmaniasis, a water-borne disease caused by minute protozoans that invade the tissues, is endemic in the horn of Africa, especially Ethiopia and Sudan.

It is spread by changes in the environment, movement of the population and is also associated with HIV infection.

"Cases of the disease have been reported from Kenya and as far south as Malawi," Yonas and Loretti said in their joint document.

Other victor-borne diseases in Africa, cited by the two scientists, include onchocercosis, dengue, rift valley fever, plague, fever, trachoma and filariasis.


LOAD-DATE: February 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


28 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 5, 1997


Mozambique;
Police Operation Against Stolen Cars Reaches Maputo


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Joint teams of South African and Mozambican policemen seized 40 stolen vehicles in Maputo Tuesday, in a joint nation-wide operation that has just reached the Mozambican capital, Maputo.

The sweeps, which reached Maputo on Tuesday, followed similar police activities in the central cities of Beira, Chimoio and Tete, where irregularities and abuse of power were so evident that local businessmen threatened to close down their companies.

Zimbabwean and Zambian policemen were also involved in the operations in Chimoio and Tete. 

Mozambican policemen in Maputo stopped vehicles Tuesday on OAU Avenue, one of Maputo's main arteries, and plain clothes South African policeman carried out inspections.

A traffic policeman, who declined to give his name, told the Mozambican news agency, AIM, that Mozambican Police were in charge of the operation, which is coordinated from the Maputo City Police Command. The role of the South Africans, he said, was limited to checking whether or not the vehicles were on their list of stolen cars.

The procedures followed by the police teams are not uniform. Some give cleared vehicles a sticker, so that they will not be stopped again. Others do not, even when drivers ask for them.

The privately-owned Maputo newssheet, Mediafax, reported that the operation also began Tuesday in Xai-Xai, capital of the southern province of Gaza. Zambian and Zimbabwean police were also in evidence there.

The provincial police commander, Raimundo Cossa, told Mediafax that he would not allow any police irregularities, and that the Mozambicans would remain in control of the Gaza operation.

He said that a South African policeman had tried to enter the residence of the provincial governor, Eugenio Numaio, but a Mozambican traffic policeman had stopped him. One of the complaints from the central provinces was that the police violated premises without any warrants.

"No-one should enter any citizen's home without a search warrant issued by a judge," he said.

By the end of Tuesday, 20 cars had been seized in Xai-Xai and were in the custody of the provincial police command.

However, Cossa said that some Mozambican car owners were the victims of South African insurance fraud. That is, the South African owners sold the cars, then reported them stolen in order to claim insurance money.


LOAD-DATE: February 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


29 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 5, 1997


Science and Health;
March 24 Designated World Tuberculosis Day


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo (PANA) - The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared March 24 as the date when it will observe the first International Anti-Tuberculosis Day.

Announcing this in Brazzaville last week, the WHO Regional director for Africa, Dr Ebrahim Malick Samba, said the day would be used to sensitize the public about the disease and donors on the need to contribute towards its eradication. 

Samba, who was addressing a news conference in the Congolese capital, said some 7.2 million new TB cases have been registered in Africa over the past five years.

The figure, he said, represented 90 percent of the world's total, estimated at eight million.

What is tragical, Samba added, is the fact that nearly a third or 2.6 million of TB infected people die each year, 2.4 million of them in Africa.

He attributed the upsurge of TB to AIDS, rising poverty and the lack of access by populations to medicines, whose prices have kept on soaring.

As a remedy, the WHO regional office announced that it will uplift its capacity to combat the disease by creating specialized teams of health personnel in 46 African states.


LOAD-DATE: February 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


30 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 5, 1997


Rwanda;
U.N. Agency Investigates Killing Of Four Agents


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

NEW YORK (PANA) - The United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights has begun investigations into the Tuesday killing of four of its field agents in Rwanda, and has asked the country's military to do likewise.

"I strongly condemn this attack," said Jose Ayala-Lasso, the agency's high commissioner, in a statement in New York. 

He said Tuesday that the military should take necessary punitive measures against the killers.

"These deaths demonstrate once again the urgent need to work in order to ensure respect for human rights and to establish in Rwanda a climate of peaceful relations among all communities," he said.

The two international and two local staff were killed in an ambush in their two U.N. vehicles in the Karengera sector of Cyangugu Province.

Ayala-Lasso has ordered the remaining human rights officers working in Cyangugu, Gisenyi and Kibuye provinces to relocate to Kigali. Those in Gitarama, Gikongoro and Butare are to remain at their base stations.

There are 139 human rights officers helping to protect people in Rwanda.


LOAD-DATE: February 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


31 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 5, 1997


Libya;
Libya Warns Of Impending Disaster In Africa


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Visiting Libyan Foreign Minister Omar Al Montaser has warned of a looming continental catastrophe if the prevailing atmosphere of political instability in parts of Africa is not resolved.

"We have to put our heads together (to end the instability)," he said. 

He was Tuesday speaking during a visit to his Nigerian counterpart, Tom Ikimi, ahead of the African foreign ministers' conference to be hosted by Libya later in February.

Montaser said intra-African conflicts needed to be resolved quickly because of "foreign elements" behind them.

Africa must resolve these conflicts, he said, to be able to concentrate on development and the improvement of the living standards of its people.

Nigerian Foreign Ministry officials said Montaser was in the country to confer with officials on the up-coming ministerial conference in Tripoli.

His visit comes in the wake of the public support Libyan leader Mouamar Khadafi has given for Nigeria's candidacy for a permanent seat at the United Nations Security Council.

Khadafi said Africa was being marginalised in spite of its superior numerical strength at the world body.

Montaser said Nigeria and Libya shared historical links and both states needed to continue working together in order to overcome foreign interference in African affairs.


LOAD-DATE: February 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


32 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 6, 1997


Zaire;
UNHCR: About 40,000 Refugees Again On The Move In Zaire


BYLINE: UN High Commission for Refugees


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Geneva - Some 40,000 Rwandan refugees fled encampments in the Shabunda area in eastern Zaire today following reports rebels have taken a nearby town.

"All the refugee sites in Shabunda are empty,"said Dillah Doumaye, UNHCR's deputy representative in Zaire. "The refugees packed their belongings, the plastic sheets they use for shelter and went away. They were prepared to leave and the departure was orderly." 

A small UNHCR plane bringing in blankets and food was surrounded by a group of about 150 people demanding to be flown out. Police twice fired shots in the air to disperse the crowd. The plane took off with all three UNHCR staff members posted in Shabunda on board after distributing the relief supplies, originally destined for the Catholic mission of Shabunda.

Local authorities said the refugees moved out after reports swept Shabunda that Katshunga, a small town located 45 km northeast of Shabunda, had fallen. There has been no independent confirmation of these reports. A UNHCR staff member went by motorcycle to Katshunga on Sunday carrying some relief supplies for a local missionary helping refugees in transit. He met a group of 150 refugees on the road to Shabunda.

The UNHCR plane failed to find a trace of the refugees who had departed and had to return to Kisangani because it was running out of fuel. The plane will overfly the area on Thursday and attempt to locate the refugees, Doumaye said. They were believed to be heading west, possibly toward Kalima and Kindu.

The refugees abandoned Shabunda a day after UNHCR completed the distribution of a four-day food ration of beans, corn meal and corn-soya blend. A food warehouse and a hospital in Shabunda were looted, allegedly by the local people, as the refugees were leaving. About 7,000 Zairians were also reported to have fled Shabunda.

UNHCR has been the only agency operating in Shabunda since other international relief workers withdrew in December in the midst of insecurity and extreme difficulties in bringing in assistance. Relief supplies had to be flown in via a small grass airstrip, put on bicycles, then boats to cross a river and finally onto the backs of refugees for the final journey to the encampments.

UNHCR is also assisting another 40,000 refugees in nearby Amisi and 120,000 in Tingi-Tingi.

The emptying of Shabunda came on the eve of High Commissioner Sadako Ogata's departure on Thursday for the Great Lakes region. She is attempting to find ways of increasing the amount of humanitarian aid into eastern Zaire and ways of assuring the safety and protection of refugees in other areas. She plans to visit refugee sites during her visit to Zaire, the first stop on her 10-day trip to the region.

(ENDS)
