Africa News


February 6, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 94 on the Great Lakes (02/05)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2160 words


 

Nairobi - In a further deterioration of the security situation in Rwanda, four employees of the UN Human Rights Field Operation in Rwanda (HRFOR) human rights observers were shot dead in the southwest Cyangugu prefecture yesterday. A fifth died in hospital later.

The observers - three Rwandans, a Briton and a Cambodian - were travelling in two clearly marked UN vehicles in Karengera commune when ambushed by a large group of unidentified armed men. UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan has expressed shock and dismay over the attack, whose perpetrators are not known.

This is the first time human rights observers have been killed in Rwanda. In an immediate response to the incident, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Jose Ayala Lasso, ordered members of UN observer missions in the western Cyangugu, Gisenyi and Kibuye prefectures to withdraw to Kigali, while observers in the Gitarama, Gikongoro and Butare prefectures were told to remain at base. 

Later, the UN announced that staff members were being temporarily withdrawn to Kigali from the four prefectures of Cyangugu, Ruhengeri, Gisenyi and Kibuye, and strict security measures were being implemented elsewhere in Rwanda.

Ayala Lasso also called on the Rwandan authorities to investigate the murders and punish those responsible. The High Commissioner for Refugees, Sadako Ogata, strongly condemned "the wanton killing" of the human rights workers. UN agencies are meeting in Kigali today to decide what further steps to take. The Rwandan government provided a plane to fly the bodies back to Kigali.

Kibuye, Gisenyi, Ruhengeri and Cyangugu prefectures, which border Zaire, have become increasingly unstable since the mass return of Hutu refugees from Zaire and Tanzania at the end of last year. Large numbers of ex- FAR/Interahamwe are believed to have infiltrated, concealing themselves among the returnees and possibly joining up with other ex-FAR/Interahamwe members hiding out in dense forests along the border.

The four prefectures are well-known hotbeds of Hutu insurgency, with the road running alongside Lake Kivu from Gisenyi to Kibuye said to be particularly dangerous. Following the killing of three Spanish aid workers in the northern Ruhengeri prefecture last month, the Rwandan army beefed up numbers in the area in a sweep against insurgents. Rwandan Interior Minister Alexis Kanyarengwe told Reuters on Monday he feared increased violence in the country after the murder on Sunday of a Canadian Catholic priest in Ruhengeri. His killers have not been identified, although Kanyarengwe pointed the finger at Hutu extremists. The priest, Fr Guy Pinard, was witness to the massacres of 1994.

* Rwandan judicial authorities yesterday handed down the 10th death sentence since it began holding genocide trials last December. The accused, sentenced by a court in Gikongoro, was a member of the extremist Hutu MDR- Power party and said to have committed numerous murders. He did not have a lawyer and refused to enter any plea. The same court sentenced a second defendant to life imprisonment, the first such penalty in the trials, as previous suspects have all received the death sentence. Meanwhile, Radio Rwanda reported yesterday that some genocide suspects in Butare were committing suicide rather than go to trial.

* Rwanda unveiled its new policy on resettlement to the international NGO community last week. The plan is based on group settlements consisting of 100- 200 families. Presenting the policy, Rehabilitation and Social Integration Minister, Patrick Mazimpaka, announced that committees headed by the local bourgmestre would be set up at commune level to oversee implementation and plan site selection. NGOs would be allowed to complete housing rehabilitation work already underway, but future work must conform to the new policy, according to which each family will receive a house with land for farming within two kilometres of the residence. The minister said if national reconciliation were to be achieved, then everyone must be willing to live and work together. With a current population of some eight million, the government saw no other way to alleviate land pressure, he stated.

* Rwandan vice-presidential adviser, Emmanuel Ndahiro, has warned Zaire against bringing in military reinforcements from Chad, Morocco and Togo, saying the war in the east would not come to an end. Kinshasa meanwhile has asked Egypt for "political assistance" to help it overcome the rebellion. According to AFP, the head of the Africa desk in the Egyptian foreign ministry, Marwan Badr, denied there had been a request for military aid. " Egypt wants to maintain balanced policies with countries in the Great Lakes region which respect their territorial integrity," he was quoted as saying. " There has been no military cooperation with Zaire since the 1980s," he added.

Washington has urged other nations to stay out of the fighting in eastern Zaire, saying it had "ample evidence" that foreign troops had entered Zaire. State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns, who would not divulge which countries Washington believed were sending troops into Zaire, said the USA would continue to "discourage actively any outside country or any outside group of foreigners or mercenary groups...from participating, entering into the conflagration in eastern Zaire".

Meanwhile a member of President Mobutu's entourage yesterday in Rabat, Morocco, to discuss military aid, again rejected any notion of negotiations with the rebels. Lubmana Kapasa, who heads the presidential press service, referring to rebel leader Laurent Kabila, said "You don't hold a dialogue with a traitor." "War remains the only solution to ending the rebellion and the position of the Zairean government has not changed one iota on this subject." He also lashed out at the international community which "up to now has not reacted appropriately" to the region's problems.

Zairean Foreign Minister Gerard Kamanda wa Kamanda returned to his country last night following an 11-day visit to the USA and Europe, intended to brief foreign governments on the current situation. In comments broadcast by Zairean radio after his arrival, he said Zaire must continue with efforts to make its "just cause" understood. "Unfortunately, we must admit that there is a lack of information, which has to be addressed," he said. He added that Zaire was awaiting Sadako Ogata's visit from 6-8 February during which the humanitarian situation in eastern Zaire would be addressed.

As the Zairean authorities admitted Kalemie port had fallen to the rebels, ADFL leader Laurent Kabila today claimed his forces were making progress on all fronts. Speaking in Goma, he said rebel troops were continuing their advance in the mineral-rich province of Shaba and were about 40 km from the Lake Tanganyika town of Moba. According to Reuters, Zaire's defence ministry acknowledged the port area of Kalemie had been taken, but fighting was underway elsewhere in the town. "They have now taken the port but our soldiers are still fighting in other parts of the town," a senior ministry official said yesterday. Reliable sources concurred with claims by Kabila that on the western front, his forces were 30km from Shabunda and advancing rapidly, while also making significant progress in the direction of Lubutu. Kabila also claimed that Isiro in the northeast would be captured in a " matter of hours". The rebels have given the Kinshasa authorities until February 21 to start negotiations or face a "widespread offensive", AFP reported.

* UNICEF said hundreds of new arrivals were reported daily in Punia, 140km southwest of Lubutu where there were currently some 2,200 refugees. Some 9, 000 refugees were en route from Kibereketa (90km east of Punia) to Kasese and onward to Punia. According to the Zairean authorities, another 11,000 refugees had passed through Punia on the way to Yumbi where 3,000 of them were now blocked at the River Lowa as no fuel was available for the ferry crossing. UNICEF said it believed the figures to be correct. UNICEF and Caritas Dioceses have set up a supplementary feeding centre in Punia which is supplied by air.

* Burundi today denied sending troops into neighbouring Zaire to back the rebels. "Burundi has never sent troops into any neighbouring countries," Foreign Minister Luc Rukingama told a press conference in Brussels. "In fact we need them to deal with our own internal situation." Zaire has alleged that Burundi, along with Uganda and Rwanda, are sending troops to fight alongside the rebels.

Burundi's Justice Minister Gervais Rubashamuheto has given details of the cases being prepared against 80 people suspected of plotting to overthrow the government in October 1993, when the-then Hutu president Melchior Ndadaye was killed. Speaking on Radio Burundi, the minister said arrest warrants would be issued next week and the suspects would appear in court in March. Last November, Burundi called for the establishment of an international tribunal to punish genocide crimes regarding the massacres that ensued after Ndadaye's death. The move was also recommended by the UN special rapporteur on human rights, Paulo Sergio Pinheiro. A UN commission of enquiry into Ndadaye's assassination concluded last July that the murder was planned in advance and executed by "officers highly placed in the line of command of the Burundian army". The massacres constituted "acts of genocide against the Tutsi minority" , the UN report said.

* Germany yesterday handed over 120,000 US dollars towards logistical support for the mission of the newly-appointed UN/OAU special envoy for the Great Lakes. Germany's UN mission said in a statement that $67,000 was earmarked for an aircraft to be used by the envoy, Mohamed Sahnoun, who is due to leave New York later this week. The rest will be used for telecommunications and equipment required by the mission which will be based in Nairobi.

* Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni is to discuss the Great Lakes crisis with former US president Jimmy Carter on Sunday. The meeting falls within a week-long visit to the USA by Museveni during which he will meet UN and US officials in New York and Washington, the Carter Centre announced. The Centre has been helping facilitate dialogue between leaders of the Great Lakes countries.

In the troubled north of Uganda, anti-government rebels ambushed and killed a police chief, the state-owned New Vision reported yesterday. It said the district police commander of Kitgum, Asafu Retesia, was the second district police chief to be murdered in two years. The rebels belonging to the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) later set his car on fire. Police said they could not establish the cause of death, the paper added.

Nairobi, 5 February 1997, 15:00 gmt (ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. 34 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 6, 1997


Kenya;
Drought Fuels Inflation In Kenya


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - Kenya's central bank says the overall rate of inflation in the country rose from 10.8 percent in December 1996 to 10.9 percent in January.

Average annual and the three-month annualized inflation increased marginally to 9.2 percent and 9.4 percent from 9.1 percent and 4.6 percent, respectively, during the same period, the bank says in its monthly economic review. 

The increase in inflation is attributed to non-policy factors, especially the decrease in the supply of basic foods following the prevailing dry weather in January and the increased in crude oil prices.

However, the underlying month-on-month rate of inflation declined to 9.7 percent in January from 11.1 percent in December 1996. "The underlying three- month annualized rate of inflation fell to 8.6 percent from 11.9 percent during the same period," the bank says.

It adds that the month-on-month inflation rate is expected to decline to 7. 0 percent by April. But, this requires that the expansion in money supply be constrained to an annual rate of not more than 16 percent.

To enhance the effectiveness of monetary restraint, the bank says, concerted effort is required to ensure that the government's budget deficit is reduced from the current level of 2 percent of GDP to a surplus by end of fiscal year 1996/97 as projected.

Government overdraft decreased by 15.64 billion shillings (1 U.S. dollar = 55 sh.) to 29.99 billion shillings mainly due to improved revenue collection by the Kenya Revenue Authority and tighter controls on government spending.

Currency in circulation increased by 2.3 billion shillings to 3.6 billion shillings, due to increased inflows of foreign exchange.


LOAD-DATE: February 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

35 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 6, 1997


Ethiopia;
Ethiopia's Food Reserve Increases Nine Fold


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Ethiopia's food security reserve has increased by at least nine fold, in four years, to 283,000 tons now, it was announced Thursday.

This reserve is enough to feed four million people for six months by providing them 600 grams of food each in emergencies, the country's Emergency Food Security Reserve Administration said. 

The agency plans to raise the reserve by stockpiling 307,000 tons as stipulated by its three-year mid-term objective. Ethiopia, which over the last two decades depended on foreign food aid due to recurrent drought and civil war that ended five years ago, has made self-sufficiency in food one of its main objectives.

As a result, the country has been able to raise its food security reserve during the last two years by drawing from the surplus production in the agricultural sector.

The agency has, over this period, loaned 110,000 tons of food to non- governmental donor organizations in Ethiopia for various development projects in rural parts of the country under the "food for work scheme."

The NGOs are presently purchasing grain from local markets to reimburse the agency.

Ethiopia is expecting a bumper crop of about 12 million tons of food grain from the 1996-97 harvest.


LOAD-DATE: February 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

36 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 6, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
World Bank President To Visit Africa


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

NEW YORK, (PANA) - World Bank President James Wolfensohn is scheduled to begin a nine-day trip to Africa on Saturday to demonstrate the bank's support for the continent's social and economic development.

"Africa is the World Bank's top priority and we want to strengthen our partnerships with the region," he said. 

At a news conference in Washington DC, he said Wednesday that he would visit Ghana, Mozambique, Senegal and South Africa to review Bank funded projects and meet government and community leaders.

"I will go and see for myself what is happening and discuss how to sustain and build on the gains resulting from improved policies," he said.

The bank's special representative to the United Nations, Alfredo Sfeir- Younis, said in New York that part of the reasons Wolfensohn chose to visit the four countries was that they were "doing very well."

Sfeir-Younis told reporters: "We want to confirm and re-affirm our commitment to them."

The bank says Africa's economic performance has improved considerably, with about 24 countries posting growth of at least 4 percent -- above the rate of population growth.

The bank says success has had a positive impact on growth and exports, improved income for millions of smallholder farmers and given grounds for optimism about the continent.

Wolfensohn said he had "very important policies" to be discussed with ranking officials., some of which had to do with deepening the macro-economic adjustment.

"Since my last trip I have been getting good news out of Africa," he said.

Wolfensohn will be accompanied on the trip by his wife, Elaine, and the bank's vice presidents for Africa, Callisto Madavo and Jean-Louis Sarbib.


LOAD-DATE: February 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

37 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 6, 1997


Libya;
Libya Supports Creation Of African Intervention Force


BYLINE: Frank Kilimba, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania (PANA) - Libya supports the creation of an African intervention force but it must comprise entirely of African troops, that country's foreign minister has said.

"The idea put forward by the U.S.A. is good. Our main concern is that the force should be controlled by the Organization of African Unity not otherwise, " Omar Al-Montaser said.

Reporting this Thursday, the Tanzanian news agency, Shihata, said Montaser was speaking to reporters on arrival on his day- long visit to Dar Es Salaam. The agency did not say he arrived.

During his first visit to Africa in 1996, former United States Secretary of State Warren Christopher proposed creating the force to intervene in African crises.

However, at the time, the proposal received mixed reactions from African states. Some leaders feared a strong Western influence, or control, on such a force since the U.S. and its allies had pledged to fund the body.

South African President Nelson Mandela said the formation of the force should be initiated by O.A.U. member states.

Montaser said African countries had every reason to take resolute steps to stop crises on the continent, such as the one in the Great Lakes region. He said Africans from immediately outside that conflict region were also concerned with its stability.

Montaser is in Tanzanian to brief his counterpart, Jakaya Kikwete, on Libya's preparations to host the O.A.U.'s ministerial meeting later in February. Montaser was in Nigeria Tuesday for the same reason.


LOAD-DATE: February 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

38 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 6, 1997


Burundi;
Burundian Opposition Requests For UN Troops


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania (PANA) - The Burundi Democratic Front (FRODEBU), the former ruling party in that strife-torn country, on Thursday requested for United Nations troops to restrain the military government in Bujumbura from further harassment of the masses.

The FRODEBU chairman, Sawanya Jean Minani, told a news conference in Dar es Salaam Thursday that the military government of Maj. Pierre Buyoya was intimidating the innocent majority Hutu people in Burundi.

The front, under the leadership of the late President Melchior Ndadaye, swept the polls in Burundi's multiparty elections of June 1993. 

Buyoya, who sprang back to power in a July 25, 1996 coup d'etat, belongs to the minority Tutsi ethnic group which is dominant in national army, now reported to be marauding around the country looking for the Hutus.

Soon after taking over power, Buyoya banned all political parties, including FRODEBU. Some of these have been fighting against the military government which is also faced with sub-regional economic sanctions aimed at forcing a return to democratic rule.

The Tanzanian News Agency quoted Minani as telling journalists in Tanzania's business capital that the military regime has been abducting and sending the Hutus to rural areas.

In these ares, he claimed, the government deprives them of of food and water and later sends television crews to film them. The objective of this, he said, was to show that it was the masses who were suffering from the effects of sanctions, imposed by neighboring states in east and central Africa.

Minani said the political problem in Burundi could be solved if UN forces intervened "to save the poor souls in Burundi."

He claimed further that the military regime in Bujumbura has expelled all Hutu students from the University of Burundi.

Minani said the only remaining undergraduates are Tutsi, who besides participating in regular courses, were undergoing military training "for the coming war against the insurgent Hutus."

The exiled Burundian politician appealed to countries in the Great Lakes region to strictly abide by the sanctions imposed against Buyoya's regime.

The Burundi military government has been trying to hold dialogue with some of the internally-based opposition members. However, it has rejected calls to negotiate with rebels who have taken arms to fight the central government.

These include the National Committee for the Defence of Democracy (CNDD) of former Ndadaye's interior minister, Leonard Nyangoma.


LOAD-DATE: February 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

39 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 6, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Europeans Vie For Coaching Job In Nigeria


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - A Hungarian coach, Kalman Meszoly, one of the three Europeans eyeing the post of technical adviser for Nigeria's national team, the Super Eagles, says he is hopeful of snatching job from a host of other European peers.

"We had a very pleasant interview and certainly I am hoping that the NFA (Nigerian Football Association) will choose me...," Meszoly said after facing the soccer body's interview panel on Wednesday.

But the Hungarian has to wait until after Feb. 11 the next interview date set for two other contenders short listed for the job, Frenchmen Phillipe Troussier and Claude le Roy. 

Patrick Ekeji, one of the NFA panelists said Thursday both Frenchmen had asked for postponements because of club assignments.

However, another NFA source told PANA in Lagos there were indications Troussier might have withdrawn his candidacy after his club, F.U.S. Rabat declined his application for leave to travel to Nigeria for the interview.

If this is confirmed, the contest could be left to Meszoly and le Roy, who are no strangers to African soccer.

The battle for the post of Eagles' foreign technical adviser, ignited since the abrupt departure of a Dutch coach, Johannes Bonfrere in Sept. 1996, came to a head last week when the Eagles' chief local coach, Shuaibu Amodu, was sacked for breach of contract.

After Amodu's replacement with Monday Sinclair, Nigerian sports minister Jim Nwobodo insisted the country needed a foreign technical adviser to take the country to the World Cup in France next year.

Bonfrere, claiming mistreatment by some sports officials, ditched Nigeria for the oil-rich emirate of Qatar after taking the West African country's under-23 squad to win the Olympic gold in August 1996.

His predecessor and compatriot, Clemens Westerhof, also left Nigeria in a similar fashion after taking Nigeria to its first World Cup in the United States in 1994.

Soccer buffs in Lagos say the problem with Nigerian football, has always been administration and not a lack of talented players.

Nigeria, which supplied four of the African all-stars that beat their European peers 2-1 in an anti-racism solidarity match in Lisbon last week, has a score of players pursing professional career across the globe.

Africa News


February 7, 1997


Ethiopia;
Workers demand re-establishment of CETU


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

Nazareth (ENA) - The Wonji-shoa plantation workers demanded the immediate re-establishment of the confederation of Ethiopian trade unions. 

The Wonji-Shoa basic trade union whose membership numbers 7,000 said the setting -up of the confederation is crucial for the respect of the rights of the workers.

Ato Argaw Denbere, head of the union organisation and follow-up department of the agro-industry federation told a meeting of the basic trade union that eight of the nine federations have agreed to set up the confederation.

The Wonji-Shoa plantation trade union is one of the 91 basic trade unions under the agro-industrial federation.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 7, 1997


Science and Health;
Ethiopia: Number Of Leprosy Patients Decreases


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 134 words


 

Ziway (ENA) - the number of leprosy patients in East Shoa and three woredas of Gurage Zone was reported to have decreased considerably. 

About 140 of the 193 patients in Adami Tulu, Jedo, Dugeda, Mesekane and Mareko woredas were completely cured of the disease following medical treatment at clinics and health stations in their respective localities in the past two years.

Ato Masresha Tell representative of the leprosy prevention and educational centre said follow-up treatment is being given for the rest of the patients.

The ex-patients are currently engaged in farm activities, it was noted.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


42 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 7, 1997


Ethiopia;
Bureau Reports Better Harvest Of Oil Seeds


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Baher Dar (ENA) - Over a quarter million quintals of oil seeds were produced this year when compared to that of last year in the Amhara Regional State, the agricultural bureau of the region reported.

The extension department of the bureau said over 1.25 million quintals of various oil seeds were produced from 271,000 hectares of land in the region. 

Ato Amlaku Asres, head of the department, said the increase in the number of investors and size of land cultivated to the seeds are the main factors for the bumper harvest.

The bulk of the niger seed, sesame, linseed and rape seed were harvested in North Gonad Zone, the head added.

The market price of a litre of edible oil has now dropped, according to consumers.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


43 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 7, 1997


Ethiopia;
Emergency Food Security Reserve Grows By Nine-Fold


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - Ethiopia's food security reserve has grown by nine-fold in the past four years, the Emergency Food Security Reserve Administration (EFSRA) announced here yesterday.

The emergency food reserve has this year reached 283,000 metric tonnes against 30,000 in 1985 E,C., according to administration manager Samuel Tumoro. 

The administration, he said, could in case of emergency feed four million people for six months by providing each 600 grams of food daily.

He ascribed the increase in food reserve to assistance donors extended to promote the objective of the administration and annual budget allocation by the government for the purchase of 5,000 metric tonnes of food.

Non-governmental donor organisations are presently purchasing grain from local markets to reimburse the 110,000 metric tonnes of food they took on loan basis from the EFSRA to expedite development projects in progress in various localities, Ato Samuel said.

The administration which used to depend on foreign food aid has over the past tow years raised its food security reserve drawing from the surplus product in the agricultural sector, he added.

Purchasing grain from farmers to boost food security reserve drawing from the surplus product in the agricultural sector, he added.

Purchasing grain from farmers to boost food security reserve will have a positive effect in warding off price fall due to surplus production besides encouraging productivity.

The administration, he said, is conducting a study to construct additional warehouses in Gondar, Bedele and Sodo towns and their environs with a view to implement its medium-term objective, stock-piling of 307,000 metric tonnes.

The construction of 26 stores in Dire Dawa, Kombolcha and Makalle at a cost of over 61 million birr has been completed, the manager said.

The country expects to harvest over 117 quintals of crop this year.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


44 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 7, 1997


Ethiopia;
Harari Council Endorses Regulation


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Harar (ENA) - The 4th regular conference of the Harari Regional Council wound up here Tuesday by approving the amended draft regulation on bureau restructuring.

According to the regulation, the 21 bureaux in the region will be folded to 12 embracing 35 departments. 

The conference has also agreed that the regional council would comprise justice, police and control sections as well as town and economic administrations and social sectors.

In a statement they issued at the end of the conference, the participants decided that following deliberations with representatives of the council on the appraisal the regional executive committee has conducted a proposal be forwarded at an extra-ordinary meeting to be called within a month.

They said the execution of development projects in the region during the past six months was minimal, calling on concerned bodies to exert efface toward implementing the projects according to schedule.

The participants also decided that the agreement concluded with the ministry of defence that the buildings and sites which served as military camps during the former regime be used for development undertakings.

They also decided that endeavours must be exerted to improve the justice administration in regional courts and alleviate shortage of judges and that concerned bodies must closely follow up the prompt trial of embezzlers.

The four-day conference assessed performance reports presented by the executive committee of the regional council and other offices.

The participants expressed satisfaction over the activities under taken by the agricultural, education and health bureaux, urging other bureaux to overcome their problems and mobilise the public to carry out development activities.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

45 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 7, 1997


Ethiopia;
Meles Stresses Ethio-French Cooperation in Trade & Investment


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - Prime Minister Meles Zenawi has expressed Ethiopia's strong desire to further strengthen Ethio-French economic cooperation in the areas of trade and investment in particular.

He made the announcement yesterday during talks with Mr. Charasse, Chairman of the Co-operation Committee of the French Senate. 

Prime Minister Meles expressed his conviction that the existing economic ties between the two countries would continue to blossom in the future.

Mr. Charasse on his part assured the Prime Minister that his country would endeavour to promote its participation in the areas of trade and investment.

France is ready to assist the railway transport sector as well as water development projects and share its experience in the legal affairs, he said.

The chairman said preparations are being made to hold the joint commission meeting of the two countries in May this year in Addis Ababa.

A trade fair which would be participated by some fifty companies would also be staged here in the capital in the coming May according to Mr. Charasse.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


46 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 7, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 96 on the Great Lakes (02/07)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1294 words


 

Nairobi - A WFP spokesperson said that their UN compound in Lubutu, Zaire has been surrounded by Zairean soldiers (FAZ). Six Zairean staff members remain in the compound and are being denied permission to leave and one staff member was reportedly beaten by soldiers. The spokesperson said that WFP understands that the situation in Lubutu was delicate "but hoped the situation would be resolved quickly and be sympathic to the fact these people are aid workers." The FAZ has reportedly confiscated radio equipment.

Following the mass exodus of refugees and humanitarian staff from Shabunda, a joint UNHCR, UNICEF, WFP, and Federation mission visited the governor of Maniema to discuss the situation and receive authorization to do overflights to locate the fleeing Shabunda refugees. Flying over the area en route to Kindu, small population movements were sighted near Matili located en route to Kalima. The governor authorized more surveillance flights for today. 

No NGOs were able to get to Amisi yesterday and some were turned back en route to Tingi-Tingi by Zairean army soldiers (FAZ), who claimed that the FAZ was engaging ADFL rebels near Lubutu. A decision was taken to reduce the presence of humanitarian workers at Tingi-Tingi. A further withdrawal of remaining expatriate and national workers is in progress today. In the event that the refugees become trapped in rebel held territory, the UN Humanitarian Coordinator for the Great Lakes Region, Martin Griffiths, has initiated discussions with concerned agencies and authorities on contingency planning for a movement of refugees from the areas of Tingi-Tingi and Amisi through rebel-controlled areas to Rwanda, should the opportunity arise.

Sources on the ground reported that at least some of the local population of Shabunda welcomed the ADFL rebels as a "liberating" force. However, other sources reported civilians fleeing. The rebels reportedly left a small military presence in Shabunda before moving on. According to sources in Punia this morning, the town had not yet fallen to ADFL rebels. In Lubutu, military sources indicated that two military helicopters had delivered 76 wounded FAZ soldiers to the local hospital yesterday. Sources on the ground report an increase in the incidence of vehicles being "borrowed" by the FAZ to evacuate their families. Unconfirmed reports indicate that the elements of the refugee population are being armed by the FAZ to fight the rebels. Moreover, with the retreat of FAZ forces, humanitarian sources also noted a resurgence of the anti-UNHCR sentiment among former DSP/Contingent soldiers, who had been previously employed by the UN to provide security for the refugee camps in the Kivu regions. UN High Commissioner for Refugees, Sadako Ogata, arrives in Kinshasa today, and discussions on outstanding issues regarding the Contingent were already planned with the Zairean authorities.

Zaire began reinforcing troops and equipment on two fronts, near Kisangani and Kalemie, on Wednesday to block ADFL advances, a senior defence ministry official told Reuters. The mercenaries fighting with the FAZ remain deployed further north at the Watsa airport, although the town itself had fallen to ADFL rebels late last week. A director of the Sizarail company told Reuters at its headquarters in Kinshasa that trains were getting no further than Nyunzu, 150 km west of Kalemie and east of the Kabolo T-junction on the Lubumbashi-Kindu line. Sources from the area believe that the ADFL may find reinforcement or encouragement among a local Banyarwanda ethnic group, the Batabwa, settled south of Kalemie, who have historic links to the Banyamulenge.

According to local sources, both Lubumbashi and Kinshasa remain calm despite the significant rebel advances. Reuters reported that the recruitment campaign to enlist 26,000 teenage soldiers got off to a slow start in Kinshasa. Mobutu, who spent Tuesday and Wednesday in Morocco, is reported to be on his way back to Zaire.

Radio 'Voix du Zaire' in Kinshasa announced that Gerard Kamanda wa Kamanda, the deputy prime minister in charge of foreign affairs, this morning received the Angolan ambassador to Gabon, Bernardo Dombele M'Bala, who bore a message of friendship from his foreign minister to his Zairean counterpart. The Angolan government reportedly expressed solidarity with the Zairean people who are facing foreign interference in Zaire's internal affairs.

* ADFL leader Laurent Kabila continued to call for a negotiated solution to the conflict. According to the Kinshasa opposition daily 'Le Potentiel', Kabila has proposed former and fellow Lumumbist Antoine Gizengo as interim- president, opposition leader Etienne Tshisikedi as interim prime minister and himself as vice-prime minister and minister of defence. Both Gizengo and Tshiskedi, whose political roots date to the 1960 independence, are members of the opposition forces in Kinshasa and have advocated for a negotiated solution. Zaire has repeatedly dismissed Kabila's offer to negotiate, saying Zaire does not negotiate with "puppets".

* Radio 'Voice of Israel' in Jerusalem reported that Israel is freezing its defence ties with Zaire in view of the difficult domestic situation in that country. This clarification was made after a senior official at the Kinshasa Defence Ministry said that China and Israel would assist Zaire in setting up and training new commando units to fight rebels in eastern Zaire. Isreal initially trained Mobutu's elite presidential guard (DSP).

* US Secretary of State Madeline Albright urged neighbouring countries, Rwanda, Uganda and Burundi, to stay out of the escalating conflict. A senior US official said: "President Museveni's position yesterday was that, well, there were just some border clashes because actually there were insurgents on the Zairean part of the border attacking Uganda and therefore Uganda had to respond -- it's kind of a hot pursuit issue," said Reuters.

* Humanitarian sources reported three attacks on agency compounds situated in Kigali, Rwanda on Tuesday night. Two guards were beaten in one attack, but no other injuries were reported. ICRC Nairobi confirmed that it is freezing its operations in Rwanda, for ten days as of yesterday. Some non-essential staff will be put on stand-by on Nairobi while others will remain in Rwanda. ICRC, until this decision, had around 120 expatriate staff in Rwanda, its largest programme in Africa. It will continue to evaluate the security situation.

Nairobi, 7 February 1997, 12:30 gmt (ENDS)

Ethiopia;
Ethiopian Diplomats and Exporters Pledge to Work Together


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

Addis Ababa - A half-day meeting of exporters and Ethiopian diplomats stationed abroad, took place at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Monday 3 February.

Addressing the meeting, Foreign Affairs Minister indicated that it was the duty of every Ethiopian diplomat to cooperate with their compatriot business people by giving information, and assessing the potential market for Ethiopian goods.

One diplomat on his part was quoted by government daily Ethiopian Herald as saying, "We most of the time send business information to the Ethiopian Chamber of Commerce which in turn should transmit it to businessmen; but from what we hear now, the Chamber has not done that effectively."

Ethiopia;
New Private Hospital Opens In Addis


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

Addis Ababa - A private hospital capable of handling daily three hundred patients was inaugurated in Addis Ababa Saturday 31 January by general manager of Ethiopian Investment Office, Ato Taddese Haile. 

According to government papers, the Tibebu General Hospital was built at a total cost of thirteen million birr -- with 4.7 million birr loan from the Construction and Business Bank. Tibebu General Hospital, owned and managed by Balambaras Tibebu Kebede, is said to have the latest equipment on hand. According to the owner the only problem the hospital is facing is lack of space.

Tibebu General Hospital has on its staff, nine doctors, and thirteen visiting specialists.

Africa News


February 7, 1997


Business and Finance;
OmniTech Exhibits Software Packages


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Addis Ababa - OmniTech Plc, the company founded in 1994 to engage in information technology system design and programme development is holding an exhibition today, Friday, 7 February between 12:00 and 6:00pm in the Chamber of Commerce Hall, to demonstrate eight software packages produced by the company.

It is hoped that the exhibition will encourage clients to invest in domestically produced software, with the benefits of convenient servicing and maintenance when experiencing problems. Said a spokesman for the company: it is an opportunity to prove that "our country is rich in having qualified experts in the field." The aims of the exhibition are to raise public awareness and to help reverse the current "trend of improper utilisation of computers" in Ethiopia. He went on to say:" we are the only company that produce software as a company," which makes this exhibition something of a novelty. 

The exhibition, to be opened by the Deputy Commissioner of the Ethiopian Science and Technology Commission, His Excellency Ato Asrat Bulbula, includes advanced packages developed for both specialised and general use. Packages such as the Legal Cases Information System tailor-made for the Federal High Court this year and Omni Truckers made for Alpha Truckers Association are displayed alongside Omni Ethiopia, an MS Windows programme with Ethiopic keyboard and fonts interface, so demonstrating the broad range of OmniTech's production.

This creative exhibition is in keeping with the company's innovative founder and General Manager Ato Daniel Admasse, the Ethiopian to design the first Amharic word-processor. In a recent press release, the Manager remarked that the occasion is "important both in creating awareness among the public and in paving the path for the expansion of the technology in the country." If all goes well, today's exhibition could see the start of some extremely exciting and fast-developing technological advances for 1997.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


50 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 7, 1997


Ethiopia;
Omo Reserve Under Siege (Editorial)


BYLINE: Tamrat Bekele, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Addis Ababa - We read with sadness and concern that Omo Reserve, Mago National Park, is losing its rare and beautiful wild animals to poachers. According to the park manager, the poachers are well-equipped with automatic rifles but the park's security men have neither the manpower nor the ammunition to stop these illegal hunters from destroying our national, natural treasures and environment.

The poachers, said to be from the areas adjacent to the park, are trading their 'loot' with neighbouring countries in return for arms. A meeting recently took place between park officials and local residents. It was agreed that no-one was to enter the park armed, but how is this to be enforced when there are only fifteen game-keepers responsible for patrolling the 200,000 square kilometers of national park? 

The game-keepers are simply unable to cope with their burden which has been made tragically clear in the figures: zebras have now been totally wiped-out from the park; elephants which were on the increase are now also fast disappearing; buffaloes are coming close to joining their fellow zebras in their plight. Add to this the failure to replace guards as they retire and we see that they, like the wildlife they are there to protect, are in imminent danger of dying out. Mago Park will soon be left to the free destruction of its murderers.

Lack of funds cannot even be held responsible for the degeneration in the park's upkeep, for an entrance charge has been in operation for the last three years. In the final quarter of 1996, this alone, generated 51,000 Birr. The ultimate irony is that the number of tourists visiting the reserve has increased three-fold in the last year but if present trends continue, then soon there will be no wild animals for visitors to see at Omo Reserve.

The chairman of the South Omo Woreda board has urged for more short-term training for game-keepers and wants to see them better equipped and with updated weapons. To respond with a defensive front of aggression would be to reduce ourselves to the level of the attackers with the possibility of killing even more animals in the event of a 'cops and robbers' shoot-out. This rather transgresses from the idea of the park as place of calm, a sanctuary for nature.

If the arguments must rage, then keep them outside the park; within its borders, energy must be devoted to preservation, not annihilation. Solutions must be tough but conciliatory. Let's see the Park working with the local community, not in antagonistically to it, promoting mutual understanding and co-operation.

Perhaps it is time that the 'recent meeting' between Park and residents became a regular occurrence with a locally-elected spokesperson for the community in continual collaboration with park officials. There is a desperate necessity for more game-keepers and who better than local inhabitants, who will have a superior knowledge of and relationship to their home environment?

We must address this issue immediately, looking to the root of the problem - the need for aggressors to poach at all. We should be looking at broader problems- if there was less regional conflict, would there be such a demand for weapons and the killing of so much wildlife?

Ultimately, this problem can only be solved in the immediate future, at local level, but the difficulties facing Mago Park differ little from those in our other national parks. The solutions, whatever they may be, must be implemented on a national scale. We must launch a national campaign, if necessary calling on the international community to keep Ethiopia the Eden that it is, for wildlife.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


51 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 7, 1997


Ethiopia;
Mago National Park in Deplorable State


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Addis Ababa - The future of wildlife in the Mago National Park in northern Omo is looking bleak. According to a report in the Addis Zemen, Amharic government daily, their number is decreasing rapidly, and the zebra in the park have completely died out. 

The park's head, Ato Bereket Nareab, said those people in the surrounding areas were coming in with modern automatic weapons, killing the animals and selling them to neighbouring countries. Apparently, the park's fifteen game keepers are no match to hunters who get weapons from neighbouring countries in exchange for their kill. Earlier, when the number of elephants was noticeably increasing, hunters came and killed off 11, Ato Bereket said. However, he also mentioned that at a recent meeting with the local people, it was agreed that no one may enter the park's ground armed.

It is a shame that regions are not giving as much attention to wildlife conservation, as they are to talking about the 'unequalled natural beauty of Ethiopia'. There is no doubt that with proper care, the country's national parks could be a major earner of much needed hard currency. The Mago National Park began charging visitors some three years. In the first quarter of the present Ethiopian year, Mago earned 51 thousand birr from the tourists. Ethiopia may have untapped natural resources, but if responsible bodies are not assigned to take care of them, then we are likely to lose the only thing we can honestly boast about.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February 7, 1997


Ethiopia;
Mourners Turn Out for Crown Prince Funeral


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

Addis Ababa - Crown Prince Merid Azmach Asfawossen, 80, was buried at the Trinity Cathedral Sunday in the presence of royal family members, followers of the Ras Teferian community, and a multitude of common Ethiopians. 

The late crown prince, who died in a Virginia hospital, USA, 17 January, had lived in exile ever since the 1974 revolution disposed of his father, Emperor Haile Sellassie. The former, also known as Emperor Amaha Sellassie, is survived by his wife Princess Medferiashwork Abebe and their four sons.

Ethiopia's last serving monarch, Emperor Haile Sellassie was murdered under mysterious circumstances soon after the revolution--but he has not yet been buried.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


53 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 7, 1997


Ethiopia;
The Funeral of Crown Prince Assfaw Wossen (A Personal Impression)


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1654 words


 

Addis Ababa - Some nostalgic devotees of the crown have feared that the funeral of ex-Crown Prince Assfaw Wossen, which was conducted on February 2, 1997 at the Trinity Cathedral here in Addis Ababa, might indeed turn out to be a non-event as officialdom would have liked it to be.

This was probably one reason why so many veterans of the legendary former Imperial Guard had not put on their imposing uniforms. The few who did had a field day, capturing the limelight as the gathered mourners fixed their gaze on them with apparent admiration and nostalgia. As if to rise equal to the occasion, the gallant men in uniform tried, with their imperious postures and gestures, to recreate the aura of royal glory of yore which they once so assiduously helped to produce. 

It was apparent that most people including myself, who came to the funeral, did not know the exact time at which the rites were to be performed. This was probably why at least one wedding ceremony was conducted at the church a little before 10 a.m. In any case, the merry-making of the wedding mocked the somber mood of those who gathered for the last rites of the man who might have been Emperor of Ethiopia but for the ironies of life. A man driving one of the cars in the wedding motorcade added insult to injury when he defiantly honked his way out in celebration! It might have been his way of paying tribute to life in the face of death, or perhaps he didn't know a damn thing about why all those people had gathered!

Hundreds of mourners had already assembled in the compound of the Trinity Cathedral by 10 a.m. Thousands more flocked to the church later, so much so that the entire church compound was almost filled to overflowing by around 1 p.m. Repeated pleas were made through the public address system for the congregated mourners to make way for the funeral procession which was by then said to be approaching the vicinity of the Trinity Cathedral. Scores of cars carrying mourners moved into the church compound, making the space problem even more acute.

Soon the Patriarch of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church, His Holiness Abune Paulos, arrived in a four-wheel-drive automobile led by a police car and followed by at least two vehicles in which bishops could be seen. One bishop arrived alone in a car from which he alighted and wove his way through the crowd towards the main entrance to the church.

From then on the level of activity in the church compound picked up dramatically. Cameras flashed and clicked. Video-cameras scanned the ranks of the crowds. Luxury automobiles carrying what looked like members of the royal family and Rastas wearing headdresses decorated with the national tricolor came in quick succession. This was a clear sign that the funeral procession was close by.

The first contingent of the procession entered the church compound, carrying photos of the late Crown Prince and, somewhat strangely to the uninitiated, ululating and clapping, but also wailing and weeping and chest- beating. Three to four such contingents passed by before the hearse which carried the coffin of the late Crown Prince, entered the church grounds. The hearse was thickly thronged by weeping mourners.

There was no cannon-toting carriage or coach, no dead march or martial music, no official cortege, motorcade or cavalcade, as would surely have been the case had ex-Crown Prince Merid-Azmatch Assfaw Wossen Haile-Selassie died a monarch. I was not able to witness the funeral rites conducted inside the church, where the remains of the Crown Prince were interred into the royal crypt built at the time the Trinity Cathedral was constructed, not least because there was no way I could have moved up-front through the thick crowds of mourners; besides, thinking that the burial was to take place at 10 a.m. I had by then stood for more than three hours, and my back and legs had begun aching rather badly.

However, according to eye-witness accounts, the funeral rites were officiated by His Holiness Abune Paulos who led the celebration of mass and later on gave benediction. A brief life-history of the late Crown Prince was read and some 60 flower wreaths were placed on his crypt.

Why did I go to the ex-Crown Prince's funeral? It so happened that I was passing by the Trinity Cathedral around 9:30 a.m. I had heard earlier that the Crown Prince was to be buried on February 2, 1997, but I didn't know exactly at what time. I saw people going to the church in large numbers. So, I joined in. I felt obliged to do so out of the enormous debt of gratitude I still feel I owe his late father, the great Emperor Haile-Selassie.

As a kid I went to a school named after the great king. Our school was one of the educational establishments which he personally visited occasionally. He never came empty-handed. I remember vividly receiving a bunch of red grapes and three birr from his Imperial Majesty's hands.

Then, of course, there were the innumerable annual Christmas gifts, cakes, soft drinks and a sweater I, along with thousands of my fellow pupils, received from him. The climax was when I experienced his electrifying charisma, receiving prizes from him at the Grand Palace for standing top of my unit in fifth grade. Those grapes had a lot to do with that academic achievement.

In college, we students at the time were pampered, in a way the average Ethiopian could not even dream of, with a stipend of 50 birr each or its equivalent in food (which is excellent by today's standards) and lodgings. It was, however, in the university's dining room, where we used to drink milk almost like water, that college students plotted to dethrone the Emperor.

I did not understand student politics very much, but all the same I was greatly impressed by the brilliance and eloquence of the student activities of the time. "Mr. Chairman, order! Point of information! objection! I move a motion to the effect The emperor's days are numbered, his regime has been shaken to its very foundations Have I not walked the streets of Paris and London. Land to the Tiller! Woe to the revisionists!" Such were the political slogans of the times.

The Emperor took the brunt of the difficulties caused by the student unrest, but Crown Prince Assfaw Wossen always stood by his father - always except perhaps once, and that probable exception was in December 1960 when he was forced to renounce his allegiance to his father on the radio by the coup makers of the day led by Brigadier Mengistu Newaye. As it turned out, the coup collapsed and the Emperor was fully restored to his throne, Assfaw Wossen was apparently fully pardoned as it was thought he could not have done it except under duress.

For the next fourteen years the Crown Prince lived, as he did in the previous thirty years, in the overwhelming shadow of his illustrious father, until the Derg staged a successful cope against the Emperor in 1974. As the " creeping coup" of the Derg casts its ominous shadow on the Emperor himself, Crown Prince Merid-Azmatch Assfaw Wossen left the country under very inauspicious circumstances, reportedly on a stretcher after having suffered a paralyzing stroke from which he never fully recovered until his death.

Throughout the Derg period, the ex-Crown Prince lived in exile in England and the United States, and shortly after the assumption of power by the EPRDF, he was crowned in exile as King Amha-Selassie by the monarchist political party Moa Anbessa ( which by the way, is legally registered by the current government) of which he was the leader and figurehead.

Finally, the February 2, 1997 funeral of the late Crown Prince Merid- Azmatch Assfaw Wossen demonstrated that a large section of the Ethiopian society still harbours a fascination for the monarchy, which many would have otherwise thought was dead and buried. His last rites commanded popular respects beyond anybody's fondest expectations, perhaps more by association with the indubitable greatness of his father than as a result of his own achievements which could hardly be considered as monumental.

Only in retrospect and by comparison do many Ethiopians seem to realize the immense unifying power of the throne. I personally have no doubt in my mind that the formal burial of Assfaw Wossen's father is going to be a momentous occasion that would bring tears to the eyes of not just thousands but millions of Ethiopians across the nation, for Emperor Haile-Selassie was, admittedly in retrospect but with all the justification and evidence in the world, a singularly talented man who fortified and modernized the foundations of our common home, Ethiopia.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


54 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 7, 1997


Ethiopia;
Neither Outstanding External Debt Nor Debt Relief


BYLINE: Our Economics Correspondent, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2040 words


 

Addis Ababa - The lingo used in the discussion of Ethiopia's external debt is exasperatingly evasive. Just ask a top-notch economist or even an equally qualified external debt accountant in the relevant government department exactly how much Ethiopia's external debt in US dollars is as of a certain date, say, Feb. 1, 1997 and how much debt reduction she got since the EPRDF came to power, and the likely reply you would get would be something like this:

"Well, it is in SDR's and you've got to disregard ruble-denominated debt. Then, of course, the debt has got to be broken down into multilateral and bilateral. The bilateral has got to be chopped up into Paris Club and London club. Reckoning in NPV terms is a must. As for the debt reduction, one has to distinguish between debt relief, which apparently includes debt restructuring, and debt reduction proper. London terms and Naples terms are also things we have to look at.

Then, of course, there are the pre-cut-off date, the post-cut-off date, the moratorium interest and the various debt ratios. So, it is a bit complicated, but I hope I have given you some clues on how you may approach your questions, which, I must admit, are relevant and timely". 

If you are a real gentleman you may just, but only just, resist an outburst at such evasive double-dutch. But could you help chatting back thus:

"For God's sake, all I want to know is whether Ethiopia's outstanding external debt, including ruble-denominated debt, is 4 billion or 5 billion US dollars and the total debt reduction Ethiopia got since May 1991 is 300 million or 400 million US dollars. That is all. I. want. to. know! How in the world do you expect me to know the Birr/SDR or dollar/SDR exchange rate? Just because the SDR is an IMF brainchild does not mean that it must still be around when it is actually almost extinct! The dollar (and you know whose dollar I mean) is still king, and all attempts to dethrone the yellow metal have come to nought!

My complaint briefly is, if you don't give me those key figures, it is extremely difficult for me to get interested in all those bits of jargon you are trying to vaunt. If I know exactly how much Ethiopia's external debt is, how much she is getting by way of debt reduction every year, or as frequently as debt reductions are made, and how much the annual debt-service is, all in absolute terms, then perhaps I wouldn't mind trying to acquaint myself with your London, Naples or even Timbiktu or Paramaribo terms!"

So, don't blame the poor reporter of the government-owned English daily, the "Ethiopian Herald", for recently sending in a news story on the matter as follows:

"Paris Club provides 67 percent debt relief for Ethiopia - The Paris Club of creditor nations have agreed on a 67 per cent debt relief for Ethiopia. In a statement the Paris Club issued in Paris yesterday the debt relief given to Ethiopia was the most generous terms of debt reduction currently provided to the World's poorest nations" - "The Ethiopian Herald", January 25, 1997.

67 percent of what? If we knew the "what", it would have been easy enough finding out how much on a 15 - birr pocket calculator! How about the following quote:

"All truth is simple. It looks complicated only when it is not known or when it is being deliberately hidden." You may try to figure out which it is in this particular case!

By comparison, apparently more knowledgeable sources report the recent news of debt relief for Ethiopia as follows:

"The Paris Club Agrees a Debt Restructuring for Ethiopia."

1. The Paris Club met on January 24, 1997 with representatives of Ethiopia. The representatives of the Creditor Countries agreed to recommend to their governments a reorganization of the maturities falling due during the period covered by Ethiopia's arrangement with the International Monetary Fund. This represents an important restructuring of Ethiopia's external debt: it applies to payments due under loans from, and credits guaranteed by, Ethiopia's official creditors.

2. The representatives of the Creditor Countries noted that Ethiopia's low per capita income and heavy debt burden call for strong adjustment efforts together with exceptional treatment of debt. The representatives of the Creditor Countries welcomed the implementation by the Government of Ethiopia of an economic and financial programme supported by the first annual arrangement under the Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility with the International Monetary Fund.

3. In response to the delegation of Ethiopia's request, Creditor Countries agreed to recommend a treatment providing notably for debt reduction up to 67% . The agreement implements the "Naples Terms" agreed in December 1994 for the treatment of the poorest and most indebted countries. Recognizing the great value of contributions already made by the Creditor Countries in order to alleviate the burden of servicing ODA debt, the maturities on ODA loans will be consolidated on a very long term basis.

4. In a voluntary manner, each Creditor Country may also undertake limited debt for nature, debt for aid, debt for equity swaps or other local currency swaps, for up to 20% of the debts concerned.

5. Lastly, Creditor Countries also agreed under certain conditions to hold a meeting to consider, by the end of 1999, the matter of Ethiopia's stock of eligible debt.

Understandably, the language of the above press release is diplomatic and somewhat legalistic. The concerns expressed about Ethiopia's low per capita income and heavy debt burden, and the recommendation for the special treatment based on them, plus the nice words uttered about the government's implementation of an economic and financial programme warm the cockles. Otherwise, the essence of the press release may be summarized as follows:

* the representatives of Creditor Countries will recommend to their respective governments that debt maturities falling due during the period of the IMF-sponsored economic programme for Ethiopia be reorganized;

* representatives of Creditor Countries recognize that Ethiopia needs strong adjustment efforts together with exceptional treatment of debt;

* representatives of Creditor Countries agree to recommend to their respective government debt reduction of up to 67 percent of the basis of " Naples Terms;"

* a voluntary debt swap arrangements of up to 20% may be undertaken;

A very brief pr<130>cis of the above, using only key words and phrases, would be:

* a recommendation to reorganize debt maturities

* strong adjustment efforts and exceptional debt treatment;

* a recommendation of debt reduction of up to 67 percent on "Naples Terms;"

* voluntary debt swap arrangements of up to 20 percent

So, our semantic algorithm tells us that the recently held talks between the representatives of the Paris Club and the Ethiopian government yielded no more than two recommendations, one observation and one agreement to act voluntarily.

Where did the reporter of "the Ethiopian Herald" get his "Paris Club provides 67 per cent debt Relief for Ethiopia?" Provides? It sounds as if we are going to get it in a few days or, in fact have already got it! But actually there is going to be a long wait before anything concrete transpires on the basis of these recommendations. The recommendations have first to reach officials of Paris Club governments with executive power.

These are typically extremely busy souls who are unlikely to be attracted by topic sentences in their executive summaries which have terms such as " debt relief" in them. They may shove off files containing such descriptors by saying, "oh, the beggar thing again!" After a long while and perhaps after being poignantly reminded of their mortality upon hearing that some people they know are battling against cancer, they may decide they may as well do something for their souls while they still can; and may have a second look at the "beggar thing"!

"So it is Ethiopia again, in the east of Africa. The Americans like to call it the Horn. Poor Ethiopians, they never could get rid of their superiority complex! It is that Prester John myth and of course there is the Battle of Adwa and the associated Menelik syndrome. If only they knew how backward they are! They still can't tell the difference between Microsoft and the Internet. O.K., what is it they want this time? 67 percent debt reduction on 'Naples Terms'? Debt reorganization? Debt swaps? If 'Naples' is 67 percent how much is 'London'?"

Important interruption.

The Prime Minister is on the phone: "You know jolly well how worried I am about this bloody thing called mad cow disease. I have had barely enough time to navigate through this labyrinth called EMU, but look at what the rest of Europe is saying about cow insanity, if ever there was such a thing!"

So, yet another long spell may elapse before the "debt relief" file receives another look from the political executives of Europe. Besides, the sums have got to be done. Suppose the executives decide to approve the recommendations, what does debt reorganization mean in terms of reductions in annual debt-service payments? What does a 67 percent debt reduction imply in dollar or sterling terms? In other words, exactly how much is Ethiopia going to get in terms of debt reduction on "Naples Terms"? Precisely the same question would be asked about the debt swap arrangement by each Paris Club country which volunteers to carry out one.

In short, the recent Ethiopia - Paris Club agreement is really nothing more than a mere recommendation upon which an executive (often parliamentary) decision is required before implementation begins, which itself is conditional on Ethiopia's economic reform performance and is to be carried out in phases! Why not take up the issue again in the year 2000!?

Pessimistic?

O.K. let us make it just a short time before the arrival of the EURO! Finally, would someone please tell us exactly how much Ethiopia's outstanding external debt is in dollar (not SDR!) terms and how much Ethiopia got again in dollar terms, by way of debt reduction since the EPRDF annihilated the Derg?


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


55 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 7, 1997


Sports - General;
South Africa Cricket: Now for the main course ...


BYLINE: Jon Swift, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1507 words


 

Johannesburg - For South African fans enjoying a feast of cricket, the arrival of the Australians is the cherry on top

IT hardly seems credible that, in the midst of what seems a plethora of cricket, we have yet more coming our way - the Australians open their account with the gentle stroll in the park against the Nicky Oppenheimer XI at Randjesfontein next week.

In the light of the fact that next Wednesday is the date scheduled for the final of the current one-day international series - and the Oppenheimer match collides with the spare day held over for the final in case of rain - it means that tours are becoming very much of the seamless wall-to-wall variety.

It has placed an immense amount of pressure on the players. Not least of these pressures has been the continuous need to perform at peak level. Even in a professional age, where the outside interferences of having to earn a living in a totally different arena have been eased by the players' percentage of gate and TV money, this call for continued excellence is an impossibility. 

All teams have their slumps, all players their drops in form. In this respect, it is well to examine the fortunes of Sachin Tendulkar and his Indian tourists, and our own side under the steering of Hansie Cronje, before examining the Australians and their current up-and-down form.

Tendulkar, like Mohammed Azharuddin before him, has suffered on a personal level, struggling to find the form with the bat that has marked him as one of the globe's premier players.

The Indians have been hampered by a lack of depth in their bowling which has permeated into virtually every other sphere of their play, and the current tour of South Africa is doubtless one they will be more than happy to relegate to the misty realms of yesterday. For even though the emergence of Rahul Dravid and Saurav Ganguly as players capable of walking the hot coals of a pitch seared by the pace of Allan Donald offers extra weight to the fact that the wristy players of the sub-continent can play outside India, there remains the problem of indoctrination on home-grown wickets.

The days when an Indian new ball bowler's main job was to turn his arm over for an over or two to take off the shine for the spinners has left us. The Indians cannot continue to over-bowl the likes of Javagal Srinath and Venkatesh Prasad the way they have. Not when the same malaise of just too many overs bowled has taken the edge off as fine a player as Anil Kumble.

In this aspect, Tendulkar could do worse than look at how Zimbabwe's skipper Alistair Campbell has used his sometimes meagre resources. Exciting as Zimbabwe have been, they lack the real bowling depth so manifest in the wealth of South African riches. Yet Campbell has used what he has sparingly and intelligently.

One always has the feeling that, even when the game has started to run away from him, Campbell knows exactly what he is doing with the attack. He is a fine captain, despite his meagre years, and he has lived with both the superb form of a veteran like Eddo Brandes and the wayward, nine-wides apprenticeship of Everton Matambanadzo.

Likewise, Cronje, coach Bob Woolmer and the South African selectors have ridden the waves of form and fortune. In this they have done a simply magnificent job. They have stuck with the classic classy talents of Andrew Hudson, without much to show on the scoreboard in the one-dayers simply because he owns that class and ability, before finally resting him.

It means that - until a spot in the final was all but secure - the frontrunners of our next generation of international players have sat it out. It has not been a bad thing in the analysis.

Paul Adams has had the breathing space he probably needs before the rigours of a three-Test series against the Aussies; Adam Bacher has doubtless learnt to bridle an impatience he has to get back out there - an aspect which has shown in the ways he has managed to get himself out; and it has lit a veritable fire in the heart of Jacques Kallis. Kallis has champed at the bit as the South African top order has stuttered, and come back into the side steaming with both bat and ball to add yet another name to the list of growing all-rounders this country can call on.

A similar thing has occurred with the return of Jonty Rhodes, bringing with him the ebullience of old and the priceless ability he owns of being able to change the tempo of a game so dramatically, be it by a sudden run-out or a whirlwind mini-innings, that re-arranges the patterns and thinking of the opposing attack so dramatically. Rhodes will always have his doubters as a five-day player, but in the limited overs game, he remains an almost priceless asset.

The willingness of the national selectors to ride the storms has also allowed Cronje to play himself back into devastating form and ease the extra burden that captaincy has placed on him. Again this is cause for congratulation, even if there would be few Indian cheerleaders.

But most of all, the philosophy of staying with the players who have given service and feeding the new blood in at a steady drip has allowed a smoothness in the process of transition that has helped rather than hindered the team.

Which leads inevitably to the state of the Australians. Their particular transition has been a stormy one since the uncompromising - and at times near brutal -ideals of Allan Border.

Border has retired, so has David Boon - arguably one of the game's greatest sledgers - the glowering mustachioed menace of Merv Hughes is gone, as has the all-day power and pace of Craig McDermott. Of the newer faces, perhaps the most typical fatality is the elegant left-hander Michael Slater who made such an impact on the last tour, although Ricky Ponting, Justin Langer and Matthew Hayden can also be counted among the casualties.

In an oblique way, captain Mark Taylor is also among the walking wounded, off form and under fire from the Australian critics, he faces the same Rubicon Cronje has got a little over halfway across as a man expected to lead and perform all in the same fragile and often complicated human package.

Shane Warne, whose guiles turned Daryll Cullinan from a would-be lion into a quivering rabbit, has also not been without his problems and, while he remains one of the world's premier bowlers, he has not found it as easy of late to send a side packing in total disarray.

No, it has not been as easy for the Australians in the past season or so as they have come to believe is almost their right on a diet of cowering post- Botham Poms.

And yet, even with the humiliation of sitting out the final of a one-day home series, the Australians remain this country's greatest rivals, the men we most want to beat. In this regard, it is well to remember that the Australians still managed to retain the Frank Worrell trophy in the ill- tempered series against the West Indians.

And perhaps even more importantly, there is nothing they hate worse than to take a beating, a thought process that the more crass historians would have us believe stems directly from an aversion to the floggings on the convict ships. Perhaps. It remains that the Aussies are redoubtable foes.

This may not be the team of hard-bitten veterans and burgeoning mirror images that arrived under Border, but there can be little doubt that they are here for a fight. One which begins this Thursday and one that could just see the dips of form level out and make Cronje and his South Africans battle for every run, each wicket and any victory that might be in the offing. It is a prospect worth weighing and savouring.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


56 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 7, 1997


Sports - General;
ATHLETICS: It's time for Adri to slow down


BYLINE: Julian Drew, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1200 words


 

Johannesburg - One of the most forlorn figures in the Centennial Olympic Stadium in Atlanta last year was that of Adri de Jongh. Instead of enjoying the highlight of her career out on the track the Germiston-based 200 and 400m sprinter watched disconsolately from the stands, her leg in plaster. That was the sad and final outcome to a season which had begun so full of promise but ended in farce.

With her personal best of 50.73 in Johannesburg last April she had finally broken into the ranks of world-class quarter-milers and Atlanta shone brightly on the horizon. But as she prepared for Atlanta the pain in her left foot which had been troubling her all season got progressively worse. A local doctor warned her that it could be the start of a stress fracture and she decided to rest for two weeks. 

Once at the pre-Games holding camp in LaGrange she had to undergo a fitness test and, in what turned into something of a comedy of errors, she was pronounced fit before breaking down in training and being taken off to Atlanta for a scan and then an operation on the day of the opening ceremony.

"They opened my foot and inserted a pin and I was in a cast for five weeks," said De Jongh. "I'm going to have it removed after the end of this season. I had a scan last Friday and they said everything was 100%. The only problem is that the screw they put in is lying next to a nerve and that is a bit irritating but it is nothing to do with the stress fracture."

Just to prove she is over the injury De Jongh not only surprised the crowd with her superb performances at last weekend's Test match against Italy but also herself and her coach Stephane Kotze. In the 400m she blasted out of the blocks and pulled further and further away from the field to dip under 51 seconds for only the second time in her life with a time of 50.91.

If that wasn't proof enough, an hour-and-a-half later she was back on the track to scorch her way to the fastest 200m time by a local athlete in South Africa for six years. "I only started training in October following my operation but when I train I train 110%. I'm still only in my pre-season programme at the moment but I knew I was going to do well in the 400m," said De Jongh.

"The 200m was a bit of a surprise though. I don't know where I got the strength from. I sprinted flat out but all the way I was praying please just get me to the line. When I looked at the time I just couldn't believe it."

Both De Jongh's 200m time of 22.82 and her 50.91 in the 400m are comfortably under Athletics South Africa's (ASA) world championship qualifying standards - modified after a huge outcry but still tougher than those of the International Amateur Athletic Federation. But with ASA stating that "all altitude performances will be converted to corresponding coastal performances" in terms of their selection criteria, De Jongh may still not have done enough.
