Africa News


February 17, 1997


United States and Africa;
Summit To Focus On Investment, Job Creation


BYLINE: Elias Abebe, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Addis Ababa - Upon completion of his four-day visit here in preparation for the fourth African-African American summit due to be held in Harare in July this year, the Reverend Dr. Leon H. Sullivan, founder and president of the International Foundation for Education and Self-Help said yesterday that the focus of the African-African American summit this time will include among other things education the creation of jobs, investment and democracy.

At a press conference held at the United States Embassy, the Reverend Dr. Leon Sullivan said that during his stay here he had met and held talks with Prime Minister Meles Zenawi, the Minister of Education, W/ro Genet Zwedie and the OAU Secretary-General Mr. Salim A. Salim.

According to him, Prime Minister Meles Zenawi who is one of the vice- chairman of the up-coming summit will address the participants of the latter which this time is expected to be attended by 25 heads of state and government, delegation from African92s in Diaspora and other several African and African American intellectuals, educators and professionals. 

The Reverend Dr. Sullivan who reportedly organized a People-to-People effort or otherwise known as Supporters of Sub-Saharan Africa (SOS) Campaign that evolved out of the Dakar Summit and that aim at seeking help for the children of Africa, had also the opportunity to witness the arrival of 300, 000 books and millions of pencils and other school supplies, as part of the effort to enhance the quality of education.

Reverend Sullivan is also the organizer of Opportunities Industrialisation Centers (OIC), one of the largest networks of self-help vocational skills training programmes in the United States, it was disclosed.

The OIC movement was established in Africa in 1970 with Ethiopia being one of the first four countries to benefit from the programme, Reverend Sullivan noted.

Reverend Dr. Sullivan further noted that both the IFESH and OIC programmes which were initiated by him operate in any African countries only upon request of the Africans themselves.

Reverend Sullivan who is a reputed black civil rights activist in the USA, is only a private citizen engaged in a number of people-to people activities, it was learned.

Africa News


February 17, 1997


Ethiopia;
Court Hears Testimonies of Prosecution Witnesses


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - The Federal High Court yesterday heard testimonies of three prosecution witnesses in the case against the former Derg officials.

The 123rd prosecution witness told the Federal High Court that what has happened to the youth who were taken form prisons on board heavy duty trucks under the pretext of investigation has still remained a mystery. 

The witness said in all the prisons he was jailed in since 1977 it was common to hear whimpering and crying of youth who were taken out from the prison cells. The witness who identified himself as a radio journalist be fore imprisonment said he served prison terms until 1981 in Derg investigation centre. first Police Station Higher 5, 16 and 25 prisons and finally in Addis Ababa Prison. He said he was tied with ropes and tortured at different times simply for being a member of the EPRP.

He named seven people including one who was said to have attempted to kill Col. Mengistu taken out of prison cells but none of them returned.

The 124th prosecution witness on his part said he served prison terms for eight years since September, 1976 in the Special crime Investigation Centre. Higher 12 and the Addis Ababa Prison.

He said, in those eight years, he had seen ten inmates taken from the pri son and never shown up since then. He mentioned the names of the ill-fated prisoners.

The other witness said gunmen in uniform arrested her son, Solomon Ejigu at midnight from his bedroom. She used to visit her son at different prisons but lost contacts later on.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


223 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 17, 1997


Business and Finance;
313,000 Tonnes of Fertilizer Available for Distribution


BYLINE: Asfaw Gemeda, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Addis Ababa - Subsidy to fertilizer and price control on its retail sales was lifted to enable peasant farmers to have wider access to the commodity, the General Manager of the National Fertilizers Industry Agency said.

At a press conference held here on Monday, Agency General Manager Bekele Mengesha noted that the role of the government in this respect would be confined only to fixing prices on wholesale of the input. According to hi m, prices on wholesale of fertilizer was set in 150 towns where it is believed to have a high demand and to be a strategic centre for its distribution.

So far, some 160,000 tonnes of fertilizer has been imported and is being supplied to sales centres across the country, said the general manager, adding that including the undistributed fertilizer last year, 313,000 tonnes is now available in the country.

It is estimated that the amount of fertilizer needed for the 1989/90 harvest seasons will be around 300,000 tonnes and yet 410,000 tonnes has been supplied to peasant farmers out of which the sale of DAP accounted for 3 22, 000 and that of Uria 88,000 tonnes.

Ato Techane Adugna, senior expert with the Marketing and Development Depa rtment of the Agency, on his part said the lifting of subsidy and price deregulation at a retail sales level was part of the measures being taken to introduce market economy and to help stabilize the market and distribution of the input.

So far, 80 percent of the retail sales of fertilizer was made through peasant cooperatives while the 20 percent through dealers and importers, it was learnt.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


224 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 17, 1997


Ethiopia;
ETTE Workers Support Reorganisation of CETU


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (EH/ENA) - Workers of the Ethiopia Tourist Trading Enterprise overwhelmingly supported on Monday the efforts of coordinating committee to reorganize the Confederation of Ethiopian Trade Unions(CETU).

At a general assembly of the basic union of ETTE, workers examined the failures of the former leaders of CETU to live up to the objectives of the confederation. Ato Wondemagegn Moges, representative of the Industrial Federation of Tourism, Hotels and General Service Workers, blamed the ex- leaders of CETU for engaging in self-interest pursuit and vying for the power. He said that CETU should be reorganized in a way that it would work towards the realization of labour rights and other fringe benefits. 

According to Ato Wondwosen the former leaders of CETU had achieved virtually not due to their confrontational approach towards the government. " Their approach was too confrontational that it was dangerous for the maintenance of industrial peace," he noted.

Ato Mezgebe Kidane, chairman of the basic union, on his part said workers of ETTC had no their alternative but to support the stance of other federations for the reorganization of CETU without any precondition.

Having thoroughly discussed the pro-and cons of reorganizing CETU, most participants voted in favour of reconstituting anew the labour confederation.

Meanwhile according to ENA reports workers of the Kombolcha Textile and Assela Malt factories have demanded the reestablishment of the confederation of Ethiopian Trade Unions(CETU).

The workers made the demand at meetings held in their respective factories at the beginning of this month.

According to the Trade Union of the Kombolcha Textile Factory, the workers unanimously voted for the reestablishment of CETU in a bid to solve their problems and consolidate ties with similar trade unions across the world to promote the rights of workers for better living conditions.

The workers also agreed to elect two representatives in place of those removed from the executive board for alleged inefficiency.

Meanwhile, the workers of Assela Malt Factory expressed their determination to closely work with the coordinating committee for the reestablishment of CETU.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 17, 1997


Ethiopia;
SEPDA constructs 1,500 km road


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The South Ethiopian Peoples' Development Association (SEPDA) has constructed 1,493 km of gravel road by mobilizing the public and also plant to upgrade their standard, the general manager of the association disclosed.

Association General Manager Matewos Shamo told ENA that the association, in collaboration with various development associations of nationalities in the region, has organized the people in different task forces and constructed the new roads and maintained some 582 km of roads which were badly in need of repair. 

He added that the development associations in the zones of the regional state have deployed the people one day every week and built 126 wooden bridges.

Ato Matewos said foundations of other 104 similar bridges have been laid in Hadiya zone and the construction of 23 km of road is under way in different zones.

The people in the region were organized under 35,556 task forces to undertake different development activities including the construction of 21 health posts, Ato Matewos added.

Among the development activities is the harnessing of the Konso River to irrigate 13,500 hectares of land, he said.

The association has secured financial and material assistance worth one million birr during the "Awassa'89 Expo".

Africa News


February 17, 1997


Ethiopia;
Authority Set to Meet Addis Water Needs


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The shortage of potable water in Addis would be solved beginning from early next Ethiopia year with the completion of some of the emergency water supply projects for the city, the Addis Ababa branch of the Ethiopian Water and Sewerage Authority said.

General Manger Tadesse Kebede, told President Negasso Gidada, who visited the projects Monday that one such project involved the sinking of 25 wells at Akaki, about 20 kms from Addis Ababa, which will supply 75,000 cubic meters each day, the Region 14 Information bureau said. 

The 18 supply projects, to be executed at various stages, are financed by the authority, the regional administration and the World Bank, the bureau quoted Ato Tadesse as saying.

Currently, the authority meets only 60 per cent of the metropolis potable water needs, it was noted.

Africa News


February 17, 1997


Science and Health;
Migrant Bird of Prey Found Dead in Ethiopia


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

NEKEMPTE (ENA) - A bird of prey with a label, indicating that it is from Europe, fastened to it was found dead at farmland in Haro Allelit, East Wolegga Zone. 

The bird has died after its wing caught fire from a burning savannah grassland in the surrounding where it was looking for something to eat, according to team leader of the forestry and wildlife protection in the zonal agriculture department.

The label attached to its limb read "3460 Helgolan Germania," he said.

The bird with red beak and limb is said to be 80 cm. long with a neck stretching about 26cm.

228 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 17, 1997


Ethiopia;
SPO Files Charges Against 5,198 Derg Defendants


BYLINE: Kisut G/Egziabher, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - The Special Public Prosecutor's Office (SPO) announced here yesterday that it has at long last charged a total of 5,198 alleged perpetrators of the Derg regime mainly with genocide and war crimes and alternatively with aggravated homicide and wilful injury.

Special Prosecutor General Girma Wakijira told a press conference which he called at his office that 2,246 of the defendants in detention were charged while the remaining 2,952 were indicted in absentia. Five thousand twenty six are male and the remaining 172 constitute female defendants it was reported. According to the SPO chief, 26 of the defendants were charged with aggravated homicide and 54 others with war crimes while the rest will have to face charges of genocide. 

"The defendants are classified into three major groups: the first group constitute the policy or decision makers, the second group are the field commanders(those who transmitted the orders of the first group and also originate fresh orders of their own) and the third group make up the perpetrators of the crime," Ato Girma pointed out.

On hundred forty sic of the defendants belong to the first group, 2,433 to the second group and 2,619 fall in the third category, it was noted.

The SPO reportedly compiled concrete evidences on crimes committed against 14,209 victims. Of these, 1,837 are victims of torture, 8,752 are victims of killings and 978 victims of enforced disappearance, the SPO chief said, adding that 2,611 are victims of war crime while 31 are murder cases.

As to the distribution of the charges, 202 defendants are to be tried in Tigray Regional State, 508 in the Amhara Regional State, 855 in Oromia, 421 in the southern Peoples' Region, 198 in Harari and 74 in Somali regional states. The rest f the defendants will be tried at the Federal High Court her, it was learnt.

It was also stated that over 3,000 personal witness and large volumes of documentary evidences, audiovisuals, forensic and other expert-evidences are ready to prove the charges.

Describing his office's performance so as far as a "conspicuous achievement" , Ato Girma said that it was unfortunate that the SPO and the Ethiopian prosecution process was blamed for delay. "a compartive study begining from the Nuremberg Trial down to the different Truth Commissions and Inquiry Commissions that were established all over the world would make this criticism unfair if not unjust." Ato Girma's conviction appeared to be that achievements have to be weighed on the basis of the complexity of the mandate, the resources available, the support extended, and the progress made.

"We are using our national law, national courts, prosecutors and defence lawyers for all these cases. This in our opinion is a major breakthrough," he underscored; adding "this process, we are sure, is the basis for an established sequence of state accountability and a great fight against impunity."

With a mandate to conduct investigation in to and institute proceedings against Derg/WPE regime perpetrators, the SPO was established in August 1992.

Present were members of the diplomatic community, various NGO representatives and representatives of the victims, in addition to local and international newsmen.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


229 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 17, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopian President Calls On Entrepreneurs To Intensify Investment


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - President Negasso Gidada yesterday called on investors to contribute their share in development endeavours launched nationwide in a bid to achieve sustainable economic prosperity.

In his key-note address at the investment promotion week launched in the Amhara Regional State, Dr. Negasso urged investors to intensify their involvement in the economic sector using the conductive atmosphere the government has created. 

Directives believed to promote local market and export items both in quality and quantity were implemented to foster economic development, he said.

Investment in the region, though encouraging, still lacks the momentum desired, he said and underlined the need to forward solutions to constraints during discussions to be held throughout the week.

Ato Adissu Legesse, head of the regional state, on the occasion briefed participants on the overall activities in the investment sector.

The president has also officially opened the exhibition organized in connection with the investment promotion week, launched for the third time in the region.

The exhibition depicting the natural resource, land use, industrial products including charts, photographs and maps was visited by participants and guests invited to attend the week long investment promotion programme.

The president, on arrival here yesterday afternoon at Bole International Airport was welcomed by senior government officials.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


230 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 17, 1997


Ethiopia;
Prime Minister Meles Reports to Parliament


BYLINE: Kisut Gebre-Egziabher, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2160 words


 

Prime Minister Meles Zenawi last week submitted to parliament his regular six-monthly report, covering a wide range of issues, with a particular focus on the development front. He meanwhile elaborately answered a number of questions raised by several MPs. Following is a condensed version of the major issues of the report.

As clearly put in the five-year government development strategy, expanding social and economic infrastructure is one of the four major roles which the federal government has to play in actualizing the development programme.

A look at this year's capital budget breakdown shows that the government has given particular attention to infrastructural expansion as provided by the strategy itself. 

The government, this year, allocated 4.8 billion birr in capital budget, a figure which reportedly exceeded that of last year by 21.6%. Of this, 25% went for the construction of new roads and reinforcement of existing ones; 13% for energy development; 10.5% for water resource development; 9.9% for the expansion of educational services; 8.7% for the expansion of transport and communications services; 7.4% for agricultural development and 6.5% for the expansion of health services.

That the lion's share went to the road projects is indicative of the dire situation which the sector finds itself in, and the direct impact it will have on the overall economy of the country. This was so expressed in the words of the prime minister who described the country's transportation expenses as "among the highest in he world."

That the education and health sectors got a relatively smaller portion of the budget, on the other hand, does not insinuate disregard of the two sectors. Rather, it was deliberately done in realisation of the fact that 80% of the former and 96% of the latter are the responsibilities of Regional States.

According to Ato Meles, the federal government's five-year plan pertaining to expansion of roads was: the reinforcement of 2613 Kms of existing asphalted road and the construction of 3833 Kms. of rural roads in various regions.

The successful completion of this 13-billion birr project, described by the PM as "the biggest ever in the country's history" is widely believed to meaningfully minimize the prevailing acute transportation problem.

According to the report, 26 designing and feasibility study projects have been formed, of which 12 are believed to be fianalized this year and the remaining 14 by next year. The Premier was sure that the EU - funded asphalt reinforcement work on the Addis Ababa - Jimma and Addis Ababa - Awassa roads would begin next year. If things go according to plan, five additional World Bank -funded projects would also begin actual work.

To put maintenance programmes on a stable ground, Ato Meles disclosed that the legal framework for the establishment of a "Road Maintenance Fund", a fund capable of generating its own income, was being laid down.

The implementation of this huge project obviously requires a strong capacity which the country doesn't have at the moment. The premier said that an all out effort is being exerted to build the necessary capacity. to this effect, restructuring the High Way Authority was well underway, manpower training programmes are going on both here and abroad. particularly the newly established engineering faculties in Bahir Dar and Makalle as well as the 25 junior technical training centres spanning the country are believed to be of great help.

As regard the goal set for the current fiscal year and the actual work done on the ground, Ato Meles had to say these: "The plan was to construct 310 Kms. of new asphalt road and 293 Kms. of feeder gravel road. until early December, 58.4 Kms. of asphalt and 78 Kms. of gravel roads have been constructed. the rainy season took the blame for the delay and the hope is to compensate these in the months ahead."

Prime Minister Meles commended the Ethiopian Telecommunications Authority (ETA) for a job well done where expansion of telecommunications service is concerned. According to the PM, the Authority has already begun, operating profit-mindedly, and that the government allotted no budget for it this year.

"From its own income and loans, the ETA this year allocated 228 million birr for the expansion of its services and things are progressing satisfactorily."

If things continue to proceed as planned and if the Authority maintains its present level of efficiency, the Premier hoped that the country will be changed for the better in 2 to 3 years where telecommunications service is concerned. According to him, the plan is to add 480,000 new telephone lines to the existing 160,000 and to connect at least 300 rural towns.

Ato Meles hinted that the ETA may in the very near future supply Addis and its surroundings with mobile phones.

Airport expansion is the other area deemed crucial where infrastructure development is concerned. This, the Prime Minister noted, is in recognition of the fast transportations services it renders, the role it plays in expanding the tourism industry as well as in safeguarding the country's air territory.

Accordingly, reinforcement and maintenance works on the asphalted Dire Dawa and Bahir Dar Air Ports had been completed and some works have been going on on the Gambella and Gode air ports to enable them host civilian air crafts as well. Similarly, the actual work to provide the Bole International air Port with a new runway and a terminal was about to begin, Ato Meles noted, adding that new asphalted airport construction projects have been under way at Arba Minch, Gondar, Lalibella, Axum and Makale.

Included in the report were projects on electric power generation and distribution. it was reported that 17 electric power generation and distribution projects have been running on a 211 million birr budget. As regards power generation, special attention was paid to the Gilgel Gibe, and the Aluto Geothermal generator project. Both are progressing well.

The prime minister disclosed that the study phase for the establishment of a second generation station at the Tis Abay had been completed and the actual work put to auction. Renovation works are also reported to have been well under way on the Koka, Tis Abay 1 and Fincha hydro-power generation stations.

With regard to electric power distribution, the report said that several installation projects are well underway, with Bahir Dar-Northern Ethiopia and Gedeo-Nekempte-Gimbi lines as the main ones.

Ato Meles said that the Ethiopian Electric Light and Power Authority (EELPA) still relies on government will stop its subsidy in 12 months time and that the Authority will have to enforce tariff adjustments to cover at least its expenses." The ultimate direction, he indicated, is that EELPA will have to emulate the ETA and work profit-mindedly. The legal frameworks for this are being laid down, it was learnt.

Harnessing the country's water resource also got due consideration form the government. This year alone, 597.5 million birr has been invested in water resource development projects which included master plan study on river basins, irrigation schemes as well as potable water projects, among others.

While masterplan studies on Omo, Baro and Akobo river basin have already been accomplished the case with the Abay and Tekeze is a little bit behind schedule. These rivers reportedly accounted for 80% of the country's water resource. The finalization of these projects is believed to bring about a major change in the county's water resource utilization.

As stated above the share of the federal government in the expansion of educational services is only 20%. And this is limited only to the administration of institutions of higher learning. According to the report, several new and existing colleges and universities have begun offering degree programmes in various disciplines as of this year. For example, the newly opened Dilla College offers programmes in medical science as well as teachers' training in eight subjects, Bahir Dar College in four engineering departments as well as teachers training in over eight subjects; Makalle University in two engineering departments; Alemaya University in medical science and teacher's training in various subjects.

Several MPs asked various questions which the MP answered elaborately.

Asked on whether or not there was any development in the Ethio-Sudanese relations and on allegations of occasional skirmish between armies of the two countries, Ato Meles said the following:

"Our relations with the Sudanese government has shown no progress over the months. It's as worse as it was since recent times. As to the skirmish, it's simply a lie. All the vociferating and the call for an army moblizations, all the beating of war drums and all the accusations on the part of the Sudanese government are mere propaganda to get domestic support by externalizing internal problems.

As to our position we don't want to shoot a single bullet no matter how fierce the provocation may be. We've had enough shooting for years and our major, perhaps the only, preoccupation is ploughing the land and harvesting maize. To put it succinctly, the Sudanese government won't invade us because it very well knows its military capacity, and we'll not provoke the Sudanese government because it's against our principle of promoting fraternal relations with our neighbours and because the time now is for harvesting food rains and not for shooting.

As to our solidarity with the generous and hospitable people of the Sudan, it will remain intact for ever. It's not for diplomacy's sake that we often describe the Sudanese people as generous, innocent and hospitable. it's because we know them closer for a long time. if any one portrays the people of Sudan as bad, that person must by very bad himself."

Asked why he often deprives the "free press" of their rights to attend his press conferences, Ato Meles said that to attend a premier or presidential press conference is an invitation and not a right. And that invitation is extended to qualified and accredited journalists and not to "journalists" who write fictitious reports.

"But the criterion to get that chance is one and only one: to stop lying," he underscored.

"But one thing the so-called free press don't seem to know about this government is that no foreign government, no matter how powerful it may be and no matter how it generously assists Ethiopia, can force us against our conviction. it may kill us by virtue of its military might but it can never force us to do things against our will. thus, it's high time that these people realize that appealing to Embassies now and then is a futile exercise."

On the progress of the case of his ex-deputy and Defence Minister Tamirat Layne, who was deposed from office on charges of corruption, Ato Meles said that the investigation has been finalized and that the case will be referred to the court.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 17, 1997


Western Sahara;
Sahara Weekly News Update (02/03 - 02/16)


BYLINE: Western Sahara Referendum Support Association


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Geneva - 09.02.97 President Abdelaziz's visit to Madagascar

In a communique the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of SADR announces that Mr. Mohamed Abdelaziz, President of the SADR and Secretary General of the Polisario Front, reached Antananarivo on Sunday 9.2.97.

He was invited to assist to the investiture of the recently elected President of Madagascar, his Excellence Mr. Didier Ratsiraka. The Sahrawi delegation, including the President's Councelor Mr. Mohamed Ould Salek and the SADR Ambassador in Madagascar Mr. Habib Boukhreis, was wellcomed at the airport by the Malgasy Vice-Prime Minister Mr. Akram Mounaji, the Army Minister Mr. Marcel Ranjeva, the Minister of Foreign Affairs Mr. Marson Evarist, the Minister of Finance, Mr. Farahouddine, General Andreamanantsou and other dignitaries of the Army and Police forces. 

The Malgasy President in a speech welcomed especially the presence of the Sahrawi and Mozambique Presidents and underlined the friendlly relations with them and their people. After the ceremonies the Sahrawi President had talks with the President of Mozambique Joaquim Chissano and the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Mauritius Mr. Paul Berenger and other chiefs of delegations. Next day he encountered the Malgasy President and the high responsibles of the State.

10.02.97 Western Sahara Page has been awarded a Four-Star rating

"Of the more than 150,000 Web sites that we've checked out, our editors believe that your site should be publicly recognized as a Luckman Four-Star winner. In acknowledgment of your efforts, we have attached Luckman Interactive's Four-Star logo. This mark of excellence is something that we only bestow upon the Web's finest sites. Put it on your site as a shining reward for your hard work. In addition to your Four-Star award, a review of your site will be featured in the new edition of our book and interactive CD- ROM-- Luckman Interactive's "World Wide Web Yellow Pages."

232 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 17, 1997


Business and Finance;
Nigeria: Everyone A Billionaire


BYLINE: Akaninyene Esiere, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1560 words


 

Lagos - Were internal revenue generation the only criter ion for having a state, Yobe state would, at best, qualify for a local government area. Of the N1.86 billion the six-year-old state intends to spend this year, it hopes to generate a paltry N50 million internally.

That is approximately the amount the Lagos State government wants to generate in two days to fund its N12.8 billion budget. While announcing the Yobe State budget in Damaturu, the state capital, John Ben-Kalio, the state administrator said the state would be relying on both the Federation Account and value added tax to the tune of N1.489 billion. Since the financial base of the state is so weak that it can barely breath on its own for weeks, the state will be doing what even the federal government shies away from: take external loans to the tune of N168 million. 

Pathetic as the Yobe State case is, the state is certainly not alone. Borno State which sired Yobe State in 1991 will equally need the federal might to survive. Of the N2.62 billion budget which Victor Ozodinobi announced January 24 before he was kicked out last week as state administrator, the state will only cough out N423 million. Ekiti, the four-month-old state also fits the bill as a parasitic state. Its N1.6 billion maiden budget will almost completely be financed outside, as the state says it will be able to cough out N 9 million internally.

This is less than what the state will get from VAT alone. Bauchi, Zamfara, Katsina, Taraba and Cross River states also have varying degrees of dependence on the federal government.

This is in sharp contrast to some states that, though would need money from the federally collected revenue, have succeeded in raising substantial funds from within. For instance, of the N4.5 billion Delta State has budgeted, it hopes to generate N1.9 billion internally. This is higher than the N1.53 billion it is getting from statutory earnings. VAT and capital receipts take care of the balance. Ogun State is in this club too.

It is generating internally N1.5 billion, the exact amount it will get from federal allocation. So also is Akwa Ibom State. Of the N2.83 billion budgetted, its share of the federation account is N1.79 billion. But by far, and by the internal reliance criterion, Lagos is the only state that does not need the federal might to function as a state. Of the N12.8 billion budgeted, Lagos will receive just N1.7 billion as statutory allocation.

Again, it is so far the only state that hopes to have a budget surplus. While it is spending N12.8 billion, its total revenue for the year as announced by Mohammed Marwa, the state administrator, is put at N15.5 billion, a surplus of N2.7 billion.)((cf0

Another characteristic of the state budgets is the attempt to ba lance recurrent with capital expenditure. On this score, most states have a fairly balanced budget compared to what obtained in years past when a chunk of state finances went into recurrent spending. For instance, Oyo State is voting over N3 billion of th e N5.6 billion budget on capital expenditure. Yobe votes over a billion of its N1.9 billion on capital projects, just as Bayelsa is putting in N1.17 billion of its N1.8 billion budget on capital expenditure.

Plateau State is spending N1.4 billion of its N2.2 billion budget on capital projects. Other states with a near-balance spending between recurrent and capital projections include Lagos, Borno, Enugu, Cross River, Sokoto, Bauchi, Zamfara, Edo, Katsina, Delta, Taraba and Niger states. But there are except ions. Akwa Ibom is one. It is voting a hefty N2.2 billion of its N2.8 billion budget on recurrent expenditure. This is made up of N1.27 billion on personnel, N487 million on overhead and N445 million on pension, gratuity, debt, etc. Despite its low level of development, the state is committing just N623 million for capital projects, a further confirmation that it is just a civil service state. Akwa Ibom has a friend in Adamawa state which is spending N1)((cf0 .35 billion of its N1.9 billion budget on recurrent expenditure.

In line with federal government directives, as enunciated by Anthony Ani, finance minister, virtually all the states are channelling their resources towards rural transformation. Sokoto, Bayelsa, Abia, Anambra, Enugu, Cross River and Niger states are voting substantially for the provision of basic amenities for rural dwellers. The same with Ogun, Oyo, Taraba, Edo, Delta, Akwa Ibom and Rivers states. These amenities are in the areas of health care, water provision, electrification, road constructi o n and rehabilitation and transportation.

The states are equally complementing federal effort at job creation, poverty alleviation and rural resource expansion aimed at achieving the economic growth and development objectives of the 1997 federal budget. Th i s is to be achieved through agriculture. Almost all the states give premium to agriculture and food production. For instance, Niger State is putting down N100 million for agriculture and rural development; Ogun State is voting N232 million on agriculture.

The state will be involved in mass production of improved seeds and seedlings. It is also carrying its rural development policy to greater length. Sam Ewang, a wing commander and state administrator, has created Ogun State Water Corporation and Bureau for

Rural Development to handle exclusively rural development matters. Sokoto, Plateau and Enugu States are also participating actively in agricultural development. Enugu State is reactivating oil palm and cashew plantations. The various state agricultural de velopment projects are to be adequately supported to assist in realising the increase in food production programme in the states.

Said Amen Oyakhire, Taraba State administrator: " Considering the fact that there is virtual absence of government in most part s of the state, the 1997 budget is focussed on aggressive rural transformation and the restoration of public confidence in government through the provision of physical infrastructures and essential social services ostensibly aimed at improving the living conditions of our people." Oyakhire speaks the minds of his counterparts in other states.

Another indication that the states are working in consonance with the federal government's overall objective is shown in the fact that hardly any of them is embarking on any grandiose project. In fact, outside the opening up of the rural areas and provision of badly needed projects in the six new states, hardly any of the states is building new projects. In most cases, the billions of naira voted for capital projects go into the rehabilitation of projects, completion of viable, value-added on-going projects. Even at that, states must be sure that the funds to undertake these are available.

The prudence, discipline and accountability philosophy at the federal level is trickling down to the states. For instance, the states' financial projections were calculated on actual financial receipts between October 1995 and September 1996 to ensure that the money hoped for would be realisable. This was meant to forestall the incidence of 1996 where most of the states' projections, especially in the area of internal revenue generation, fell short of actual collectable funds. For instance, while Imo State dreamt that it would generate N6 million in 1996, it actually squeezed N396 million internally.

Again, each of the states has set up a project planning/monitoring committee in deference to the federal directive that all projects under execution must be monitored to ensure that implementation guidelines are adhered to. The states are also overhauling their internal revenue generation mechanism.

Given that all the states that have so far released their budgets belong to the billionaire club, will there be any genuine excuse if, by the end of the year, the economic well-being of the citizens has not substantially improved?

(With Louis Onyia)


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 17, 1997


Nigeria;
Out He Goes


BYLINE: Peter Akpona, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Lagos - By the time he was summoned to Aso Rock for the second time within weeks to answer charges of financial impropriety, Victor Ozodinobi knew that his days as the Borno State administrator were numbered.

After days of uncertainty, the curtain was finally drawn on his brief tenure last Tuesday when he got "the Mohammed Maina treatment." Maina, a colonel, was in 1991 removed from office as military governor of Borno by former president Ibrahim Babangida. He was promptly replaced by Mohammed Marwa, then a lieutenant colonel and deputy defence attache at the Nigerian Embassy in the United States. Maina was in office for only a couple of months. 

On his part, Ozodinobi, a colonel who has been ordered back to the barracks, was in office for less than six months. He was appointed along with others on August 21 in a mass change of guards that affected all the then 30 states.

A statement signed by David Attah, chief press secretary to the head of state, merely informed that Sani Abacha, the head of state had approved the appointment of A. Aniebo, a lieutenant-colonel, as the new military administrator of the state.

Alhough Attah's statement gave no reason for the action, Theweek investigations showed that Ozodinobi was booted out because he played into the hands of his powerful adversaries in Borno. Popular with the masses for his anti-corruption stance, the Anambra-born colonel was said to have made enemies of several members of the indigenous elite whose sources of easy w ealth he plugged as soon as he assumed duties.

In what was at first thought to be a smear campaign, Ozodinobi was soon accused of swindling the state by cornering choice and usually inflated contracts for himself and his allies. His waterloo came when his enemies, said to include influential traditional rulers, used some civil servants loyal to them, to obtain vouchers indicating that the erstwhile administrator might have awarded contracts worth over N150 million to himself and his acolytes. The vouchers were promptly forwarded to the presidency along with petitions alleging maladministration on the part of the former administrator.

Worse for Ozodinobi, he had ruffled more than a few feathers while dissolving the state executive council in December. Apart from berating his commissioners for allegedly leaking government secrets at will, Ozodinobi miscalculated when he appointed six di rectors-general from the minority areas hitherto given crumbs during such appointments.

The first challenge before Aniebo, the new administrator, is to reconcile Borno citizens with the soldiers serving in the state. The relationship between both camps is frosty and has been further strained by the recent mob action involving students of the Government Day Secondary School located within the barracks of the 231 Tank Battalion, Biu, and some soldiers from the battalion. The disagreement over the outcome of a sporting event between students of GDSS and Government Secondary School, Waka, both in Borno State, had resulted in a fight that claimed the life of Nsuite Wande, a student of GDSS. The deceased was the son of a soldier from the 231 Tank Battalion.

On November 30, some students of GDSS and others believed to be soldiers and colleagues of Wande's father stormed the town at night and went on a rampage to avenge the death of the boy.

Among things destroyed during the riot were the official residence of the principal of Government Science Senior Secondary School which was torched. The academic block of the school and two cars were also destroyed. The school was the venue of the botched games.

Ozodinobi, who was the commanding officer of the 231 Tank Battalion before his appointment as administrator, quickly set up a judicial panel to look into the circumstances surrounding the riot and recommend appropriate disciplinary actions for those found guilty of involvement in it. The former administrator was said to be under pressure from Abuja over the outcome of the panel's finding, as Aso Rock was desirous of meting out more serious punishment should the one recommended by the panel be considered inadequate or inappropriate. The panel's report, it was gathered, indicted soldiers from the 231 Tank Battalion as being behind the riot.

Aniebo will score an early plus if he is able to liaise with the authorities at the battalion to checkmate the unruly ones among the soldiers.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 17, 1997


Business and Finance;
Nigerian Aviation - Death at Noon


BYLINE: Saleh Buba, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Lagos - The day would have ended like any other day for the crew of the 15- seater Sky Power Express plane who had planned their itinerary to run through Plateau, Borno and Adamawa states. The aircraft with registration mark SN-AXS and callsign EAN143 was that day chartered by the Central Bank of Nigeria to carry its mail and certain important documents to some major cities in the North.

The first leg of the journey had ended very well as the plane effortlessly discharged the cargo meant for Jos. The pilot therefore took off for Yola enroute Maiduguri. 

But as fate would have it, majority of the cities in the North-Eastern zone of the country were heavily enveloped by harmattan. The hazy clouds that day made visibility in the air very poor. It was this bad weathe r that the pilot ran into at Maiduguri and he found it difficult to land. The pilot then chose to re-order his itinerary by flying to Yola, which had been scheduled as the last port of call. By the new plan, the pilot intended to land the plane in Yola, offload the documents for the Adamawa State capital, and then head for Kano were he hoped to also deliver some cargo.

But his plan was aborted at the Yola airport by a yet more hazy weather than the situation he had tried to avoid in Maiduguri. Landing in Yola then became difficult as the landing signals were blurred to the pilot. Efforts by the Federal Airports Authority of Nigeria officials to light up the runway and thereby enhance visibility did not yield any result. With the plane's fuel said to be fast dwindling, the pilot was said to have decided to risk landing despite the poor visibility. )((cf0

The decision was to end in a crash which claimed the lives of five of the people aboard including Samson Mshelia a group captain and experienced fighter pilot. The group captain was said to have tried to lend a helping hand when the plane was in distress in the air. The decision is believed to be his undoing, as the crash met him in the cockpit.

Seven others were critically wounded and were admitted for treatment at the Springfield Hospital opposite the airport. Three of the survivors were treated and discharged for minor injuries and shock at the Yola Specialist Hospital.

The plane crash created panic among residents of Jimeta area, who had never before experienc ed such a deafening din as that caused by the crash-landed plane. The Yola airport has been in existence since it served as a landing site for the British colonial regiment in the North. The crash also led to a total blackout in Yola and Jimeta following the serious damage done to NEPA high tension cables by the plane.

Prominent citizens in Adamawa State including Kalu Igboamagh, the military administrator, and his wife, Grace, as well as Aliyu Musdafa, the Lamido Adamawa, have visited survivors of the crash in hospital, while prayers for the repose of the souls of the dead and the speedy recovery of those injured had been held in many religious centres.

But citizens belatedly await the official statement on the cause of the accident, which is an unfortunate addition to the long list of aviation disasters recorded in the country in the past twelve months.

A team of aviation experts has arrived Yola to have an on-the-spot assessment of the crash. So far, the investigating team has recovered the plane's black box. Investigations are still on as the team has been busy taking pictures of the wreckage and inter viewing people in connection with the incident.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


235 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 17, 1997


Nigeria;
Sambo's Cross


BYLINE: Emmanuel Ado, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Lagos - For Abdussalam Sambo, until lately the executive secretary of the National Primary Education Commission, it is not yet time to what he describes as the the unwarranted character assassination" to which Mohammed Liman, the ministe r of education, and Sani Idris, interim administrator of the commission, have subjected him. Not even his detention, at the Kabala Doki police station, Kaduna, has forced him to launch a counter-offensive. Sambo believes that he will eventually be vindicated.

But if Sambo will not challenge Liman's actions, not so Usman Mahmood Abdullahi, director of finance and supplies, Alhassan Abdullahi Iman, deputy director of finance and supplies, and James Ayuba, director of internal audit. The three men have collectively dragged Liman to the Federal Court, Kaduna, for wrongful suspension from duty. They are urging the court to restrain Liman from further interfering with their conditions of employment. 

Last December 9 the federal high court presided over by Ok echukwu Okeke granted their prayers, pending the determination of the substantive suit. That notwithstanding, Liman has gone ahead to dismiss the three top officials of the commission, who, in reaction, have filed a contempt suit against him.

Indications are that Idris, the interim administrator of NPEC, sees the sacked officials, particularly Sambo, as being guilty as charged. While recently briefing chairmen of state primary schools education boards, he alleged that Sambo, in brazen disregard of governm e nt regulations on tenders, single-handedly awarded contracts valued at N537,950,040.25 for the printing of continuous assessment booklets and diaries for primary schools.

To bring home the enormity of Sambo's purported offence, Idris stressed that the dec ision to award the contracts was taken without the approval of the federal executive council, "the only body that can award contracts of this magnitude." But Sambo's supporters vehemently deny this, claiming that Sambo had Liman's approval before awarding the contracts.

Sources say that many of the contractors were sent from Abuja by people whose requests Sambo could not refuse. For instance, the contractor who installed the communication equipment at the commission's new headquarters building was said to have been sent by a serving general.

Another allegation against Sambo is that contrary to government requirement of its agencies, he failed to insure with the National Insurance Company of Nigeria the 587 vehicles he imported for distribution to the local government education authorities under the World Bank-assisted primary education programme.

The former NPEC boss is accused of not only choosing a different insurance firm, but of unilaterally approving the payment of N81,121,243.41 as premium.

The other alleged sins of Sambo include spending the sum of N70, 8,404.56 to rehabilitate and relocate to the present site of the commission, N62,069, 370.43 in furnishing offices and residential quarters of senior staff of the commission, and N19,114,500 on printing of files for personnel audit without the approval of the relevant authorities.

To Idris, the contract for the printing of carbonised forms was the most scandalous. According to him, Sambo not only paid Nicouct Services Nigeria Ltd. the sum of N11,358 ,750 out of the total contract sum of N15,145,000, but also awarded the contract the same day the company submitted its tender. Also being counted against Sambo is the fact that to publicize the "good work" he was doing, he spent N27,164,124.25 in 1996 alone.

The summary of government's case against Sambo is that primary schools have remained what they were before his appointment, despite the release of about N32 billion to the commission between 1994 and September 1996. According to the findings of the audit panel that probed the commission, more than N1.1 billion was invested in commercial and merchant banks while until this year, government policy was that its agencies should bank with the central bank. The panel observed that as a result of this practice, the commission was in the habit of releasing funds to state primary education boards late.

That may well be so. But, according to Sambo's supporters, the question which Liman must answer is, why did he fail to inaugurate the governing board of the commission, which would have served as a check on Sambo ? Why, indeed ?


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 17, 1997


Nigeria;
Their Own Agenda


BYLINE: Wisdom Dike, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Lagos - Ask any member of the five political parties in Rivers and Bayelsa states and he will tell you that his attention for now is focussed on next month's local government election. But in reality, many top politicians in both states are looking beyond the polls to see how their future ambitions could be realised. The party big-wigs are scheming to ensure that their candidates win the ultimate prize at the state level - the governorship ticket.

In the Rivers State chapter of the Democratic Party of Nigeria, the State Election Committee headed by G.U. Ake is seen as an instrument set up by a group within the party to ensure that only their favoured candidates secure the party's nod to contest the local government election, with the ultimate aim to smoothen the gubernatorial path of a particular aspirant. 

Ake, deputy chairman of Rivers DPN, is accused of setting rigid standards for chairmanship aspirants in the party. Among the conditions for clearance is that an aspirant's involvement in community development must be visible. Falling short in this regard, many aspirants have back-pedalled, giving way to stronger politicians whose performances in community development were adjudged good.

Eager to sweep the polls, the DPN in the state has inaugurated a campaign committee with Uche Secondus as chairman. Secondus told Theweek that the committee's mandate is to mobilise its members and the electorate to vote massively for the DPN. The initiative is being supervised by Peter Odili, controversial national secretary of the party and a governorship aspirant who may end up as the greatest beneficiary of the intra-party schemings.

In the United Nigerian Congress Party, Rufus Ada-George, former governor of Rivers State, and Sergeant Awuse, national organising secretary, are still enmeshed in a game of wits. All the aspirants for the council election within the party have found support in either men.

As for the Grassroots Democratic Movement, chairmanship and councillorship positions have been zoned among the geo-political groups in the local government areas in)((expnd3(expndtw15(cf0 an attempt to check intra-party squabbles. The party leadership is said to have adopted this strategy to curb attempts by some party stalwarts to manipulate the nomination process in favour of certain individuals. In Port Harcourt local government, the GDM has zoned the party chairmanship to Ogbuanabali. In doing this, it is relying on the popularity of Chike Nyeche-Woluchor, a former chairman of the council, to win the election.

This plan has created more problems for the ambition of Aleruchi Williams, immediate past chairman of Port Harcourt local government, who resigned his position last December to contest the council polls on the platform of the Congress for National Consensus. Williams received the greatest shock of his life shortly after his resignation when his gift of seven bags of rice and two goats to his community was rejected by the youths, who accused him of neglecting his community while in office.

In Bayelsa State, the big political players in all the parties are said to be sponsoring different aspirants to consolidate their grounds for the governorship election. In the UNCP, the gubernatorial aspirants include Tuesday Kemeagbeye, forme r speaker of Rivers State House of Assembly; Inatimi Spiff, ex-secretary to Rivers State government; and Anderson Eseimokumoh, a first republic politician and businessman. In all, 15 governorship aspirants from the various parties have indicated interest in the Bayelsa Government House.

In Rivers State, 10 political top-notchers have extended their tentacles in the five political parties for the gubernatorial race. Among them are C.D. Orike, a former attorney-general in the state, Awuse, Nyeche-Woluchor, Dominic Anucha, Odili, Andrew Uchendu and Sampson Ngerebara. Apart from setting up formidable structures,these aspirants have embarked on tours of the local government areas as part of efforts to sell themselves to the electorate.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


237 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 17, 1997


Nigeria;
A New Opposition Platform


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1240 words


 

Lagos - Will Nigeria really have an alternative government next month? This is a question which Nigerians at home and abroad may have to grapple with for some weeks. The question becomes necessary following the commencement by pro- democracy activists based in Europe and America, of moves to set up a legislative body to make laws for Nigeria.

Bolaji Akinyemi, a prominent member of the external wing of the National Democratic Coalition, had last week disclosed that the coalition in conjunction with the National Liberation Council of Nigeria and about 26 other pro-democracy groups in Nigeria, Europe and the United States would set up a 100-member parliament with full legislative powers on matters affecting the country. Akinyemi said that the assembly, the composition of which remains shadowy, was billed to be inaugurated next month. The former external affairs minister explained that the setting up of the legislative body is borne out of the need for practical steps to be taken to facilitate the end to military governance in Nigeria. "Logic," he said in a British Broadcasting Corporation interview, "stops at a particular point and practicality had to take over." 

Akinyemi claimed that an alternative voice of democracy that cannot be located within Nigeria has become inevitable. Without giving a concise working scope of the parliament, he maintained that the touchy issue of the governmental system and, by extension, the mode of constitution Nigeria should operate, would fall under the jurisdiction of the parliament. His words: "Issues to be discussed under the assembly include whether Nigeria should remain a highly centralized or unitary state or remain (a) federal one. "

The idea of alternative government was first mooted in 1995. Nobel Laureate Wole Soyinka, who left Nigeria in 1994 had in June the following year called on the pro-democracy and human rights activists abroad to set up a government in exile as an alternative to the Sani Abacha regime. As he explained later in an interview with the BBC, the government would be exercising authority on behalf of Moshood Abiola, the detained politician presumed to have won the annulled June 12, 1993 presidential election. Espousing a similar idea, Ralph Obioha, at the time NADECO's Canada and US representative, had declared in September at a forum in Washington that the coalition had accepted the challenge to form a government.

After that initial enthusiasm, the idea was left to gather dust on the drawing board. In the interim, the pro-democracy movement got a fillip with the setting up of a new body - NALICON - by Soyinka himself in 1995. Also, a radio station whose transmission point was suspected to be in Europe hit the airwaves on June 11 last year to mark the third anniversary of the ill-fated presidential election. Known originally as Radio Democratic International Nigeria, but later re-christened Radio Kudirat in honour of Abiola's assassinated senior wife, the station debuted with interviews with Soyinka and Anthony Enahoro who himself had earlier in the year fled abroad. Like Akinyemi, the veteran nationalist said that the government-in-exile's preoccupation would be to write a new constitution for Nigeria. He pointed out that apart from the 1959 constitution, all other constitutions had been imposed on the country by military regimes. To this end, Enahoro continued, the parliament would seek to restructure Nigeria along the path of a true federation.

The actualisation of the alternative idea may well be an indication that the pro-democracy activists abroad are moving deeper and deeper into the path of confrontation. Akinyemi's BBC appearance came on the heels of an interview granted to The Washington Times by Abacha, in which the general condemned the activities of the pro-democracy groups, describing them as terrorists.

Said the head of state: "People like Wole Soyinka, they are terrorists." Abacha, like his lieutenants, indicted the pro-democracy activists for the various bomb blasts that rocked the country in the recent past, wondering why people who want democracy should be sabotaging a democratic process. He further alleged that the activists are being aided by foreign elements including non-governmental organisations. Amidst such labellings, analysts say, NADECO may have stepped up the quest for an alternative government to shake off the negative image being carved out for it by the Abacha regime.

Tunde Babawale, a political science teacher at the University of Lagos, is one of those who think this way. According to him, the pro-democracy activists want to "merely emphasise the fact that there is the need to phase out the crisis through dialogue." Babawale told Theweek that the reality of the inauguration of the parliament whenever it takes place is an "indication of political instability within the country and therefore would serve as an irritant or pose problems for the military regime."

Ayo Olanrewaju, a Lagos-based legal practitioner, shares this view. He noted that the proposed parliament would put "heat on the military junta" just as the home-based pro-democracy activists at home are doing. Several attempts made by Theweek to reach NADECO members in Nigeria on the issue last week were not successful.

For now, a lot of questions surround the alternative government project. How effective would the parliament be ? Who will inaugurate the body since Abiola is in detention ? For a body craving for democratic ideals, how democratic and legitimate is such a body? Akinyemi himself provided part of the answer. According to him: "The fact that the new members of the parliament are not elected by universal suffrage does not detract from its legitimacy."

As far as Babawale is concerned, the issue of the legality of the parliament should not even arise as the 1979 constitution is there. He asked: "Who says they can't put the 1979 constitution into use ? What is the constitution guiding the military government ?" The University teacher noted that the Abacha regime itself, like other military governments, has been surviving on the basis of an arbitrary suspension of the constitution.

A clear battle of wits seems imminent. With Abacha's pregnant statement in The Washington Times interview that whether or not he contests the civilian election is for his military constituency to decide, next month may well be Nigeria's ides of March.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

238 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 17, 1997


Burundi;
Costly Resettlement Of Displaced People in Burundi


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi (PANA) - The rehabilitation of victims of the civil war which has been raging in Burundi for three years will cost an estimated 54 billion Burundian francs (271 BF = 1 USD), according to a three-year plan of action prepared by the ministry charged with the resettlement and reintegration of displaced persons and returnees.

The amount includes various expenses on security, humanitarian assistance, housing and household equipment, as well as the purchase of agricultural equipment and inputs for the people, according to the plan. 

It added that the large part of the amount would come from bilateral and multilateral donors.

Priority action would include Sanitation in the existing camps, national and international solidarity campaigns, setting up small income generating projects, training seminars on tolerance, cohabitation and peace.

The document considers security as a necessary condition for the plan to succeed and calls especially on the ministry of national defence to "organize and ensure security in camps for displaced people and around resettlement sites".

Burundi has about 880,000 displaced people, 480,000 inside the country and 400,000 abroad, according to figures released by the ministry.

Since October 1993, the Burundian civil war has claimed about 150,000 lives and caused "large scale" destruction of public and private infrastructure.


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


239 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 17, 1997


Mozambique;
South African Chamber Interested In Niassa Wildlife


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - The South African Chamber for Agricultural Development in Africa (SACADA) has submitted a request to Mozambique to be involved in wildlife management in the Lugenda Valley in the northernmost provinces of Niassa and Cabo Delgado.

The area covers some 3,000 hectares. Sacada envisages the involvement of local communities in managing and exploiting the natural resources of the area. 

"We are interested in this project. The study the South Africans have presented guarantees the sustainable use of forestry and wildlife resources with the involvement of the local people," Aires Aly, the Niassa provincial governor, told the Mozambican News Agency, AIM.

But the national director of forestry and wildlife, Sergio Chitara, was more cautious. He said the Sacada project was "not profound. It's only preliminary."

He said that it would be necessary to provide more detail, and locate the project within the Mozambican government's overall strategy to ensure the correct use of natural resources.

In any case, said Chitara, it was only after the approval of statutes for the Mosagrius Development Corporation, that the Mozambican authorities would be in a position to take a decision on the proposal.

The Mosagrius Corporation is the vehicle for cooperation between Mozambique and South Africa in the entire agricultural, livestock and forestry area. Each of the governments will have 50 percent of the shares.

They will also hold the land on which all agricultural projects will take place. It will have an initial capital of one million U.S. dollars.

Under the Mosagrius programme, South African farmers will farm land in Niassa, particularly in the Lugenda Valley. Hence Sacada's interest in wildlife management in the same area.

An Mozambican official told AIM that the agreement formalizing the Mosagrius Corporation will be signed within a matter of days. He claimed that, after a year's delay, Sacada has finally reacted to the draft Mosagrius statutes presented by the Mozambican side.

"We have to analyze the South African reply before we can sign the document, " the Mozambican said.

Sacada has blamed the Mozambicans, particularly the Investment Promotion Center, for the delays.


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


240 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 17, 1997


Sudan;
Security Forces Recover 180 Stolen Camels


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Sudanese security forces have managed to recover 180 camels stolen by armed gangsters in Western Darfur State, near the border with Chad. INL002 from SSS.074 (970217-18:15) QN PANAINL . PANADKR MSG073G/02E PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PAN(2) The Alwan newspaper said Monday "a joint force from the army, the police and the popular defence forces had recently managed to retrieve 180 camels stolen by armed gangsters form Dareesa in Wadi Salih province in Western Darfur State."

"The joint force pursued the gangsters a week ago, reached and engaged them and killed many of them," it added.

But Alwan did not give the number of gang members killed or say whether the security force suffered any casualties.

Darfur area was scene of a spate of armed robbery during the 1980s, largely attributed to the civil war in neighbouring Chad at the time.

However, a security campaign launched by the government in the early 1990s has reduced the incidence of robbery, the paper said.


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
