February 21, 1997


South Africa;
VERBATIM (Column)


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Johannesburg - ' This is the first time Mrs Machel has appeared with the president at a state function, but they will be appearing together a lot more in the future. '

- An official in President Nelson Mandela's office, after the couple held hands while meeting with members of the Swedish royal family

' The two battalions are trained and are ready to participate. '

- Army Colonel Jaco van As, in reference to South African troops prepared for use in multinational peacekeeping forces

' Naturally it is fucking politics ... with the whole fucking country behind him (Fran ois Pienaar) ... Now I hear that Mluleki George also wants to fucking resign on Friday. It's kaffirs man, it's the fucking NSC, the fucking kaffirs. ' 

- Former Springbok rugby coach Andr' Markgraaff, on the tape that led to his resignation

' A young girl came out of one of the houses, her clothes on fire. She tried to escape. One of the terrorists shot her before she could leave the courtyard. '

- A witness to an Algerian massacre in which 31 people died

' Life in Soweto can only get worse because people with capital are leaving. Who will want to invest here if black people are investing somewhere else? '

- Taxi driver Themba Hlatshwayo, speaking of middle-class people moving out of Soweto

"Words can't describe how I feel. I've been blessed beyond ....."

- Pop star Michael Jackson after his wife Deborah Rowe Jacksopn gave birth to a boy

"Violence in this region has been endemic for some time, but this is on a different scale."

An aid official in the southwestern Angola city of Lubango, after violence pushed 1 000 people from their homes

"We have given the Swaziland government two weeks to address the issues facing the country. It is unfortunate that we have to be so hard on them, but they have shown they are not willing to co-operate."

Morgan Tswangirai, secretary general of the Southern African Trade Union Co- ordinating Council, on plans to join other labour groups in support of the unions in Swaziland

"The situation is extremely volatile. Shoot-at-sight orders have been issued to contain the violence."

Indian state of Tripura home minister Samar Chowdhury, as separatist rebels killed 22 people in remote villages in the state

"I think the police have been marvellous. This is the type of action which the public demands of police and keeps the criminals on the hop."

A shopper at the Rosettenville, Johannesburg supermarket where police gunned down five armed robbers after lying in wait for them

South Africa;
PEOPLE (Column)


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Johannesburg - ARRESTED: Lwendo Hamusankwa, editor of the Zambian independent bi-weekly The Chronicle, detained after publishing a report that arms and ammunition had been stolen from an army barracks on the outskirts of Lusaka

DIED: China's patriarch Deng Xiaoping (92), last seen in public in February 1994, after a stroke; Nora Beloff (78), the first woman political correspondent in Britain, after a short illness; Egyptian Hanem Mohammed Ismail burnt her daughter Mona Youmna Mussa (21), because she wore trousers

ELECTED: Zingile Dingani, Free State MEC for finance and economics, as the new provincial chair of the ANC, by beating the national executive's preference Ivy Matsepe-Casaburri; Bonga Majola to replace !Khoisan X as PAC head in the Gauteng legislature

FOUND: Tug-of-love baby Timothy Funnell, found abandoned a few days after he was snatched from his adoptive father's arms in Malawi

NEGOTIATING: Zairian leader Mobutu Sese Seko and rebel leader Laurent Kabila are expected to begin negotiations in Cape Town to resolve the crisis in Zaire

SCRAPPED: The National Party office of secretary general, which was occupied by Roelf Meyer, to free the negotiator to focus on options for creating a new party

SHOCKED: Mluleki George, on hearing Markgraaff describing him as a "fucking kaffir"

REFUSED: Rightwinger Willem Ratte, arrested for trying to steal weapons from a military base in the North-West, has been refused bail

REJECTED: President Nelson Mandela has rejected pleas from black business leaders to write off pre-1994 unpaid tax, which they said members complied with the political struggle and calls that taxation without representation is tyranny

SUED: Lynn Ingram, who was held for 11 days as the suspected kidnapper of baby Micaela Hunter, is suing the state for unlawful arrest and is claiming R250 000


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997

332 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 21, 1997


South Africa;
ANC 'entrapped' Nat opponents


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

Johannesburg - Stefaans Brummer reports on underhand tactics at the pre- election negotiations

THE African National Congress "deployed women" to compromise its National Party opponents during the pre-1994 negotiations - and entrapped a senior negotiator, a top ANC intelligence official says.

The claim that the ANC's Department of Intelligence and Security (DIS) successfully used the "honeytrap" method - the oldest trick in the book of intelligence plots - corroborates intelligence documents in possession of the Mail & Guardian that say a prominent hardline NP Cabinet member acted as a " mole" for the DIS as it had "a hold" over him which was "directly related to (his) personal life".

The mole, repeatedly referred to in the documents by the alias "C Witkoppen" , is disclosed in one, dated April 6 1993, as the NP minister. The DIS official, now a senior member of one of the country's newly amalgamated intelligence agencies, independently gave the same name. 

While NP and ANC negotiations this week said the allegations were untrue or unlikely, the intelligence official said the minister had been one of the " successes" of the ANC spy agency's efforts to compromise NP negotiators. "We had a job to do, and we did it," he said.

Speaking on condition of anonymity, he said the minister had been trapped in about October 1992 - shortly after the "record of understanding" between the ANC and the NP, which heralded the final phase of negotiations that led to South Africa's first democratic elections in April 1994. He claimed another senior NP negotiator, whom he did not name, was also "compromised" when the DIS learnt of his gay activities.

But he said the plot had soon outlived its usefulness when the government's then- National Intelligence Service (NIS) got wind of it and told DIS members: "We know what you are up to."

He said he could not disclose whether the "mole" had in fact been useful to the ANC.

The former NP minister is one of the central figures in a storm raging in the NP and Afrikaner circles after recent accusations that former President FW de Klerk had "caved in" to ANC demands at the negotiations table.

The former minister this week claimed the documents were a disinformation plot against him, but did not speculate who may have been behind it. He dismissed the DIS official's "confirmation": "I am not going to talk about such nonsense with you; you are wasting my time."

The documents implicating him are from a string of intelligence reports composed by former Civil Co-operation Bureau agent Eugene Riley, who died in an unsolved shooting in early 1994. In 1993, he was a freelance agent for the NIS. The M&G last month published details from the Riley file which implicated a group of DIS members in a wider conspiracy to assassinate South African Communist Party leader Chris Hani.

Documents on the "mole", like the Hani documents, are based on information given to Riley by "Ramon", described in the documents as an ANC member. Both sets of documents were addressed to "P", whom the M&G has identified as Riley's NIS handler.

The "mole" documents include the following:

* March 29 1993: "Disinformation" relating to "a concept of how the negotiations are going to be jeopardised if the Transkei's sovereignty is to be invaded" has been sent to the government negotiating team through mole "C Witkoppen" as part of "Operation Puma".

The disinformation exercise was to test the government stance on the Transkei, its military leader Bantu Holomisa and the Azanian People's Liberation Army - as the ANC armed wing, Umkhonto weSizwe, needed to know the government stance for its own strategic planning purposes.

The disinformation was passed to "Witkoppen", in typed form, by means of a " dead letter box" in Pretoria.

* April 6 1993: "A photograph and the name of the 'mole' C Witkoppen alias (name withheld) has been obtained from the source 'Ramon'." (Attached to this document is a photocopied photograph of the "mole".)

* April 9 1993: "All information received from C Witkoppen is sent by the abovementioned to specific 'dead facsimiles' ... The abovementioned fax machines are housed in covert offices/houses in Rivonia, Sandton, Parkhurst, Houghton, et cetera ...

"The source claims that the ANC's hold over the mole is directly related to the mole's personal life."

The documents contain obvious inaccuracies. In some of them, "Witkoppen" is referred to as "a mole in the office of Roelf Meyer" - an historical inaccuracy.

The April 9 report also says "Witkoppen" had already been in contact with his ANC handler, "Eric", for three years. This contradicts the DIS member's account that the minister had been "compromised" in about October 1992.

The minister played a prominent role in the Codesa II negotiations, which ended inconclusively in May 1992. Negotiations between the ANC and the NP only restarted after the Bisho massacre, when the "record of understanding" was reached between the two parties that September.

The minister was not on the government's full-time negotiating team when multi-party negotiations restarted in early April 1993, but he would still have had access through his membership of Cabinet.

The obvious inaccuracies in Riley's intelligence reports can be explained in two ways: intelligence chains are notoriously unreliable and mistakes may have been made by any of the actors, including Ramon's informants, Ramon himself, or Riley.

The second explanation: the documents are badly composed fabrications - although their apparent origination with Riley, who died more than three years ago, makes it unlikely they are recent fabrications. This scenario also fails to explain the corroboration from the intelligence official.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


333 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 21, 1997


South Africa;
Meyer Hunts Black NP Leader


BYLINE: Marion Edmunds, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Johannesburg - Roelf Meyer set off into the political wilderness this week to seek a black Messiah to lead a new movement capable of challenging the African National Congress in 1999, and salvaging the moderate faction of a fragmenting National Party.

Talent-spotting for a new black leader, Meyer told the Mail & Guardian this week, would be one of his main tasks - one he can now focus on after effectively abandoning leadership of the NP to hardliners.

He is accompanied in his quest by five trusted moderates: Sheila Camerer, Paulina Cupido, Nic Koornhof, John Mavuso and David Malatsi. 

They are to move around the country, talking to influential figures, church leaders and businessmen to attract those who want to create a strong opposition to the ANC to prevent it dominating politics in the 21st century.

Meyer was freed up for the task on Wednesday when party leader FW de Klerk stripped him of his secretary general post.

The NP has already consulted Professor Frederick van Zyl Slabbert, a man experienced in opposition politics, for advice.

This week he described the NP's dream of a new black moderate opposition leader as the stuff of "political fantasies".

Van Zyl Slabbert believes Meyer's journey into the unknown may presage the end of the NP, with a loss of its current voters to the left and the right, and a small core in the Western Cape hanging on to the hardline attitudes of conservative whites and coloureds.

If his search to find a great black hope fails, Meyer may have to lead the new movement himself. But commentators doubt he has the right touch.

"He is a good man, perhaps too much of a gentleman, and he has done an important job. But I don't think he has the personality to be the leader of a party ... they don't need a new leader or a new name - they need a new nature, " political scientist Professor Sampie Terreblanche said.

Meyer's attempts to change the party's "nature" have been hampered by the success of his colleagues in the Western Cape, under Kriel's leadership.

Kriel and his allies are appealing to a segregated audience - undermining Meyer's real chances of setting up a multi-racial future for the party.

By sending Meyer out - or allowing him to be pushed - De Klerk is forcing his party to speak in two voices: one of sectoral interest, the other of a multi-racial opposition. The NP has had great experience doing the former, but very little in articulating the latter.

What must be even more upsetting to Meyer is that the Democratic Party and the Inkatha Freedom Party have appeared unsympathetic to the notion of a new movement, preferring instead to flirt with the ANC.

Meyer remains optimistic: "The basic point is the need to make a start at forming a new political movement, to take an initiative, and there are far more signs now that people are interested than they were. Success breeds success, we must get the ball rolling."


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 21, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 106 on the Great Lakes (02/21)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1667 words


 

Nairobi - Efforts continued today in Cape Town, South Africa, to bring the warring parties in Zaire together for talks. Parks Mankahlana, spokesman for President Nelson Mandela, said the South African government was not releasing any details, reports Reuters. After speculation yesterday over the first face- to-face talks between the government and the rebels, the South African government is trying to contain expectations by emphasising that the talks will be "a long process".

A spokesman for Laurent-Desire Kabila, leader of the rebel Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire, said that Kabila was only ready for talks in South Africa "with people who are mandated to make a decision". The spokesman, Deo Bugera, nevertheless said that the ADFL was scaling down their military offensive to assist efforts to start up peace talks. Kabila has previously insisted on meeting with Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko. Ailing President Mobutu is due back in France tonight, report news agencies. 

The prospect of face-to-face talks in South Africa neutralises a rebel deadline of February 21 (today), wherein the ADFL threatened to go on a major offensive unless Kinshasa agreed to talk. Fighting intensified at the begining of this week, with the Zairean government bombing rebel-held towns and the rebels threatening military bases and air-strips. Fighting appears to have lulled since Thursday, when at least four diplomatic peace initiatives came to the fore (see IRIN Update 105), although representatives of the Zairean crisis government in Kinshasa have continued to issue threats of more air-raids. Earlier this week, some reports indicated that the government troops had pushed back rebel forces between Lubutu and Walikale.

* According to state-owned KBC, President Moi of Kenya announced today that a major summit would be held in Nairobi on 12th March "to discuss conflict resolutions in various parts of Africa". The report did not specify if the March 12th summit would discuss the Zairean crisis, nor that it was the anticipated "Nairobi III" summit. The "peace quartet" of Foreign Minsters from Kenya, South Africa, Tanzania and Zimbabwe said yesterday Zairean Ministers of Defence, Foreign Affairs and Prime Minister Kengo wa Dondo in Kinshasa had expressed a willingness to attend the "Nairobi III" conference, but had said that foreign troops must first be withdrawn so that the summit would be "a forum to discuss the future of Zaire". The Foreign Ministers said their respective heads of state had to be briefed before the date and venue of "Nairobi III" could be announced.

Although there is general consensus on the need for a "Nairobi III" summit - based on a five-point peace plan proposed by Joint OAU/UN Special Representative for the Great Lakes Region, Mohamed Sahnoun, and endorsed by the UN Security Council, there is debate about who will participate and what the agenda should be. The official stance of the Zairean crisis government has consistently been that foreign troops withdraw before peace talks proceed. The Zairean government accuses Rwanda, Uganda and Burundi of being involved in the conflict; an accusation the countries deny. The rebel ADFL, on its part, says any attempt to resolve the crisis without ADFL representation is unacceptable. The first two regional heads of state summits on the crisis were hosted by President Moi in Nairobi - but rebels have since accused him of being partisan.

* Yesterday evening Joint OAU/UN Special Representative for the Great Lakes Region, Mohamed Sahnoun, met in Nairobi with UN Regional Humanitarian Coordinator Martin Griffiths before flying on to Geneva. Martin Griffiths said the various peace initiatives were an important development and that " the concerted movement towards cessation of hostilities should aid progress on a Nairobi III summit, and also help vital humanitarian access".

* Food arrival by truck this week at the Tingi-Tingi camps increased food availability. Trucks carrying 410 tons took four days to reach Tingi-Tingi from Kisangani - up to now, food deliveries have depended on daily flights from Kisangani, which have been hampered by obstruction and fuel appropriation by authorities. One UN aid worker said getting food to Tingi- Tingi is "not a logistical nightmare, it's a political nightmare". According to WFP, the food is now being distributed at sector level organised by women's committees. Lack of staff and an implementing partner means food must be distributed and monitored by refugees. This method tries to ensure that food reaches children and families. However, concern remains that armed Rwandan militia receive food earmarked for genuine refugees; an issue that can only be resolved through separation.

* The speaker of Burundi's parliament, Leonce Ngendakumana, said in a press conference yesterday that negotiations were needed because "war does not lead to peace", reports AFP. He said hundreds of citizens were being killed either by armed groups or by the army, and there were arbitary arrests and harassment of people. He said the effects of sanctions was to make Burundi " cut off from the world" and that Burundi needed to find a means of dealing with the crippling regional sanctions. Ngendakumana faces legal proceedings related to the 1993 upheavals, and was banned last December from leaving the country. He was also recently arrested after criticizing the regroupment policy. The Burundian authorities have re-grouped in camps well over 100,000 people in rebel-affected areas; disease in the camps has increased, according to the World Health Organisation, because of insanitary conditions and lack of shelter.

* The International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda in Arusha delayed the first hearing in the trial of Theoneste Bagosora after the defence counsel failed to appear in court. Theoneste Bagasora, cabinet director in Rwanda's former defence ministry, is believed to have directed events during the first few days of massacres in Rwanda in April 1994 and is widely considered the most wanted genocide suspect indicted by the Tribunal. The next hearing is set for March 7th.

* According to diplomatic sources, insecurity in Rwanda is "of major concern". Killings, ambushes, and harassment of civilians by armed groups, have increased dramatically since the massive repatriation. Travel for UN agencies from Kigali to western Prefectures needs a government escort. According to one humanitarian source, the need for government escort makes it difficult for UNHRFOR to impartially monitor human rights abuses.

* Amnesty International, the London-based human rights organisation, accused Zairean soldiers of gross abuse of human rights, saying retreating soldiers had raped and killed with impunity. It called on the Zairean government to respect human rights, and called on governments to stop supplying weapons and military personnel to armed groups in the region. Independent human rights monitoring in rebel-held areas has yet to be established.

* While there are now large groups of refugees now accessible to humanitarian agencies in eastern Zaire at Tingi-Tingi, Kalima and Punia, totalling an estimated 193,000, UNHCR calculates that by the end of January 1997, as many as 189,000 more Rwandans and 39,000 other Burundians are still unaccounted for. The breakdown of figures - which refer only to refugees in Zaire from Rwanda and Burundi - is as follows. In order to save space, we have compressed the table as follows:

Category: Total figure (Figure for Rwandans/Figure for Burundians)

Total refugees before the conflict: 1,258,158 (1,111,232/146,945)

Total returns to country of origin up to end-January 97: 815,996 (726, 164/100,000)

Arrivals in third countries: 10,168 (2,168/8,000)

Remainder: 432,013 (385,068/46,945)

Portion of remainder located: 193,000 (187,000/6,000)

Portion of remainder unaccounted for: 229,265 (189,590/39,675)

These figures are of course best estimates, but take into account estimated births and deaths. They also correct a slip on returnee numbers contained in IRIN Update 101.

Nairobi, February 21 1997 16:10 GMT (ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)

Africa News


February 21, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Frenchman Clinches Soccer Coaching Job In Nigeria


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Frenchman Phillipe Troussier has been named foreign technical adviser to Nigerian national soccer teams after he edged out two other European rivals.

The chairman of the Nigerian Football Association, retired retired Col. Abdulmumuni Aminu, announced after the association's marathon meeting Thursday that Troussier was chosen because he was one of the three candidates in employment.

The unsuccessful candidates were Kalman Meszoley from Hungary and German Burkard Ziese. 

Troussier, currently coaching a club in Morocco, replaces Johannes Bonfrere, the Dutchman who ditched Nigeria after leading the country to an Olympic soccer victory in August, 1996.

Aminu said in addition to an undisclosed sign-on fee, Troussier would be paid 10,000 U.S. dollars a month, 2,500 more than Bonfrere got.

Trousier, 42, is on record as one of a few European coaches that could boast of a grasp on African football.

After handling several clubs in Cote d'Ivoire, he took over the country's national team the "Elephants" into the African qualifying series of the 1994 world cup.

He becomes the 18th foreign coach in Nigeria, beginning with Englishman Les Courtier, who in 1956 handled the country's national team, then known as the " Red Devils."

But the sport has since grown in importance and popularity in Nigeria, such that soccer buffs consider it a unifying factor in the multi-ethnic, culturally diverse and populous nation of some 100 million people.

A delighted Troussier, commenting from Rabbat on his selection says "it is an honor."

He pledged to do his best with Nigeria's array of talented soccer players scattered across the globe.

His first crucial task will be leading Nigeria to qualify for the world cup in France in 1998.

Meanwhile, Troussier's selection has been hailed by a cross-section of Nigerians.

Tormer Nigerian international Thompson Oliha, who played for Cote d'Ivoire's Africa Sports during Troussier's stint in that country, said the Frenchman was capable of results.

Taiwo Ogunjobi, manager of Shooting Stars, a division one club based in Ibadan, western Nigeria, called Troussier's appointment a good choice by the football association.

He said soccer administrators in the country should now settle down to serious work because it would be a "calamity" if Nigeria failed to qualify for France '98.


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


336 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 21, 1997


Mozambique;
At least 1,500 Mozambicans Rescued From Floods


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Rescue operations in flood-stricken parts of central Mozambique ended Thursday after some 1,500 people had been flown to safety from areas of the Zambezi valley.

The operation was conducted with fixed wing aircraft and helicopters of the Zimbabwean and South African air forces. They also carried essential aid such as medicines and school materials to areas that were cut off from the district capitals. 

Meanwhile, at least 20,000 people from Mozambican provinces of Tete and Zambezia are reported to have taken refuge in neighbouring Malawi, in the region of Sange.

Little information is immediately available on these people but the Mozambican official relief body, the D.P.C.C.N., says it will send a team to assess the needs of these Mozambicans.

The agency's national director, Silvano Langa, said that because of still rising water levels of the Zambezi River and its subsidiaries, the number of people destitute may increase. For this reason, the agency said it was difficult to estimate the quantity and type of aid needed.

"But we will need at least 2,000 tons of seeds to distribute to people as they resettle. We are aware that thousands of families will need tools because they have lost everything in the floods," he said.

The Mozambican government, he said, will meet Monday with donor organizations and United Nations agencies. It will be asking for emergency aid for flood victims in the four central provinces.

"We do not yet have the estimate of our needs but the main concern that we will take to the meeting has to do with activities to be carried out after the floods. We are talking of roads and bridges, medicines, chemical products for water treatment and for agriculture but we also have serious needs for food and tools," he said.

Another task that the government proposes to undertake is to try and persuade people to stay away from areas vulnerable to floods.

"They may have their fields there but we are going to discourage the building of houses," he said.


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 21, 1997


Liberia;
Calls For Support For West African Peace Monitors


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 827 words


 

UNITED NATIONS, New York (PANA) - Nigeria's foreign affairs minister, Tom Ikimi, and the United Nations have called for the strengthening of the West African Peace Monitoring Group, or Ecomog, as the peace process in Liberia enters perhaps a last and crucial stage.

Ikimi told the second ministerial meeting of the special conference to support the peace process Thursday that the Nigerian-led peacekeeping force remained the key to providing adequate security in Liberia, particularly during the May general elections.

"It is important that we give due consideration to the need to sustain the peace momentum now prevailing in the country,"he said. "Ecomog should, therefore, be strengthened and provided with adequate resources." 

The meeting was attended by representatives of donor countries, member states of the Economic Community of West African states who sent the peace monitors to Liberia, and the United Nations system.

It was organized jointly by Nigeria, which currently holds the chairmanship of Ecowas, the United States and the Netherlands. It was hosted by the U.N.

U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan presided at the meeting, which he said was not a pledging conference.

Ikimi, who arrived in New York on Wednesday, said that although the original projection for Ecomog to be able to cover Liberia effectively was 18, 000 men, the force was currently 8,980-strong.

Therefore, he called for help to airlift troops that had been pledged by Benin, Burkina Faso, Gambia, Niger, and to enhance Ecomog's capability, in line with the current effort to ferry troops from Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana, Mali to Liberia.

Ikimi, who was accompanied on his trip by the special envoy of the Ecowas chairman for Liberia, Balarabe Balewa, said that Germany, the Netherlands and the United States had helped Ecomog. The United States Air Force began airlifting additional Ghanaian troops to Liberia, Tuesday.

However, Ikimi said that the force still suffered "substantial inadequacies in order to meet any eventualities and cope with the demands of the upcoming elections."

He called for a better coordination within the U.N. system to ensure the provision of emergency relief and support facilities, and a streamlining of the role of the world body and its partners to remove duplication and waste.

He told the meeting of the decisions by the Ecowas Committee of Nine in Liberia and that so far 28,000 men have been disarmed. But the momentum, he said, had to be maintained.

"It would be a wise option for us all, including genuine potential donors, to hold firmly on the present ray of hope and not let it slip by," he said.

Supporting this, the U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan warned against complacency in the pursuit of peace in Liberia, in spite of recent positive developments in the country.

"While acknowledging the considerable progress that has been made, we must now intensify rather than relax our efforts," Annan said.

Annan also called for the provision of additional resources to Ecomog, the reintegration of demobilized fighters into the society and reactivation of basic institutions of governments and society.

He said, also, that the conditions for free and fair elections must be created and that any effort to disrupt the peace process must be resisted by all concerned.

"We have the means, let us now clearly demonstrate -- both to the people of Liberia and to ourselves -- that we have the political will to do what needs to be done," he said.

The Abuja Peace Agreement is generally regarded as the last-ditch effort to bring a lasting peace to Liberia, where an estimated 150,000 people have been killed in seven years of factional fighting and a quarter of the country's estimated 2.82 million people were refugees.

Previous peace accords, including the Yamoussoukro agreement of 1991, the Cotonou Agreement of 1993 and the 1994 Akosombo agreement, have failed to end the fighting.


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.
