363 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 24, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Former President Called A Homosexual Rapist In Court


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 880 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Alleged homosexual activities of former Zimbabwean President Rev. Canaan Banana, with his ex-aide-de-camp, were made bare in the High Court on Monday with a judge recommending investigations into the sodomy practices.

"No one is seen to be above the law," High Court Judge Justice Bartlett said.

Sodomy is a criminal offence in Zimbabwe.

Former Police Inspector Jefta Dube told the court that he was homosexually abused by Banana at State House, the official residence of the president, from 1983 to 1986. 

Bartlett, who sentenced Dube to 10 years in prison for the 1995 murder of a police constable during a music concert at Gwanzura Stadium in Harare, said the allegations could not be dismissed as not being "reasonably possible."

The judge found Dube guilty of murder with actual intent but with diminished responsibility after relying on the evidence of two psychiatrists who testified that the accused suffered from post-traumatic stress disorder.

Dube had also given his evidence "clearly" on how he was haunted by his forced homosexual escapades with Banana resulting in his excessive intake of alcohol and drugs.

Judge Bartlett said that stress, coupled with Dube's drug and heavy drinking, could not be ruled out as contributing to his three-year subjection to sodomy by Banana.

That evidence was corroborated by former Senior Assistant Police Commissioner John Chademana. He testified that Dube had reported to his police superiors that Banana was sodomizing him.

Dube also complained to retired army and Air Force of Zimbabwe commanders Solomon Mujuru and Josiah Tungamirai.

Chademana testified that Dube's report, which culminated in his being granted audience with Vice President Simon Muzenda (then deputy prime minister), came in the wake of numerous intelligence reports about Banana's " homosexual activities from many parts of the country."

Judge Bartlett described corroborative evidence by Patience Mleya, Dube's aunt, as being a "transparently honest feeling of the helplessness of the accused."

However, Bartlett said that Dube's evidence could not be rejected as not being "unreasonably possible." The court could have been better placed to make a factual finding if the state had summoned Banana to give evidence.

Dube described how he awoke in State House one morning after being apparently drugged to find his trousers off, sperms between his legs and Banana telling him, "We have helped ourselves."

The serving president, Robert Mugabe, has unwaveringly criticized homosexuals perverts and sodomites, saying they were "worse than dogs and pigs" and undeserving of rights of any kind.

A prominent international statesman Banana, 61, was Zimbabwe's first black president at independence in 1980. He is married with four children and is currently a professor of theology at the University of Zimbabwe. He retired as Zimbabwean president in 1987 to pave way for Mugabe (then prime minister) following the introduction of the executive presidency.

Dube shot and killed the Police Constable Patrick Mashure at the musical concert in September 1995 after the deceased had questioned him on why he was urinating in public.

His defence was that Mashure had provoked him by asking: "Iwe ngochani mukadzi wa Banana urikutundireyi ipapo (Shona vernacular for, "hey you homosexual and wife of Banana why are you urinating there?)."

His mind, befuddled with alcohol and marijuana compounded the trauma from the alleged homosexual scenes with Banana, Dube drew his pistol and shot Mashure in the head.

Advocate Byron Hove, who said while it was his client's wish to have Banana investigated for sodomy, told the court that Dube would sue the former president.

Judge Bartlett granted Dube leave to appeal against conviction and sentence after the lawyer successfully argued that the conviction "goes against the weight of the evidence."

Bartlett also said that the two psychiatrists should treat Dube for post- traumatic stress disorder.


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


364 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 24, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Anyaoko Urges African Leaders To Focus On Democracy


BYLINE: Prof Malema, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 947 words


 

GABORONE, Botswana (PANA) - A two-day Commonwealth meeting on democracy began Monday with an appeal to the leaders of its African members to focus on issues of democracy.

The two-day Round Table on Democracy and Good Governance, between African ruling and opposition parties, will discuss the essential and universal ingredients of democracy.

Resolutions of the meeting will be presented Wednesday to the heads of states' two-day retreat in the northern Botswana town of Kasane.

The summit is expected to be attended by the presidents of Botswana, Gambia, Kenya, Malawi, Mozambique, Sierra Leone, South Africa, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe. Other representatives will be sent by Cameroon, Ghana, Lesotho, Namibia, Seychelles, Swaziland and Uganda. 

Opening the meeting, Commonwealth Secretary-General Emeka Anyaoko urged both the ruling and opposition parties to work together to consolidate democracy in Africa.

"I hope that in your deliberations you will pay particular attention to the discussing the essential and the universal ingredients of democracy and consider the structure and processes, including the constitutions, needed to support democracy and develop a democratic culture," he said.

Other factors which had to be assessed, he said, were the proper relations between the ruling and the opposition parties and move away from the "winner take all" politics.

"We have to examine the impediments in the way of democracy in Africa, whether ethnicity or religion, the denial of human rights or the politics of exclusion," he said.

Meanwhile, Zimbabwe Foreign Minister Stan Mudenge, who chairs the Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group on the Harare Declaration, said Monday that the body, which met in London early February, resolved that Gambia, Nigeria and Sierra Leone must speed up measures to embrace democratic principles.

Addressing journalists in Harare, Mudenge said following its visits to the three countries, the group discovered that the countries had partially implemented the recommendations of the declaration but that violations of human rights were still evident.

He said while Nigeria, which was suspended from the Commonwealth in 1995 for the execution of writer Ken Saro Wiwa and other political opponents, had made great strides in improving its human rights record, it still continued to detain opponents without trial.

The ministerial group, he said, also noted that the continued exclusion of a significant part of the Gambia's civilian leadership from the political life of the country continued to be detrimental to the cause of democracy in that country.

"In the meantime, the group welcomed the conclusion of the electoral phase of the transition in the Gambia marked by the parliamentary elections" of January 2, 1997, he said.

The ministerial group was formed in 1995 as Commonwealth mechanism for dealing with serious or persistent violations of the declaration principles arrived at in 1991.

In a related development, Anyaoko was quoted from London as saying participants hope to evaluate the state of Africa's fledgling democracies and "consider the best way forward" for Africa.

"It is hoped that the best practice will rub off and bad practice will be exposed for what it is," he said.

The meeting, he said was "unique" and part of the Commonwealth's continued efforts to give greater support to the democratic process in Africa.

Africa still has autocratic regimes but it has made progress over the past decade in planting the seeds of democracy.

In 1990, nine African Commonwealth states were governed by military regimes or dictatorships. Now, only Nigeria remains. It was suspended from the organization because of its human rights record.

South Africa's white minority regime gave way to a multiparty democracy in April 1994, resulting in the election of Nelson Mandela as president and his African National Congress as the governing party in an multiracial democracy.

To the praise of the international community, countries such as Ghana, Malawi, Mozambique and Uganda also held relatively peaceful democratic polls after 1990, while Angola recently ended a decades-long civil war.

On the negative side, the ministerial group, last week, expressed "serious doubts" about the credibility of Gambia's presidential poll in September 1996. It was won by Yahya Jammeh who, as an army lieutenant, sized power in a July 1994 coup.


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


365 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 24, 1997


Libya;
Salim Reaffirms Africa's Support For Libya


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - The Secretary-General of the Organization of African Unity, Salim Ahmed Salim, has reaffirmed Africa's support for, and solidarity with, Libya which has had to cope with the air, diplomatic and military sanctions imposed on her by the United Nations Security Council since 1992, over the Lockerbie affair.

"All African states have called for an end to the sanctions imposed on Libya and for a peaceful settlement of the Lockerbie crisis in conformity with international law," he said. 

Salim was giving a news conference Sunday in Tripoli where he is attending the 65th annual meeting of the organization's Council of Ministers. The four- day meeting began Monday.

He said that the OAU and the Arab League were discussing measures to settle this crisis. He did not elaborate.

"We think it is time to lift the sanctions imposed on Tripoli in view of the several positive steps taken by Tripoli towards the peaceful settlement of this affair," he said.

The holding of the meeting in Tripoli, he said, clearly attested to the level of African support for Libya.

Salim also called for urgent action by African countries to resolve all conflicts such as the crisis in the Great Lakes region and other inter- African conflicts.

The organization has a department -- the O.A.U. Organ For Conflict Resolution, Prevention and Management -- charged with this task.

Salim said that Africa's strength lay in the unity of its peoples who now have to meet all challenges in a rapidly changing world, which leaves room only for big economic blocs and large political groupings.

He appealed for the settlement of all ethnic problems and conflicts plaguing the continent through mechanisms established by Africans. If not, he said, Africa's development would be compromised.


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


366 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 24, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
African Ministerial Council Meeting Opens In Tripoli


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - The 65th ministerial council session of the Organization of African Unity (OAU) opened Monday in Tripoli, the Libyan capital, with a preparatory meeting of ambassadors and other plenipotentiaries of the 53-member body.

Focusing on pressing political, economic and social issues bedeviling Africa, it is the first time the council meeting is being held outside the organization's headquarters in Addis Ababa.

This, officials of the organization say, is in solidarity with Libya, which is under a United States-sponsored United Nations sanctions. 

The fourth ambassadorial meeting precedes the Ministerial Council session, which begins Wednesday.

Top on the agenda is the situation in Africa's Great Lakes region, the conflict in Burundi, Liberia, Somalia and the U.N. sanctions on Libya.

Regional economic integration, to be achieved through the African Economic Community, agreements on border trade and inter-African economic cooperation are some of the other agenda topics.

In his report covering the period June 1996 to February 1997, the O.A.U. secretary general, Salim Ahmed Salim, said there was need for a redoubling of efforts at solving the problems that hindered Africa's political and socio- political progress.

The meeting is also considering the O.A.U's budgetary matters in relation to the arrears of 56.2 million U.S. dollars owed by member states in assessed contributions.

The financial crisis facing the dakar-based Pan African News Agency, PANA, an O.A.U organ, is also listed for discussion.

In his introductory remarks, Salim noted that non-payment of contributions by O.A.U. member states was frustrating tangible efforts at making PANA financially autonomous through the UNESCO recovery plan.

The agenda also includes a number of legal and financial issues to be reviewed by expert committees in addition to items proposed by member states.

This is the first major conference in the Libyan capital since the O.A.U.'s twice postponed summit in 1982 over the lack of a quorum.

The Libyan authorities are making great political capital of the event in the elaborate preparations, apparently to compensate delegates who have endured the inconvenience of a tedious journey to Tripoli because of the U.N. air embargo on the North African country.

The Green Square, commemorating the great Al-Fateh revolution, and other landmarks in the Libyan capital are wearing a new look welcoming delegates to the O.A.U. meeting.

The pro-government press has hailed the meeting as prove of the "confidence the African states are putting in the Great Jamahiriya and recognition of its pioneering role in Africa."


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


367 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 25, 1997


Business and Finance;
It's Boomtime For Cape's Bed & Breakfast Industry


BYLINE: Chene Blignaut, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 800 words


 

Cape Town - Predictions of a tourism boom, coupled with hopes of quick returns, have led to a mushrooming of guesthouses and bed-and-breakfast establishments in the Western Cape.

Whether you call it informal, specialised or alternative accommodation, the phenomenon has translated into one of the country's fastest growing industries, with the Western Cape leading the race.

Industry experts believe hoteliers have reason for concern at the trend, which seems to be supported by reports of lower occupancy by some hotel groups in the past season. 

In the city alone, the number of guesthouses and B & Bs is believed to have tripled in the past year to more than 500 And the suburbs, not traditionally tourist hotspots, are not far behind.

Although statistics are hard to come by in this industry, experts believe the number of guesthouses and B & Bs has doubled in the southern suburbs in recent years, while the Tygerberg area has staked its claim on the tourism map with more than 100 establishments of this kin

Further afield, in the popular tourist towns of Hermanus, Montagu and Stellenbosch, there is hardly a street without one or more guesthouses, B & Bs and self-catering units. But the burgeoning industry is not without its problems. Paramount among these is the maintenance of acceptable standards.

Tourist accommodation venues can apply for accreditation from Satour by complying with a number of basic requirements. But this does not amount to grading and is voluntary. "Maintaining standards is of serious concern to us," said Di Campbell, owner of the majestic Table Mountain Lodge in Tamboerskloof and former chairman of the Southern African Guesthouse Association.

"Many people with very little knowledge of the industry and of service levels required are opening their doors to the outside world. If we are not careful, this small sector will spoil everything for us."

This was confirmed by Liz Westby-Nunn, committee member of the Western Cape Tourism Business Council, who markets guesthouses and owns one in Swellendam.

"Many unskilled people are entering the business without understanding the full significance of the industry and without the necessary professional attitude."

What people did not realise was that if you opened a guesthouse you "sell your soul".

"You lose your privacy, your time and your friends," said Ms Westby-Nunn.

Fourteen to 16-hour days were nothing unusual, Ms Campbell sai Tourism bodies in Tygerberg, Stellenbosch and Hermanus are talking about establishing their own grading systems for informal accommodation by categorising establishments into luxury and budget classes.

But Ms Campbell believes this has to take place on a national level to be effective. She believes the booming industry is having a serious impact on middle-market hotels because business travellers are realising guesthouses offer personal service, luxuries and extra touches at cheaper rates than the " no frills" service offered by these hotels.

Steep hotel prices in the city have also led to an increase in corporate clients in guesthouses and B & Bs in the suburbs.

"The Tygerberg is ideal for the corporate tourist because of the huge number of big national companies that have their head offices here," said Paul Rosenbrock of the Tygerberg Accommodation Association.

Guesthouses and B & Bs in the southern suburbs also cater primarily for business clients. Industry experts cautioned strongly against over-optimistic expectations when offering tourist accommodation.

"Too many people simply decide to use their retirement packages to open guesthouses without doing the necessary preparation," said Mr Rosenbrock.

Ms Campbell agrees: "Once you feel confident that you have analysed all the pros and cons and that you feel comfortable to be in this industry, the sky is the limit."


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February 25, 1997


Business and Finance;
Africa's Rain Bonanza Tipped To Help Profits at Pep


BYLINE: Business Editor, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Cape Town - Strong prospects for agriculture, continuing store renovation and an aggressive expansion into other African countries should boost Pep Stores profits, according to managing director Arnold Louw.

Reporting a 15 percent increase in shareholders' profits to R75,7-million in the six months ended December, Mr Louw said good rains over large parts of Botswana, Namibia, Zambia and Zimbabwe had helped the clothing chain perform " exceptionally well" in these countries.

Five new stores were opened in Zambia, making a total of 13. In Zimbabwe, Pep raised its stake in Power Sales from 25 percent to 40 percent. 

Power Sales contributed R1,7-million to group profits, while the listed Pep Namibia and Pep Botswana added about R13-million to net earnings.

Mr Louw said Pep, which now had 1 185 outlets, had bucked the trend by raising turnover 16 percent to R1,12-billion in the six months, while sales in the clothing sector fell.

"Pep's performance therefore ran counter to the general market trenby This growth resulted from a good year in agriculture, aggressive marketing and consumers returning to cash."

The partial write-off of R60-million spent on electronic point-of-sale systems (Epos) slowed growth in operating profit to 11 percent, while growth in investment income was mostly offset by higher finance charges.

These higher finance charges reflected investment in improved information systems and higher stock levels. Mr Louw said that the benefits of the new systems were not yet reflected in the results.

The group's Scottish venture, Your More Store, had performed well over the half-year, he said, contributing almost R9-million to group earnings. The chain now had 115 outlets.

Mr Louw warned that intensified competition from imports was still putting pressure on margins in the manufacturing sector.

"The problems experienced by the textile industry at present necessitate the investigation of all rationalisation opportunities in an effort to remain competitive with the rest of the world," he sai Pep was paying a dividend of 13c a share, covered 2,4 times. Because of the change in year-end, shareholders could expect a similar dividend in the second half-year.

Africa News


February 25, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 108 on the Great Lakes (02/25)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1600 words


 

Nairobi - Reports of insecurity in Kisangani and Kindu have increased concern among the humanitarian community. There have been conflicting reports concerning looting in Kindu; the Zairean government has denied soldiers are looting in the garrison town.

* Rebel leader Laurent-Desire Kabila flew to South Africa today, report news agencies. According to Reuters, a "regional military source" stressed that Kabila would not be meeting representatives of the Zairean government, but confirmed that his visit was "part of consultations with the South Africans on the Zaire conflict". Kabila's departure comes a day after South African President Mandela announced that he and regional leaders (including Kenya, Tanzania, Zambia and Congo) would meet Zairean President Mobutu on March 19.

In Cape Town, Honore Ngbanda Nzambo, senior security advisor and nephew to President Mobutu, said he met last week with a US delegation led by Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs George Moose, reports AFP. Ngbanda said a South African delegation was present, acting as facilitators. The Zairean representative also said he had met Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni who was in Cape Town last week. Ngbanda praised the "sincerity" of the US team but said the international community "still seems to be playing the hypocrite, and double-talking", reports AFP. He said that the international community had proof of "involvement" of Uganda, Rwanda and Burundi in the fighting but refused to "denounce the agressors". 

* Tingi-Tingi (I and II) camps - served by air and ground transport from Kisangani only - continue to have an alarmingly high death rate despite improved rations of now 1700 kilocalories. Aid workers point out that health recovery is difficult to achieve on less than a full ration, but also fear that the high mortality rate points to appropriation of food by Rwandan militia and ex-soldiers in the camps. UNHCR has said it is investigating the possibility of evacuating by air the most vulnerable refugees (predominantly children); but any significant change in the security situation in Kisangani directly threatens the existence of the Tingi-Tingi camps.

Rwandan leaders in the two camps at Tingi-Tingi are said to have strong control over refugees and are preventing amalgamation or dispersal of the camps. A journalist recently returned from Tingi-Tingi told IRIN that dormitories and houses on one side of Tingi-Tingi (1) camp were "full of healthy men without dependents". According to the journalist, Rwandan militia and ex-FAR (Armed Forces of Rwanda) are fighting against the rebels - "FAZ have the guns, but FAR have the motivation". There are unconfirmed reports of executions of refugees by the Rwandan camp leaders. In Lubutu hospital, of 126 soldiers wounded in combat last week, only 13 were Zairean and the rest were Rwandan, humanitarian sources confirm.

* Seven people were killed and an infant wounded in an attack on Monday evening, in Bujumbura, Burundi, reports AFP. The attack targetted Paul Nkunzimana, a district secretary of Kamenge, an outlying district of Bujumbura; his wife was killed in the attack. Five suspects, identified as Hutu rebel sympathizers by the authorities, were later arrested. It was the second attack in a week in Kamenge, known as a centre of Hutu unrest in 1994- 95 until the authorities swept the district. District chief Joseph Ndayizeye said that residents have slowly been returning since September and now number 2,500, reports AFP.

* In a nine-page report, the Rwandan government has criticised the United Nations International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda. According to the statement, the tribunal has become "discredited in the eyes of the Rwandan people who have been bitterly disappointed by its seeming inability to make serious and sustained efforts in bringing to justice the architects of the genocide". In a press conference last week, Justice Minister Faustin Nteziryano said the tribunal had failed to go after the ringleaders of the genocide, but had pursued "lesser criminals".

The Rwandan government criticised the tribunals chief prosecutor Louise Arbour, who divides her time between the international tribunal for Rwanda and the international war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, based in the Hague. The government said she had failed to fulfill the court's main objective "to try persons responsible for genocide to the end that justice may become a tool for promoting reconciliation and peace in Rwanda." The complaints follow a highly critical internal UN report that said the tribunal was failing in all its administrative functions.

* The Sudanese army and militias have killed more than 35 Ethiopian " mercenaries" and Sudanese rebels in Khor Al-Gana area, eastern Sudan, reported a government paper on February 22. The report said Ethiopian forces and rebels of the Sudan Peoples Liberation Army (SPLA) had fled, leaving behind their dead, weapons and food supplies carrying Ethiopian markings. Sudan has accused Ethiopia and Eritrea of supporting the rebel offensive. Both countries deny any involvement.

* European Union Foreign Ministers gathering for their monthly meeting in Brussels were greeted by drum-beating protestors yesterday. Protestors were demonstrating for more positive EU action in Africa's Great Lakes region, reports Reuters. The Great Lakes was one of the subjects to be discussed at the monthly meeting.

* A heads of state summit was held at Yamoussoukro, Cote d'Ivoire on 20 February under the chairmanship of President of Togo, General Gnassingbe Eyadema. A joint communique issued after the summit included recommendations on the Great Lakes crisis, and called for an intervention force. It also requested an extraordinary session of the Central Organ (for Conflict Resolution) of the OAU on the crisis at the heads of state and heads of government level.

* A two day peace conference will be held in Kampala, Uganda, from tomorrow. The conference - "The Challenge of Peace in Northern Uganda: A Search for Solutions" - is being coordinated by the Agency for Cooperation and Research in Development (ACORD) and the Ugandan Women's Network (UWONET). Participants will include representatives from local communities, government, UN agencies, NGOs and experts in conflict resolution. For more information contact Sam Aisu at ACORD, PO Box 280, Kampala (Tel: 256-41-267667/8, FAX: 256-41-267669, e-mail: ACORD@MUKLA.gn.apc.org).

* Following yesterdays student riots in Nairobi over the death of a student leader, the United States embassy issued a statement today deploring the " violent and so far unexplained death" of leader Solomon Muruli. The statement urged the government to give high priority to investigating the circumstances surrounding Muruli's death, and a full and prompt disclosure of the results. The British High Commission also released a statement. Nairobi University was closed until further notice yesterday, and hundreds of riot police stood by as students packed up and left the campus.

* Leader of the mercenaries fighting for the Zairean army, Christian Tavernier, said on Sunday in a telephone interview from eastern Zaire that " the balance of strength is currently against us", reports Reuters. Tavernier accused Uganda of supporting the rebels, claiming "well-organised units come from Uganda, carry out an operation, attack a position, and then retreat". He said "The Zairean army is in a tangle, like the rest of the country, with almost no logistics".

On the other side of the fence, Colonel Willy Mallants, a former advisor to President Mobutu who is now an advisor to the rebels, told Belgian radio that the Zairean government was employing "war criminals" to fight its battle. He said the mercenaries should "be before the international tribunal in the Hague".

Nairobi, 25 February 1997, 15:45 GMT (ENDS)

Africa News


February 25, 1997


Business and Finance;
African Currencies: Ghanaian Cedi Depreciates Further


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1185 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The Ghanaian Cedi dropped further this week, opening on Monday at the mean rate of 1,787 to the U.S. dollar from 1,770 to the greenback on the same day last week. But the CFA franc appreciated marginally to the nominal rate of 565.7 to the dollar, up from 567.5 the previous week. 

In Dakar on Tuesday, the currency exchanged at 551 (buying) and 581 (selling) for one dollar.

The Following were the nominal exchange rates of African currencies against the U.S. dollar on Tuesday:

371 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 25, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
African Ministers Meet On Continent's Problems


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - African ministers begin a three-day meeting Wednesday against the backdrop of daunting soci-political and economic problems facing their continent.

Underscoring the magnitude of the crises is the fact that the delegates to the Organization of Africa Unity's 65th ministerial council have been forced by a United States-sponsored United Nations air embargo to take a rather circuitous and inconvenient route to attend the meeting in the Libyan capital, Tripoli.

According to a delegate from Sudan, which is also under threat of a similar sanction, "this is part of the prize we have to pay for coming from Africa in a world dominated by Western hegemony." 

Libya has been under the pangs of the U.N. sanctions since 1992 for its refusal to surrender for trial in the U.S. and Britain two of its nationals accused of the December 1988 bombing of PanAm flight 103. So, it is using the O.A.U. meeting to make a political statement on African solidarity.

To the Libyans the O.A.U. meeting is a way of easing Tripoli's isolation, although it remains to be seen how this can be transformed into a major influence at ending the sanctions in the face of Washington's stiff opposition.

Political and social strife is another worrisome topic that will engage the African ministers. There is the escalating conflicts in the Great Lakes region where Zaire is accusing Burundi, Rwanda and Uganda of supporting anti- government forces which have captured swathes of the country's east. These countries have denied the Zairean charge.

So far, subregional peace initiatives including a meeting of regional leaders in Nov. 1996 in Nairobi, Kenya, have failed to end the crisis, which raised humanitarian and security concerns in the region.

While, Zaire welcomes intervention by the O.A.U., the Uganda delegation to the ongoing ministerial meeting in Tripoli insists the issue should not be internationalised. The Ugandans say "it is an internal issue, which Zaire can be helped to solve by its neighbours."

The horn of African is another trouble spot with the conflict in Somalia defying solution. There is also Angola, where the 30-year old civil war has refused to disappear.

Apart from refugee problems created by these conflicts, Africa also has to deal with the problems of drought and famine.

On a more positive note, there is gradual restoration of peace and democracy in Sierra Leone, through the efforts of Cote d'Ivoire to get the Revolutionary United Front to end the war against Freetown.

In addition, with the help of the subregional Economic Community of West African States, Liberia is closer now to elections after seven-years of civil war.

On the whole, until its next summit in Harare, Zimbabwe, in June the O.A.U. may be busy with its dogged search for peace and solutions to the continents myriad socio-economic and political problems.


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


372 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 25, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Burundi Conflict Gulps Lion's Share Of O.A.U. Peace Fund


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - The conflict in Burundi has gulped some 62 percent of the O.A.U. special Peace Fund, set up in 1993 to facilitate its mechanism for conflict prevention, management and resolution, according to the organization's reports.

Official statistics, presented at the ongoing 65th ordinary session of the Council of Ministers in the Libyan capital, showed that 9.6 million U.S. dollars of the total 18.7 million available to the fund by the end of December 1996 was spent on the organizations Observer Mission In Burundi. 

The fund has only three million dollars after an expenditure of 15.6 million dollars on various continental peace efforts. These included 1.5 million dollars devoted to preventive diplomacy in the Comoros, Congo, Gabon, Liberia, Mozambique, Rwanda, Sierra Leone, Somalia and Togo.

Procurement of military and other equipment for the peace efforts gulped 2. 5 million dollars, while non-military component of the mechanism accounted for 1.7 million dollars.

Contributions and donations from Africa amounted to 6.2 million dollars, while donor countries and international organisations outside Africa contributed 12.4 million dollars.

O.A.U. Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim, in his report to a meeting of African ambassadors ahead of the Council of Ministers meeting beginning Wednesday, appealed to member states to step up their voluntary contributions to the fund. This was instituted in Cairo, Egypt, at the 29th O.A.U. summit in 1993.

Salim told the envoys that a pledge of 2.8 million dollars was being processed from the European Union and the Belgian government towards the fund.


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


373 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 25, 1997


Zaire;
Nine Zairean Army Officers Desert To Join Rebels


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo (PANA) - Nine ranking officers of the Zairean army have deserted to join rebel forces trying to overthrow the central government in Kinshasa.

"We are just on transit in Brazzaville. Our aim is to reach eastern Zaire to help the commander in chief of the Congo Liberation Army led by Mr Kabila," said one of the officers.

This officer, a colonel in military intelligence, was identified in the news conference Monday only as Anti, not his real name.

He said that the authorities in Kinshasa suspected that officers originating from eastern Zaire supported the rebel leader, Laurent Kabila. Some 10 officers, along with politicians from the country's radical opposition and parliamentarians, Anti said, were under house arrest.

Kabila is reported to have said that many officers and soldiers were waiting for his signal before wage an all-out war against the 32-year old regime of President Mobutu Sese Seko.

"Kabila's advantage is that he is supported by the people and, especially, by the largest part of the national army," Anti said.

He said that regular soldiers were deserting and joining the rebels, known as the Banyamulenge, and that this was an indication the "Zairean soldiers are fed up."


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


374 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 25, 1997


Mozambique;
Mozambique Calls For Total Land mine Ban


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - The Mozambican government threw its weight Tuesday behind the international campaign against land mines, when the country's president, Joaquim Chissano, called on mine producing nations to end their manufacture and sale immediately.

Such measures, he said, were needed in order to halt the indiscriminate killing and maiming of "the thousands of people who are victims of these lethal devices every year."

Opening the fourth International Conference on Land mines, Chissano said that an end to the manufacture of land mines, all other efforts, including demining, would be useless. 

He compared demining to efforts at filling a sieve with water. instead of perpetually removing mines. He said it would be to "turn off the tap" - namely, shut the factories that produce the devices.

Some 1,000 areas in Mozambique have been mined. Between January 1993 and January 1997, 7,400 kilometres of road, 1,700 kilometres of railway, 1,800 kilometres of electricity transmission line and 2,300 quare kilometres of farmland had been demined.

Since 1992, sappers have removed about 30,000 mines from Mozambican soil. Currently, the pace of operations has quickened and perhaps 11,000 mines a year are being removed.

However, he said that at this rate it would take between 46 and 160 years to ensure that the country was free of mines: the exact length of time depending on how many mines were placed during the wars Mozambique has suffered since 1964. Estimates range up to 1.5 million.

"It is not just for the country to have to wait so long to be free of land mines," he said.

He called on the international community to make more resources available to speed up mine clearance.

Chissano attacked the lack of concern shown by countries where land mines are produced. One of the reasons they were not bothered, he said, was that mines rarely killed citizens of these countries.

"These weapons never exterminate their own people. They destroy the peoples of other countries," he said.

The major focus of concern was on the producing countries, he said, since once they stopped manufacturing these devices, the problem would cease to exist.

Chissano said he wanted an international treaty banning the production, storage, transport, sale and use of land mines, particularly anti-personnel mines.

The coordinator of the international campaign to ban land mines, Jody Williams, told the Mozambican news agency, AIM, that she regarded the Maputo conference as one more step towards precisely such a treaty.

"This conference will not only draw the attention of the world to the problems caused by mines in this region but will also help us define strategies to create a Southern Africa free of land mines" she said.

Among those sponsoring the conference is former Education Minister Graca Machel, widow of the country's first president, Samora Machel.

She told the agency that for as long as measures to impose a total ban were not taken, the world would continue to watch innocent people suffer death and mutilation.

She noted that, although the war in Mozambique ended over four years ago, mines were still killing an average of 40 people a month.


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


375 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 25, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Zimbabwe Police To Probe Banana On Sodomy Allegations


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwean police will begin investigations immediately into sodomy allegations against the former Zimbabwean president, Rev. Canaan Banana, Police Commissioner Augustine Chihuri said Tuesday.

"These are allegations that have been made and before then (the investigations) I cannot say much more than that," he told the Zimbabwe Inter- Africa News Agency.

Banana's alleged homosexual rape of his former police aide-de-camp was made in a Harare High Court where the victim and former police inspector, Jefta Dube, was convicted of the murder of a former police constable. 

Dube's defence was that he was not responsible for his actions. This he put partly to the trauma he suffered when Banana repeatedly sexually abused Dube in the official presidential residence, between 1983 and 1986.

Dube told the court he shot his fellow policeman, Constable Patrick Mashure, at a musical concert at Gwanzura Stadium in Harare after Mashure called Dube "Banana's wife."

Justice Bartlett, after finding Dube guilty of murder with actual intent but with diminished responsibility, recommended that the police commissioner and the attorney-general's office investigate the allegations.

"No one is seen to be above the law," Bartlett said.

Sodomy is a criminal offence in Zimbabwe.

Dube's lawyer, Byron Hove, said while his client was "only too willing" to have Banana prosecuted, Dube would definitely be suing the former president.

President Robert Mugabe has unwaveringly criticized homosexuals as perverts and sodomites, saying they were "worse than dogs and pigs" and undeserving of rights of any kind.

Judge Bartlett, who sentenced Dube to 10 years imprisonment, said the allegations against Banana could not be dismissed as not being "reasonably possible."

Two psychiatrists testified that Dube suffered from post-traumatic stress disorder.

Judge Bartlett said he could not rule out that the stress, coupled with drug and alcohol abuse, could have been the result of his three-year homosexual abuse by Banana.

A prominent international statesman married with four children, Banana, who is a theology professor at the University of Zimbabwe, retired in 1987 to pave way for Mugabe (then prime minister) following the introduction of the executive presidency.


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


376 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 25, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
O.A.U Hopes Morocco Will Rejoin The Fold


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - The Organisation of African Unity (O.A.U.) welcomes the recent resumption of diplomatic ties between Morocco and Ethiopia and sees it as a positive sign that Rabat could rejoin the O.A.U, an official of the Addis Ababa-Based continental body has said. "We see good signs because Ethiopia is not just a country, it is the headquarters of the O.A.U," Ibrahim Dagash, the organization's spokesman told PANA Monday. 

Speaking at the venue of the 65th session of the O.A.U.'s ministerial council, he said Morocco's seat at the 53-nation body, Africa's foremost political organisation, had remained reserved for Rabat to take up.

Dagash said Morocco was welcome to return to the organization from which it suspended its membership in 1983.

Last week, Morocco resumed diplomatic ties with Ethiopia after an 18-year break over Addis Ababa's recognition of the Polisario Front.

It was O.A.U's admission of the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic, Polisario's political body, that led to Rabat's suspension of its membership.

Morocco is in dispute with Polisario over ownership of the former Spanish territory called the Western Sahara.

The issue is before the United Nations which plans a much-awaited referendum to determine whether or not the people of the territory want independence from or union with Morocco.


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


377 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 25, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
O.A.U. Still Bogged By Arrears Of Contributions


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - With total unpaid contributions of 56.25 million U. S. dollars as of the 1996/97 fiscal year, the Addis Ababa-based Organization of African Unity (O.A.U.) is still owed a lot of money, an official has said.

"Although members are paying up, the situation is still critical," said Ibrahim Dagash, head of the Organization's Information Division, ahead of the annual foreign ministers' conference of the continental body. 

The outstanding amount represent almost twice the organization's annual budget of about 30 million dollars.

In his report to the 65th ministerial council, O.A.U. Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim's said that only 11 of the 53-member countries are up to date in their 1996/97 regular budget.

These are Senegal, which has paid in advance in the 1997/98 budget; Botswana, Cote d'Ivoire, Eritrea, Ghana, Lesotho, Malawi, Mauritius, Namibia, South Africa and Zimbabwe.

Although O.A.U. officials said that this was an improvement over the same period in 1996, when some 60 million dollars were owed the body, they added that here was need for stronger financial commitment by members to enable the organization live up to its responsibilities.

Chad, the Central African Republic and Equatorial Guinea are in arrears of between 10 and 12 years. They risk sanctions, including denial of voting rights and other privileges.

Four other countries, the Comoros, Cape Verde, Sao Tome E Principe and Zaire, on the other hand, have been granted varying rescheduling concessions between February 1997 and January 2003.


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


378 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 26, 1997


South Africa;
Cosatu Fires First Shots Over Labour Bill


BYLINE: Business Editor Alide Dasnois, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 960 words


 

Cape Town - The new Employment Bill, which will set basic conditions of employment for all employees in South Africa, is to be submitted to Cabinet " in the next couple of weeks", according to Minister of Labour Tito Mboweni.

But the Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu) has already fired the first warning shots in what could be another tough battle for Mr Mboweni.

The new legislation will revamp the old Basic Conditions of Employment Act and the Wage Act and draw them into a single piece of law aimed principally at protecting the most vulnerable workers.

Unlike the Labour Relations Act, which came into force last November after a long fight between business and trade unions, and which was aimed mostly at improving bargaining rights for unionised workers, the Employment Bill seeks to set minimum standards of employment for those who cannot improve their own conditions through bargaining. 

Although it will set floor conditions for everyone, it is aimed mostly at farmworkers, domestic workers, temporary and part-time employees and anyone else who is not in a position to negotiate better working conditions.

The bill, which will be published for comment only once it has been approved by Cabinet, is likely to incorporate changes proposed in a Green Paper last year, including:

* A reduction in the working week from 46 to 45 hours for day workers and from 48 hours for shift workers; * A reduction in the working week for security workers from 60 hours to 48 hours over two years; * Extra pay for night work;

* A ban on employment of children of less than 15 years - the official school leaving age;

* Better protection for pregnant workers and four months' maternity leave;

* Double time for Sunday work; and

* A compulsory rest day (not necessarily Sunday) for every worker.

Mr Mboweni says he still is aiming for a 40-hour week, but wants this to be achieved through collective bargaining or through setting conditions in specific sectors rather than across the board

The proposals do not make specific provision for paid maternity leave, suggesting that women continue to get maternity benefits from the Unemployment Insurance Fund, but that steps be taken to improve the allowances pai Some variation of working conditions is allowed for, "to enable employees and employers to use working time more productively", says the Department of Labour.

But basic rights - such as the ban on child labour and protection against employer abuse or unfair dismissals - are not to be tampered with although other conditions may be allowed to vary to fit the demands of work in different sectors.

Cosatu, not satisfied with the minister's assurances on the 40-hour week, wants a phased approach and a time frame now.

The federation, which has been involved in negotiations on this issue in the National Economic Development and Labour Council (Nedlac) for eight months, also is calling for six months' maternity leave, four of them pai It also is campaigning for a limit of 16 years on the employment of children.

And, in the context of employer pressure for greater flexibility on the labour market, Cosatu also is worried about the variation of standards.

The trade union programme of action, which kicked off yesterday, will include marches, pickets and rallies between now and April when Cosatu's central executive committee meets and assesses progress.

If sufficient progress has not been made, Cosatu says, a general strike will be called for May 12.

So far, Mr Mboweni has chosen to act hurt rather than angry in the face of Cosatu's statements.

He was "extremely surprised", he said last week, at Cosatu's plans to mobilise towards a general strike.

"Given the complexity and sensitivity of the issues involved, there is a need to handle the negotiations around such a bill with the utmost care," he said.

He said he was talking to Cosatu general secretary Sam Shilowa, that he was committed to a negotiated agreement and that he was sure that "the areas of uncertainty can easily be ironed out to ensure success when the negotiations begin".

Once Cabinet has approved the bill, it will be published in the Government Gazette and then tabled for more negotiation at Nedla

Mr Mboweni, who sees this bill as one of the most important new laws to be debated by Parliament in 1997, is determined to get it through this year, in line with promises made by President Mandela in his opening address to Parliament.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


379 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 26, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 109 on the Great Lakes (02/26)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1760 words


 

Nairobi - Laurent-Desire Kabila, rebel leader of the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL), held talks in Pretoria, South Africa, with South African, US and UN officials. Joint OAU/UN Special Representative for the Great Lakes region, Mohamed Sahnoun, arrived in South Africa on Tuesday. The South African news agency SAPA reported that Sahnoun; US secretary of State for African Affairs George Moose; and South African deputy Foreign Minister Aziz Pahad were present at the first round of "close proximity" talks. The South African government continues to stress that the talks would take time. One diplomat present at the talks said that the presence of UN/OAU and US officials aimed at reconciling all the international and regional initiatives for eastern Zaire (see IRIN Update 105) .

The Zairean government representative, Honore Nzambo Ngbanda - senior security advisor and nephew to President Mobutu Sese Seko - is reported to have left South Africa. He participated in last weeks exploratory talks in Cape Town.

* Rebel spokesman Raphael Ghenda told AFP today in Goma that Kindu garrison town "is about to fall". He said that looting by soldiers and flight of the population "has become a classic scenario - our forces are on the point of capturing the town". Kindu has a major airport, is a railhead for the mineral- rich Shaba province, and was a major military base for the government counter- offensive. The Zairean government denies there has been looting. 

* World Food Programme sent in its first airlift of emergency food supplies to Punia yesterday - an outpost about 170 kilometers south of Tingi-Tingi camps, eastern Zaire - where 4,000 Rwandans have arrived in poor nutritional condition. An estimated 160 refugees are arriving daily. A WFP/UNHCR mission visited Punia on Sunday. WFP said it completed its largest food distribution to date in Tingi-Tingi on Monday, where some 170,000 Rwandans received a seven-day food package containing maize, beans, corn-soya blend and vegetable oil. WFP said it now had "ample stocks" in Tingi-Tingi camps but was concerned about the impact of insecurity and the onset of the rainy season.

Humanitarian sources from Tingi-Tingi camps confirmed today that a commercial air operation has been flying Rwandans out of Tingi-Tingi camp to Kisangani, and on to Nairobi. The flight costs around $800. Well-placed sources say a few hundred Rwandans, including ex-FAR, have left Tingi-Tingi by air recently. Sources say the exodus of ex-FAR could facilitate repatriation attempts of refugees to Rwanda, and assist the on-going negotiations for the opening of safe corridors. Unconfirmed reports say ex- FAR have requested that lower-ranking former-FAR from Tingi-Tingi be re- integrated into the Rwandan army.

In Punia, an AFP reporter says refugees arriving fearful of the rapid rebel advance. The reporter, who interviewed refugees in Punia, says most of then hid in thick forest and scrub for weeks and are fearful of being caught in fighting. Refugees are arriving from the north and south, and feel trapped; AFP say the refugees are hoping the international community will open a new camp to provide them with a safe haven.

* Speculation continues about the security situation in Kindu and Kisangani. The Governor of Maniema, based in Kindu, left the garrison town yesterday for Kisangani, and went on to Kinshasa by a private airline last night. In an interview with AP, a group of senior Zairean officers said dissension and chaos within the army leadership, as well as low morale, years of low wages and dismal living conditions, had driven them to defect to the rebel ADFL. Nine senior officers have fled to Brazzaville, Congo, and say they are in " transit" to join the front in eastern Zaire. Speaking to AP, a former colonel who gave his name only as "Anti" said the other officers included three other colonels, two majors and two captains, as well as one other officer. Anti claimed hundreds of other officers and rank-and-file soldiers had already switched sides and were in eastern Zaire to aid the rebels.

* An article in Le Monde today said a Western eyewitness, who has lived in the region for four years, claims that rebels in eastern Zaire have massacred civilians in the Goma region. The eye witness says he saw mass graves and gave nine examples, with their location. Two of the examples he gave were mass graves outside Katale camp, one containing more than a hundred people killed by machine gun, and the other containing 300 people wrapped in plastic sheeting. To-date, there have been no independent human rights monitors in eastern Zaire to investigate various claims relating to killings by the fleeing Zairean army and the rebels.

* A statement today from the Belgian government emphasised it was concerned about human rights violations committed by all parties in Zaire, and was trying to verify any information regarding genocide in the region. The statement, by a spokesman from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, follows a published interview with Belgian Development Minister Reginald Moreels, who said rebels were committing genocide in eastern Zaire.

* A meeting of the Organisation of African Unity in Tripoli, Libiya, is preoccupied with the crisis in Zaire, reports AFP. OAU Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim in a report prepared for the meeting stressed the need for a ceasefire as soon as possible. Rwandan Foreign Minister Anastase Gasana called for an "African solution" to the conflict. In his report Salim Salim underlined the urgency for an international conference on peace, security and stability in the Great Lakes region. Other items on the agenda include Burundi and Somalia. Burundi's representative at the OAU, Luc Rukingama, is trying to get regional sanctions lifted, report AFP. 53 Foreign Ministers are meeting in Tripoli at the OAU conference.

* President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya said yesterday he was "hopeful" of an imminent solution to the conflict in Africa's Great Lakes region, and said he had made "concerted efforts in finding a solution". Moi complained African leaders had recieved little international support in imposing sanctions on Burundi's military regime. Moi said Kenya had been thrown into turmoil because of regional conflicts, resulting in "influx of refugees, illegal possession of firearms and the disruption of economic activities". The Kenyan president made the remarks in Gaborone at a banquet held at a Commonwealth conference on democracy. About three thousand Kenyan students and other protestors marched through Nairobi in a another day of demonstrations over the death of a student leader.

* President Mobutu Sese Seko has postponed his return to Zaire from his villa on the French Riviera, aides said on Tuesday. Mobutu arrived in France on Friday and underwent medical tests at the weekend. He had planned to leave for Zaire on Tuesday, but aides said he would leave on Wednesday at the earliest, report AFP.

* A five-day conference on the River Nile basin opened yesterday in Addis Ababa. At least 250 government representatives and researchers are attending from Burundi, Egypt, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Kenya, Rwanda, Sudan, Tanzania, Uganda and Zaire. The ten states are expected to spell out their positions on the use of the Nile resources. Also taking part are representatives of international organisations such as the World Bank, UNDP, the European Union and donor countries. Opening the conference, the Ethiopian Minister for Water Resources said Ethiopia contributed 86% of the Nile's waters and had the right to equitable share.

* Hutu rebel leaders in Burundi have announced they had set up their own " courts" to try those they deem responsible for political and other killings in Burundi, reports AFP. Rebel leader Leonard Nyangoma said several trials in Burundi had convicted Hutus of genocide against Tutsis in the massacres that took place after the 1993 coup; the rebel "courts" would now try Tutsis suspected in involvement in the military coup, said a statement released to the press. Leonard Nyangoma - head of the National Council for the Defence of Democracy (CNDD) - said roving tribunals had been set up in all the country's provinces. He also denounced the United Nations, charging that it was indifferent to the unrest in Burundi and was failing to set up an international criminal tribunal similar to the one set up for Rwanda.

* Deposed Burundi president Sylvestre Ntibantunganya is reportedly ready to leave the US ambassador's residence in Bujumbura after talks with his successor, Major Pierre Buyoya. In a statement yesterday, the opposition Front for Democracy in Burundi (FRODEBU) said Ntibantunganya was ready to leave after hiding since July 1996 in the US residence. The announcement has not been confirmed.

Nairobi, 26 February 1997, 15:35 GMT (ENDS)

380 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 26, 1997


Zaire;
More Food Reaches Zairean Camps Amid Constraints


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 907 words


 

Rome - The onset of the rainy season in eastern Zaire will create further obstacles in reaching some 170,000 Rwandans in refugee camps, said the United Nations World Food Programme today.

WFP sends significant quantities of food by air to refugee camps such as Tingi Tingi, but growing problems of heavy cloud cover will limit the number of flights WFP can make each day. Land routes from Kisangani to the camps are also expected to become even more problematic as bad patches in the road become impassable due to rain which has already started in some areas.

Recent reports of insecurity in eastern Zaire are also having an impact on humanitarian operations. Reports of insecurity in the region may negatively affect WFP deliveries of food from Lusaka to Kisangani which is a 2,000 km journey using road, rail, and barge. Over the weekend, WFP sent 200 tons of food from Kindu to Kisangani by barge, and a further 300 tons is on wagons south of Kindu. WFP presently has an additional 1,000 tons of food in Lubumbashi in transit to Kisangani. These supplies represent at least 20 days' worth of food for the 170,000 refugees in Eastern Zaire, the highest in- country stockpile of food since December 1996 when the crisis began. 

"It is ironic that in a moment when we have overcome many complex problems affecting food deliveries, other uncontrollable constraints like poor weather and insecurity are threatening to curb our operation," said WFP spokesman Trevor Rowe.

Yesterday WFP completed the largest food distribution to-date in Tingi Tingi camp where some 170,000 Rwandan refugees received a seven-day food package containing maize, beans, corn-soya blend and vegetable oil. In order to undertake such a large distribution, WFP had to haul most of the food 240 kms overland. This involved contracting 55 trucks and 39 pick-up vehicles - virtually every commercial truck and pick-up available for miles in the Kisangani area. The now-ample WFP food stocks in Tingi Tingi camp will be bolstered by more convoys set to leave Kisangani tomorrow with 210 tons of food, which is a three-day supply for the camp population.

As refugees continue to flee locations in Eastern Zaire, their health progressively deteriorates and relief agencies such as WFP are forced to shift their operations in order to respond. Last weekend, some 25,000 refugees from Kalima camp fled on the heels of a rebel advancement.

WFP today sent in its first airlift of emergency food supplies (six tons) to Punia, an outpost town some 170 kms south of Tingi Tingi where 4,000 Rwandan refugees have arrived in poor nutritional condition, and an estimated 160 refugees are arriving daily. The decision to send food follows a WFP/UNHCR mission to Punia on Sunday

WFP flies in an average of 15-20 tons of food daily from Kisangani to Tingi Tingi on DC-3 turbine planes. The planes make three to four trips each day, landing on Tingi Tingi's main road, which also serves as an airstrip. Over the weekend, WFP tested the makeshift runway's ability to handle larger cargo planes by dispatching an Andover aircraft which can carry 50 percent more cargo than the DC-3 aircraft. After a successful landing on Sunday, WFP immediately began using the plane to airlift food supplies to the camps, sending to Tingi Tingi three flights on Monday with a total of 18 tons of relief food.

"No matter how much we try, relief operations to Eastern Zaire continue to be hampered by tremendous logistical constraints," said Rowe. "Impassable roads, small airstrips, scarce fuel supplies and insecurity are still major hurtles."

Problems in the initial phase of the WFP operation to Eastern Zaire were also compounded by limited availability of Government approved aircraft to fly in food supplies and reduced numbers of WFP staff to assist in the operation due to Government delays in issuing authorized travel clearances to aid workers.

For more information:

Brenda Barton/Michele Quintaglie WFP Kenya Tel. 254-2-622704/622336

Trevor Rowe WFP Rome Tel. 39-6-5228-2612

(ENDS)

Africa News


February 26, 1997


Ethiopia;
Journalists Urged To Expose Corruption, Abuse Of Power


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - Region 14 Journalists Association underscored here Saturday that the fight against corruption and abuse of power to render possible the nurturing of a democratic culture will not be successful without conscientious participation of journalists.

In a statement he made at a programme organized to introduce members, association chairman Tadesse Gebre-Mariam said journalists should upgrade their professional skill to enlighten the people in the endeavour to build a new democratic society. 

The establishment of the association is a step forward in ensuring the public right to information and of the journalist to gather the same, he said, adding the profession could deserve public respect only when members discharge responsibilities entrusted to them.

The journalists, in a bid to foster development endeavours in the country, should enlighten the public on socio-economic activities, policies and regulations issued to facilitate the implementation of the development strategy.

The regional association, he said, has registered achievements in safeguarding the rights and benefits of members over the past six months.

The association plans to form research, education and recreation committees, the chairman said and called on members to join hands to this end.

Veteran journalists Negash Gebre-Mariam, Mamo Widneh and Mairegu Bezabih on the occasion urged journalists to impart accurate, balanced and fair information through persistent efforts aimed at achieving professional efficiency.

Artistic performances were staged on the occasion alongside traditional and modern songs by the Kistane Band.

LANGUAGE: English

382 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 26, 1997


Ethiopia;
Public Comments On Registration And Licensing for Businesses


BYLINE: Kisut G/Egziabher, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - The Parliamentary Economic Affairs Standing committee organized a public-hearing session here yesterday during which concerned and interested bodies commented on the newly drafted proclamation concerning commercial Registration and Business Licensing.

On hand to elaborate on the bill was Trade and Industry Minister Kassahun Ayele, who said that making the commercial code consistent with the free market economic policy and removing needless hurdles which the business community face were the major objectives of the proclamation.

According to him the relevant law still in force was the commercial code of 1960 and most of the regulations, particularly those adopted the Derg regime, remain attuned to the command economy. 

Ato Kassahun described the bill as a viable instrument for creating a conducive business environment for the law abiding business community and for curbing illegal ones.

According to the draft proclamation, business licences for all sectors except seven will be issued only by the pertinent institutions of the trade and industry sector, unlike in the past when a number of government offices were involved. Licences for the seven sectors will be issued by various offices owing to the specific nature of the activities which require special technical knowledges.

The draft proclamation provides: "Any person shall principally register only once eventhough he carries on different commercial activities in different regions."

According to Ato Kassahun, registration fees which used to exceed a million birr, depending on the size of the capital invested, were limited to no more than 200 birr under the new proclamation. As to Efficiency, he said that an applicant bearing all the required documents must get his licence within five working days.

The draft proclamation was approved by the Council of Ministers and referred to the House of Peoples' Representatives.

At yesterday's session, participants representing federal and regional investment bureaux, the Chamber of commerce as well as the business community at large, raised various question on which Ato Kassahun, together with three other colleagues elaborated.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


383 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 26, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopia: Kalub Gas Plant Construction To Begin Soon


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The Kalub Gas Share Company has announced that the construction of a plant that would produce 65,000 tonnes of petroleum products in Somali Regional State will begin soon.

Upon completion after two years, the plant, whose construction is to commence within three months with the sinking of 3,700 - meters deep wells at a site 25 kilometre west of Shilabo town of Ogaden zone, will produce LPG, gasoline, kerosene and diesel fuels, according to company General Manager Jehad Abakoyas. 

According to a survey carried out by a foreign company 23 years ago, the areas has a deposit of 74 billion cubic metre natural gas, Ato Jehad noted.

The amount of petroleum explored at Kalub is comparable to the amount in high deposit countries including the United States of America, he said.

The Kalub Gas development project, to be undertaken with a 74 million dollar World Bank loan and an additional budget by the share company, will create job opportunities to 300 residents of the area, he indicated.

When the sale of the liquid petroleum products begins, it is expected to curb depletion of forests for fuelwood, Ato Jehad pointed out.

>From the sale of the petroleum products the country will annually obtain 17 to 29 million birr in revenue, he said, adding the project has also a prospect to supply electricity to towns around the site.

Citing a basic study conducted by the Ministry of Mines and Energy, he indicated the prevalence of similar deposits in Gembela, the Rift Valley, and some areas in the south.

The Kalub Gas Share Company was established in 1986 E.C. by the government - shareholder of the greater stake - four governmental organizations, five national regional states and over 400 private investors with a capital of 102 million birr.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


384 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 26, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Nile: Ethiopian Minister Reaffirms Right To Fair Share


BYLINE: Abebe Gelaw, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - Ethiopia has the right to an equitable share of the Nile and to utilize its water resources, the Minister of Water Resources noted here yesterday.

Opening the 5th Nile 2,002 Conference, to be held until February 28 at the new conference centre of UNESCA, Ato Sheferaw Jarso stressed that Ethiopia, in the exercise of its sovereignty to the utilisation of its water, reserves its right to make use of them without causing "any appreciable or significant harm to other riparian states."

The Minister pointed out that despite huge potential for cooperative development in the Nile Basin, the record shows dismal performance with little or no effort among the concerned countries, "In this regard, the Nile Basin must be one of the few international water courses which lacks any measure of cooperation or any form of comprehensive agreement applicable to all riparian states," he said. 

Ato Shiferaw said that it was quite appropriate that the conference was held here in Ethiopia which is the source of the Blue Nile as well as the major contributor to the Nile waters. Noting that the Nile traverses ten African countries covering one tenth of the continent, he expressed hope that the conference will provide a unique opportunity for these states to create " a comprehensive framework" for cooperation. "In the course of deliberations, what should also not be forgotten is the unique and diverse features of the Basin which, on the one hand, exhibits exotic panoramic beauty and, on the other hand with some exception, the remotest, most inaccessible and least developed part of the world," the Minister stated.

Ato Shiferaw went on to note that Ethiopia is prepared to engaged in fruitful discussions with other riparian states in the determination of equitable shares of water based on universally accepted principles of international law. "It is thus high time that countries of the Nile Basin set up the institutional framework and engage in serious discussions to derive optimal benefit from their shared water resources and enhance the sustainable development and conservation the eco-system in the Basin," the Minister noted.

Ato Mezemir Medmim, Chairman of the National Organizing Committee, said earlier in a welcoming address that the reasons why Ethiopia is hosting the conference is that many nations owe a great deal to the Nile as "it is but 86% Ethiopia." According to Ato Mezemir, another reason can best be explained by the Ethiopian saying which he puts as, "The daughter of Abbay (Blue Nile) is thirsty," both in literal metaphoric senses.

"While Abbay or the Blue Nile contributes the major portion of the entire flow, there are times when many people of the world wondered whether there was a drop of water in Ethiopia at all," he said, adding that why the " daughter of Abbay" should be thirsty is a subject matter of the conference not only for Ethipians but for the international community as well.

Ato Mezemir pointed out that 17 international, governmental and private organizations including FAO, UNDP, Danish International Development Agency, USAID and Canadian International Development Agency had provided financial support. The last covered over a quarter of the budgetary requirement.

The Canadian ambassador, Mr. Gabriel M. Lessard, said his country's involvement in the Nile stems from the issues at stake: the economic social and eco-system of more than 250 million people of the Basin.

"The years of drought and last year's flood here in Ethiopia are just few examples which vividly illustrate the point," he pointed out.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February 26, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopian Investors Launch Projects


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

DIREDAWA (ENA) - Some 35 entrepreneurs with a combined capital of 113 million birr are engaged in various development activities in Dire Dawa Administrative Region, the investment office said.

Office acting head Adugna Abebe said the investors are engaged in Health, Education and Agricultural Development Projects. 

Work on eight of the projects has already been completed, he said and added the projects could create job opportunities to 1,140 people in the administration.

Six of the entrepreneurs are undertaking horticultural development, animal fattening and dairy product projects on about 70 hectares of land, it was learnt.

The acting head of the office said a private clinic built in Dire Dawa town at a cost of four million birr has gone operational while work on the construction of the five-million birr hotel is well underway.
