Africa News


February 26, 1997


Zimbabwe;
DUPED (Media Watch COLUMN)


BYLINE: staff reporter, The Insider (Harare)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Harare - The teaser on Monday, January 27, promised fire works. The story, the following day, left a lot of readers wondering what the fuss had been all about. Some even felt cheated. 

After its successful series on child abuse, a lot of readers believed the Reserve Bank story would be equally revealing. But it ended, not just a disappointment, but it left the impression that there was much more to the story than met the eye.

"The Reserve Bank is a public institution, right? It is indeed. But to whom is it answerable? Certainly not to the public like all other institutions," read the teaser. It went on to list questions that had been asked by The Herald: "Was it true that the Reserve Bank was spending money as soon as they printed it? Was it true that half of the new Reserve Bank building was empty? Was it true that they built themselves expensive chalets at Juliasdale ... was it true that they built themselves a high-tech shooting range under the Reserve Bank building?"

These were all questions that wetted any reader's appetite. Herald news editor Funny Mushava and business editor Cephas Chitsaka had pieced the story together despite the reluctance by the bank to talk to the paper. But come Tuesday when the story appeared. First it was not by Funny Mushava and Cephas Chitsaka unless there was a mistake somewhere since it was only by-lined Funny Mushava. Indeed, all the questions in the teaser were raised but somehow some explanation was given. After reading the story one was left with a feeling that perhaps this was the first instalment of a series which would be carried on the following day. But that was the end of it. Next, was a story quoting Finance Minster Herbert Murerwa that he was happy with the way the Reserve Bank is being run. Murerwa had provided the paper with a good news peg to pursue their story if they really believed the Reserve Bank was wasting taxpayer's money, but that was the end of it.

This led to a lot of speculation about what the purpose of doing the story was. Some observers, thought perhaps someone at Herald House had an axe to grind with someone at the Reserve Bank. Others felt maybe someone just wanted to tell us that the Governor of the Reserve Bank had spent millions of dollars on renovations at his official residence which he had not been using since 1993. Yet another theory was that perhaps it was to bring to our attention that IMF officials come here on holiday and not on business as they spent their time at the chalets in Juliasdale. Another "wild" suggestion was that it was perhaps one chef trying to outdo the other. In short, people were so short-changed they tried to build a better story of their own.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


387 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 26, 1997


Zimbabwe;
World Bank's $700m Continues To Be Elusive


BYLINE: staff reporter, The Insider (Harare)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Harare - The much-talked about World Bank $700 million facility, (which should now be around $760 million since it is actually US$70 million), the biggest facility for the indigenous business sector continues to be elusive.

Seven months have now gone since local World Bank officials said it would be disbursed. If Indigenous Business Development Centre (IBDC) president Ben Mucheche was right last year that five years had gone by since negotiations on the facility started then negotiations are now in their sixth year. 

The facility which was scheduled to be put on line in July, and received the green-light form the World Bank vice- President for Africa Callisto Madawo, a Zimbabwean, towards the end of last year and was even toasted by Finance Minster Herbert Murerwa when he visited Washington, has still not been disbursed vindicating The Insider which predicted that the facility would not be disbursed until this year. Although Parliament has now approved the loan, it is still not clear when it will be disbursed.

According to sources, the major hold-up has been disagreement between the World Bank and the government about the interest rate that should be charged. The bank insists that market rates should apply. The government is looking for a cheaper facility similar to the one it has provided under the Credit Guarantee Company.

Even commercial banks that will administer the facility argue that the problem in Zimbabwe is not lack of cash but high interest rates that are crippling the business sector. What business requires, they argue, is cheap money so if the World Bank money is not going to be cheaper than that already available on the open market, the facility is likely to be of little benefit.

While the two are still haggling about the technicalities, things seem to be moving in favour of the World Bank. Interest rates are starting to decline and they are likely to drop further following the Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe's reduction of its rediscount rate by 3.5 percent. Insiders, however, say there could be another hitch-who will disburse the money?

While there is no question that the bulk of the money will be disbursed by commercial banks, the question now is which ones. Watchers say the country's largest commercial bank, Standard Chartered, may be out unless it abruptly changes its current thrust. Sources say the bank no longer handles loans of under $250 000, which is probably what most small to medium enterprises require. Although chief executive, Barry Hamilton said his bank was trying to devise a means of effectively lending to small businesses because this is a very important sector, he also stated that the bank had lost substantial amounts of money to small businesses.

"We have not come out of it but we have been hurt by it," he was quoted as saying. Public-owned Zimbank in which the state is a major shareholder could also be out as it is trying to get up on its feet after being rescued by the Reserve Bank because of bad debts. This will leave only Stanbic, Barclays and the Commercial Bank of Zimbabwe which currently seems to be a darling with small businesses. But because of the publicity the fund has been given, almost every prospective business person is looking forward to a slice of the funds. Even the little known Indigenous Youth Empowerment Group is demanding its fair share of $10 million from the facility.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


388 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 26, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Chikowore Sees Reason At Last


BYLINE: staff reporter, The Insider (Harare)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Harare - Public Construction and National Housing Minister Enos Chikowore has seen the light at last. Unfortunately, this comes at the very time his ministry seems to have lost steam in its housing programme which was hailed - - once again unfortunately - - just prior to the 1995 general elections. 

He has finally admitted that the goal of housing for all by the year 2000 is unrealistic. And the year 2000 is only 35 months away. Chikowore said that the present housing waiting list is 670 000 and under the current rate of housing provision the backlog could increase to over one million by 2010.

But in the same breath he set 2010 as the target to provide housing for all. One can only hope he was misquoted because this does not make sense. All the same he must be commended for realising that 2 000 is not too far off.

IN fact, the way things are going, most people are expecting to be worse off by the year 2000. In Harare, for example, where the waiting list has been stagnant at 100 000 is likely to be worse as houses are increasingly getting out of reach of most people. While statistics seem to tell a different story, the reality is that nothing much is changing. One can only hope that other government departments and agencies can take cue from Chikowore because we still hear of health for all by the year 2000, or about 600 000 AIDS orphans by the year 2000. This figure has been touted about for the past three years yet the number of people dying of AIDS is reportedly increasing and is now reported to be 500 a week.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


389 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 26, 1997


Business and Finance;
Nokia Ads in Zimbabwe: SOME CELLPHONE!


BYLINE: staff reporter, The Insider (Harare)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Harare - The Com Shop advert about Nokia cellphones may just be doing what the doctor ordered. It has stirred the controversy that attracts attention to a product - - though this may be in bad taste to some.

Whether this is translated to sales or a boycott is something else but, it has created the attention. Debate on the advert "the one with the sulky model and the Nokias" was kicked off by Barbara Reed, who runs a market research firm. In her letter to the local media, Reed posed several questions about who the advert was targeted at. 

Was it aimed at those who believe they need "two Nokias and no brains," Males whose careers picked in the late 60s . .... Males whose organs are bigger than their brains ... Males with an infantile humour ... Females who think it's clever to be associated with the males described above ... Businessmen whose brains are below the belt?"

Reed was supported by Bev Clark who appears to own a Nokia. "If I had known how sexist their advertising was going to be, I certainly would not have bought a cellphone from them. It should be noted that advertising such as this isn't harmless and just irritating. By continuing to objectify women, whether it is subtle or just plain Nokia stupid perpetuates gender inequality. "

Praxedes Dzangare for DDH & M Advertising , the advertising agency which placed the advert asked: "Could that just have been a plug for a research company or was Barbara Reed really offended by the Com Shop advertisement for Nokia?... I'd like to say that we have far more women here than men- - eleven to five at last count. I am the MD, the media chief is a woman, two account directors are women ... We did give the advertisement a lot of thought when we first saw it, then ran it past all the girls here. Without exception, they found it more amusing than offensive .... There have been a number of calls from distressed women, all of very similar views, which I suppose one could describe as 'actively feminist'. Of course, we regret any offence to them and will try to steer a slightly different course next time. However, there have been at least as many calls from men and women who accepted the subject as a light- hearted flag-raising performance, which is how we ourselves viewed it".

The debate is likely to go on.

Business and Finance;
Zimbabwe's Strange Bedfellows


BYLINE: staff reporter, The Insider (Harare)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Harare - FLAMBOYANT businessman, Phillip Chiyangwa's threats may just be mere rhetoric. At least that is what one of the men who should have felt the wrath of the Affirmative Action Group when he came to Zimbabwe last year thinks. 

Standard Chartered Bank Zimbabwe's chief executive Barry Hamilton told delegates to a conference of business people in Victoria Falls: "I would like to think that his comments were mere rhetoric. We have reached a perfect understanding ..... Mr Chiyangwa was in my office the other day."

Contacted by a local daily Chiyangwa was quoted as saying: "Yes, we have opened dialogue but the results of our meeting are very slow in coming." Strange bedfellows, one might think. But the other question maybe what kind of "perfect understanding" have the two antagonists reached?

Africa News


February 26, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zimbabwe: Merlin Recovery Raises Questions About Cone


BYLINE: staff reporter, The Insider (Harare)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Harare - Bulawayo towelling firm, Merlin is back. "The greatest thing in this world is not so much where we are, but in what direction we are moving," the company says in adverts currently running in the local press.

"Thanks to our stakeholders and especially a dedicated staff and the loyalty of our customers, Merlin is forging ahead, supplying a thriving local market, focusing on all round excellence. Yes, Merlin is here to stay and going forward committed to building and maintaining quality in the Zimbabwean textile industry." 

The company was rescued by its sister company Merspin which pledged to invest $40 million relieving the company of a substantial amount of its interest-bearing debt and saving 1 200 jobs. This is good news indeed but it also puts into question: how did the other textile company, Cone, collapse completely after all the efforts and money the government and financial institutions put in and the sacrifices workers made?

Is the case of Cone now closed for good, when stories continue to be told about how its former principal owner is living in luxury and is reported to be expanding his other businesses, both locally and in neighbouring countries? Perhaps, as some government critics recently advocated, the Central Intelligence Organisation (CIO) should take up the matter as this is a case of greater national importance than harassing little nobodies. After all, the lives of nearly 50 000 people were put - - and are still - - at stake.

Or is it that the much-feared organisation cannot do anything because investigations could open up a can of worms? There have always been whispers that some chefs were involved in the wheeling and dealing of the previous owners? These whispers say the former owners were so well connected that this is why they managed to off-load all the company's debts to the government and financial institutions. The previous owners came out clean when they closed the factory while the government and financial institutions were saddled with heavy debts and workers were left empty-handed and given false hopes that the company could salvaged by someone else.f


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


392 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 26, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Two Important Conferences Lined Up In March


BYLINE: The Insider (Harare)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Harare - Two important conferences aimed at boosting investment in the country as well as exports are lined up for March, one in London and the other in Maputo.

The London conference which will be attended by top government officials including President Robert Mugabe is being organised by the Confederation of Zimbabwe Industries together with their British counterparts and will be held from March 15. It is a follow up to another conference that was held three years ago. 

The Mozambican mission is being organised by the trade promotion agency Zimtrade whose director, Morrison Sifelani has just resigned. Zimtrade says Mozambique provides limitless opportunities for Zimbabwe. Potential exports to that country include general foodstuffs such as groceries, biscuits, tea, coffee, jam, marmalades, cordials, dairy products, mealie meal, flour, edible fats and oils; engineering products and services which can include fire extinguishers, motor vehicles and motor vehicle spares; catering equipment, cosmetics; plumbing fittings and equipment; stationery, domestic appliances, utensils and enamelware; agricultural inputs and implements; railway components, grain bags, nets and ropes; tyres and tubes; bathroom accessories; plasticware; brushes; asbestos and assorted construction components, packaging materials; and paint and paint accessories.

Zimbabwe badly needs to boost its exports. According to the latest figures from the Central Statistics Office the country had a trade deficit of $2.2 billion in the first half of last year. It imported goods worth $12.6 billion and earned only $10.4 billion. The main imports were machinery and transport equipment which accounted for 40.4 percent of the amount spent on imports, manufactured goods which took 16.6 percent and chemicals which accounted for 12.9 percent. The main exports remained unmanufactured tobacco accounting for 22.5 percent of total export revenue followed by ferro alloys with 9.4 percent.

South Africa continued to dominate Zimbabwe's imports accounting for 38.1 percent followed by the United Kingdom with 9.4 percent and the United States with 5.7 percent. Japan, Germany and France followed. Most of Zimbabwe s exports went to the United Kingdom which took 13.2 percent, followed by South Africa with 11.3 percent and Germany with 7.2 percent. Major exports also went to Japan., Mozambique and Botswana.

In his message to mark the end of 1996, Sifelani said 1997 should see an increase in the volume of exports both regionally and internationally as 1996 had been a year of consolidating existing markets. He pointed out, however, that for this to happen, the business environment in Zimbabwe had to improve. Manufacturers should introduce new products, adapt existing ones and improve packaging if they were to withstand competition in the international arena. He said local businessmen should be more aggressive because they and stop being too risk averse . While trade with Botswana had recorded little change that in Namibia had increased by up to 400 percent since the signing of a trade agreement with that country.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


393 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 26, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zimbabwe Business Briefs


BYLINE: The Insider (Harare)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1040 words


 

Harare - Computer giant, IBM must be feeling the heat. After being accused of frustrating Zimbabweans within the local subsidiary, Bedford Investments, the company has resorted to placing full page adverts in the local media stating its commitment that it "fully accepts the requirements of the ZIC (Zimbabwe Investment Centre) that 30 percent of the equity should be held by local investors".

But accepting and implementing are two different things. Since its re-entry into Zimbabwe 14 months ago, the company says, IBM has more than doubled its business. It also says the majority of the company's employees and management are Zimbabwean. But the fact remains, some of the Zimbabweans are not happy. Denny Marandure, for example, has just resigned for allegedly being "parked" in South Africa. By the look of it, something must be terribly amiss within Bedford Investments. The adverts the company is placing are not cheap and Bedford Investments is going to great lengths to paint a picture that everything is above board. A full page in The Herald costs between $26 000 and $31 000, and that's a lot of money to spend on 140 words. 

THE government, always short of revenue, could have lost $8 million, allegedly through errors by shipping agents in the last quarter of 1996 had customs officials simply accepted and just ticked as correct all entries made by shipping agents. The Collector of Customs and Excise at Beitbridge Johnson Moyo is reported as saying out of an average 200 billls of entry submitted to customs, 30 percent fell under wrong tariffs. In January alone the department discovered some2 730 errors which would have cost the state $2.4 million if they had been let through. Shipping agents are now being charged $300 per error.

ALTHOUGH not producing enough to meet local demand, Zimbabwe is now stuck with more than 100 000 tonnes of wheat because of cheaper imports from Argentina. The Grain Marketing Board which recently reported that it had drastically reduced its debt is said to be saddled with 60 000 tonnes while private growers have 45 000 tonnes. GMB chairman Kumbirai Katsande who is also the managing director of Nestle, which itself is supposed to use a lot of wheat in its baby foods and other cereals, says local millers prefer Argentinean wheat which sells for US$250 a tonne, and is supposedly cheaper than local wheat which goes for $2 580 according to the latest Zimace prices. But the price difference is very insignificant unless the Argentinean wheat is well below US$250. Katsande said local wheat was of even better quality which poses even more questions as to why local millers prefer it.

With this year's good rains and most dams almost full, wheat farmers were going to have a bumper harvest but most are reported to be switching to barley which is grown under contract with National Breweries. But Natbrew requirements for barley are reported to be only between 55 000 and 60 000 tonnes. The government allowed local farmers to export wheat last year. But it looks it is not only wheat producers who are facing problems.

Zimbabweans have an appetite for imported foods according to Katsande and food manufacturers are finding it cheaper to import finished food products than manufacturing them because of the distorted tariff regime. He said the present tariffs favour the import of finished products as opposed to raw materials. Even retailers, he said, found it more lucrative to have direct supply arrangments with South African retailers who in turn supported their country's food manufacturing industry. "This linkage does not exist in Zimbabwe," he said.

SMALL-scale millers who have been credited with bringing down the price of mealie meal are now beginning to fell the pinch and they have increased their prices by between 10 and 12 percent. They say they can no longer contain the costs following the increase in the price of maize by the Grain Marketing Board, but most of the millers source their own maize and only resort to the GMB when they cannot find maize on the market. The GMB increased its maize selling price from $1 500 to $1 675 a tonne which is roughly the selling price on the open market. According to ZIMACE there are offers of up to $1 750 a tonne in April with the price likely to drop down to $1 500 the following month.

ZIMBABWE Alloys is suspending operations for the whole of March because of low metal prices on the world market. The company is facing stiff competition from lower priced products from China and the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS). But according to the Central Statisics Office, ferro alloys were the second major export from Zimbabwe in the first half of last year. Tobacco took top honours.Sales of ferro alloys brought in $840.7 million in the first six months of 1996 compared to $823 million in the first half of 1995.

ONE of the country's major tea producers. Tanganda is expecting to produce more than 8 000 tonnes of tea for the year ending October. Coffee production is also expected to surpass 600 tonnes. In the last financial year ending October it produced 8 909 tonnes of tea in 14 months. Coffee production was very disappointing resulting in an overall loss of $3.2 million compared to a profit of $9.8 million the previous year.

HARARE-based drink manufacturer Tru-Cool could go into liquidation because of competition from back-yard manufacturers in the high density suburbs.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


394 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 26, 1997


Business and Finance;
Interesting Mergers on the Zimbabwe Stock Exchange


BYLINE: Charles Rukuni, The Insider (Harare)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Harare - The Zimbabwe Stock exchange has turned into a market of stark contrasts. While the industrial index has been reaching new highs almost every month rising from just under 4 000 points at the beginning of 1996 to over 10 000 points a year later, the mining index has hit a 12-month low coming down to some 965 points.

This is despite news that there is growing interest in the mining industry, particularly in diamonds, although up to now only one mine is operating in the country. An analysis of share prices of the seven listed mining companies shows that all except Wankie have been badly hit. 

Ashanti which at one time traded for $200 is down to $100 but it has not hit its lowest price of $80 in the past 12 months. Bindura is around $8 down from a peak of $14.75. Gold miners Falcon and Falgold are worse. Falcon has dropped from $29 to $12.50 and Falgold from $3.10 to 90 cents. Wankie has only lost marginally from its peak of $6.20 to $5 but is way above its 12 monthlow of $1.70.

In industrials, although prices have started falling of late, the story is completely different with companies like ZSR which once traded (in the past 12 months) for $2.25 now trading at $15 and Zimpapers which at one time was down at $1.70 peaking at $30.

Even Truworths, in the troubled clothing industry and with its chief executive allegedly in some scam is up from $1.45 to $11, and sugar company, Hippo from $1.70 to $14.50.With most analysts predicting that there is likely to be no significant rise in the industrial index in the first half of the year as the market seeks to consolidate itself, focus seems to have turned to the mergers which have just been approved by the Reserve Bank. PGI has been given the green light to acquire troubled Johnson and Fletcher which was owned by the Meikles. J& F which at one time traded at $1.10 had gone up to $4.20 peaking at $4.80 while PGI itself has only marginally risen from $4.40 to $6.50 in the past 12 months. PGI is offering three PG I shares and $4 for every five J & F shares.

According to one market analyst the high cash content of the offer should be of concern because PGI was suffering from a high interest bill in the interim stage. The analyst said PGI would have to improve its cash generation significantly in the second half to ensure that the interest bill does not effectively eliminate operating profits. But there could be rewards to be reaped. Through the acquisition PGI has effectively gained a stranglehold on the manufacture and supply of timber and glass to the construction sector.

The other merger is between Hunyani and FP Holdings, another Meikles company. Hunyani is offering FP shareholders one Hunyani share and 76 cents for every 10 FP shares they hold. At the beginning of this month Hunyani was trading at $3.45 while FP was trading at 39 cents. It highest price in the past 12 months was only 40 cents and the lowest 18 cents. Hunyani's highest price was $4 and the lowest $2.45. The market analysts said FP was likely to contribute $11 million to Hunyani s operating profits during the year as there were likely to be huge cost savings through the streamlining of the head office as well as the slight reduction of workers.

In addition, the use of Hunyani's purchasing power should allow them to improve the purchase costs associated with their raw material supplies, the analyst said. The outlook for Hunyani is encouraging. Production of tobacco should be strong this year, and the company s sacks and cartons division should perform well given the phenomenal demand presently being experienced for fast food. The analyst also noted that Hunyani s intentions to move into the open crate boxes for distribution to horticultural concerns should prove profitable in the medium term, but he warned that operating margins have declined for four consecutive years and this trend is likely to continue. He said that while operating costs for Hunyani increased by only 12 percent last year, this was not in line with the cost increases associated with labour and raw materials. But the good news was that with the contribution from Print Holdings attributable profits were likely to be around $70 million to $75 million.

But the greatest attention seems to be focused on Trans-Zambezi Industries, a company that has acquired loss-making public companies and is trying to turn them around. TZI has just announced that it wants to acquire the entire share capital of Chloride and Art and would like to be listed on the ZSE. Art has been trading at around 10 cents from 65 cents and Chloride at $1.30 up from a 12-month low of 28 cents. TZI is offering one share for every 444 Art shares or nine cents for every Art share, one share for every 100 Art preference shares or 40 cents and one share for every 30 Art A shares or $1. 33 in cash. The same offer has been extended to Chloride where it is offering one share for every 30 Chloride shares or $1.33 cash. TZI shares will be in the form of depository receipts, the aim being that local receipt holders will not be prejudiced by double taxation.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


395 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 26, 1997


Zimbabwe;
IBDC Proposals For Indigenisation


BYLINE: a staff writer, The Insider (Harare)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 3814 words


 

Harare - STARTED last month this is the final part of the Idigenous Business Development Centre (IBDC) document on indigenisation which was presented to the ZANUPF national conference in Bulawayo in December.

The government through the Reserve Bank should direct that a minimum of 60 percent of investible funds be made available to the indigenous sector. This has been done in India and Malaysia and it has succeeded. These are the institutions which have failed the nation in providing funds for creating employment due to institutional racism and a colonial banking culture. As a matter of priority, government should review legislation governing the operations of financial institutions with the view to making them socially and politically receptive to the indigenisation policy and further take a long term view of the economic development of Zimbabwe.

The Banking Affairs Board should be put in place as soon as possible and the Banking Act must be amended. Government should admit new banks into the system under the mandate that 60 percent of the shareholding should be indigenous. Financial institutions, though state-owned or foreign-owned are in the main biased against indigenous business. Thus, even in those institutions which are government controlled, the indigenous entrepreneur faces similar problems to those in foreign, white owned institutions. The situation calls for decisive, corrective action by government. 

Family houses should not be taken by banks as security for loans in order to protect families who are on a daily basis being thrown out of their houses and rendered destitute. Adequate opportunity should be given to people to reschedule their loans with financial institutions. The Reserve Bank Act Chapter 173 must be amended in order to be supportive of indigenous people and stop regarding us as a high risk area as is the case now. The Reserve Bank Board must be changed in order to put in place more effective blacks who protect the interests of indigenous people.

In the light of the above, urgent action needs to be taken to substantially increase indigenous participation in the financial sector. The measures should include:

*Where the government has majority shareholding, the financial institutions must be given clear directives to support and fund indigenous companies.

*Government should either introduce legislation to regulate the use of pension funds and insurance investments for the benefit of indigenous people who in any case are the major contributors to these funds.

At all times government must make available loans at concessionary rates of interest to indigenous people.

Insurance and pension funds should be used for the development of indigenous businesses and the construction of factory shells where indigenous businesses can operate from. The largest mutual society in insurance business is Old Mutual with $12 billion assets. If only 10 percent of the Old Mutual funds were earmarked for the indigenous programme it will amount to $1.2 Billion. But for this to happen government must be serious about the indigenisation programme in the first place.

Up to this time, 16 years after independence the board of directors of Old Mutual is still nominated by interests in South Africa. The general manager and the actuary are nominated by South African interests with the Commissioner of Insurance and Registrar of Pension and Provident Funds only rubber- stamping these nominations.

The Minister of Finance and Attorney-General should examine the special responsibilities and principal functions of the Commissioner of Insurance as stipulated in Part 11 and Part 111 of the Insurance Act of 1987, with a view to ensuring that black Zimbabweans are appointed as general manager and chairman of Old Mutual as a condition of acceptance of the mutual society to function in Zimbabwe.

Ideally the issue of non-banking and mobilisation of insurance funds in particular should be reviewed under a broad policy sweep. The government of Zimbabwe can legitimately exercise the following of its prerogatives:

*Review the position of the chief executive and chairman of Old Mutual and ask the present board to set a panel of interviewers.

*The nomination of the actuary at the end of the expiry of the incumbent's (tenure) to be that of indigenous citizens who will be sympathetic to the development objectives and goals of Zimbabwe.

The reality of the management of Old Mutual is that the board is not autonomous. Control is still vested in the South African board of Old Mutual who appoint the local board of directors. Zimbabwe should look at the internal incorporation of Old Mutual as a matter of urgency.

Through a regulatory mechanism foreign investment should be directed to ensure qualitative indigenous participation of at least 61 percent. The chairman of such a company and even a foreign owned company must be Indigenous. There should be areas exclusively left for indigenous businesses. While foreign investment is welcome, it should not be accepted at the expense of our sovereignty and the indigenisation of the national economy.

The aim of foreign investment should be to complement local indigenous investment. Too much is being done to promote foreign investment and very little is being done to promote local, i.e indigenous investment. This goes against the grain and logic of who we want to promote in order to control our nation s economy.

No permits for safari camps, tour operators, hunting concessions, etc. should be renewed and given to non-indigenous people in order to enable indigenous people to now enter this foreign currency earning sector. This area remains a preserve for whites and foreign multinationals at present.

This sector needs to be urgently de-racialised. The sector is dominated by white minority entrepreneurs. Indigenous participation in the sector is limited mainly to government participation. The main factors impeding indigenisation include: unavailability of land; limited access to finance; restrictive legislation. In addition, government should also put in place a package of incentives and deliberate policies for affirmative action to encourage and promote the entry of indigenous entrepreneurs into small and medium enterprises in the sector. There is need to urgently review existing legislation in order to ensure that it does impede the participation in the sector by indigenous people. Tourist training facilities should be expanded.

Concentration of activity in the construction sector is among a small number of large and medium sized members of the Construction Industry Federation of Zimbabwe (CIFOZ) which is largely white, which accounts for 75 percent total construction sector domestic turnover despite the existence of many small indigenous contractors who largely belong to the Zimbabwe Building Contractors Association (ZBCA). Apart from racist attitudes prevailing in the sector, other constraints to indigenisation include: shortage of skilled manpower; inadequate financial resources and obsolete plant and equipment.

More indigenous people should be allowed to become stock brokers and a parallel stock exchange which deals in indigenous securities only should be established.

The policy objectives articulated in the economic reform programme as outlined in the budget are: the reduction of central government deficit from 10 percent to 5 percent of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) by fiscal year 1994/95; reform of public enterprises to include a series of measures aimed at eliminating the large budgetary burden of the public enterprise sector by making the public enterprises more efficient; moving away from a centralised system of allocating foreign exchange to a fully market based system through trade liberalisation; liberalisation of price controls and relaxation of labour controls; investment promotion and domestic deregulation; monetary and financial sector reform; and implementation of a social dimensions of adjustment programme to assist the poor and vulnerable members of society.

The biggest pressure that our government faces is that of indigenising this economy and creating employment. It is therefore important that we look at our priorities and allocate resources through the national budget in order to achieve the objective. There is need for a parallel programme to assure the indigenous people a stake in the economy so that they can feel supportive of ESAP and its overall objectives.

This proposal points to areas that should receive attention in the indigenisation programme. Without specific policies and measures parallel to ESAP, the indigenous sector can easily be obliterated and marginalised under the new economic framework. Because the indigenous sector is still fragile, indigenisation should also involve the promotion and consolidation of the public sector.

Government officials should not continue to make recommendations which commit the nation on matters that cause us undue hardships. Consultation should be made with more indigenous people as opposed to only consulting with white lobby groups and at the same time yielding to their so-called public pressure. ESAP should not be pursued at the expense of indigenous people. The little that indigenous people had is being lost. We need to learn to protect our interests and not simply adopt and run with programmes which undermine, weaken and interfere with the consolidation of our economic nationhood. We are continuing to borrow offshore funds at low interest rates in order to support the protection of foreign companies by importing goods from outside while our local companies are being rendered uncompetitive because of high interest rates.

Government should give work to black consultants and stop favouring foreign consultants who are not knowledgeable about our economy and the problems of our people. We should like to see the immediate reversal of this trend in favour of our indigenous consultants including lawyers, accountants, doctors, etc, who in most cases are more qualified than these non-indigenous consultants. Parastatals and government departments should use indigenous lawyers, accountants, auditors, estate agents, insurance brokers etc. There should be a requirement that foreign donors and organisations should use local consultants.

Parastatals should be directed to implement affirmative action in awarding tenders to indigenous people. Shares in parastatals should be donated to the National Investment Trust Fund. Parastatals should not be sold to foreigners, since that amounts to selling the indigenous birth right of indigenous people. Joint ventures between indigenous entrepreneurs and foreign entities should be encouraged particularly in the proposed Export Processing Zones provided indigenous people control 61 percent.

Persons appointed to parastatal boards and other boards are expected to represent government and in the course become instruments of policy changes including implementation of the same. By virtue of their appointment by government as part of its affirmative action (hitherto known as black advancement) some of these indigenous appointees have now turned out to be Uncle Toms while others are simply downright cowards who are afraid of changing the status quo. Under the guise of professionalism some of these representatives unashamedly turn against government and start to actively represent white people s interests in return for a few or no favours at all. Government should as a matter of urgency review the whole list of these appointments with a view to changing representatives to such boards.

Some government officials blindly recommend and support programmes which seek to transfer power government to market forces/whites. Such activities amount to an abdication of responsibility and national duty. The market forces are: multinationals - white; large companies - white; white associations and white cartels; white lobby groups; a white stock exchange which is made up of 60 percent Old Mutual, 30 percent pension funds and 10 percent other. Blacks are consumers whose powers can only be exercised precariously in a consumer boycott.

Having established white controlled economic and trade associations whites lobbied for power to be transferred from government ministries to these associations (i.e the market ) in order to perpetuate racial economic control of the economy by a minority group. It should be noted that many of these associations have cornered lucrative economic sectors including all activities linked to exports. It should also be remembered that a lot of economic acts of Parliament were amended just before independence and power/control was removed from government and transferred to white controlled associations. Some of these associations even took with them government assets through such schemes. Government should de-recognise all economic associations and let the proposed Indigenisation Commission reconstitute these associations with indigenous mandates.

There has been a lot of lobbying to impress upon government to reduce its expenditure. As part of this exercise expenditure on health, education and the civil service is supposed to be reduced and it is wrongly proposed that parastatals should be sold. Consequently the power and control which black people have through their government would then be transferred to whites or white associations and as a result economically voting out the little control that we have on the economy.

Ironically none of these pressure groups is highlighting the issue of government revenue. Surprisingly all these lobbies are silent about the billions of dollars which government is losing through transfer pricing by members of their associations. For example, government is losing more than $3. 4 billion a year in the tobacco exports alone through such practices. It is a known fact that economic security and national security are interwoven. Activities of this nature which are intended to undermine government s capacity to support and sustain its national obligations should be viewed very seriously because they are ultimately intended to weaken and destroy our government and its people.

To the extent to which advertisers who in the main are white controlled companies with dominating representation in the Advertising Media Association (ADMA), it is not correct to believe that all privately owned and some of the government newspapers express completely independent views. Both the editorial and advertising policies of even some newspapers in which government is a shareholder appear to be tailor made to advance and protect white minority interest groups who continue to control 98 percent of the economy. It is easy to note that the papers are now preparing blacks psychologically and mentally for both economic and political surrender to whites. For example a number of white owned institutions in this country have broken the law by conducting chimbadzo. On a daily basis the newspapers carry adverts of houses owned by blacks being repossessed. Most of these houses being repossesed have been the result of illegal interest on interest being charged by these financial institutions.

When requests were made to place adverts highlighting this practice white people protested to their colleagues in the media and were assured that such adverts would not run in spite of government being the majority shareholder of some of the papers. Topics and issues concerning the indigenisation of the economy are totally omitted by some of the papers. When issues of indigenisation are being published it is only in the context of either condemning or undermining them. We have always expected our national media to uphold and defend the ideals of the broad masses of Zimbabweans. Unfortunately this does not seem to be happening. It is important that our vision and the ideals which were born during the liberation struggle for political independence, black economic empowerment, national unity and stability should continue to be upheld.

We are now fed up of our national media trying to lead and manipulate our government s thinking on matters concerning foreign investment. Publishing, upholding and supporting views of racist whites and their fronts appears to be the ultimate of what constitutes Press Freedom these days. The composition of all media boards where government has an interest in the media should be urgently reviewed and reconstituted.

The budget is an instrument which government should use in a bold manner to allocate and direct resources in order to achieve its objectives. Some of the objectives to be achieved in the short term are:

*Employment creation and entry of indigenous people into the economy by providing an environment for sustainable domestic and indigenous led investment.

*Create markets and opportunities for indigenous participation and economic empowerment in the main stream productive sectors and transform the imbalance in the ownership structure of assets.

*Promote decentralised economic growth and support rural development thus effectively distributing wealth.

*Implementation of an effective land resettlement and water harvesting programme.

Given the above, government should take measures and allocate resources through the budget in order to achieve these objectives. We have had standstill budgets for too long. Such budgets obviously preserve the status quo which is most unacceptable. The Credit Guarantee Company should be turned into a development commercial bank. It already has the money and what is left is for it to open up branch offices in all provinces. Government should set aside $2 billion this year for indigenisation.

The largest market in Zimbabwe is provided by government. Government is the biggest buyer of goods and services in the country and is therefore the biggest market with close to $8 billion to spend for such goods and services. This market should be made available to indigenous businesses through a deliberate affirmative action policy. There is no doubt that the affirmative action policy implemented by the Ministry of Public Construction has provided a sure entry for indigenous businesses in this sector.

Tenders below $25 million should be competed for by indigenous businesses only. A vigorous programme in implementing the affirmative action policy in the awarding of tenders at district, provincial and national level should be pursued. Tender committees should be set up at district , provincial and national levels in order to monitor the implementation of the affirmative action policy. At the moment government does not have a mechanism of monitoring implementation of the affirmative action policy.

Hospitals and government institutions should give preference to women, cooperatives and youth groups when making purchases of goods and services which can be obtained within their local areas.

A National Productivity Centre should be set up. The centre will focus on looking at what can be produced in our country, and establishing the local and export markets for the products in advance in the same way as how the growing and marketing of tobacco is done. This function can be given to the Planning Commission, Ministry of Industry and Commerce and Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe.

Commissioned greenfield manufacturing projects to qualify for a five year tax moratorium, to allow cash flow stabilisation. Uncollectable taxes from indigenous traders in rural areas to be written off. Allowance of death duties should be increased to $1 million to take account of the inflation and devaluation of the Zimbabwe dollar.

Duties and taxes on imports of machinery and capital equipment by indigenous people to be waived.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


396 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 26, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Government Financial Managers Groping In The Dark


BYLINE: Charles Rukuni, The Insider (Harare)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2227 words


 

Harare - Critics of structural adjustment programmes always complain about meddling by the Bretton Woods Institutions (BWIs) the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. They claim that these institutions second their advisers to the Central Bank and the Ministry of Finance to keep tabs on what is happening.

If this applies to Zimbabwe, then the BWI advisers must be on a honeymoon, probably spending most of their time at the Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe chalets at Juliasdale as claimed by The Herald.

So far the BWIs have given Zimbabwe an almost clean slate. Apart from failing to trim the large civil service, controlling government expenditure and failing to meet targets set under the first phase of the Economic Structural Adjustment Programme, they claim the country has not yet been thrown to the dogs. It can be salvaged. All they won't give it is balance of payment support. 

But investigations by The Insider have just revealed that not only is the government failing to control expenditure and to collect all the revenue due to the State --although tax officers have just launched a door-to-door inspection and collection campaign--but it is also failing to properly account for that little revenue it gets.

The Insider has just discovered that up to now accounts for the financial year ending June 1995 have not yet been audited, yet the Audit and Exchequer Act clearly stipulates that this should be carried out by March 31 each year. In this case the audit should have been completed by March 31, 1996. As a result, the country is literally groping in the dark not certain whether the money allocated in 1994-95, and in 1995-96 was properly used or not.

The 1996-97 financial year has already gone eight months and it is only four months before another budget. Unfortunately the main culprit is the government s financial manager, the Ministry of Finance. It is reliable understood that treasury held up the audit because it only submitted accounts for the Consolidated Revenue Fund for the year ending June 1995 in January this year. Apparently the salary of the Comptroller and Auditor- General is charged to this Consolidated Revenue Fund.

According to section 31 of the Audit and Exchequer Act, unless the treasury otherwise directs, all appropriation accounts should be closed and the financial returns should be submitted to treasury within one month after the end of the financial year.

This means treasury should have the final returns at least by the beginning of August. Returns to the Comptroller and Auditor-General should be submitted within two months. Treasury should prepare and submit to the Comptroller and Auditor-General statements of account showing the transactions of the Consolidated Revenue Fund and the financial position of the State within four months after the end of the financial year. This means the accounts submitted in January this year should have been submitted by the end of October 1995.

But the Comptroller and Auditor-General is equally to blame. He has the powers to summon any officer and is entitled to receive "without undue delay from that officer" any information he requires to discharge his duties. The Insider also understands that the Auditor-General can close his books and prepare his report even if some accounting officers have not submitted their accounts. All he has to do is state this in his report.

According to the Comptroller and Auditor-General's report for the year ending June 30, 1991, the Auditor-General submitted his report on March 31, 1992 and clearly stated: This is the first time since independence that I have been able to meet the Statutory date of March 31. The credit goes to my staff for their dedication and commitment and of course to the cooperation I received from accounting officers . Team effort paid with the Auditor-General beating the deadline by 30 days for the year ending June 30, 1993 but the rot started creeping in. The audit for the year ending June 30, 1994 was five days late. It was signed on April 5, 1995. The 1995 audit has not yet been signed and it has to be tabled in Parliament before it can be made public.

Observers say even when the Auditor-General meets statutory requirements there is nothing to be proud of. "Why should he brag about it when it takes his office six months to audit twelve months' work? After all, government ministries are required to submit their accounts to the Auditor-General two months after the end of the financial year and he is given six months after that to audit the same accounts. There is nothing to boast about. In fact, there must be something terribly wrong with the way his office operates. Imagine a public company like Delta taking six months to audit its books, can that ever be acceptable?"

While a lot has been said about the need for Zimbabwe to be on the IMF s good books, there is now a strong belief that it is not the IMF money that Zimbabwe needs but the discipline that (comes) packaged with the IMF money . The influential First Merchant Bank in its latest quarterly guide to the economy clearly states that by the end of this financial year, Zimbabwe will have gone nearly two years without the IMF s financial support -- 21 months to be exact. As a result the country has received reduced levels of funding from donor countries and aid agencies yet all indications are that its economy is booming. As a country, our real failing over the years has simply been our own lack of self-discipline. If the authorities and politicians had run our affairs with more accountability, our better managed resources would have been more than sufficient to promote the needed economic growth, the bank says.

With the country appearing to be heading for an economic boom, the delay in finalising the audit may appear trivial but studies carried out by The Insider last year indicated that although fewer ministries were overspending the amount that they overspent had more than doubled in the four years between 1991 and 1994 -- the last year for which an audit is available.

While seven ministries out of 25 exceeded their allocations by $113.7 million in 1991, four ministries out of 25 overspent by $269.1 million the following year. Although the figure declined to $46.2 million in 1993, it shot up to $241.7 million in 1994. During the four years 14 out of 22 ministries overspent in at least one year. The worst culprits were the ministries of Home Affairs, Public Construction and National Housing, Finance, Transport and Foreign Affairs. The 1995 audit would therefore show whether there has been any improvement in the financial management of taxpayers' money by these ministries.

Another aspect that should be of interest to all taxpayers is how the drought levy is being used. It is not yet clear where the funds are being allocated as it had been hinted that the Grain Marketing Board might be involved. Former Finance Minister Ariston Chambati once said that part of the money would be used to buy strategic reserves while the bulk would be kept as cash reserves because it was costly to keep food reserves physically. There are strong fears that these cash reserves are not reflected in the government balance sheet. There are some whispers that since the government is usually short of cash, treasury might have used the money to pay off some of government s running expenses.

According to the last audit report, there are two funds related to drought: the National Drought Fund and the National Drought Relief Fund. As of June 30, 1994 the National Drought Fund, which was established to alleviate the effects of drought and other natural hazards adversely influencing food security and to promote the development of food production designed to counteract drought and/or purposes incidental thereto, had $31.7 million made up of $19.5 million in cash at the bank, $5.3 million in interest and nearly $7 million in investments. No expenditure was incurred from the fund with the cost of administering the fund, estimated at $6 250 being met from votes.

Under the National Drought Relief Fund also set up to alleviate the effects of drought and other natural hazards adversely influencing food security and to promote the development of food production designed to counteract drought and for purposes incidental thereto , there was $13.5 million as at June 30, 1994 with $10.7 million in cash at the bank and $2.8 million in advances to projects. This fund had nearly $27 million the previous year and $13.4 million was spent on projects which were not spelt out in the report. Although smaller than the National Drought Fund it was more costly to administer. Administration expenses, which were met from votes were estimated at $20 750.

Another thing that is worrying financial administrators is that the delay in finalising the 1995 audit means a delay in assessing the real impact of the Stop-Payment System which was introduced by the government in the 1995-96 financial year. Finance Minister Herbert Murerwa in announcing his current budget implied that the system was working and, for the first time, ministries had managed to keep within their budgets. Public companies, however, clearly said this was not entirely true because some of them especially those in the construction industry reported that their operations had been severely affected by the stop-payment system as government departments had not paid for goods already supplied or their clients could not pay them because they in turn had not been paid by the government.

According to one insider, the delay in auditing the government finances could also result in the wrong accounting officers being blamed. This is what happened in the case of Home Affairs Secretary Tineyi Chigudu. He was blamed for something that had been done by his predecessor. The audit report has to be debated in Parliament. If it is finally released the 1995 audit will be debated in 1997 and MPs might blame the wrong permanent secretary if there have been changes in the ministry.

But it appears no one really cares. Even Parliament, which is supposed to be the watchdog, and to which the Auditor-General is answerable, has not been barking. It has been approving budgetary allocations every year without insisting on finding out how money allocated the previous year was used. In fact, debate on some of the votes even appears to be a mockery if one closely scrutinises some of the government finances. One account, for example, has not been published since 1989 yet the department continues to be allocated money to cover its losses.

According to the last available Auditor-General's report accounts of the Central Mechanical Equipment Department (CMED) have not been published for the years ending June 1990, 1991, 1992, 1993 and 1994. The report was for 1994. Until the release of the 1995 accounts it is impossible to know whether the CMED has finally published its accounts. The Harare International Conference Centre, which has become a popular venue for both local and international conferences, had also not published its accounts for the years ending 1992,1993 and 1994. The National Fund for Rehabilitation and Reconstruction was two years in arrears. It had not published its accounts for 1993 and 1994. The same applied to the Medical Stores Trading Account, the Village Community Workers Bicycle Revolving Fund, and the Settlement Loan Fund. The Social Development Fund was one year behind, and so were the Rosemary and Norman Levin Bursary Fund, the Vocational Training Loan Account and the Vocational Training Loan Fund. Parliament has therefore been approving funds into these accounts without knowing how the money is being used, and for years.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


397 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 26, 1997


Sports - General;
Quick recall not likely for Pienaar


BYLINE: Gavin Rich, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1040 words


 

Cape Town - Carel du Plessis' arrival on the coaching firmament is unlikely to mean a reprieve for deposed Springbok skipper Francois Pienaar.

While the new national coach is talking of a change in approach, which would mean yet another shift in thinking from South Africa's top players, the former Bok wing seems satisfied that the men who took the Boks through the end-of-year overseas tour unbeaten are the ones to beat the British Lions and win the Tri-Nations.

This will come as a huge relief to a playing staff who must be getting tired of the switching and changing which has seen four new Bok coaches in five years. Each new coach has different ideas on how the game should be played and which players are best equipped to do the job, and understandably a change in boss leads to uncertainty. 

With the British Lions due in South Africa less than three months from now and the Tri-Nations to follow soon afterwards, upheaval at playing level is the last thing needed by a rugby nation desperate to wipe out the memory of last year's first-ever home series defeat by New Zealanby

Du Plessis has promised to use form and merit as his sole criteria for selection and said the need to spread the playing resource base as wide as possible would of necessity include looking at those players who are seeking their fortune in Britain.

However he did not appear to think much of the prospect of a return to the frame for Pienaar and Joel Stransky.

"The problem is that there are question-marks over the standard of British club rugby and even if those players do perform well there we don't know how to judge their readiness for a test series," said Du Plessis.

"The Super 12 is played at a much higher level than rugby in the northern hemisphere and that is where I expect the players to come from. To be honest with you, it is unlikely that we will call up a player who is not either playing in South Africa or in the Super 12."

And if Du Plessis was not altogether sold on Andre Markgraaff's playing style, he does appear to have respect for his selections.

"The results at the end of last year speak for themselves. I want to keep the momentum going and I have no intention of making unnecessary disruptions to the squad at this stage. The players all came through well on last year's tour and as far as possible I would like to stick to them."

That means Gary Teichmann is likely to remain as captain of a squad, which should retain its distinctly Natalian flavour.

But although Teichmann yesterday described Du Plessis as a nice guy and pledged his 100 percent support for whoever was coaching the Boks, it remains to be seen how the players will react if Du Plessis' new style represents a major shift from that followed towards the end of the Markgraaff era.

Du Plessis has described the Markgraaff way as one-dimensional, a view which is unlikely to be shared by those players weaned on a modern style of rugby which saw Natal rack up a record number of tries en route to the Currie Cup title last year.

At present Du Plessis' new approach is known only to himself and those South African Rugby Football Union officials who backed his appointment ahead of more experienced candidates and even some who know him well fear that his much-spoken-of vision may be more romantic than practical.

We will only know once he has started coaching, but the management team he assembles around him could give us some indication.

Current assistant coaches Nick Mallett and Hugh Reece-Edwards, both forward- thinking modern students of the game, are avid disciples of the 90s flat-ball approach, and are unlikely to be satisfied with a fundamental shift from that which started to evolve on the tour of Argentina, France and Wales.

Both have expressed a desire to meet with Du Plessis before deciding on their future involvement with the national team as they quite rightly feel they cannot be attached to something they don't believe in.

Du Plessis, for his part, has not gone as far as to say that he will dispense with direct rugby and it may be that he just intends mixing it up more (something Markgraaff himself was keen on) and introducing new options.

If that is the case, it would come as a significant boost to South Africa's chances of beating the Lions, Australia and New Zealand as it would entail less of an adjustment. As one official put it yesterday, South Africa, having made great progress towards the end of 1996, can ill-afford to return to square one again.

Du Plessis intends to name his management team next week, but he has hinted at a change.

"I don't want to create any expectations, but I think there might be a change to the coaching," said Du Plessis, who added that he wanted to keep the basic management structure intact.

If there is a change, it seems Mallett, who many in top coaching circles felt was the ideal man to commandeer the Springbok ship, could be the one to go.

It seems Du Plessis favours former Bok flanker Gert Smal as his forward coach, which would mean no place for Mallett, regarded by many of those who were there as the real success story of late-1996.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 26, 1997


South Africa;
Call for major changes in laws on rape


BYLINE: Lindsay Barnes, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Cape Town - Radical changes have to be made to the judicial system if more women are to be encouraged to report the crime of rape, women's organisations say.

They are unanimous in their call for major improvements in the handling of cases of violence against women, while acknowledging that some improvements have been made. In spite of the Government's promised intervention, there is no sign that the number of rapes are dropping. 

Provincial Rape Crisis director Carol Bower said it was "very possible" there had been an increase in reported rape in the Western Cape this year.

This could not necessarily be attributed to an increase in rape incidents as it was easier for women to report rape in the new South Africa, she said.

A more "user-friendly" criminal justice system was vital in the fight against rape, said Western Cape Rape Crisis legal advisor Bronwyn Pithey.

It was one thing for Government departments to recognise in legislation that rape victims had to be handled more sensitively, but this had to filter down through training to police and prosecutors at ground level, she said.

Lifeline counselling manager Caron Erasmus said that during counselling rape victims displayed feelings of anger and helplessness. The decision whether or not to go ahead with a case was undermined by a feeling of powerlessness because of the functioning of the judicial system. Rape Crisis received an average of 90 rape-related calls a month.

"Many of them (rape victims) decide not to prosecute because the system perpetuates these feelings and they are ambivalent whether or not it would help to go to court," she said.

Lisa Vetten, education co-ordinator for the Sexual Harassment Education Project in Gauteng, said there was a vast discrepancy between people convicted in indecent assault cases and rape cases (73 percent compared with 50 percent). The difference could be attributed to the onus on the State in rape cases to prove the victim did not consent to sex.

"Rape is the only crime where the State is obliged to prove the absence of consent. This means a victim has a better chance of getting a conviction with indecent assault," she said.

She suggested rewording the definition of rape so that a woman could alter the charge to indecent assault.

She called for the moratorium on prosecution posts to be lifted and said a possible solution was a pool of private attorneys to be engaged on a contractual basis on rape cases. Few prosecutors were assigned regularly to rape cases.

Statistics, she said, were needed on how long it took from the time a rape was reported to the end of the court case. Statistics were also needed on how many rape charges were reduced to common or sexual assault.

It was also time the State looked at establishing victims' advocates, who would offer support such as information on how a police investigation was proceeding and when the case was expected to get to court. "At this stage the victim is only a witness in the case. Things need to be rebalanced so that the victim is regarded as being as important as the suspect."

Ms Pithey said it was encouraging that the Government was becoming more committed to the issue as a result of outspoken MPs and rape victims such as Nomboniso Gasa, who was raped on Robben Island, going publi South Africa suffered from a culture in which violence was seen as a means to resolve conflict and invariably the most vulnerable groups - women and children - were the victims, she said.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


399 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 26, 1997


South Africa;
Cape's new traffic chief puts service in saddle


BYLINE: Sharkey Isaacs, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Cape Town - New provincial traffic chief Sherman Amos, who started his new job at the beginning of the month, is determined to transform the image of his department in the eyes of road-users.

Mr Amos, 43, promised that phased-in changes "are a-coming" to change the department's image from a traffic "force" into a traffic "service" with high visibility. "I intend adopting an approach which will see sweeping changes. Don't get me wrong, it will not make personnel soft and there will still be law enforcement. We will still be on the lookout for people who wilfully disregard legislation . 

"Law enforcement will still be carried out but it will now be done in programmes tempered with controlled restraint and the ultimate goal will not be to issue tickets but rather to educate and advise," he said.

One of the first innovations he plans will be a 24-hour help desk at the Gene Louw Traffic College in Brackenfell.

"It will give help to all road-users, including pedestrians."

Staff would be vigilant at all times, not just during the festive season and at Easter, when there were larger volumes of traffic on the roads.

"The courts must also be encouraged to adopt tougher approaches to serious offenders, as in a recent hearing in Laingsburg in which a motorist was fined R9 000 when found guilty of reckless driving."

Mr Amos said his personnel had already pledged loyalty and support and he now sought the support of all road-users.

As head of a department with a staff of about 400, he is required to make regular inspections of the 12 traffic centres across the province.

He has to control an area extending from Cape Town to Sir Lowry's Pass, Grabouw, Knysna, Mossel Bay, Oudtshoorn and through the Karoo up to Beaufort West, as well as up the West Coast past Citrusdal and Clanwilliam to Lambert's Bay, and beyond Nuwerus.

Mr Amos is a former public prosecutor at Goodwood Magistrate's Court, has his B Juris degree from Unisa and a B Proc from the University of the Western Cape.

He never looked back after joining the traffic department of the Cape Divisional Council in Ottery in 1973. He joined the provincial administration's traffic wing in 1986. He was promoted to principal provincial traffic inspector in 1990.

One of the highlights of his career was a transfer in December 1995 to the National Department of Transport in Pretoria when he was promoted to deputy director in the directorate of traffic legislation.

Africa News


February 26, 1997


Sports - General;
Ball moves to quell Italian fury over Rome 'skulduggery' quotes


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Cape Town - Olympic bid chief executive Chris Ball has sent a written apology to the Italian media to quell a storm of protest over suggestions that arch-rival Rome has been guilty of "skulduggery and disinformation" in the race for the Games.

With less than two weeks to go to the crucial shortlist selection in Lausanne, the bid company sought yesterday to placate Roman officials angered by suggestions they had had a hand in highlighting Cape Town's crime problems to their advantage.

The Italian media cried foul - one newspaper, Il Tempo, carried a report under the headline "Olympic Poison from Cape Town" - after a news agency report quoted Mr Ball as saying South Africa had been warned there would be " all sorts of skulduggery, including disinformation". 

The report also quoted him as saying: "Rome is trying to knock us off. If Rome can persuade the world that Cape Town is not safe, Cape Town can't beat Rome. The IOC itself understands that crime is not an issue in the Games. The issue is security and Rome has bigger security problems than Cape Town."

The remarks arose from Mr Ball's protest at the negative slant of agency reports on the International Olympic Committee evaluation commission's assessment.

In a carefully worded statement to the Italian media yesterday, Mr Ball said: "A (news) report has come to my attention which attributes a number of inappropriate comments to myself regarding Rome. I would like to make it clear that the discussion referred to has been misunderstood and I apologise for any awkwardness that this may have caused."

He added: "We have had regular contact with representatives of the Italian media and they will know that the comments are inconsistent with the ongoing tenor of our communication."

The Cape Town bid team had "consistently respected the integrity of the bidding process and I have personally ensured that we have followed both the letter and the spirit of the rules in this contest in every sense".

The saga is understood to have been discussed at talks yesterday between Sports Minister Steve Tshwete, head of the National Olympic Committee of SA Sam Ramsamy, Mr Ball and other officials.

South Africa;
Cape Town 'flight from hell' still in air - after three days


BYLINE: Joseph Aranes, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Cape Town - What should have been the flight of a lifetime for hundreds of tourists coming to South Africa from London turned into a "flight from hell".

Three days after taking off from Heathrow airport on what was supposed to be a 12-hour non-stop flight to Cape Town, they have yet to arrive. They are due here later today - at least they hope so.

Their nightmare began when their South African Airways jumbo jet had technical difficulties after take-off which forced the pilot to make unscheduled landings leaving the passengers stranded in Paris, Zurich and Frankfurt.

SAA spokeswoman Janie van Vuuren said all the passengers would arrive in Cape Town later today.

The travellers boarded the ill-fated flight at Heathrow airport on Sunday but soon after take-off the pilot had problems with the wing flaps and decided to land at Charles de Gaulle airport in Paris.

Passengers were taken to a hotel while technicians tried to rectify the fault. The aircraft took off on Monday evening, but the problem repeated itself and the pilot put down in Z/rich, Switzerland.

A technical team from Johannesburg was called while the passengers were flown to Frankfurt to board another SAA flight to Cape Town. Arrangements were also made for some passengers to board other flights. Ms Van Vuuren said SAA had apologised profusely to the passengers for the inconvenience.

Africa News


February 26, 1997


Business and Finance;
Singapore's PM tips SA as economic springboard


BYLINE: William-Mervin Gumede, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Cape Town - South Africa could become the economic link between the booming economies of East Asia and South America, Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong has said.

Africa was between East Asia and South America and South Africa was strategically placed to serve as an important bridge on the continent - just as Singapore did in East Asia, Mr Goh said.

South Africa could begin by allowing airlines to fly freely in its airspace, Mr Goh, who also discussed the matter with President Mandela, said his suggestion went beyond just airlines and included other trade and economic areas. 

He warned that South Africa should not depend on aid, but find the right economic strategies to take the country forward.

Mr Goh said yesterday Singapore was a hub in East Asia, where exciting growth was taking place. In Singapore's next growth phase, it would be looking at investing its capital elsewhere.

He said South America, which had growth rates of up to seven percent and low inflation, was one of the options.

Deputy President Thabo Mbeki said Singapore was admired worldwide for its economic successes and it was a challenge to South Africa "to see if we can emulate your example".

A high-level Singaporean delegation, which arrived in South Africa on Monday, included 40 businessmen scouting for investment opportunities, and several senior government members. Deputy Foreign Affairs Minister Aziz Pahad said the talks indicated the growing ties between the two countries.

Singapore's National Development Minister, Lim Hing Kiang, welcomed South Africa's focus on Asia, and said government agreements between the two countries had also been discussed. The South African delegation at the talks included Deputy Finance Minister Gill Marcus and Deputy Trade and Industry Minister Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka.

Mr Goh also met Home Affairs Minister Mangosuthu Buthelezi and Western Cape Premier Hernus Kriel.

A state banquet in his honour took place at Tuynhuys last night. He is visiting Robben Island today and will have talks with Deputy President Mbeki before leaving for Johannesburg.
