Africa News


February 26, 1997


Business and Finance;
Shoprite looking for banking partner


BYLINE: Alide Dasnois, Business Editor, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Cape Town - Pepkor's supermarket chain Shoprite Checkers is getting ready to break into the financial services market later this year, but has not yet chosen a banking partner, managing director Whitey Basson says.

Mr Basson said finishing touches were being put to Shoprite's in-store technology and the systems would be ready in June or July.

Financial services could grow to be "a good part" of Shoprite's business, he said. 

"We have 25 million customers a year. We can sell them baked beans or we can sell them funeral policies. Even if we have a hit rate of 10 percent, we can sell two million policies."

He would shop around for the best financial services deal for his customers, Mr Basson said.

Commenting on Pick 'n Pay's plans to offer financial services through Boland Bank, he said though Boland Bank and Shoprite had a common chairman and controlling shareholder in Pepkor head Christo Wiese, "I do what is good for my customers".

Boland Bank would be in the running as a partner, but so would other banks, he said.

Shoprite beat tough retailing conditions with a 20 percent increase in operating profits to R107 million in the six months to December. Turnover was up 28 percent, boosted by the takeover of Sentra last year.

But Sentra's profit-to-turnover ratios, which Mr Basson said were 50 percent lower than Shoprite's, limited the half-year profit growth.

Investment income jumped from R23,6 million to R43 million, though the rise was partly offset by climbing finance charges.

Attributable profit was up 81 percent to R103 million, swelled by exceptional items - compensation for the cancellation of a lease and income from the sale of land and buildings.

Mr Basson said he expected similar growth in trading profits in the second half year.

Shoprite had done well to raise profit margins from two percent to more than 2,2 percent in spite of tough competition, he said.

He would not be drawn on the group's expansion plans, noting only that up to 10 more supermarkets would be opened in South Africa this year, though none of them in the Western Cape.

The group's seven Zambian supermarkets were maintaining "acceptable" turnover levels and profit margins.

"Other opportunities in Africa are being investigated and our first supermarket in Mozambique will open in June."

Mr Basson said one possible use for Shoprite's R423-million cash hoard was the financing of further expansion into Africa. South African financial institutions were not always willing to take this on, he said, and Shoprite needed to fund its own growth into the rest of Africa.

Africa News


February 26, 1997


South Africa;
Child sex fiend freed in Cape Town


BYLINE: Johann Schronen, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Cape Town - A self-confessed paedophile who has admitted having an uncontrollable desire to rape very young children and babies has been let loose in Cape Town.

This follows a blunder by British police, who mistakenly assumed he would be arrested in South Africa after his deportation from Britain.

But when he arrived here on Saturday after being flown under guard from Britain, where he served a sentence for a sex-related charge, he was allowed to go free, as he faces no charges here. 

Zimbabwean-born Dennis Hundermark, 49, was delivered to Cape Town police at the city's airport by three burly Scotland Yard detectives who said he was a dangerous man who posed a constant threat to young children and to himself.

Hundermark travelled to Europe last February hoping to star in child sex videos, but was convicted in Britain for "incitement to procure a girl under 21" after an undercover detective posed as a video producer.

He was also convicted for stealing a girl's panties, which he was wearing when he was arrested.

But after serving only three months of his 16-month sentence, Hundermark, who has South African and Zimbabwean citizenship and carries a South African passport, was released from a British prison on Friday and deported to South Africa.

When he arrived about 10am on Saturday, Cape Town Child Protection Unit officer Jacci Storm questioned him briefly but could not find a reason to hold him, although he had allegedly admitted raping a nine-year-old girl at least 12 times in Zimbabwe.

Hundermark was then driven to a hotel in the northern areas and, according to Inspector Storm, he was thought to be heading for Harare, where he has relatives. Detective-Inspector Andy Hewett of Scotland Yard, one of the three London policeman who escorted Hundermark to South Africa, said he had attended the trial and was horrified by Hundermark's admissions in court.

"Hundermark told the court that he was sick and needed help," said Inspector Hewett.

"His fantasies included having sex with babies in nappies and raping toddlers, no matter whether they were boys or girls.

"He said he was like a speeding train waiting to crash and admitted in court it was a matter of time before he did it again."

Inspector Hewett said Hundermark was a danger to children anywhere in the world and should be behind bars. During their investigation, British authorities learned about his many "brushes with the law" allegedly involving child sex in several other European countries.

Scotland Yard was convinced South African police had strong cases against Hundermark and he would be arrested the moment he had set foot here.

"Hundermark himself believed that he was heading for jail here in South Africa," said Inspector Hewett.

"But police at the airport did not even know about us bringing the man. Only later a Child Protection Unit detective arrived and questioned him briefly and then he was driven to a hotel.

"Hundermark couldn't believe his luck. He was ecstatic that he was actually free to go," said Inspector Hewett.

Western Cape Child Protection Unit acting commander Jan Swart said he had checked police records thoroughly and established that Hundermark was not a wanted man in South Africa.

"But I sincerely hope he is a rehabilitated person because one step over the line will land him behind bars," said Captain Swart.

"My advice to him is to get help if he needs it so he will not become our client."


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


405 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 26, 1997


South Africa;
Super-models and their businesses flocking here to the 'in' place


BYLINE: Sarah Young, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1507 words


 

Cape Town - Move aside Miami, here comes Cape Town. Beautiful beaches, spectacular drives and a phenomenal pool of talented people are turning Cape Town into one of the top international modelling destinations. SARAH YOUNG investigates for Living Africa magazine.

It may be an idea to spend a few moments meditating before venturing into Cape Town's streets - just to make sure you have your cool in place. There are so many gorgeous people around that a simple stroll could be hazardous to your health...twisting your neck, falling over your feet, that kind of thing.

Take the arrival of Boss Models, for instance. The international agency that claims to have virtually created the male super-model has landed in Cape Town with a stable of international modelling talent that includes the likes of Marcus Schenkenberg and Joel West (two of the Claudia Schiffers of the male modelling world). 

Communications director Paul West says the company has hopes its Cape Town agency will do as well, or better than, its Miami, New York and London offices.

"We're here because there's an untapped talent pool here, and I don't just mean models. You have very good make-up artists, photographers, stylists," the list goes on.

"It's also a beautiful location that the rest of the world hasn't seen. You've been shut off from rest of the world for years, it's like the land time forgot. Everyone is talking about South Africa, especially in the States. There's a lot of frenzy to see what all this talk is about.

"You have beauty here that's unparalleled. Our clients have never seen anywhere as beautiful as Cape Town."

West says Boss isn't just here to make a quick buck, though. The gorgeous guys and gals have joined environmental activists and Muslim spiritual leaders in a bid to stop developers from building on the pristine slopes of Table Mountain. In early January this year, on an icy cold day, naked Boss models crept up into the wet fynbos, just as the sun was rising and launched " Models for the Mountain". Their aim: to make the preservation of one of the country's most beautiful features fashionable.

Models who pull in R3 000 and R15 000 a day offered their services free, as did everyone else involved.

The mountain's already been a backdrop for a number of Boss and other international shoots. Esquire, The Face and GQ are just some of those who've already come to the city. West says: "The reason they're able to come here now is that we can offer them the type of service an agency in New York or London would offer. I think that because of our resources worldwide we can help develop the whole market in Cape Town."

He believes that in future South African models will be able to base themselves in Cape Town and still work internationally. In the past, they've been forced to go to cities such as New York and Milan because South Africa was too much of a backwater.

He doesn't see Cape Town's star waning in the near future. "This isn't like some small American town that's suddenly hit the news and is going to disappear just as quickly."

Locals say the changes have an incredible impact on their lives. Rory Sales is your proverbial tall, dark, handsome guy. In the late Seventies he began modelling when the television commercial industry was in its infancy.

He was one of the chunky young men who brought South Africa the "braaivleis, rugby, sunny skies and Chevrolet" ad, among others. This was the beginning of a career which later saw him working as a lackey in the blossoming local film industry and modelling in the States.

He is generally positive about the new developments, but adds a word of caution. "People see the glamour, but they have no idea of the hard work that lies behind that."

Since the early 1990s, he and wife Cath have run a successful production company from their Noordhoek home. Sitting on the balcony of his office, overlooking the fynbos and five kilometres of pristine beach, Sales talks about the development of the film and commercial industry in Cape Town and how it's affected people.

Up until about 1990 being in the film or modelling industry in South Africa probably meant you were in Johannesburg.

Granted, in the early Seventies there was a small international ad industry in Cape Town. Ashley Lazarus, who's now based in New York was then directing Peter Stuyvesant ads in the Mother City. And in the mid-Seventies John Young saw the beginning of what he believed would be a vibrant film and commercial industry blossoming in the city and started a lighting company.

Then the National Party government decided it would at long last permit television broadcasting in South Africa.

Sales explains: "In the late Eighties the South African movies industry boomed. But it was an artificial, tax-driven boom that didn't spark much life into the commercial industry."

The political changes of the early Nineties gave the country's film and commercial industry its first real boost in decades.

Surprisingly, he says the low rand value is not top of the list of the city's attractions.

"The low rand is offset against high hotel and car hire prices and the relatively high cost of flights from Europe. Shooting costs are also rising faster than the rate of inflation."

He says that as the rand drops locals are upping their prices, rather than leaving them low and offering foreign companies a sexier deal. He believes if the rand gets stronger a lot of business could be lost because local have become too expensive.

Another problem foreign companies face when they shoot here, is that they're expected to get work permits.

"These super tourists are expected to go through the schlepp of getting work permits for the privilege of spending between R100 000 and R300 000 a day here," Sales says. Late last year, the stills industry managed to get this changed so that people shooting for magazines and catalogues now only needed business permits.

The film industry is lobbying for the same sort of deal.

Sales says "the fantastic diversity of talent and looks" in the city is part of the reason for this.

Another of the city's main attractions is its diversity of locations.

Over the past year, Ridley Scott Associates and Tony Kay - who shot the Gatorade sports drink ad - are just two of the big names that have graced the city with their illustrious presence.

Vogue recently did a couple of shoots in Cape Town.

Foreigners such as Frenchman Philippe Marinig of Picto photo lab are also setting up shop here.

What's the spin-off of these developments for Cape Town and its people?

Locals in the industry agree it goes way beyond foreigners coming here, shooting commercial and leaving.

"The industry gives work to literally thousands of people, from those selling clothes and curios, to car hire firms and hotel," says Sales.

Zane's another Capetonian who began his career as a model. About five years ago he went out on his own with Outlaw. "It wouldn't have been possible before that because the market was very closed."

He says Cape Town is definitely a "hot spot to shoot," but there are gaps in the industry.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


406 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 26, 1997


Ethiopia;
Council demands extension programme launching in Afar


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

AYSSAITA (ENA) - Members of the Ayssaita woreda council demanded the launching of the agricultural extension programme in Afar National Regional State in view of its significance for food self-sufficiency.

In a statement they issued at the end of a day-long conference held last Saturday, members of the council said the woreda economic development office should be strengthened in manpower in a bid to organize farmers in the region for the extension programme .

They said, through the Ayssaita Woreda boasts wide fertile land, the efforts made to harness the Awash River for irrigation development is insignificant. 

According to Ato Mehammed Al Hamid, head of the regional agricultural bureau, preparation is underway to launch the programme in the region as of next year.

Meanwhile, the property administration and general services section head under the regional department of agriculture disclosed that agricultural machinery the afar people received from the federal government are exposed to damage due to mishandling.

According to the head, the equipment exposed to damages include tractors and their parts, water pumps, generators, mills and welding machines used by the former state farms in Ayssaita, Date Bahri and Middle Awash.

The head said eventhough the Afar agricultural development task force set up in the second half of 1994 took charge of the machinery in Ayssaita and Date Bahri, it is now impossible to correctly figure their number because of the dissolution of the force after its subsidy was suspended.

Similarly, the task force set up by the regional council to administer the agricultural machinery in Middle Awash failed to get 110,000 birr it requested for storing the equipment at a spot.

Ato Musa Ahmed, agricultural department head of zone 3, said machinery worth over seven million birr are exposed to damages in Defen Belhamo and Meteka warehouses.

Among the items exposed to damages because of mishandling some water pumps are illegally used by individuals, the head added.

Ato Awol Arba, economic sector head of the regional council, said a task force will be set up to collect the said machinery and conduct study on ways of developing 15,000 hectares of land.

Africa News


February 26, 1997


Ethiopia;
Court hears testimonies against Derg officials


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - A prosecution witness said the late Dejazmatch Kassa Wolde-Mairiam, a senior official in the then Ministry of Pen, a one time university president, an administrator and minister of agriculture during the reign of Emperor Haile-Selassie was imprisoned following his arrival here to answer a call made over the radio.

The witness in a testimony he gave yesterday to the Federal High Court said he knew the late dejazmatch, his cousin, since 1959 and related how he was jailed after his return in July or August 1974 from Bako where he was engaged in agricultural activities.

he said he was supplying the deceased up until July 1979 at the headquarters of the Fourth Army Division and that of the Derg till the time he was told to stop bringing supplies by the prison. since then he has never set eyes on him, he added. 

He said he had easily identified the remains of the late dejazmatch among the five bodies exhumed in 1992 on the premises of the residence of Ras Asirate Kassa.

The 132nd witness on his part said he had been catering for the late patriarch, Abune Tewoflos of the Ethiopian orthodox church until July 1979. since then, for several years, he had no idea about the wherabouts of the late patriarch.

He said he had been at the spot and identified the remains of Abune Tewoflos when the exhumation of the bodies took place.

The Special Prosecutor has requested the court to postpone the hearing of testimonies of five witnesses on grounds that the issues they raise might be of concern to the 44th defendant, Lieutenant Getahun Tekle-Mariam presently admitted to a hospital.

The defence lawyers has also reinforced the point saying he prefers the testimonies to be heard in the presence of his client.

The court has accepted the requests.

The trial was adjourned until Feb. 27.

408 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 26, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Population Report Sends Shock Waves in Zimbabwe


BYLINE: Elliot Mahende, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwean economists would relish projections of a slow down in population growth since this would mean prosperity as resources would be distributed among fewer people.

But not when the cause of slow down is a higher death rate and lower fertility due to HIV and AIDS.

Which is why the report by the Blair Research Institute of Harare and Oxford University of London predicting that Zimbabwe's population of 11.5 million would remain static or even decline during the next 20 years, due to the deadly human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), has caused shock.

"It would be helpful if the population stopped growing but not this way," said well-known economist John Robertson. "This will mean the deaths of many people before they contribute to the growth of the economy." 

Researchers Tom Zhuwau and Stephen Chandiwana of the Blair Research Institute and Simon Gregson and Roy Anderson of Oxford University, in a pioneering study, have concluded that a combination of increased deaths due to AIDS and a falling birth rate will sharply reduce Zimbabwe's population growth rate pegged at 3.1 percent in the last census.

Life expectancy would drop from the current 57 years to 30 years. Zimbabwe's population was expected to reach 16 million by the year 2010.

The social communications secretary of the Catholic Bishops Conference, Father Oskar Wermter's reaction to the results of the study on the socio- demographic impact of HIV was more striking.

"My first reaction is simply one of shock," he said. "The dry figures and statistics of this report hide much suffering and many personal tragedies.

"Surely losing a large part of our young adult population with their education and vocational skills, their roles as parents and carers for the next generation can only be very bad and most depressing news," he said.

So devastating has been the findings that parliament is preparing for debate on the forecast HIV/AIDS tragedy, according to the chairperson of the Select Committee on Service Ministries, Angeline Masuku. Her team is studying the report.

Although conceding that the findings will only come to pass if intermediate determinants remain constant, notably that if Zimbabweans do not change their behavior and that no cure for aids is found soon, the researchers say they do not mind painting their scenarios in strong primary colors.

"It's time we looked at the problem in the face and did something about it, be it in behavioral change or coming up with the appropriate policies," Zhuwau said.

The most disturbing aspect of the findings is the distortion in the population age/sex structure. Researchers project that there will be more people in their teens and early adulthood while the experienced and economically more important 30-59 year age-group will be drastically reduced by the year 2016.

Moreover, because women tend to get infected at an earlier age (because for economic reasons women generally marry men who are older and already infected) there is likely to be a shortage of females over time at young adult ages.

The researchers also noted a decline in fertility, that is the average number of children born to every woman of child-bearing age.

Reasons for the decline, which could be attributed to the prevalence of HIV, included increased use of condoms, delay in marriage due to fear of HIV, and that parents who would have lost a child due to HIV would not want to have another.

The strongest criticism of the study has been the size of the sample population (929 households) and the justification for extrapolating the results to cover the whole country.

"Some people might think the sample population was too small for Zimbabwe," said Dr Lazarus Zanamwe, a lecturer in population studies, department of geography, at the University of Zimbabwe.

Zanamwe also questioned the projection that the population might actually decline, saying according to some models, the national fertility rate of 4.2- 4.3 percent was sufficient to sustain a population growth in the face of HIV.

He also questioned the projection that the population would be made up largely of teenagers and young adults, saying even these are at risk from current infections unless there was change in behavior.

Justifying the extension of the results from the study area to the whole country, Gregson said the results from the study area were not different from what the National AIDS Control Program had established for the whole country.

This was supported by John Smith, an actuary with the First Mutual Life Assurance Society of Zimbabwe. He said the projections were consistent with those that had been done by the Actuarial Society of South Africa.

Those projections portrayed the Zimbabwean situation as being worse than in South Africa but better than in Zambia and Uganda.

Robertson also supported the findings, saying they reinforced statistics from other parts of the country.

Calling on population planners to carefully study the report, Father Wermter said the church should also intensify its AIDS and Family Life Education Programs.

"The church will also insist that we invest not so much into negative measures like population control but into positive programs like education, especially of women and girls, health and vocational training, supported by a moral renewal, stressing values like self-discipline, honesty, respect for human rights and solidarity," he said.

While other critics might dismiss the report as an academic generalization, the fact remains that Zimbabwe has already started experiencing a higher mortality rate due to AIDS, which causes an estimated 500 deaths per week, according to estimates by the Ministry of Health and Child Welfare.


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February 26, 1997


Mozambique;
Flood Warning For Zambezia


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Heavy rains in the central Mozambican province of Zambezia are causing flooding on the Licungo River, which runs through the province's second largest town, Mocuba.

In a statement issued Wednesday, the National Water Board said that 92.7 millimeters of rain fell on Mocuba, Tuesday. The accumulated rainfall over the past six days was 234.9 millimeters.

The level of the Licungo at Mocuba rose from 7.05 meters (7.71 yards) Monday to 7.7 meters (8.4 yards) Tuesday morning. This is 50 centimeters higher than the maximum level reached by the Licungo during flooding in 1996.

The board warns that flooding in the Licungo basin will worsen, and urges the local authorities to ensure that people living near the river banks are evacuated to safety.

Flooding on the Licungo follows an improvement in the situation in the Zambezi, Pungue and Buzi valleys, farther south, where there was severe flooding earlier February.

Some 300,000 people were affected by that flooding in the provinces of Sofala, Manica, Tete and Zambezia, and 78 people were known to have lost their lives.

The floods had swamped 7,300 houses and 79,520 hectares (19,494 acres) of crops.

The Mozambican government on Monday appealed to the international community for emergency aid valued at almost 30 million U.S. dollars to assist the victims and to repair flood damage.

Foreign Minister Leonardo Simao launched the appeal at a meeting in Maputo with representatives of donor countries and organizations.


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 26, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Commonwealth Leaders Change Venue


BYLINE: Prof Malema, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

GABORONE, Botswana (PANA) - The 18 heads of Commonwealth African states, who have been holding round table talks in Gaborone, shifted Wednesday to Kasane, a resort near the border with Zambia, to finalize their discussion on ways to enhance democracy and good government on the continent.

The crucial talks will mostly be held behind closed doors, officials said Wednesday in Gaborone.

At a banquet hosted for the Commonwealth leaders Tuesday Botswana's president, Ketumile Masire, urged his counterparts to take measures to improve Africa's tarnished image. 

"We are convinced that this meeting should not be allowed to pass as an event. It should be seen as the beginning of a process which entail constant nurturing until it bears the fruit which all our people can enyoy."

"It is essential that Africa has a problem of a negative image. This stems from the international news media often concentrating their coverage on the negative developments in Africa. Botswana's view is that this negative image can only be reversed by establishing democratic and transparent institutions," Masire said.

He said Botswana believed strongly in regional cooperation and that a number of conflicts, which have afflicted Africa, could be attributed to the lack of democracy.

"Such conflicts frustrates efforts towards regional cooperation," he added.

"It is indeed difficult for any country to carry out any meaningful bilateral cooperation and trade relations with its fellow African states which are involved in a civil wars," he said.

Masire also urged African leaders to grab every available opportunity within their reach, to address their nations' problems.

"One of the key steps towards the solution of any problem is the recognition and acceptance of the fact that problem do indeed exist," he added. "In this respect, our round table is a crucial step in the search for available solutions.

The absence of good government, he said, bred suspicion and cynicism among the governed, with the resulting "erosion of confidence in the national institutions, leading to political instability."

He told his colleagues that the Southern African Development Community, a 12-nation economic grouping, was taking some necessary measures to promote stability and development after many years of subregional instability.

"Political stability and sustainable economic development in our countries need the support of our people, particularly at the grassroots level. Our people must never feel that the development process, be it economic, social or political, is being imposed on them," he said.


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Business and Finance;
Zimbabwe's Industrial Index In Record High


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 93 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Zimbabwe Stock Exchange key Industrial Index notched another 61 points Wednesday to close trading at another all-time high of 10724 in active trading characterized by heavy share purchases.

The Mining Index, whose performance has been disappointing since late 1996, lost six points and ended trading pegged at 882.9 points, the stock exchange said in its daily market report.

412 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 26, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
O.A.U. Conflict Body To Meet On Great Lakes Crisis


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - An emergency summit of the 18-member O.A.U. committee on conflict resolution is to meet March 18-19 to discuss the fighting and political instability in the Great Lakes region.

O.A.U. Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim said Wednesday that the meeting was in response to the deteriorating security situation in the area, especially eastern Zaire.

Three venues, Togo, Nigeria and the O.A.U. headquarters in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, are being considered as venue for the special summit. 

The summit is to be preceded by a Council of Ministers meeting to prepare the agenda for the African leaders.

Members of the committee, known as the O.A.U. Central Organ for Conflict Prevention, Management and Resolution, are Algeria, Cameroon, Congo, the Comoros, Egypt, Ethiopia, Gabon, Guinea, Malawi, Mauritania, Mozambique, Nigeria, the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic, Sudan, Tanzania, Togo, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

Salim told PANA that the secretariat had been encouraged in recommending the summit by the leaders of Nigeria, Togo and Benin, who met recently in Abuja, the Nigerian capital, and jointly expressed their concern about the conflict and the need for an urgent solution.

Earlier debate by the ministerial session had been dominated by the crisis in that part of Africa, with the Zairean foreign minister, Kamanda wa Kamanda, insisting that Rwanda and Uganda were aiding rebel incursions on its territory.

But his Rwandan counterpart, Anastase Gasana, denied the charge, saying the conflict was an internal Zaire problem.

"Allegations of invasion is diversionary," he said, adding that Rwanda was only being made a scapegoat by Zaire.

The Uganda delegation also spoke in the same vein, saying that accusations and counter accusations were no solutions.

The conflict in the region, apart from resulting in loss of lives, has created refugees and other humanitarian problems.

So far, it has defied regional and international peace initiatives.


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February 26, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Nigeria To Host African First Ladies Summit


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Africa's leading political body, the Organization of African Unity (O.A.U) is to support an African First Ladies' Summit for Peace planned for April in Abuja, the Nigerian capital. This was part of decision by the organization's Committee of Ambassadors at the ministerial council session taking place in Tripoli, Libya. 

The decision followed Nigeria's offer to host the summit as part of regional peace efforts.

Nigeria's ambassador to the O.A.U., Brownson Dede, said: "The summit is to give African first ladies a chance to contribute their quota to the quest for peace in Africa."

He said the idea followed the 1995 World Women Conference in Beijing, China, in which the Ghanaian and Nigerian first ladies, Nana Rawlings and Maryam Abacha, played an active part.

After a lengthy discussion on the need to confine the activities of the first ladies to humanitarian issues, the committee urged the O.A.U. and the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa to support the initiative.

A similar initiative is already in progress at the level of the West African subregion.

African first ladies are expected to tour troubled areas on the continent with the aim of mobilizing support for victims of conflicts, who are mainly women and children.


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 26, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Delay In Africa's Economic Integration


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Eleven of the 53 member-countries of the Organization of African Unity have yet to either sign or ratify the treaty establishing the African Economic Community (AEC), almost seven years after it was adopted by African leaders, an official said Wednesday.

O.A.U. Assistant Secretary-General Vijay Makhan told the organization's ongoing 65th ministerial council meeting that such delay and the "lukewarm" attitude of chief executives of regional economic communities posed a threat to continental integration.

In his report to the conference, he said that Eritrea and South Africa were yet to sign or ratify the treaty adopted in Abuja, the Nigerian capital in 1991. 

Countries that have signed but yet to ratify include, Benin, Djibouti, Equatorial Guinea, Gabon, Lesotho, Madagascar, Mauritius, Swaziland and Togo.

Delegates from some of these countries told PANA the delay was in some cases due to "administrative reasons," rather than a lack of political will or opposition to the treaty.

Mahkan said most chief executives of regional economic organizations, who were supposed to champion the treaty, never attend O.A.U. meetings.

Regional economic communities were charged with laying the foundation of the integration expected to take Africa out of underdevelopment and toward the modern age.

However, Mahkan told the meeting the O.A.U. secretariat was moving ahead to lay down the structures.

To this end, he said the first ministerial meeting and summit of the O.A.U. 's Economic and Social Commission were held in Yaounde, Cameroon, last year, to try and kick-start the implementation of the protocol.

He said there was need for effective cooperation between the AEC and the African, Caribbean and Pacific countries. Both bodies plan a summit in Libreville, Gabon, later in 1997.

Similar collaboration is also planned with the Geneva-based World Trade Organization.

In their contributions, some delegates called for greater emphasis on social issues in the work of the Economic and Social Commission.


LOAD-DATE: February 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 27, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 110 on the Great Lakes (02/27)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1654 words


 

Nairobi - Laurent-Desire Kabila, leader of the rebel Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL), held talks with South African President Mandela today according to press reports. Rebel sources have said Kabila will not meet with Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko's officials in South Africa, but insists on one-to-one talks with Mobutu. President Mobutu, who is in France, says he will not talk to the rebels.

* Reports of fighting and looting in and around Kindu continue. The Zairean Ministry of Defence has admitted there is fighting around the garrison town, but claim today that government troops had pushed back rebels and reached the strategically important Elila bridge about 50 kilometres east of Kindu. The Ministry of Defence said there had been "violent exchanges" with the rebels at Moyengo, about 40 kilometres south of Kindu, reports AFP. According to one well-informed source in the region, the rebels intend to take Kindu to give Mobutu "an incentive" to negotiate.

* In Kinshasa, the defence ministry reported that Ugandan troops were massed in the northeast of the Upper Zaire region, around Mount-Bleu, Bunia and Mahagi, close to the Ugandan border. It said the Ugandan forces were equiped with tanks, heavy guns and rocket launchers. 

* Kabila's forces "are moving in on Zaire's third largest city, Kisangani, and the Tingi-Tingi refugee camps", Rwandan state radio reported yesterday. Kabila, however, has previously given assurances that he will hold back his troops for humanitarian reasons from Tingi-Tingi and Kisangani.

* Seventeen heads of state in the Organisation of African Unity will meet on March 18-19 to discuss the war and refugee crisis in Zaire, OAU officials and foreign ministers said today in Tripoli. OAU spokesman Ibrahim Dagash said that the gathering would involve countries in the Central Organ (for conflict resolution) of the OAU and would probably meet in Lome, Togo (Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, and Abuja, Nigeria are also being considered). Libiyan leader Colonel Kadhafi was expected to open the OAU meeting yesterday but inexplicably failed to turn up. OAU spokesman Ibrahim Dagash said the OAU had been told by the Libiyan government that Kadhafi would come for the closing session on Friday.

* The French government expressed hope yesterday that peace efforts led by Pretoria "will very soon achieve concrete results", reports AFP. Foreign spokesman Jacques Rummelhardt said there was urgent need to reach a truce and stop the fighting in eastern Zaire.

* Refugees International said in a statement yesterday that while peace talks were a "welcome first step" towards a solution in eastern Zaire, they were "not focused on the dire emergency at hand: the fate of hundreds of thousands of sick and starving displaced Zaireans and Rwandan and Burundian refugees". It said that reports of high mortality rates in Tingi-Tingi camps, fears of appropriation of food by Rwandan militia, and possible execution of refugees by Rwandan camp leaders, makes the outlook for refugees and the displaced in eastern Zaire "bleak". The statement also points out that the fate of some 25,000 refugees from Kalima (before, Shabunda) remains unknown. The refugees were in "very bad condition" before fleeing Kalima. Refugees Interational recommends that: donor governments express their support and provide every means necessary to evacuate vulnerable people from eastern Zaire by air; the government of Zaire permit humanitarian agencies to search by air and on the ground for refugees who fled into the forest; the international community support the UNHCR in every way possible to facilitate the rescue and repatriation of refugees near Kingulube.

* UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan accepted the resignations of the chief administrator and deputy prosecutor of the Rwandan genocide court, UN spokesman Juan-Carlos Brandt said yesterday. Chief administrator Andronico Adede of Kenya and deputy prosecutor Honore Rakotomanana of Madagascar submitted their resignations after meetings with Annan in New York. According to the spokesman, the Secretary-General concluded that "the continuation of the two officials of the Tribunal in their posts would not be in the interests of the United Nations and the work of the Tribunal". Annan has appointed Agwu Okali of Nigeria, who works in Nairobi for the UN agency HABITAT, as the new chief administrator, or registrar. Chief Prosecutor Louise Arbour of Canada was also summoned to New York last Friday for consultations with the Secretary-General. In a report released this month UN Inspector-General Karl Pashcke found unqualified staff, financial waste and mismanagement at all levels of the court.

* Cameroon's Court of Appeal freed six Rwandan war crimes suspects Wednesday stating that there was insufficient evidence to extradite them to the International UN Tribunal in Arusha. Officials said that the Court of Appeal had found that the accusations against the men were "not sufficiently grave" and that the evidence presented was "insufficient". The UN Tribunal had provided last minute evidence against two of the men, which had prolonged their stay in custody. The six men are among 13 people the Cameroon authorities arrested in 1996 in response to requests from the Rwandan government which had named them as taking part in the 1994 genocide.

* Most of the exiled Rwandans arrested by Kenyan police in a "swoop" this week have been freed, reports AFP. Among those picked up and held were former Rwanda prime minister Jean Kambanda, who held office April-July 1994. High profile Rwandan exiles campaigned this week on behalf of certain groups of Rwandans, releasing a statement claiming the swoop was aimed at "Hutus" - the swoop, however, targetted all Rwandans. Sources quoted in the press suggested the swoop could be linked to the recent arrival several hundred Hutu ex-FAR and other Rwandans from Tingi-Tingi camps in eastern Zaire. Police swoops against refugees and immigrants are commonplace in Kenya.

* Burundi radio reported on Wednesday that security forces carried out a search at Gisenyi displaced persons camp. The security sweep follows an attack in Kamenge, northern Bujumbura, on Monday night, which targetted a district secretary. Seven people, including his wife, were killed and an infant stabbed. A military source said that the search was carried out on the basis of intelligence provided by one of the assailants arrested on the night of the attack, and 18 more people have been arrested.

* At the opening of a two-day conference in Kampala on "the challenge of peace in northern Uganda", President Yoweri Museveni sent assurances that the government is willing to facilitate any genuine initiative to bring peace and an end to conflict. His remarks were relayed through a speech reacd for him by the prime minister, Kintu Musoke. In the speech, the president warned those "who seek assistance from Sudan to stop it for the well-being of their people and economic growth in northern Uganda", reports Ugandan state radio. On the same day, Ugandan radio broadcast an appeal from the Resident District Commission (RDC) from Kabarole district, Western Uganda, Dan Mugisha Mwesigye. Mwesigye appealed to rebels in southwestern Uganda to voluntarily surrender and "join the rest of the Ugandans in developing the country". The RDC said that no rebel would be punished if he surrendered. He also said that not all the rebels who attacked Kasese were Tabliqs - Ugandan Muslim Fundamentalists - and that the government was of "all people, including Moslems".

* Uganda has halted civilian flights to the northern town of Gulu. Civilian air operators said the ban had been in effect since Tuesday, reports AFP. Major General Salim Saleh, special presidential advisor to the north, said the government feared Sudan would bomb the north. Gulu is the heart of an insurgency by Christian fundamentalist rebels. The Ugandan government accused Sudan of bombing the nrothern town of Moyo on February 13; Sudan denied it.

* The Pan-African Conference on Peace, Gender and Development begins on Saturday in Kigali, Rwanda. The conference is organised under the auspices of the OAU, ECA, various UN agencies and the Netherlands government. The conference was conceived by the coalition of Rwandan women, the Government and civil society represented by Pro-Femmes/Twese Hamwe, the National Advisory Board on Women and the Ministry of Family and Promotion of Women.

Nairobi, 27 February 1997 14:10 GMT (ENDS)

416 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 27, 1997


Business and Finance;
Shoprite plans R30-m Bellville retail centre


BYLINE: Charlene Clayton, Property Editor, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Cape Town - A R30-million, commuter-friendly shopping centre is to be built on two hectares in the heart of Bellville's business district.

Shoprite Checkers has won the contract for the development of the 15 000 sq m retail development. The site, which belongs to Transnet, is below Voortrekker Road and is bounded by Tienie Meyer Drive and Modderdam and Belrail roads. 

The centre will be called Commuter City and is due for completion next year.

The site, previously used as a parcel receiving and dispatching depot by Transnet, adjoins the Bellville station, the main Tygerberg regional bus depot and the largest taxi depot in the area.

Philip van der Merwe, deputy managing director for Shoprite Checkers Properties, said a feature of the design would be easy links for pedestrians between different forms of transport.

Big tenants would be positioned along a pedestrian street and around a centre court - all of which would be linked to the bus terminus, the taxi terminus and Bellville station.

There would be a shopping area on the edges, facing on to the parking area and the bus and taxi termini.

Food, fashion and service-type shops would be grouped together, Mr Van der Merwe said.

Small traders would be housed in spaza-type shops fronting on to the bus terminus from both sides, where they could display their wares in open units featuring retractable roller shutters.

Mr Van der Merwe said Commuter City was the result of co-operation between Transnet, the local authority, the commuting public and the property industry.

"Other national anchor retailers have expressed interest in taking up retail space," he said.

Sipho Mashinini, senior manager at Propnet, said developers had been invited to incorporate Reconstruction and Development Programme (RDP) principles in the project through the empowerment of professional practices, smaller contractors, formal and informal entrepreneurs and taxi operators.

The community would be consulted in the early planning stages of the development, he said.

Andre Malan, of the Bellville town planning department, said: "We hope that the provision of additional facilities at the commuter ranks will contribute to peace and business entrepreneurship in the area."

The development is based on a 50-year lease and is expected to be completed during 1998.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


417 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 27, 1997


South Africa;
Urban farmers stay in touch with their roots


BYLINE: Sabata Ngcai, Staff Reporter, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Cape Town - Urban farming may seem to be a contradiction in terms - but herds of cattle and goats grazing on the verges of the N2 highway or using a pedestrian bridge to cross to the other side have become familiar sights in Cape Town.

Although effectively landless, a handful of people originally from the Eastern Cape are keeping cattle, sheep and goats in the townships of Langa, Nyanga and Guguletu to augment their meagre wages. Others who have lost their jobs are looking at farming as the alternative.

Although their stock is often stolen and impounded for straying across roads, they are determined to continue. 

They say keeping livestock is important among Xhosa-speaking people because animals are used to cure sick children and for boys undergoing circumcision. Xhosa customs include the slaughtering of a goat before boys are sent to initiation school.

According to Xhosa tradition, when a child is born the imbeleko is performed to introduce a child to the ancestors so he grows up in good health. A goat is used.

When the ancestors appear in one's dreams asking to quench their thirst, the interpretation is that the person in whose dreams they appear should make umqomboti - Xhosa beer - and inform people in the community when it is ready to be drunk. In some cases people take sifted dry cow dung and spread it beneath the umqomboti container while waiting for the beer to ferment.

Some urban farmers say they breed livestock because they grew up in homes where their parents were farmers.

Stololo Mvandaba from Cofimvaba in the former Transkei said he grew up in a family of farmers.

The 54-year-old farmer, who did not go beyond lower primary schooling, came to the Mother City in 1961 to look for a job.

He worked as a labourer in various construction companies until 1990, when he bought a second-hand taxi. The taxi was written off in an accident in 1994.

In the same year he bought two baby goats. Since then he has stayed at home and looked after the goats, building a kraal for them next to his shack.

Mr Mvandaba bought six more goats and the first two produced kids. Later he sold three goats and bought two calves and sheep. Today Mr Mvandaba has 60 goats, 30 sheep and six head of cattle.

He is the chairman of the newly-launched Sibanye Small Farmers' Association for township farmers.

Mr Mvandaba said his interest in livestock stemmed from the fact that he grew up in a home that was rich in cattle and sheep. "It was the only line I thought I should follow because I left school early."

He said the community no longer struggled to get livestock when they wanted to perform customary rites.

"People who are preparing to send their boys to the initiation school come to me to buy goats. Even those who want to perform imbeleko buy goats from me.

"According to tradition, when a young baby loses weight, the parents remove the end of a cow's tail, mix it with cow dung and tie it around the child's neck," he said.

The goats cost between R200 and R400 each depending on size, while the cattle sell for between R1 500 and R2 000 each.

In spite of problems he faced, including stock theft and traffic officers impounding animals, he said firmly: "Farming is my life."

Another farmer from Langa township who has been breeding cattle for the past four years is Johnson Ndude from Engcobo in the former Transkei.

He works as a security guard in Langa. Being the sole breadwinner at home, he felt his monthly salary of less than R1 000 was not enough to provide for his family.

When he came to Langa four years ago he found that some men were breeding cattle. He was interested and joined them. Now he has more than 10 head of cattle.

He keeps his livestock in a large kraal behind the Langa migrant labour hostels. Like Mr Mvandaba, Mr Ndude grew up in a farming home.

His thoughts about home brought back fond memories of livestock he left there.

"I breed cattle for money and for the love of them," he said. "I go home once a year and I felt I should breed cattle here, so that I could remain in touch with what I love most."


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


418 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 27, 1997


Business and Finance;
South Africa's Telkom gets ready to changes (Commentary)


BYLINE: Jay Naidoo (Min for Posts, Telecommunications & Broadcasting), Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1814 words


 

Cape Town - The passing of the Telecommunications Act in November 1996 was a milestone in a process which was embarked on by government soon after its inception.

Government's vision, embodied in the policy framework which gave rise to the Act, is to ensure vigorous growth in the telecommunications market through the extensive roll-out of a modern network, providing universal access in South Africa, especially to previously disadvantaged areas, and at the same time preparing to meet the challenges of competition.

How was this best to be achieved? Especially as the South African marketplace was characterised by a high teledensity (number of lines per 100 people) in affluent urban areas, making this sector extremely attractive to potential competitors, and extremely low teledensity in less affluent urban and rural areas, which only had longer-term potential for growth.

A further factor was the challenge of restructuring Telkom, the largest telecommunications enterprise in Africa, into an organisation capable of delivering a speedy roll-out with the necessary technology, in such a manner that it would still be able to hold its own in a highly-competitive marketplace when liberalisation occurred. 

The route chosen, in common with a number of other developing economies around the world, was that of finding a strategic equity partner (SEP). The Act, which was the culmination of a long process of consultation including Green and White Papers, permitted the government, through the Ministry for Posts, Telecommunications and Broadcasting, to proceed with the sale of up to 30 percent of Telkom to one or a possible consortium of international telecommunications operators. The Government also intends to make a further 10 percent equity stake in Telkom available to previously disadvantaged communities.

Requests for proposals have been issued and four companies - Deutsche Telekom, France Telecom, Southwestern Bell Corporation (SBC) and Telekom Malaysia - are expected to bid, either singly or in consortia, in the final round. The bids will be evaluated by the Ministry's advisors, and a recommendation made to the Minister. The process is expected to be completed in April. There are no preferred bidders.

A strong regulatory framework, modelled on international best practice, was a cornerstone of the new Act. The Act meets the policy objectives of the promotion of universal and affordable telecommunication services, which are responsive to the needs of consumers, and the promotion of fair competition within the telecommunications industry.

The framework was thus intended to smooth the transition from a market currently dominated (but not monopolised) by Telkom, to one in which there is robust competition amongst a variety of telecommunication service providers.

The provisions of the Act, which envisages a three-tiered structure, are already well on the way to being implemented.

The South African Telecommunications Regulatory Authority (SATRA) has been established, chaired by Nape Maepa, as well as the Universal Service Agency (USA), chaired by Mlungisi Hlongwane. Draft Telkom licenses have been issued by the Ministry and are expected to be finalised shortly. Other Telkom licenses will be issued by SATRA, which has been given wide powers by the Act and is one of the most independent regulatory bodies in the world.

Policy directions relating to the Human Resources Fund, a fund to promote the provision of adequately skilled human resources at all levels of the telecommunications sector, and the Universal Service Fund, which will assist in providing telecommunications to needy people and communities which have no access at present, have also been issued.

The Ministry will continue to provide policy direction and oversee its shareholding in Telkom. The Ministry is also directly responsible for administering the Human Resource Fund, and overseeing the activities of the USA.

At the second tier, SATRA will be responsible for monitoring Telkom's compliance with the Act, essentially acting as a watchdog for the industry. After an initial three-year period, during which Telkom may not increase its overall basket of tariffs by more than inflation minus 1,5 percent, SATRA will be responsible for setting tariff structures. SATRA also sets interconnect guidelines.

As an independent regulator, SATRA must balance the interests of consumers on the one hand and stakeholders in Telkom and market participants, on the other.

At the third tier, Telkom, together with whichever SEP wins the bid, is responsible for telecommunication operations, including an aggressive roll- out of services which has only been equalled in a few countries in the world, and the upgrading of existing services.

The draft licenses, which were published by the Ministry at the beginning of February, inter alia provide SATRA with the mechanism to monitor Telkom, and will bring about far-reaching changes in the telecommunications environment.

The three licenses are for: Public Switched Telecommunications Services (PSTS); The transmission of radio frequencies; and Value Added Network Services (VANS).

They are for a 25-year period, with Telkom being permitted to provide local and long distance telecommunication services, international and pay phone services on an exclusive basis for five years, during which it has to meet stringent roll-out and service quality targets. Failure to achieve these targets will result in the payment of monetary penalties by Telkom.

Roll-out targets include targets in respect of the total number of new exchange lines, new public pay phones, new lines for priority customers such as hospitals, schools, libraries, local authorities and post offices, new lines for villages, and replacement lines. Service quality targets will substantially increase Telkom's accountability to customers.

The Government welcomes informed debate about the restructuring process. Extensive consultation surrounded the drafting of the Green and White Papers, the election of SATRA members was conducted in an open and transparent manner, and public hearings have been held around the draft license. It is unfortunate, however, that some debate has been ill-informed and indicates a lack of understanding of the newly-created regulatory framework and its relation to international precedent.

Contrary to certain allegations, competition already exists in the South African telecommunications industry. Not only do the two cellular operators, MTN and Vodacom, compete with each other, but they also compete with Telkom in that they provide many of the same services. Competition among these operators will be enhanced by a more liberal interconnection regime, to be introduced under the Act, whereby the cellular operators will be able to secure access on more favourable terms. In addition to the cellular operators and their service providers, there are more than 50 paging companies in South Africa. A new cellular service provider is expected to be licensed.

Full competition among providers of customer premises equipment, including telephones themselves, has been introduced. Providers of Value-added Network Services, including the provision of a broad range of services via the Internet, are also subject to full competition.

The five-year exclusivity period is shorter than is common in other countries where the basic infrastructure is underdeveloped.

This phased approach to liberalisation allows the telecommunications operators to meet their universal service obligations before the introduction of full competition, regarded as essential if the country as a whole is to gain the full economic benefits of being part of the global telecommunications market.

Another issue which has been contended is that of price. Telkom late last year introduced a new tariff strategy which, among other things, kept the overall basket of increases at seven percent - two percent below the expected rate of inflation.

An element of the strategy is the rebalancing of tariffs - another step in preparing Telkom for competition. Historically, Telkom has heavily subsidised its local call tariffs by charging higher rates for its long distance and international calls. Rebalancing involves local calls becoming more cost- related, with a significant decrease in the price of long-distance and international calls.

In order to make the service more affordable, installation charges were cut in December by more than 40 percent, while pay phone tariffs remained unchanged. Special concessions were also made for pensioners.

It is inappropriate, therefore to accuse Telkom of high prices. In addition competition will inevitably lead to lower prices.

As we approach the millennium, it is the Government's responsibility to ensure that firm foundations have been laid for the country's entry into the information society.

Everything in its power has been done to ensure that this commitment is fulfilled.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February 27, 1997


South Africa;
Leading figures join bid fundraising drive


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Cape Town - Deputy Finance Minister Gill Marcus and two other leading national business figures have joined the Olympic bid team to spearhead a private sector fundraising drive.

Ms Marcus is joined on the bid executive by Ian Goldin, chief executive of the Development Bank of South Africa, and Khaya Ngqula, chief executive of the Industrial Development Corporation.

The move comes as Cape Town, confident of a place in next week's shortlist selection, gears up to lobby support internationally in the crucial six months to the final vote on September 5. 

Over the past few days, two private sector sponsors have pledged R1-million to the bid and the Cape Metropolitan Council has contributed R2,5-million. The City of Cape Town is also to consider a similar investment.

These sums, which follow the overwhelmingly positive technical assessment by the International Olympic Committee's evaluation commission, are intended to give the bid a competitive edge in the race against leading rivals Rome, Athens, Stockholm and Buenos Aires.

The funds are to be used to pay for preparations for the presentation to the IOC in Lausanne next week and in September, and travelling and accommodation costs, as well as the costs of visits by IOC members in the next six months.

Ideally, the bid needs R20-million to make the most of this phase of the project.

Bidding has already attracted more than R300-million in government infrastructure investment in the Western Cape and has provided unprecedented exposure to the city internationally.

Against this background, CMC exco chairman Pierre Uys argued that private and public institutions had every reason to invest in the bid to give every chance of succeeding.

"We are sending out the message that it's time for people to put their money where their mouth is.

"We have passed the technical test with flying colours - now we must keep the bid going."

He hoped the City of Cape Town "will come up with their share".

Democratic Party councillor Brian Watkyns said though he was "fully behind the bid", the cash injection was inadvisable before the shortlist selection and without having sight of the bid's financial records.

Africa News


February 27, 1997


South Africa;
UK lashed over child sex fiend


BYLINE: Lindsay Barnes, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Cape Town - Cape Town child-protection agencies have hit out at "grossly irresponsible" British authorities for deporting self-confessed paedophile Dennis Hundermark to South Africa.

Hundermark has been described as a "human timebomb", allegedly with an uncontrollable urge to rape young children and even babies.

He was set free in Cape Town at the weekend after serving only three months of a 16-month sentence in Britain for a sex-related offence. 

Hundermark, who has a South African passport and dual SA-Zimbabwean citizenship, was brought to Cape Town under guard by three Scotland Yard detectives.

British police mistakenly assumed he would be arrested here, but he was freed in the city when local police found no South African charges against him were pending. His present whereabouts are unknown.

Child protection groups accused the British authorities of granting Hundermark early parole simply to foist an unwanted criminal on South Africa.

The groups demanded police investigate him as a threat to society because of his alleged confession in a British court that he was unable to control his overwhelming desire to rape young children.

Hundermark is reported to have admitted in court that it was only a matter of time before he struck again.

His whereabouts should be monitored and communities in which he was living informed of the alleged danger, child-protection organisations said. Cape Town police had followed the letter of the law in not arresting him, but this showed inadequacies in the law and the need to re-examine the constitutional provisions.

Rape Crisis legal adviser Bronwyn Pithey said South Africa needed an arrangement with other countries stipulating that people deported here after being convicted of crimes should serve the rest of their sentences here.

"Why do we have to wait for something more to happen? If the police Child Protection Unit is not investigating him, a question mark hangs over their heads."

Caron Erasmus, Childline counselling manager, said Hundermark should be in therapy and under no circumstances allowed to work with children.

She labelled his early release and parole as "bizarre" and queried the law for not locking up self-confessed child abusers.

Alan Jackson, director of the Child Welfare Society in Cape Town, asked if the British authorities had established the legal position in South Africa before deporting Hundermark.

The Department of Justice should urgently reconsider legislation to avoid a repetition of this situation, he said.

The police should be informed constantly of Hundermark's whereabouts. "If he is allowed to operate here without people knowing his history, we have a serious problems on our hands," Mr Jackson said.

Science and Health;
Ethiopia: Deforestation exacerbates soil erosion, shortage of rain


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

ZEWAI (ENA) - Deforestation in Munis Woreda, Arsi Zone, has exposed the region to shortage of rainfall, the zonal department of agriculture disclosed. 

The department said the natural forest on 800 hectares of land in the woreda has now been completely depleted causing aridity and soil erosion.

Ato Ahemed Hussien, team leader of environmental protection and land use section under the department, said nearly 100 peasants and development workers were offered an eight-day training in a bid to alleviate the problem throughout forestation and terracing.

Ato Urgassa Letemo and Ato Anto Bedada, participants at the training, said forest clearing that has been going on for long due to lack of awareness has now exposed them to such excruciating problems.

Africa News


February 27, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopia & South African Chambers Sign Agreement


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The Ethiopian Chamber of Commerce and the Johannesburg Chamber of Commerce yesterday signed an agreement providing for the enhancement of the liaison and cooperation between the respective organization in the field of export, investment, business information and other commerce oriented activities.

The agreement was signed by Ato Wubshet Workalemahu, President of the Ethiopian and Addis Ababa chambers of commerce, and Mrs. Letitia Schutte, mission leader of the south Africa business delegation at a ceremony held at the Imperial Hotel.

According to the agreement, the two chambers of commerce should recommend to their respective commercial authorities all such measures as in the opinion of the would be beneficial and helpful to increase trade and economic cooperation between the two organizations. 

They will also take such steps as may be necessary and feasible to promote trade and economic cooperation between the two organizations and notify and help each other where possible in the holding of trade exhibitions or fairs for the promotion of products of the two organizations.

The agreement would also enable the two chambers of commerce exchange trade and market information and disseminate to the businessmen of the two organizations information on the goods and services respectively available, whenever possible.

The agreement will be in effect for a period of three years as of the date of signature and will be extended if the two organizations so approve prior to its termination.

Speaking on the occasion the mission leader Mrs. Schutte said the objective of the visit of the south African business delegation is to get firsthand information from the Ethiopian business community for establishing trade links between the two countries' businessmen.

Meanwhile, Mr. Mohdher Zenaidi, Trade Minister of Tunisia received in Tunis the day before, the Ethiopian economic delegation led by the general secretary of the Addis Ababa Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

According to Tunisia's Press Agency the delegation which is composed of businessmen is staying in Tunisia until March the 3rd. They are reporting to visit several economic enterprises and hold contacts with their Tunisian counterparts notably those in the food industry, building materials, electric equipment and electronics, as well as those in the pharmaceutical industrial sectors.

Mr. Zenaidi expressed hope on the occasion that the visit of the delegation would contribute to definite new fields of cooperation and achieving results in promoting trade exchanges between the two countries.

Ethiopia;
House Speaker Consults On Return of Axum Obelisk


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - House Speaker Dawit Yohannes urged yesterday the national committee for the return of the Axum Obelisk scheduled to fly to Rome Saturday, to discharge responsibilities in recognition of the peoples' demand for the reinstitution of the relic.

During talks with members of the committee, House speaker Dawit said the Italian government has shown good will for the return of the obelisk, urging members of the delegation to exert their utmost effort for the realisation of the hitherto campaign. 

The delegation led by Deputy Foreign Minister Dr. Tekeda Alemu is expected to begin talks with senior Italian officials in Rome on Monday.

The delegation comprising representatives of ministries of justice, information and culture, the House of Peoples' Representatives as well as the mayor of Axum town and renowned personalities.

Members of the delegation are expected to reach consensus on Italy's responsibility in returning the obelisk now standing in Rome in front of the building of the UN World Food Programme.

Italy's foreign minister is expected to attend the opening of the meeting, it was reported.

The Ethiopian delegation has also as its member Engineer Kidane Wolde- Giorigis who in 1963 EC flew to Rome to study the condition of the obelisk and seek ways for its return.

The Axum Obelisk was looted in 1937 upon orders by the then fascist Italy leader Benito Mussolini.

Africa News


February 27, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Need for talks on Nile waters equitable utlization stressed


BYLINE: Abebe Gelaw, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - there is an imperative need for negotiations on the redistribution of the Nile waters as their utilization at present is "grossly unjust" and ignores the legitimate rights and interest of most riparian states, an Ethiopian legal expert noted Tuesday during the ongoing 5th Nile 2002 Conference on legal and constitutional framework for cooperation.

Ato Girma Amare, head of the Legal Affairs General Directorate in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said that there was an urgent need for negotiations on the equitable utilization of the Nile to avert potential crisis arising from separate actions by riparian states. "The status quo should not be allowed to continue as it does not promote cooperation among the Nile basin countries for optimal utilization of their untapped resources," he stated.

Ato Amare pointed out that there is, on the one hand, a "purposeful and determined effort" by Egypt "to use and consume every drop of the Nile "even to the extent of diverting it beyond its natural drainage basin while, on the other, other riparian states are sooner or later bound to assert their right to engage in the actual utlization of their waters using standards which they deem legitimate and appropriate. 

According to Ato Amare, such trend would give rise to competitive and conflicting uses of the water resource. He indicated that if this state of affairs is left unattended to, the situation could "degenerate into crisis and not augur well for beneficial cooperative relationship among the Nile basin States."

The expert was of the view that one strategy for upstream-down-stream cooperation in the utilization of the Nile, as suggested by hydraulic experts, is the construction of a number of reservoirs on the upper reaches of the flow to control its variation. "Impounding the Blue Nile at Lake Tana in Ethiopia could prevent the loss of as much as 15 billion cubic meters per year of the much needed water, almost a fifth of the Nile's annual flow, by evaporation and seepage from the downstream lake Nassar, created by Aswan High Dam" he noted.

He said, however, that such an arrangement, whatever its significance it is unwilling to lose her "monopoly" over the flow of the Nile. "There is an over-exaggerated sensitivity that if a dam is built on the highlands of Ethiopia to harness the waters of the Nile it will be exposed to Egyptian vulnerability". he pointed out.

The expert emphasised that Ethiopia should not be expected to postpone indefinitely the use of its water resources for its abundant water resources of the Nile for its development needs, to ensure food security for its growing population and avert the dangers of drought which it had painfully experience," he said.

On the basis of its share of the area of the Nile's drainage basin and its huge water contribution, Ato Amare noted, Ethiopia should be entitled to a large portion of the Nile's waters. he pointed out that it is presently using less than I billion cubic meters while contributing 72 billion cubic metre of water on average, amounting to 86 per cent of the Nile water. Ethiopia has for a long time been relegated to a position of merely asserting its claims against down-stream states, while making no effective utilization," he added.

Ato Amare suggested, however, that countries of the Nile should engage themselves in fruitful negotiations to allocate equitable share of the Nile waters. "There is no reason why countries of the Nile basin do not accept and negotiate their shared resources on the basis of the universally accepted principle of equitable utlization of transboundary waters," the expert stated.

In the course of the deliberation, Ato Amare gave clarifications on various points raised by participants.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


425 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 27, 1997


Ethiopia;
Better Harvest Expected Than Last Year


BYLINE: Kisut G/Egziabher, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

AWASSA - The Southern Nations, Nationalities and Peoples' Regional State (SNNPRS) expects to reap 17.67 million quintals of agricultural products during this harvest season - representing a 31.3 per cent growth over that of last year.

Submitting the latest six-monthly report to the 4th regular conference of the regional state which was opened here yesterday, SNNPRS President Abate Kisho said that the expected harvest was to be collected from 4,504 half- hectare extension package demonstration sites and 1.44 million hectares of land tilled in the traditional way. Ato Abate attributed the success to the newly adopted extension package scheme and described it as a positive sign of the regional state's irreversible drive towards attainment of self- sufficiency in food. 

According to Ato Abate, peasant farmers embraced in the package reaped an average of 55,31, and 12 quintals per hectare of maize, wheat and "teff", respectively. He nonetheless singled out delayed debt repayment by farmers as the main obstacle to the implementation of the overall agricultural extension package, to which he called for a quick solution. He said that over 16 million birr was still in arrears.

During the next crop season the extension package has been so designed as to include oil seeds, pulses, spices, fruits and vegetables as well as poultry among others it was learnt.

The report disclosed that the regional investment bureau has since 1984 EC, issued a number of entrepreneurs with licences for 242 projects with a total capital outlay of 1.03 billion birr. Many of the licensed projects cover agriculture, agro-industries, construction, trade and real estate as well as hotels and tourism.

The majority of the projects are reportedly still in the formative stage and that when they begin operation the are expected to generate employment for some 39,800 people.

Ato Abate reminded participants of the November 1996 Investment Promotion Workshop, which this regional capital hosted, had served its intended purpose. According to him, following the convening of said workshop, 90 investors applied for new licences of whom 37, with a total capital outlay of 102.7 million birr, have already been granted the necessary documents.

The regional president revealed that some people in the Agriculture, Works and Urban Development as well as Water, Mines and Energy Resources Development Bureaux have been suspected of embezzling public fund and properties and that their cases have reached the courts. He said that the police have been investigating more such cases.

Ato Abate's report covered a wide range of issues in the economic, political and social sectors. The afternoon session was devoted to discussing the economic aspects of the report.

The conference will continue discussion the political part of the report, on justice and security in particular, it also deliberates on two draft proclamations for the establishments of judicial, administrative council and rural road fund.

Yesterday's opening session was attended by some senior Federal government officials who represent the region.

LANGUAGE: English
