Africa News


February 27, 1997


Southern Africa;
Dogs Maul Pigeon Thief To Death


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The trick by thieves using poisoned meat to kill guard dogs is well known. But two men who tried this Tuesday in Kasama, northern Zambia, found the bait is not foolproof. 

On that fateful night, the district police said, a man offered poisoned meat to four "vicious" canines, so that he and a fellow thief could later steal pigeons from a barn.

Unfortunately, for the thieves, only one of the ferocious dogs took the bait and died.

For some unexplained reason, the other three dogs just sniffed at the meat and went back to sleep, police told reporters Wednesday.

"Thinking that they had successfully accomplished their mission of killing the dogs, the two men later returned to the house and climbed the barn and started stealing the pigeons," northern regional Police Deputy Commander Crispas Siame was quoted Thursday as saying.

The thieves managed to rustle 44 pigeons from the barn and were happily climbing down, having let "the sleeping dogs lie."

As fate would have it, one of the thieves stepped on a weak piece of wood and fell. The noise woke the three sleeping dogs. Then, they set upon the man. One of the thieves escaped with the birds.

Another had his ears, mouth and other parts torn off by the dogs which left him an unrecognizable corpse.

The Kasama District Police said are trying to identify the deceased and his runaway colleague -- and possibly to recover the pigeons

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 27, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Zambia To Host Comesa Summit


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - After a lapse of two years, the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA), summit will be held April 10 in Lusaka, Zambia's information and broadcasting deputy minister, Ernest Mwansa, said Thursday.

Opening a two-day Comesa workshop for journalists, he said the summit will be held April 10. 

The announcement, at the opening of a two-day Comesa workshop for journalists, comes against doubts about the future of the regional integration organisation after Mozambique and Lesotho gave notice of their attention to leave in favour of the 12-member Southern African Development Community, or Sadc.

Both countries said their immediate interested lay with Sadc.

"WE should concentrate on Sadc, rather than joining an institution with a lot of members and where there is conflict between the members," Mozambican Foreign Minister Leonardo Simao said in December, 1996.

He said even when Comesa was created, Maputo had some reservations, " because our volume of cooperation with many countries in the organisation was negligible. We just signed adhesion to the Comesa treaty but we have never ratified it."

Sadc consists of Angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Malawi, Mauritius, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Swaziland, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

Comesa comprises Angola, Burundi, Comoros, Djibouti, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Kenya, Madagascar, Malawi, Mauritius, Mozambique, Namibia, Rwanda, Somalia, Sudan, Swaziland, Tanzania, Uganda, Zaire, Zambia and Zimbabwe.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


428 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 27, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Egypt Says Its Share Of Nile Water Is Insufficient


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Egypt has officially stated its intention to maximize utilization of the Nile river's water to meet the requirements of its rapidly growing population.

At meeting in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, Egyptian water authorities said they were dissatisfaction with the current supply, saying it is insufficient to meet its domestic demands.

Egypt said this in a position paper presented to the fifth Nile 2002 Conference which entered its fourth day Thursday in the Ethiopian capital. 

Although the other upstream Nile riparian states consider Egypt and Sudan to be taking the lion's share of Africa's largest and longest river, under the 1959 treaty, Egyptian water authorities say their country needs more water to improve food security.

The Nile river riparian countries are Burundi, Egypt, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Kenya, Rwanda, Sudan, Tanzania, Uganda and Zaire.

To drum up support for its case, Egypt has adopted a gradual "confidence building" approach to the development of the Nile through cooperation on regional and subregional bases among the countries in the river basin.

The Egyptian stand is in contrast to the demand of some riparian states such as Ethiopia "for an equitable share" of Nile waters in the not to distant future.

"Projects beneficial for the Nile river basin countries, without any appreciable harm to each other, could be the first step for regional cooperation and confidence-building measures," Egypt says.

At present, Egypt cultivates 7.8 million acres (3.2 million hectares) of irrigated land and wants more water for an additional 1.6 million acres (647, 520 hectares) of reclaimed land by the year 2000.

"Horizontal expansion and land reclamation for agriculture is a must due to the fact that the area of cultivated land per capita is decreasing rapidly because of rapid population growth," the Egypt.

With a population of 62 million, Egypt's ratio of cultivated land is about 0.12 acre (0.05 hectares) per person.

Egypt also wants the establishment of a Nile basin regional data bank that would be linked with national data banks of the various riparian states.

This way, it hopes the riparian states would be able to reach "an overall integrated plan" for development.

However, it says that this requires "a lot of effort and financial resources."

The ongoing meeting on the sharing of the Nile water is a follow-up to four previous ones, which were held in Egypt, Sudan, Tanzania and Uganda.

Kenya will host the 1998 conference while the 1999 meeting is scheduled to be held in Zaire, to discuss the water-sharing procedure on the 6,500- kilometer long river Nile.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


429 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 27, 1997


United States and Africa;
Kadhafi Urges Rejection of U.S. Force Proposal;
Africa-United States,


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Libyan leader Moammar Kadhafi has urged African countries to shun the creation of a continental peace force as proposed by the United States.

"African countries have their own armies and police that can solve African conflicts," he said at a dinner he hosted Wednesday in Tripoli for delegates attending the 65th ministerial council meeting of the Organization of African Unity.

"We must set up our own force to prevent any foreign intervention in African affairs," he said. 

Kadhafi said that any African force acting under orders of any foreign power would be rejected by all of Africa.

He called also for member states of the organization to establish a special fund to finance an African controlled force, while not rejecting the idea of foreign contributions to the fund.

"We can accept financial contributions from the United States, France or any other country on condition that such contributions are not linked to obligations or preconditions," he said.

He was reacting to a proposal made in 1996 by former U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher during an African tour to canvass support for the controversial proposal.

Several states, including South Africa, had expressed reservations over the idea, saying it should be an African rather than a foreign-controlled force.

Kadhafi, who survived a 1986 U.S. Air Force raid on his Tripoli residence, said Africans were capable of mobilizing and funding their peace force.

"America should remain in its territory," he said.

Kadhafi also used the occasion to address Africa's many problems, blaming most of them on the "colonialists," whom he accused of fuelling conflicts that serve their objective of perpetual subjugation of Africa and its people.

He condemned the U.S.-sponsored United Nations sanctions against Libya, saying this amounted to passing judgement without a trial.

The Libyan leader described as a "challenge of African unity and solidarity, " Tripoli's hosting of the Organization of African Unity's Council of Foreign Ministers meeting, despite of the sanctions imposed on Libya in 1992 over allegations that his country was involved in the 1988 bombing of a PanAm jetliner over Lockerbie, Scotland. Some 270 people were killed in the plane and on the ground.

Kadhafi reiterated that the suspects arrested by Libya in connection with the case could be tried in a neutral country but not in the United States or Britain.

He praised delegates to the council meeting for "defying the American sanctions," by finding their way to Tripoli from Tunisia by road, a distance of some 300 kilometers (186.42 miles).

It is the first major meeting, bringing together at least 30 African foreign ministers, in Tripoli since the imposition of the U.N. sanctions.

Libya unsuccessfully tried to host an O.A.U. summit in 1982.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

430 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 27, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
African Leaders Pledge To Support Democracy


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

KASANE, Botswana (PANA) - Leaders from 18 African countries, who met in Botswana for a two-day commonwealth round-table summit which ended Thursday, have affirmed the importance of civic education as a key element in the promotion and protection of democracy, amid concern that democratic principles were crumbling on the continent.

The leaders, who met in the northern Botswana resort town of Kasane, said it was important to provide educational campaigns which emphasized the rights and obligations of all: government, opposition parties and civil society.

However, they expressed concern about the role of some non-governmental organizations which, with foreign support, promoted activities harmful to stable democratic processes. 

In a communique released at the end of the summit, the leaders underlined that "sustainable democracy could only grow within societies and could neither be prescribed nor imposed from outside."

In expressing this belief, they referred to the experience of de- colonization of Africa and their own national struggles for political freedom which had been inspired by the desire to win democratic rights for their peoples.

The round table summit was organized by the Commonwealth secretariat in London, Britain. It was used by the leaders to review progress in democratization in their respective countries since the adoption of the Harare Commonwealth declaration of 1991 and to exchange views on how they might meet present and future challenges.

The leaders received the report of the preparatory meeting of the two-day round table held Monday. They welcomed the fact that it was the product of a cross-section of representatives of governing and opposition parties from their respective countries.

The summit was attended by the presidents and prime ministers of Botswana, Cameroon, Gambia, Ghana, Kenya, Lesotho, Malawi, Mauritius, Mozambique, Namibia, Seychelles, Sierra Leone, South Africa, Swaziland, Tanzania, Uganda, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

The leaders reaffirmed their commitment to the principles contained in the Harare Declaration. This document included the protection and promotion of democracy, democratic processes and institutions which reflect national circumstances.

In particular, the leaders called for the universally-accepted ingredients of democracy, which included the right of people to elect freely their government, the primacy of the rule of law and independence of the judiciary, the right of freedom of expression and association and the transparency and accountability of government.

Since the Harare Declaration, Africa had made considerable progress in democratic restructuring. As a result, all the member countries, but for Nigeria, have now jettisoned military or one-party rule. However, Nigeria is engaged in a process to return to civilian rule by 1998.

Nevertheless, challenges and impediments in the way of consolidating democracy remain with poverty, underdevelopment, ethnicity and the weakness of supporting institutions essential to sustainable democracy being the major impediments.

The leaders agreed that measures to remove these obstacles called for national effort by all political leaders to cultivate a culture of tolerance, mutual respect and cooperation to promote national peace and stability.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February 28, 1997


South Africa;
Tutu and Boraine Meet with de Klerk


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Cape Town - Statement from Archbishop Desmond Tutu, chairperson, TRC, February 27, 1997

Dr Alex Boraine and I met Mr F W de Klerk, leader of the National Party, for just over an hour at the offices of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission in Cape Town today.

Mr de Klerk asked me for the meeting after controversy over the Steyn Report, and I insisted that Dr Boraine should be present. Mr de Klerk raised the issue of the Steyn Report only briefly before moving onto other issues, and I made clear to him that there is no difference in attitude between Dr Boraine and myself on the key issues facing the Commission.

The meeting was dominated by issues raised by Mr de Klerk, including:

* What he described as the perception that the Commission is not even- handed;

* His concern that we are not placing enough emphasis on reconciliation; and

* His conviction that only a handful of members of the Security forces during the apartheid era was guilty of gross violations of human rights (he said in the same way, this was probably true also for the liberation movements).

Dr Boraine and I reassured Mr de Klerk that the Commission was totally committed to even-handedness and gave him a range of examples demonstrating this.

We also sought to reassure him that reconciliation was our ultimate goal, although the Commission could play only a small part in the long-term task of bringing it about.

Mr de Klerk also dealt with the logistics of his party's reply to the extensive list of questions which he was sent after he made an initial presentation to the Commission last August. He said he expected to deliver the reply in two weeks' time, after which a date for a public hearing would be arranged between us.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February 28, 1997


South Africa;
Truth Panel to Hold Public Hearing for Drug Doctor


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Cape Town - Statement by Dr Alex Boraine, vice-chairperson, Truth and Reconciliation Commission, February 26, 1997.

As a consequence of the recent Appellate Division judgement requiring the advance provision of documents to those implicated in Commission proceedings, the TRC has granted Dr Wouter Basson a postponement of his appearance before the Commission. 

Dr Basson was to have appeared at a closed investigative inquiry of the Commission, conducted in terms of Section 29 of the Promotion of National Unity and Reconciliation Act, tomorrow and Friday. However, lawyers for Dr Basson have requested copies of documents in the Commission's possession and indicated that they will need time to prepare for his appearance.

The Commission will supply the necessary documents and will set a new date for his appearance within a few days.

The Act gives the Commission the power to release information in its possession to the public, including that gained in Section 29 investigations. As a result of the delay in hearing Dr Basson, as well as of the importance of the matter, we have decided that instead of holding a closed inquiry, and then releasing information, we will now subpoena Dr Basson to appear at a public hearing.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

433 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 28, 1997


Uganda;
WFP Starts Relief Food Operation in Northern Uganda


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

Rome - The World Food Programme today approved a new relief food operation for northern Uganda where insurgency by rebel forces has caused an increasing number of people to flee their homes. Some 220,000 people in the Gulu and Kitgum districts have been uprooted and are consequently impoverished, many of them during the last three months when rebel attacks spread heavily into the Kitgum area.

"The people in northern Uganda are really suffering, and the situation can only get worse if insecurity continues," said WFP's Executive Director, Catherine Bertini while visiting Kitgum town today. "Most of the people are farmers who are too terrified to return to their land to plant their crops. If they don't plant, there will be no July harvest -- and if there's no July harvest, the people will need relief food until this time next year." 

At the beginning of the year, insurgency into Kitgum district intensified. Once used as a route by rebels to transit to Gulu, Kitgum itself suddenly became the site of attacks in January when a large force attacked several villages and indiscriminately killed more than 300 people. This led to the sudden displacement of 62,000 people.

The new WFP food operation, worth US$6.7 million including transport costs, will assist 110,000 of the most vulnerable people in northern Uganda. To the extent possible, WFP will distribute the food through food-for-work projects which will help people grow their own food. Other food rations will be distributed through four non-governmental organizations (NGOs) who have been working in the area for many years.

Since July 1996, attacks on civilians by the "Lord's Resistance Army" (LRA) and the "West Nile Bank Front" have increased, with more coordinated and frequent attempts to abduct and convert the local population. Several thousand people have lost their lives or have been subjected to torture and mutiliation upon refusing to join the rebels or to provide them refuge.

These attacks have cause the local population to flee their villages. Their homes, food stocks and standing crops are usually torched, their personal property looted, and their livestock stolen or slaughtered. Most people fled their villages penniless and without possessions, arriving in townships and displaced sites with fragile economies and limited economic opportunities.

This rapid influx of internally displaced people to these sites has led to overcrowding, and a complete collapse of water and sanitation systems followed by outbreaks of measles, dysentary and other diseases. Malnutrition, once only a limited and seasonal phenomena in these districts, has become perennial and chronic. Insecurity caused health workers and teachers to flee the rebel-hit areas long ago, leaving only nine out of 45 health clinics operating, and a mere 32 of the total 180 schools operational in the Gulu district.

"WFP has already given several batches of emergency food to northern Uganda in order to stop malnutrition from spreading, particularly amongst young children and women," said Bertini. "But to combat the mounting problems cause by more people being displaced, WFP must now help out on a much larger scale."

The Government of Uganda has also been providing food and non food items to outlying areas of Gulu district since July 1996.

The depopulation of villages has separated farmers from their land and agricultural livelihood. It has disrupted production and marketing over vast areas, covering one-quarter of the country's cultivable land mass. Insecurity has prevented most farmers from harvesting last season's crop. The few who managed to do so were unable to sell their limited surpluses due to a breakdown in the transport system. Lack of fuel and increased risk to transporters because of landmines and ambushes have made truckers refuse to operate in the area, or only at a high price. High transport costs have in turn, forced the price of cereals to soar beyond the means of the average consumer, particularly of the displaced.

A total of 220,000 persons have been affected by the conflict, including 80, 000 who move to the relative safety of trading centres and military outposts in the evenings, returning to their land to farm during daylight hours. Another 20,000 are residing with friends and relatives in more secure areas of the country. The remaining 120,000 people have been totally displaced from their land and sources of income, and are crowded within churches, schools, hospital grounds and other sanctuaries. Women, children and the elderly, plus those hospitalized for illness and injuries, are amongst the most vulnerable.

WFP's food assistance to 110,000 people in northern Uganda will extend until July 1997.

WFP is also feeding 260,000 refugees, mostly southern Sudanese, in five camps spread through northern Uganda. Rebel insurgency has made the delivery of food to this population increasing difficult. Refugee camps have themselves been targetted several times by rebels active in the area, resulting in the death of more than 200 refugees.

For more information contact: Brenda Barton Regional Information Office, Kenya Tel: (254-2) 622594/622336. Allen Jones/Michael Jones, WFP Kampala Tel: (246-41) 231112/251758

(ENDS)

Africa News


February 28, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 111 on the Great Lakes (02/28)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1774 words


 

Nairobi - An unconfirmed number of refugees are reported to be moving out of Tingi-Tingi camps, eastern Zaire, by foot, in fear of an imminent attack. Rwandan camp leaders in Tingi-Tingi camps today said that all expatriate workers should evacuate from the camps as an attack was expected tonight. The French NGO Action Contre la Faim decided today to evacuate from Tingi-Tingi camps and Kisangani, because of tension and insecurity.

* Humanitarian sources describe Kisangani as "tense" - because the behaviour of the Zairean soldiers is unpredictable in the changing situation. There are unconfirmed reports that the Zairean army has sent in reinforcements to Tingi-Tingi camps, including mercenaries.

* Well-placed regional sources confirm that Kindu has been occupied by rebel forces of the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo- Zaire (ADFL) since yesterday monring. The airstrip has also reportedly been taken by the rebels. 2,000 FAZ troops stationed in Kindu garrison town reportedly fled after extensive looting. Fleeing FAZ are reported to be moving westwards towards Katako-Kombe, and are expected to arrive sometime this weekend. Local Zairean press described Kindu today as a "ville morte". The World Health Organisation is trying to evacuate a 15-person medical survey team which had been despatched this week to Katako-Kombe. The team had gone to investigate a Monkey Pox outbreak. 

Diplomatic sources say that the capture of Kindu and its airport represents a significant strategic gain for the rebels.

* Sources in the region say that the rebels have made significant gains between Isiro and Kisangani, and the towns of Bafwangbe and Bafwabogbo were confirmed to have been taken by the ADFL. ADFL are reported to have reached Bafwaboli - about 100 kilometres east of Kisangani.

* The approach road to Tingi-Tingi is said to be controlled by Rwandan militia, and the presence of Rwandan soldiers injured in combat in local hospitals point to continued fighting between Rwandan militia and the rebels. Humanitarian sources say the front line has moved closer to the camp, and is believed to be defended by Rwandan milita. Rwandans and aid workers in Tingi- Tingi camps reported over the last few days that "the sound of battle" can be heard at night. Journalists have reported barrack-like housing exclusively for men on one side of Tingi-Tingi 1. News-agencies have reported that some ex-FAR and former professionals have flown out of Tingi-Tingi, but that the exodus has been predominantly women and children.

* Private air companies continue to fly out Rwandans capable of paying $800 or more, to Nairobi via Kisangani, but there is no evidence that the "elite exodus" has reduced the hold of camp leaders on genuine refugees - well- placed sources indicate that, on the contrary, it is the camp leaders who control and administer the exodus. The presence of Rwandan soldiers injured in combat in local hospitals points to continued fighting between Rwandan militia and the rebels. The approach road to Tingi-Tingi is said to be controlled by Rwandan militia; journalists have reported barrack-like housing exclusively for men on one side of Tingi-Tingi I. News agencies have reported that some ex-FAR and former professionals have flown out of Tingi-Tingi, but that the exodus has been predominantly women and children.

* The Foreign Minister of Zaire, Gerard Kamanda Wa Kamanda on Thursday ruled out any ceasefire with the ADFL as long as "foreign troops" remained in eastern Zaire. At the ministerial meeting of the OAU in Tripoli, Kamanda repeated accusations that Uganda and Rwanda had sent troops to assist the rebels. He said that if "foreign troops" were pulled out in accordance with UN Security Council Resolution 1097 "we can discuss under what conditions peace and stability can be restored". He said proposals for an African " buffer force" being discussed in Tripoli was a good idea "in principle" but said there was no reason to believe that such a force would suceed where a multi-national force had failed. Kamanda was interviewed by Radio France Internationale, South African radio and AFP.

* The Organisation of African Unity special summit on the crisis of Zaire, March 18-19, will be held in Togo, the OAU announced yesterday. The summit is expected to address the possible deployment of an African buffer force between the warring parties in Zaire.

* In a speech to a formal session of the UN Security Council, US ambassador Bill Richardson warned Angolans against any involvement in the conflict in Zaire. Richardson did not specify whether the reference was to Angolan government forces of those of the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA), led by Jonas Savimbi. It is the first time the US has officially implied that Angolans are involved in the conflict. The international dimensions of the eastern Zaire conflict have not diminished; the remarks about Angolan involvement came on the same day that the Zairean government accused Uganda of amassing troops in

The Field Coordinator for UNHCR based in Goma, Filippo Grandi, said yesterday that UNHCR "categorically denies" allegations that 500,000 Hutu refugees in eastern Zaire have been killed or have disappeared. Grandi told AFP in Goma that UNHCR would have known if massacres on a large scale had taken place, and said the international community "should not play around with words as serious as 'genocide'". He said there was no doubt that some refugees had been killed, but "there was nothing to prove organised massacres" . He described the figure of 500,000 as "pure fantasy". This week the Belgium Minister for Development and his spokesman said there are reports of " genocidal acts" in eastern Zaire, by rebels - although a statement by the Belgian Foreign Ministry later emphasized that the Belgian government was interested in reports of killings by all parties in Zaire. The French Foreign Ministry said yesterday that it considered the genocide reports "reliable" and called for an international enquiry. There has been no independent monitoring of human rights in rebel-held and government-controlled eastern Zaire to-date.

* On February 26, the Cyangugu court in southwestern Rwanda, sentenced Thedodore Munyangabe to death and to pay compensation of more than 34 million Rwandan francs. He was found guilty of crimes of genocide and other crimes against humanity, reported state-run Rwandan radio. He has 15 days in which to appeal. Between 27 December and 18 February 1997, 18 judgements have been handed down in genocide trials. Eleven of these were death sentences, six were life imprisonments, and one was an acquittal, reports the UN Human Rights Field Operation in Rwanda (UNHRFOR). UNHRFOR, while welcoming the start of genocide trials has "noted concerns" regarding aspects of the proceedings, in particular the lack of legal representation.

The latest report from the UN Human Rights Field Operation in Rwanda (UNHRFOR) states that, since the beginning of January, "the human rights and security situation has drastically deteriorated... in particular in the four prefectures bordering Zaire." UNHRFOR received reports of the killings of 424 Rwandans in 55 incidents. The report (UNHRFOR/UPD/13/2) indicates that at least 163 of these killings were allegedly perpetrated by agents of the state - 107 of which took place in the course of military operations in Ruhengeri. The ex-FAR and Interahamwe militia are blamed with 42 killings - mostly of genocide survivors and witnesses. The UNHRFOR also reports that 99,300 persons were detained in central prisons and local detention centres at the end of January. These do not include detainees in military facilities, to which UNHRFOR does not have access.

* The UN Secretary General's Special Representative for Burundi, Marc Faguy, left Burundi yesterday after months attempting to persuade Burundian leaders to pursue a political, non-military solution, and implement a ceasefire. He told journalists that Burundi leaders had expressed a willingness to negotiate.

A US diplomat in Bujumbura said yesterday that deposed Burundian president Sylvestre Ntibantunganya was still residing in US embassy property. The former president's party, Front for Democracy in Burundi (FRODEBU) said on Tuesday that Buyoya had persuaded Ntibantunganya to leave, reported AFP.

* Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni bet a journalist in March 1996 that rebel leader Joseph Kony would be killed or captured in about seven months; but he lost the $1,000 bet. "Our work is to kill these people, and we shall crush them", Museveni announced at a press conference last March. The journalist reportedly declined the wager for lack of a stake, but has recieved the money in two installments from the president's office, the Monitor newspaper reported today. Journalist Tamale Mirundi recieved a million Ugandan shillings.

Nairobi, 28 February 1997, 15:15 GMT

435 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 28, 1997


Business and Finance;
Job creation project for Western Cape


BYLINE: Alide Dasnois, Business Editor, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Cape Town - Guguletu, Mitchells Plain and Atlantis are among nine areas targeted by the Western Cape Department of Economic Affairs for a new Local Economic Development (LED) programme aimed at job creation.

"This is not a programme of promises but of delivery," department head Tony Ruiters said at a briefing yesterday.

The LED programme was a key element in the province's economic policy, due to be released within two weeks, and would be developed in line with the Government's Growth, Employment and Redistribution (Gear) plan. 

The province was aiming for the creation of 50 000 permanent jobs a year by the year 2000, economic growth of 8 percent a year and the quadrupling of exports. The Western Cape government was confident that it could beat the national economic growth target of 6 percent a year "by 1,5 percent or 2 percent", he said.

The nine areas targeted by the Led programme are Mossel Bay, Montagu-Ashton, Plettenberg Bay, Beaufort West, Vredendal, Genadendal, Mitchells Plain, Guguletu and Atlantis.

Mr Ruiters said a profile of the population, including data on unemployment, age and economic activity was being drawn up for each area. Key growth industries in each area would be identified and skill shortages evaluated. A Local Business Service Centre would be set up by the provincial government in each area to boost the capacity of small and medium businesses and help them to network with each other and with bigger business.

The Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) incentives to small and bigger businesses would be used to attract investment to these areas.

The target towns would also be marketed abroad, said Mr Ruiters, with representatives taking part in any trade missions overseas.

Experience had shown that this was a good way to attract foreign investment.

The LED programme would fit in with the DTI's plans for local industrial parks, one of which is in Lansdowne-Guguletu, Mr Ruiters said.

Provincial Minister of Economic Affairs Chris Nissen said the LED programme was "an economic solution to urbanisation".

The movement of people into Cape Town was not only from the Eastern Cape but also from smaller towns in the Western Cape, he said.

"By developing towns like Vredendal, Beaufort West, Plettenberg Bay and other towns in the Overberg, we are looking for an economic, rather than a political, solution to urbanisation."

Mr Nissen said he would soon be able to announce a major foreign investment in Mitchells Plain, most of it from Malaysia.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 28, 1997


South Africa;
From Waterfront to wine estate


BYLINE: Chene Blignaut, Staff Reporter, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Cape Town - A new railway station opposite Spier wine estate near Stellenbosch, linking the Victoria & Alfred Waterfront to the Winelands, has been officially opened.

The construction of the Cape Dutch-style station was commissioned by Spier, using contractors from previously disadvantaged communities. 

Intersite Property Management Services, the property arm of the SA Rail Commuter Corporation, was approached by Spier, which wanted a station close to the estate to enable people to catch the Spier steam train from the Waterfront.

A lease agreement for the land on the railway reserve opposite the Spier estate was negotiated.

Intersite regional manager Kevin Roman said the link-up with Spier was in line with the company's vision to transport people at any time - not just to and from work.

Negotiations were underway to extend the platform to accommodate a 12-coach commuter train.

"This will open up the wine farm to local tourists who rely on trains for transport.

"It is also in line with our objective to facilitate maximum private sector involvement in the portfolios we manage," said Mr Roman.

Opening the new station this week, Western Cape Economic Affairs Minister Chris Nissen hailed it as an ideal illustration of the successful partnership which needed to be created between the state and the private sector in the development of the country's economy.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


437 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 28, 1997


South Africa;
Cape Town on track for hassle-free commuting


BYLINE: Sharkey Isaacs, Transport Reporter, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Cape Town - An ambitious upgrading programme will leave more than 1000 Metrorail train coaches vandal-proof and offer commuters a safer, more comfortable ride.

Upgrading at Transnet workshops will cost between R500 000 and R600 000 compared with R3-million for a new coach.

The first train complete with modernised coaches is expected to arrive in Cape Town from Gauteng by the end of the year, said Transnet's regional operations manager Piet Lotz. 

He said Cape Town had been given a sneak preview of the prototype coaches in December when some were sent to the Peninsula. They were used during the visit by the International Olympic Committee's evaluation commission for the city's 2004 Olympic bid.

The modernised coaches differ from trains now in use in almost every respect except for their external appearance.

Seats in the upgraded coaches are more comfortable and vandal proof, and the floors are constructed with fire-retardant Finnish wood.

Side and ceiling panels are made of fire-resistant mouldings and the coaches have improved lighting.

Each coach also has a public address system installed to broadcast music. The doors are tamper-proof and are equipped with panic buttons.

The windows are shatterproof and baggage racks, previously constructed using aluminium and regularly vandalised, have been made with epoxy-coated steel which has very little scrap metal value.

Although the coach is well ventilated and the windows let in air, they do not open wide enough to be used as an escape route by ticket dodgers.

The programme is expected to take 15 years to complete.

* The popular Changing City series run by the Cape Argus is also available on our Internet site. This is a valuable electronic record of the changes happening in our city as reported through our columns.

The site is updated daily from Monday to Friday. Access the site through a hyperlink on our main page at http://www.inc.co.za/online/cape_argus or directly on http://www.inc.co.za/online/cape_argus/changing_city


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

438 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 28, 1997


South Africa;
Mandela's mystery 'gift': DP won't know until it's been unwrapped


BYLINE: Political Correspondent CLIVE SAWYER, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1320 words


 

Cape Town - The Democratic Party federal council this weekend will consider President Mandela's offer of a role in government. considers the arguments for and against acceptance.

Chinese custom is that it is rude to open a gift in front of the giver.

It is only once you get it home that you find out just what it is and whether it suits you.

The Democratic Party has found itself in this position with President Mandela's offer of a role in government, frustrated beyond measure by the vagueness of it all. 

It may be argued that even Mr Mandela himself had no clear position in mind when he made the offer and that it was merely in line with his oft-repeated statement that there were good people throughout the political spectrum.

The point of him repeating this message so often is a logical consequence of his new patriotism theme and a vision, as he articulated last weekend, of a Zimbabwe-style unity government.

Mr Mandela's notion already has inspired extreme caution among the Pan Africanist Congress, a party with an even smaller share of the vote than the DP, which has rejected any suggestion of a merger with the African National Congress leviathan.

Where does the DP find itself as it gathers this weekend?

One of the party's strongest points is that it does not suffer the lack of identity or sense of division with which the National Party is burdened.

It is a party of social democratic liberal values, with a long and proud tradition of articulating those values, and can claim with little fear of contradiction to speak on behalf of the interests of business, small and large.

It speaks the language of those perturbed by perceptions of declining standards of morality and security, from a stronger moral platform than the NP, which daily is further besmeared by the revelations of the Truth Commission.

Its constituency consists mainly of people whose levels of education and wealth are well above average in an as-yet unreconstructed economy.

But for all this, the DP stares at a bleak horizon when it considers its prospects of expansion.

There has been nothing to suggest it has made anything but the slightest inroads into the black electorate since 1994, a goal commonly acknowledged as essential to any party with plans to stay in business in the 21st Century.

Its existing constituency, of relatively wealthy middle-class whites, is undergoing attrition on three fronts.

Emigration, a low birth rate and the pattern displayed in other liberated African countries of whites becoming less involved in politics as they sense their importance dwindling, could mean fewer crosses next to the DP's name as election goes by.

It must be said immediately that this very factor of alienation and disillusionment among its constituency could spell the DP's end if it accepts President Mandela's offer.

To lower the standard of liberal democracy to disappear into the camp of the majority party could be seen as nothing more than a cynical act of selling-out for which the party would pay dearly in 1999.

To be handed a job on a commission, in any other government role, or - as slim as the chances might be - a position in the Cabinet and then perform at less than optimum would expose the party to ridicule from all sides.

The ANC would be able to argue that the DP, its most piercing critics, had done no better in government than they; the NP would be able to accuse the DP of falling into all the traps which they themselves were said to have done.

Against this is the argument of the DP agreeing to Mr Mandela's offer as a form of national service.

The argument goes that all those at Kempton Park acceded to a deal to deliver each of their constituencies to sustain a stable and democratic transition.

The DP and the NP were part of that deal, but the NP reneged when it left ahead of 1999 on a political whim of its own, however much the divorce may have been to the considerable relief of both parties at the time.

Thus it falls to the DP to bring itself and its constituency into the engine room of the transition, rather than banging away discordantly outside.

The other argument for acceptance is one which bears in mind the continuing precariousness of race relations, and the fact that the balm of reconciliation has a long way to go to healing the wounds of the past.

This is the danger of a perpetuation of the racial polarisation of politics, a danger acknowledged by every party, if sometimes only - for the reasons outlined above - for the sake of their own survival.

With the NP out of government, the new constitution having spelt an end to its prospects of ever forcing a return to a mandatory coalition and the Inkatha Freedom Party being widely perceived as having a specific ethnic base, the image of government is increasingly one of being black, ranged against an opposition which is overwhelmingly white.

While some may regard this perception as spurious, given the significant inroads the ANC has made into sections of the white population and the fact several of its leading MPs come from that community, as well as the NP's gains in the coloured community, it is a perception of unquestionable potential danger when viewed from the outside world.

DP entry into government would strike a major blow against this perception.

The party could take its friends in business with it to the inner sanctums of power (which is, of course, not to say they do not already frequently drop in), earning the kudos of the middle-man.

This would be a major gain for the ANC, some of whose members frankly are frustrated at the party's failure to develop organic links with business.

Most of all, in the federal council's warmest and farthest flights of fancy it could picture Tony Leon at the side of Nelson Mandela at a meeting in a township, which could do Comrade Tony's image no end of good in a constituency where he is seen as a retrogressive critic of transformation.

Against these visions, the party may balance memories of the fate of smaller parties seduced by larger ones, including that of the Labour Party and others, swallowed by the ANC in 1994, its most useful members kept on and the carcass of the party left by the wayside.

The DP may be well advised to take up Mr Mandela's offer and, by so doing, fulfil the goal of every party to have access to power; but before then, they will have to be rude and demand to know what is inside the mystery gift.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February 28, 1997


South Africa;
The Hundermark fiasco (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Cape Town - There has been an outcry over the deportation to South Africa of paedophile Dennis Hundermark after he had served only three months of a 16- month prison sentence in Britain.

If paedophile Dennis Hundermark was considered dangerous enough to be deported from Britain to South Africa accompanied by three burly policemen, adequate forward planning should have been done to ensure that on arrival here he would pose no threat to the children of this country.

Instead, a nightmare scenario unfolded. Hundermark, who has been described as a constant threat to young children and to himself, was released by the British authorities after having served less than one-fifth of a sentence on sex-related charges, and was delivered to freedom in Cape Town because there was no legal justification for detaining him in South Africa. 

This after he had admitted to bizarre fantasies in a British court, reportedly including the raping of toddlers, and after he had described himself as a "speeding train"; a person who was sick and in need of help.

How did this appalling incident come about? The British authorities, reportedly, were under the mistaken impression that Hundermark would be arrested on his arrival here. Was communication between the authorities of the two countries so poor that a potentially disastrous misunderstanding arose? Or, as some in South Africa might be tempted to suspect given Hundermark's astonishingly brief sojourn in prison, did the British authorities merely act precipitously to get rid of an awkward problem as quickly as they could?

The public is entitled to answers, not only because of the danger to which children in South Africa might have been exposed by the release here of a self-confessed and dangerous paedophile, but also to ensure that this sort of incident does not recur. Given the potential in these matters for irrational emotions to be stirred, a calm and measured official investigation is called for.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


440 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 28, 1997


Sports - General;
Kallis in SA's No 3 hot spot


BYLINE: John Freudenberg,, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Cape Town - Jacques Kallis can take great strides in making South Africa's troublesome No 3 batting position his own in the first test against Australia which began at the Wanderers today.

The 21-year-old Western Province batsman is the latest in a long line of guinea pigs who have been thrown into what has become South Africa's hot spot during the last few seasons.

The last South African No 3 batsman to score a century was Hansie Cronje, who hit a memorable 122 in the corresponding test at the Wanderers against the 1994 Australians, but whose weakness against short-pitched bowling has seen him drop down the order. 

Since then Brian McMillan, John Commins, Andrew Hudson, Daryll Cullinan, Herschelle Gibbs and Adam Bacher have all been tried in the first-drop position in tests.

Kallis, recalled to the side for his first test of the season after playing two tests against England last summer, is aware of the heavy responsibility which rests on him occupying the pivotal position in the top-order.

"There is a lot of pressure on me because No 3 has been a problem area for the team but, without wanting to sound arrogant, I feel I can provide the answer," Kallis said .

"I feel very comfortable at No 3 and just have to go out and be confident, and play like I've been playing all season."

When Kallis made his test debut against England at Kingsmead last season, he made one batting at No 6, and then made just seven runs in 90 minutes while batting at No 7 at Newlands.

Although the team management obviously wanted to ease him into the side by batting him down the order, Kallis says he would have been happy to have been thrown in at the deep end straight away.

"I enjoy No 3 because the new ball goes off the bat quickly, and there are normally more gaps in the field when you come in. The bad balls usually go for four, and you can get full value for your strokes," Kallis said.

"Obviously, there are disadvantages as well because if you nick one, the chances are there will be a third slip in place," he said.

Kallis said the fact that selection panel convener Peter Pollock had stated that he would bat at No 3 when the team was announced at the weekend had helped him mentally prepare for his role. "It was nice to know I was in the 11 and not carrying the drinks again," he said.

Although he didn't make a big score for Western Province when they played Australia a fortnight ago, Kallis spent almost three hours at the crease, which has made him a little more relaxed during the test build-up. "I've seen how some of their bowlers have tried to bowl to me and restrict my scoring, so I've been able to work on that."

McMillan's absence also means he is likely to figure more on the bowling front than might otherwise have been the case.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


441 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 28, 1997


South Africa;
Wall of fire spreads


BYLINE: Norman Joseph, Sharkey Isaacs and Andrea Weiss, Staff Reporters, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Cape Town - Fanned by a gale, the inferno that has razed hundreds of hectares of fynbos and plantations near Somerset West today spread to the Stellenbosch side of the Hottentots Holland mountains

A fire operations centre has been set up at Mont Fleur, the highest farm in the Stellenrykkloof, which could be under threat if the fire heads down the valley.

It has been contained at Sir Lowry's Pass and the historic Vergelegen wine estate, but the 130km/h gale is making conditions difficult for firefighters, who are battling a wall of flames over a 7-8km front. Three helicopters poured water on the flames from first light today. 

Ferdi Mostert, civil protection officer with the Cape Metropolitan Council, said the fire was still burning fiercely in an SA Forestry Corporation bluegum plantation north-west of the Hottentots Holland mountains today. Heavy smoke was making visibility difficult.

Damage estimates are not yet available. A spokesman for Water and Forestry Minister Kader Asmal said he hoped a figure would be available by the end of the weekend if the fire was finally contained.

A spokesman for provincial Agriculture Minister Lampie Fick said the damage appeared to be confined to plantations and nature conservation areas, but an assessment could be done only once it was out.

The fire started on the Knorhoek farm on Monday, spreading to Vergelegen later that night. It has consumed hundreds of hectares of fynbos and plantations, but vineyards and orchards have been saved.

On Lourensford farm, big plantations owned by Safcor have been badly damaged and firefighters have been battling to contain the blaze there for two days.

Don Tooth, general manager of Vergelegen, said today the fire was now being fought on the Stellenbosch and Somerset West side of the mountain.

Farmers in the area had been "overwhelmed" by the way the community had rallied to their assistance, he said. Besides assistance from the authorities, ordinary people had offered donations or helped by taking messages, answering phones and distributing goods.

On Vergelegen the fire was contained at this stage but there were still hot spots in various areas being monitored carefully.

"The fire is nowhere near being put out. What we need is for the wind to drop. They are fighting a wall of fire over a good 7 to 8km front," he said.

Meanwhile Cape Town firefighters, already stretched because of the Somerset West fire, fought a number of bush and grass fires in the Pensinula, including a blaze on Signal Hill, in the teeth of a gale in the past 24 hours.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 28, 1997


Ethiopia;
Court Continues Hearing Testimonies


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

ADDIS ABABA(ENA) - The Federal High Court yesterday heard testimonies given by five witnesses of the Special Prosecutor against the former Derg officials.

One of the witnesses said his son, Abrihe Bementu, had been detained in Harar where he used to work and was locked up at the Central Prison for nine months.

Abrihe has then been told that he was sentenced to five years term of imprisonment and was transferred to a jail in Addis Ababa, he said. 

The witness said his son spent four years at the Addis Ababa Prison before he was taken back to the Central prison.

"I had been delivering food to my son all through the years until the day I was told not to any more," he said.

He said he had learnt the death of his son after 1991 from a document found from the then Ministry of Internal Affairs.

Another witness testified that his son, Seyoum Bekele, had been under arrest at a prison in Higher 02 Kebele 09 in 1970.

"He (his son) told me that he was detained for allegedly being a member of the Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Party (EPRP)," the witness said.

The witness said he had no idea as to whether Seyoum was alive or not since June 1979 when he was told by the prison officials not to bring any more food for his son.

Another witness of the Special Prosecutor said he found his brother, Mekibib Kinfu jailed at the Central Prison in 1979.

I have never seen my brother since 1980. I only received his clothes and shoes he wore while he was in the prison," he said.

The fourth witness aged 51 said he had been thrown into jail for moths in 1979 without any warrant.

He said he was imprisoned at the Addis Ababa Prison up until October 1984 for allegedly being member of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front (EPLF).

He named nine people who he said had been summoned by the prison officials never to return again.

The fifth witness said in April 1977 four armed men held and drove him in a military Jeep to the Forth Army division where he said he was imprisoned for days.

He said he met six of his work mates at the Addis Ababa Prison where he was also thrown into. He called out the names of the individuals.

"I have no idea why they had to lock me up," he said and pointed out that two of his colleagues had never shown up after they left the prison summoned by the prison officials.

The trial was adjourned until March 4.

Africa News


February 28, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Ethiopian Expert Urges Annulment Of Nile Water Treaties


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 787 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - An academic of the Addis Ababa University has urged for the annulment of existing treaties between the lower riparian countries on the use of the Nile waters to pave the way for a basin-wide cooperating among the countries of the Nile Basin.

Ato Yakob Arsano, a political science lecturer at the Addis Ababa University made the suggestion in a paper presented Wednesday at the 5th Nile 2002 Conference under way here at the United National conference Centre.

"Riparian governments must henceforth believe and formally accept that the previous Nile water agreements are not only unfair, but also have been detrimental to the sovereign rights of the upper riparian countries. Therefore they be done null and void", Ato Yacob said. 

He further noted that the treaties between down stream countries, I.e. Egypt and Sudan or their colonizers, were made without any consideration for the interest and rights of upper riparian countries.

The upper riparian countries, which almost contribute the entire waters of the Nile, are Ethiopia, Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, Eritrea, Rwanda, Burundi and Zaire.

"All previous and existing treaties were designed in the colonial vain and legacy of it", Ato Yacob said adding that "the treaties have totally shunned the interest and water rights of the upper riparian"

As things stand now, and with the increase of population within the basin, which is anticipated to triple between 1990 and 2025, the situation is more contentious than is conducive for cooperation.

The demand for water, infact, is soaring beyond the available water resources in the entire basin.

The projected annual water need for Egypt and Sudan for irrigation is 65.5 billion cubic metre (BCM) and 31.15 BCM respectively, Ato Yacob said and noted that this is about 12.26 BCM greater than the total available water in the basin.

"This is a clear indication that when all the riparian states come up with their respective national water master plan, the available water resources and the national demands will be at irreconcilable variance", he said.

Ato Yacob's suggestions were strongly reufted by delegates from Sudan and Egypt. One delegate from the Sudan, infact said that the suggestions were rather a reciepy for conflict.

Another proposal forwarded by the academic to prevent contentions and possible conflicts was the establishment of a basin wide legal regime on the basis of which all water matters shall be regulated.

The 5th Nile 2002 conference wound up yesterday with a keynote address by Vice Minister of Water Resources Ato Adbulreshid Dulene. We will come up with the detailed story of the conference in tomorrow's issue of the herald.

Intellectuals' conference underway in Tigray

MAKALLE (ENA) - More is expected of intellectuals to alleviate the socio- economic problems of the rural peoples in Tigray, head of the regional state stressed.

Opening a conference of intellectuals' here Wednesday Ato Gebru Asrat said intellectuals deployed in rural areas are expected to change the lives of inhabitants without aspiring to work only in urban centres.

According to Ato Gebru, intellectuals assigned in rural areas are engaged in the education, health, agricultural and other sectors, in addition to conducting research and formulating directives in a bid to alleviate socio- economic problems.

The regional head of state said intellectuals should contribute toward the expansion of irrigation development, capacity building and the implementation of the five-year development programme.

Five hundred intellectuals drawn from regional bureaux, zones, woredas, as well as government and NGO offices are taking part in the conference focusing on extension service, potable water supply and other development activities.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 28, 1997


Ethiopia;
House refers, ratifies proclamations


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The House of Peoples' Representatives yesterday discussed and referred the bill to amend the proclamation providing for the establishment of the mass media and ratified a loan agreement.

In its 35th regular session, the House discussed the article which states that the Ethiopian Radio and television, Press and News agencies can issue directive concerning salary scale employment and administration of journalists, production and technical staff and referred it to the Mass Media and cultural Affairs Standing Committee.

The draft proclamation further indicates that the agencies could employ, and administer as well as fix salaries and allowance of journalists, production and technical staff in accordance with the directives issued by the board and administer the administrative staff in accordance with civil service laws. 

The Agencies could not employ gifted workers as the nature of the occupation dictates besides academic qualifications for provisions addressing such a particular case were not made in the code for civil service administration, according to the draft bill.

The bill takes into consideration the need on the part of the agencies to employ competent and talented media men particularly journalists and technical staff.

General managers of the agencies, could, in line with directives given by the board, hire professionals fixing their salary and allowances.

Workers in the administrative section will operate under the civil service law since their job does not demand specials talent and professional skill, the draft bill indicated.

The House has also ratified the draft proclamation to amend provisions in the Civil Code. Accordingly banks are allowed to directly sell collaterals on conditions that debtors fail to repay loans.

The loan agreement between Ethiopia and the International Fund for Agricultural Development was also unanimously adopted by the House.

The interest-free loan with a ten year grace period will be repayed in forty years.

Africa News


February 28, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Singapore Prime Minister Arrives In Zimbabwe


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Singaporean Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong arrived in Harare Friday on a three-day official visit to Zimbabwe which will culminate in the signing of a bilateral agreement.

Tong is accompanied by an 80-member delegation of government officials and businessmen. Members of the delegation said the business people were interested in investment and trade with Zimbabwe in areas such as infrastructure development, food processing, information technology and clothing manufacturing.

Tong is expected to fly to the northern resort town of Victoria Falls on Saturday. Before leaving Sunday, he and Mugabe will sign an agreement, still to be negotiated.

Zimbabwe and Singapore enjoy good trade relations although the balance of trade favors Singapore. In 1995, Zimbabwe imported goods worth 7.3 million U. S. dollars from Singapore, while it exported goods worth six million dollars.

The two countries signed an air services agreement in 1996 to improve trade and boost tourism.

Mugabe has made a determined drive in Asia to woe investments to Zimbabwe. He led a Zimbabwean business delegation to Malaysia, Singapore's neighbor, in 1994. Malaysia's President has also visited Zimbabwe.

Malaysia Airlines has opened a representative office in Zimbabwe, as part of a strategy to spread its wings in this region.

To entice investors, Mugabe's government in 1994 reduced company tax by 2.5 percent to 37.5 percent and removed customs duty on capital goods.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


446 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 28, 1997


Mozambique;
Mines Land Mine Conference Ends In Agreement To Work For Ban


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 840 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Delegates from 60 countries ended their fourth international NGO conference on land mines Friday asking governments to commit themselves signing an international treaty banning all production, use and sale of the weapon.

That treaty is due to be signed in December. That is when governments in favor of a ban will meet in the Canadian capital, Ottawa. A draft ban treaty, drawn up by the Austrian government, already exists. Belgium and Norway will host treaty negotiating sessions in June and September. 

The final declaration of the Maputo conference urged governments "to open all meetings of the Ottawa process to participation by a delegation from the International Campaign to Ban Land Mines, and to invite NGO representatives to form part of government delegations to these meetings."

Participants urged governments, even before any treaty negotiations, to take unilateral measures to ban mines. By this measure they would be following the examples, set in February, of South Africa and Mozambique.

Such unilateral measures, the delegates said, would "build momentum towards the signing of the Ottawa treaty."

One problem looming is the definition of an anti-personnel mine. The conference wanted to block loopholes: it called for "a simple, clear and unambiguous treaty that bans all anti-personnel land mines, and not just those weapons 'primarily designed' or adapted to be exploded by the presence, proximity or contact of a person."

Speakers warned against diluting any treaty with the "primarily designed" clause. This, they said, would allow governments to continue under the pretext that they were not "primarily designed" to be exploded by human contact.

The final declaration at Muputo also called on those countries that have produced and supplied mines "to accept their responsibility and to assist with clearance and victim assistance programs."

The conference wanted greatly increased resources for mine clearance " particularly in those nations and regions that have banned the weapon." The conference was focussed on making Southern Africa mine-free. During the week significant steps were taken towards this goal. On the first day of the conference the Mozambican government announced its ban on anti-personnel mines.

Swazi and Malawian representatives said their governments were committed to the Ottawa process, while a letter form the Tanzanian foreign minister pledged that country's support. A Zimbabwean representative said the government in Harare would shortly make its position known, and he specifically denied the frequent claim that Zimbabwe manufactures mines.

Support was also forthcoming from the Angolan parliament but the position of the Angolan government is still unknown. Angola, as the most heavily mined country in Africa, is crucial to the campaign -- particularly as there are credible reports that mines are still being laid there.

At the end of the conference, Gil Manuel, a spokesman for the Mozambican Campaign Against Land Mines, which hosted the event, was supportive of Mozambique's position but warned that more needed to be done.

In particular, he wanted all stocks of land mines held by the Mozambican Defence Force destroyed at a public ceremony. Furthermore, he wants a law banning mines to be passed by the country's parliament, the Assembly of The Republic.

On Thursday, the head of the parliamentary group of the ruling Frelimo party, Armando Guebuza, said that Frelimo deputies might sponsor such legislation.

The coordinator of the International Campaign to Ban Land Mines, Jody Williams, described the conference as "a great success," noting that initially only 300 delegates had been expected -- but 450 actually turned up.

She warned that Ottawa was not the end of the road.

"A ban is not just a treaty," she said. "It means ensuring universal adherence to the treaty, removing all the mines already in the ground, and repairing the lives of the victims. That work will not end when we sign the treaty in Ottawa."


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


447 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 28, 1997


Sierra Leone;
Freetown Calls On Anti-Government Forces To Embrace Peace


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Sierra Leone said Friday that the leader of the Revolutionary United Front, Foday Sankoh, constituted the only obstacle to the restoration of peace in the country.

"My country wishes to appeal to him to change his recalcitrant posture," Foreign Minister Sheri Bougana said Friday in Tripoli. 

She told the Organization of African Unity's Council of Ministers that while President Tejan Kabba's government had demonstrated good faith, the front continued to hamper the implementation of the November 1996 peace agreement signed in Cote d'Ivoire.

For instance, she said, while the government had released all of the front's soldiers held prisoner, the front was still holding school children " adopted" during fighting.

At the front's insistence, Bougana said foreign mercenary troops had also left Sierra Leone, to pave way for the 1996 election. The polls, which brought Kabbah to power, were conducted with the help of the O.A.U., the Commonwealth and Cote d'Ivoire, which hosted the peace meetings.

She described as a good sign, the front's acceptance of the deployment of the U.N. proposed 750 international peace monitors in Sierra Leone.

In addition, she asked the international community to support the trust fund set up to consolidate the peace.

The Sierra Leonean war, which started in 1991, has killed at least 10,000 people and devastated the economy.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


448 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 28, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Nigeria Urges Acceleration Of Liberian Peace Process


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Nigeria has urged that the momentum of ongoing Liberian peace plan be sustained to prevent the war-torn country from relapsing into another avoidable carnage.

"The situation should not be seen as all clear, it is still volatile," Tom Ikimi, the country's foreign minister, told PANA Friday.

Nigeria is current chairman of the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas), which has a peace monitoring force, Ecomog, in Liberia, trying to end a seven-year-old civil war. 

Ikimi said although some progress had been recorded, based on the Abuja 1995 and 1996 peace plan, the "stages ahead are very crucial and delicate."

He said that while some 28,000 of the estimated 35,000 factional fighters had been disarmed, an undisclosed quantity of arms were still to be retrieved. He warned about the danger of these weapons finding their way into the hands of the former combatants.

Under the peace accord brokered by Ecowas, national elections are to be held in May to be conducted by a 10-member Independent Electoral Commission. It would include one member each from the Organization of African Unity (O.A. U.), Ecowas and the United Nations, while others would be drawn from the former factions and the civil population.

Ikimi projected that if the plan went well Ecomog, numbering 8,980 men a week ago and being reinforced with about 2,500 more troops, would begin a total pull out from Liberia six months after the polls.

He said another problem could be the fate of some 800,000 Liberian refugees scattered across West Africa.

Commending the O.A.U., U.N. and the international community for their help in resolving the crisis in Liberia, Ikimi said the displaced people should be supported to return home to participate in the electoral process.

"ECOMOG still suffers some inadequacies and we appeal to the international community to assist the peace process on Liberia," he said.

Liberia, founded in 1847 by freed slaves from the United States slipped into civil war following the Dec. 24, 1989 rebellion by Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front of Liberia against the government of President Samuel Doe.

At least 150,000 people are estimated to have been killed in the war.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


449 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 28, 1997


Libya;
Libyans March In Support Of O.A.U., Denounce U.N. Sanctions


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Thousands of Libyans, mainly youths, marched through Alfatha street in Tripoli on Thursday, venue of the 65th ministerial council meeting of the Organization of Africa Unity, in support of African solidarity.

The placard-carrying marchers also condemned the sanctions imposed on their country by the United Nations since 1992. 

Some of the placards read: "All Libyans Pay Tribute To Africa's Free Will", "Africa is for Africans," and "No Alliance With Africa Except With Itself."

In the statement issued by the popular congresses, on behalf of all Libyans, the marchers said the presence of at least 30 African ministers at the meeting was "a defeat for America and its allies."

The ministers and their delegations, as well as O.A.U. Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim, broke the session briefly to greet the marchers, who demanded an end to U.N. sanctions on Libya.

Sanctions were imposed after the United States and Britain accused two Libyan nationals of involvement in the downing of a PanAm jetliner in 1988, over the Scottish town of Lockerbie.

Tripoli has rejected U.S. demand that the suspects be tried in America or Britain but said they could face trial at the World Court at the Hague.

The sanctions have dealt a serious blow to the economy of the oil-producing north African country.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 28, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
O.A.U. Scribe Calls For Quick U.N. Reform


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - The Organization of African Unity, the continent's foremost political body, called Friday for an urgent reform of the United Nations Security Council to make it more representative of the world and protect the interests of Africa and other marginalized continents.

"This is of serious concern, it is not clear when or how it will happen but it must happen," said Salim Ahmed Salim, the organization's secretary-general.

At a news conference in Tripoli, where is attending the organization's Council of Ministers meeting, he described the U.N. as a product of the Second World War. Just two African countries, Libya and Ethiopia were members when the United Nations was set up in 1946. Today, there were 53 African countries representing some one-third of the 186-member world body. 

"Not only Africa but other countries have concern in relating with the world's sole super power, the United States," he said.

Under the present circumstance, he said, Africa must be able to respond more swiftly and effectively to its challenges. But, he said it was regrettable that the O.A.U. lacked the capacity to give teeth to its decisions.

Salim outline the organization's efforts to resolve the Africa's myriad conflicts, especially in the Great Lakes region, the Horn of Africa, Angola, Burundi, Liberia, and the dispute between Libya and France, Britain and United States over the 1988 downing of PanAm jetliner over Lockerbie, Scotland, and a jetliner belonging to the private French carrier, UTA, over Niger in 1989.

Libya is facing U.N. sanctions over its refusal to surrender for trial, in either United States or Britain, two of its nationals accused for the bombings.

Salim said while the O.A.U. condemned terrorism, it disagreed with the insistence that the suspects be tried only in Europe.

"We stand for justice and this means that the suspects could be tried in a neutral country," as proposed by Libya, he said.

Another alternative, Salim said, was for them to face trial at the Hague or the Security Council could set up a tribunal to end the crisis.

Salim said the presence of some 43 foreign ministers for the organization's council meeting in Tripoli was a demonstration of solidarity with Libya over the U.N.'s unfair sanctions.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

451 of 451 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 28, 1997


Zaire;
Hopes Of Zaire Peace Talks Dampened Amidst Confusion


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - Optimism that the two sides in the eastern Zaire conflict would soon hold peace talks was dampened Friday following reports that the envoy who met President Nelson Mandela over the issue was not empowered to negotiate.

South African television reported that the Zairian government had announced that Honore Ngabanda, although an envoy of President Mobutu Sese Seko, was not a member of government. As such, he was not empowered to negotiate on the question of peace negotiations.

Mandela met Ngabanda on Thursday, a day after the South African leader's audience with the Zairian anti-government leader, Laurent Kabila.

Both talks were aimed at trying to get the two sides to be involved in peace talks which officials hoped would lead to a cease-fire in Zaire.

However, after Thursday's meeting, Mandela was noncommittal.

"All I want to say is that there is progress which is encouraging," he said.

Expectations are that will be an official reaction from the South African government later Friday, before Mandela leave the country on an Asian tour.

Meanwhile, his absence for the next 10 days has also dampened hopes of any immediate success in the Zairian peace initiative. No major developments are expected until his return to South Africa at the end of next week.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1997
